column2: ['Graduate Diversity Admissions Fair: Registration is open! #1065']
column5:
['Thinking about pursuing a graduate degree? Join us for our virtual Graduate Diversity Admissions Fair October 7-11! Discover what UC Berkeley has to offer, including program details, application tips, and funding opportunities. 
You can expect a lot to choose from. Over 50 different sessions from UC Berkeley departments and graduate programs in one hour information sessions.
Register now. After registering for the fair, you can start adding individual sessions to your personal agenda. Be sure to add the Economics PhD session on October 8th 2-3pm.
Register today (button link: https://bit.ly/div-adm-fair-reg24)']

column2: ['Behavioral Economics Association Applications Open - Infosession Tonight! #1053']
column5:
['üöÄ Join the Behavioral Economics Association (BEA) @ UC Berkeley! üöÄ
üîç What is Behavioral Economics? Ever wonder why we make certain choices, like splurging on things we don't need? Behavioral Economics combines economics and psychology to uncover the "why" behind our decisions! It‚Äôs more than just theory ‚Äì it‚Äôs the secret to creating smarter products, conducting meaningful research, and developing powerful strategies.
üì¢ Who are we? BEA is a passionate and diverse group of undergrads focused on promoting and applying behavioral economics. Whether you‚Äôre interested in consulting, product management, or research, we provide hands-on opportunities through real-world projects with big tech companies, startups, and nonprofits. From hosting career workshops to fun events like yacht galas and Lake Tahoe retreats, BEA is where you develop both your professional skills and social network! üåäüéâ
üíº Our Divisions:
Consulting: Work with clients from startups to Fortune 500s across various industries, gaining strategic skills and industry insight.
Research: Contribute to academic articles with the potential for publication, perfect for aspiring academics or policy researchers.
Product Management: Develop and apply product management skills through workshops and real-world projects with clients.
‚ú® Ready to Apply? Applications are open NOW on our website, beaberkeley.com! Don‚Äôt miss our info sessions, product mixers, and case prep workshops to get a taste of BEA before joining, or schedule a coffee chat with one of our executive board members to learn more! Infosession 2 is tonight at 8 pm in Social Sciences 185.
üîó Ready to make an impact? Apply today and become part of a dynamic team pushing the boundaries of behavioral economics! For questions or accommodations, email us at beaatberkeley@gmail.com.']

['Berkeley Economic Review is accepting applications for writers, researchers, editors, peer reviewers, web designers, and anyone passionate about economics! We are Berkeley‚Äôs premier undergraduate economics journal and the largest student organization under the Economics Department focused on research and academia. We promote undergraduate research in economics among students at UC Berkeley and encourage pre-college research as well as undergraduate research at other academic institutions.

Our work is showcased through three main publication avenues: our journal, magazine, our website. In our annual journal, you will find the top submissions selected from many undergraduate papers we receive from students worldwide. Our semesterly magazine features articles we create and interviews with esteemed Berkeley Economics faculty, with more articles and interviews available on our website.

If you are interested in joining, come to our first info session tonight at 7pm in Evans 648. You‚Äôll learn more about what we do and meet the incredible memBERs of our organization. If you‚Äôre interested but can‚Äôt make it tonight, we have another info session on Wednesday at 7pm, also in Evans 648.
BER Info Sessions
Mon Sep 9 (Today) at 7pm in Evans 648
Wed Sep 11 at 7pm in Evans 648
We hope to see you there!']

column2: ['Mathematics Undergraduate Student Association | First GM Thursday, 9/5 6:30pm @ Evans 1015 #1034']
column5: ['The Mathematics Undergraduate Student Association (MUSA) is holding its first general meeting on Thursday, 9/5, at 6:30pm in Evans 1015! There will be pizza, board games, and a brief introduction of what we do. MUSA aims to create a warm, inclusive environment in the math department by hosting weekly events such as Math Mondays, trivia nights, LaTeX workshops, and the BUMP mentoring program that pairs under and upperclassmen. For those interested in taking upper-division math courses or proof intensive courses we offer the MUSA 74 Decal ‚Äì a 2 unit PNP course that introduces rigorous proof writing and fosters familiarity with the objects encountered in advanced courses such as Abstract Algebra and Analysis. \n\nKeep in touch with us via our newsletter or Discord server, both found at https://linktr.ee/berkeleymusa.']

['Berkeley Economic Review, the premier undergraduate, peer-reviewed, academic economics journal, is currently recruiting writers, researchers, editors, peer reviewers, web designers, or anyone who wants to be involved in economics journalism and academia.

column2: ['Learn how to file taxes and volunteer with the VITA DeCal! #1007']
column5:
["Looking for volunteer opportunities to combat income inequality? Want to learn real-world skills like how to do taxes?

UC Berkeley VITA is a student-run program under the Public Service Center that provides free tax-filing services to low-income communities throughout the Bay Area. Last year, VITA volunteers logged over 2,400 hours and returned almost $2 million to clients through tax refunds.

In the fall, we teach a DeCal about how to actually file taxes and discuss the larger environment of American income inequality. Classes are Thursdays, 6:30-8:30pm, for 2 units P/NP. In the spring, you'll put your newfound knowledge to use preparing taxes at volunteer locations, which are offered either in-person or remotely. UC Berkeley VITA is a great way to meet new people, learn a useful skill, and make a tangible impact! All majors are welcome, no prior knowledge or experience needed, and applicants of all immigration status and citizenship are welcome to apply.

Apply to join us at tinyurl.com/VITA24-25Application, due Friday, September 6th at 11:59pm PDT!

Questions, comments, or concerns? Reach us at ucberkeleyvita@gmail.com. Learn more about us at linktr.ee/ucberkeleyvita!"]

column2: ['Research Fellowship at Stanford Law School - first deadline: Oct. 21 #1001']
column5: ['Stanford professor and economist John J Donohue, is seeking 2 full-time Pre-Doctoral Research Fellows to begin work in the summer of 2025. This is a unique opportunity for graduating seniors and recent college graduates to participate in groundbreaking empirical social science, public policy, economic, and legal research. Past fellows have found the experience to be valuable preparation for graduate school and have matriculated to a number of prestigious graduate, law, and business programs.']
['For the career fair tomorrow from 12-4, is it recommended/necessary to attend the full 4 hours? How much time should you commit to something like that?']

['Dear Students,

This is to introduce the Undergraduate Research Assistantship Program for Fall 2024. The goal of this program is to connect undergraduate students majoring in Economics who are interested in doing research with faculty and grad students.

For this edition of the program, we will be focusing on RA arrangements compensated by enrollment in Econ 199 units. Each student can be enrolled in up to three Econ 199 units per semester, and each Econ 199 unit must represent a dedication of at least three hours per week. All units are P/NP. This course cannot be used to fulfill an elective requirement for the major.

To apply for a research assistant position, fill this form: https://forms.gle/G8zzMQatTHw9TyvF9. Faculty and grad students will be able to view applications and will contact undergraduate students on the week starting from September 2nd. Notice that the form includes the option to signal particular interest in up to three projects - find a spreadsheet with information about the various projects being offered this term here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/175aF-veyhdRIVV7haLpA3V8CwQLbuab2X3lfU8MTSzc/edit?usp=sharing

Questions to be sent to ugradraprogram@econ.berkeley.edu,

Undergraduate Research Assistantship Program Team']

column2: ['Recruiting for Analyst Position at Cornerstone Research! #987']
column5:
['Hello!
 My name is Angela Li, and I graduated from UC Berkeley in 2022. I currently work as a Senior Analyst at Cornerstone Research, an economic and financial consulting firm that provides expert testimony in high-profile litigation. My experience at Cornerstone has been rewarding in many aspects, as I‚Äôve had the opportunity to work on collaborative teams with leading academic experts while developing relevant quantitative and qualitative skills.
 Cornerstone will be hosting an Information Session and Case Workshop on Tuesday, September 17 from 6:30 ‚Äì 7:30 pm in the Stephens Lounge at MLK Student Union. Students must register beforehand via Handshake. Additionally, we‚Äôll be attending the Consulting Forum on Wednesday, August 28 from 12:00 ‚Äì 4:00 pm in Pauley Ballroom (3rd floor) at MLK Student Union, as well as the Business and Public Service Career Fair on Thursday, September 12 from 12:00 ‚Äì 4:00 pm at the Recreational Sports Facility.  You can find more information about these events on Handshake or by getting in touch with the UC Berkeley Career Center.
 Additionally, please be aware of the application deadlines below and click the links for descriptions of the Analyst and Summer Analyst roles.
Analyst:  Sunday, September 22 at 11:59 pm
Summer Analyst:  Sunday, September 29 at 11:59 pm
 Reminder: You must apply directly on our website in order to be considered.
 Finally, I would like to highlight that Cornerstone:
 Recruits students from all majors; we find that our most successful analysts have a demonstrated interest in research and desire to learn complex economic and financial concepts
Works across industries including antitrust, healthcare, finance, intellectual property, and securities, and has a generalist model that provides analysts with opportunities across sectors
Maintains a positive work-life balance, supporting our diverse staff with a strong analyst culture
Is an ideal place to start a career‚Äîanalysts from Cornerstone often go on to top M.B.A., J.D., or Ph.D. graduate programs or proceed directly into technology, business, finance, or nonprofit work
 If you have any additional questions, please feel free to contact me at angela.li@cornerstone.com.
 Warmly,
 Angela Li
Senior Analyst
Cornerstone Research']

column2: ['UPENN CALL FOR SUBMISSION: Penn Undergraduate Law Journal #944']
column5:
['Call for Submissions - Penn Undergraduate Law Journal [www.pulj.org]

The Penn Undergraduate Law Journal (PULJ) is soliciting submissions for its twenty-second issue. Please see below for details. 

QUALIFICATIONS FOR SUBMISSION

SUBMISSION DEADLINE: September 8th, 2024 at 11:59pm EST
 PULJ is seeking articles ranging from 20 to 100+ double-spaced pages in length. Our journal is especially receptive to research articles, senior theses, independent studies, and final essays written for courses. Articles need not be written on United States law‚Äîthey can be written on the laws or legal system of any nation. We consider submissions on a rolling basis, so if your piece is not finished by the noted deadline, please still submit it for consideration in our subsequent issue.

Students in any field of study are encouraged to submit their work, so long as their pieces relate to law or legal systems. Possible disciplinary perspectives include, but are not limited to, history, criminology, economics, sociology, anthropology, English, biology, neuroscience, philosophy, linguistics, psychology, and political science.

Please submit your work here: https://www.pulj.org/submissions.html

Selected pieces will be published in our twenty-second issue of the Penn Undergraduate Law Journal. If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to notify us of them through the contact page of our website, which can be accessed here: http://www.pulj.org/contact.html
Thank you for considering our journal, and we hope to have the opportunity to consider your work!

All the best,
The PULJ Team 
Penn Undergraduate Law Journal
www.pulj.org   |  contact@pulj.org
The PULJ Team']

column2: ['Seats Available in Seminar PoliSci 191: "Post-Conflict Politics and Policing in Comparative Perspective" #942']
column5:
['Note: Course will not count towards Economics elective major requirement.
Seats are available. See here for details.
Course Description
Police are often the state institution that we are most likely to interact with regularly, and they are the main institution mandated to provide day-to-day security, one of the most fundamental governance functions. However, while police are responsible for public safety, they can also be an instrument for control and even repression by the state. And, in general, security can be hard to (re)establish, especially after civil war.
This seminar therefore focuses on policing in various global contexts, especially post-conflict, and it examines the politics around these security institutions. We will examine what state forces look like during civil war, how the design of state security institutions changes post-conflict, especially with regard to the police, and how these institutions function and potentially contribute to peacebuilding. Post-conflict orders are especially prone to failure. We will also think beyond these states that have had civil conflict to understand questions about policing more broadly.
 The seminar is especially aimed at both the substantive of this topic, as well as the research process, beginning focused study of specific cases. In this course, taking the comparative perspective seriously, all students will develop case studies on how policing structures and controls change at pivotal moments of conflict termination and then how those changes affect outcomes such as citizen trust and cooperation. Students may also choose to code variables about post-conflict state policing, rebel demobilization, and peacekeeper patrolling if they wish for a mixed-method approach. Significant portions of the class will focus on collecting and assembling descriptive evidence in case studies.
Requirements
The Junior Seminars are intense writing seminars which focus on the research area of the faculty member teaching the course. The seminars provide an opportunity for students to have direct intellectual interactions with faculty members while also giving the students an understanding for faculty research.
Subfield: Either International Relations or Comparative Politics 
Prerequisites
Political Science Majors of Junior and Senior status (must be 3rd or 4th year students with at least 60 units completed) with a minimum overall UC GPA of 3.25. Interested and eligible students must email Professor Aila Matanock at matanock@berkeley.edu with a 250-word maximum statement of interest, ideally a week before they would like to enroll, and Prof. Matanock will review and contact them with enrollment instructions.']

column2: ['Application open for Los Angeles Review of Books Fall 2024 internship! #914']
column5:
['Art of Writing provides UC Berkeley undergraduates with paid literary internship opportunities (writing, editing, social media, etc.) with our partner organizations.

Applications are open for the Art of Writing Los Angeles Review of Books Fall 2024 internship! The application deadline is August 11, 2024.

The intern will work closely with LARB‚Äôs core editorial staff, at least 10 hours per week, between September 3 and December 13, 2024. This remote Fall 2024 internship comes with a $2,000 stipend provided by Art of Writing.

Our internships are designed to support undergraduate students who may not otherwise have access to such opportunities. Thus, we are prioritizing students with financial need and early career candidates. To demonstrate financial need, you must have an Estimated Family Contribution of equal to or less than $26,000. See your Financial Aid & Scholarships Profile under My Finances in Cal Central to check your EFC (Estimated Family Contribution) amount. 

For more information, and to apply, visit the Art of Writing website.']

1. SF Fed - Hiring RA in Summer 2024
Research Associate: https://rb.wd5.myworkdayjobs.com/FRS/job/San-Francisco-CA/Research-Associate_R-0000022948-1
Are you a motivated college graduate looking for a chance to make a difference? The Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco is looking for a Research Associate to join our Economic Research team. We welcome applications for a position that starts in the summer of 2024.
Applications must include the following to be considered:
a resume,
a cover letter, and
undergraduate transcript (unofficial is acceptable)
If you would like to submit optional letters of recommendation, please have your references send them to SF.ER.RARecruiting@sf.frb.org.
We will begin reviewing applications immediately and keep the position open until the role is filled.
How to Apply:
We'd love to hear from you! Please submit your information and application online at: https://rb.wd5.myworkdayjobs.com/FRS/job/San-Francisco-CA/Research-Associate_R-0000022948-1
2. UC Center Sacramento - Internship Opportunities for Fall and Spring in the State Capitol
Interested in spending a semester in Sacramento taking classes and gaining experience with an exciting internship in the California State Capitol?

You can easily transfer your tuition while you study and live one block from the State Capitol with UCCS. Each semester, UCCS offers internship placements within and around the State Capitol in Sacramento for UC students interested in exploring their careers and building their experience with a semester of studies and service in government offices and centers. It includes coursework and research training that culminates in a full semester of credit earned alongside your internship. 
It is open to students from all departments who wish to explore internships in healthcare policy, local government policy, law, arts and media, communication and journalism, politics, social welfare, justice-making, human rights, civil service, legislative and executive branches, business, education, environment, state agencies, non-profits, and more!
The upcoming info session dates are:
Mon., April 22nd, 2pm - 3pm, Tues., May 7th, 3 pm - 4 pm, Thurs., ay 30th, 12 pm -1 pm

3.  Close Out With Confidence: Expanded SLP Services This RRR & Finals Weeks
As we enter the final week of classes, the SLC Strategic Learning Program is thrilled to share our end of semester services for RRR and Finals Weeks!
Conquer your final exams and assignments with confidence by partnering with the SLC Strategic Learning Program (SLP). We've got your back with an expanded array of services tailored to give you just the boost you need to reach the finish line!
Here's what's in store:
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Your Time‚Äù Time Management Workshop Finals Edition: During the last week of classes and RRR Week, we will be hosting special editions of our ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Your Time‚Äù Time Management Workshops geared specifically to support you in managing your time and schedule during the RRR & Finals Period! RSVP at bit.ly/slp-tmw. 
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Your Time‚Äù Weekly Tune-Ups: Once you attend the ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Your Time‚Äù Workshop, join our time tune-ups to make your RRR & Finals Weeks plans even stronger! We‚Äôll be holding our Tune-Ups at our regular time of Mondays, 12 - 1 pm in Ch√°vez 151, and just for RRR Week we‚Äôre adding a time on Thursday, 5/2, 12 - 1 pm to give you yet another opportunity to adjust your plans for the final push!
SLP Power Hours: Boost your productivity and make headway on your finals exam preparation! These supercharged working sessions are designed to help you maximize your productivity and keep you motivated as you tackle your studying head-on. We‚Äôll be offering Power Hours every day from 4/29 to 5/8! Check out the times and RSVP at bit.ly/slp-ph. 
For a full list of SLP services during RRR & Finals Week, please see our program calendar. 
In between SLP services, head to the C√©sar Ch√°vez Atrium to study, take advantage of SLC tutoring, and grab a snack or refreshment! The Ch√°vez Student Center will be open M - F 9 am - 6 pm throughout the RRR & Finals period.
Wishing you all the best as we wind down the semester and looking forward to seeing you at the SLC!
4. LDC Speaker Series 4/23 Cecilia Ay√≥n & Launch of Center on Immigration & Child Welfare
In partnership with the UC Berkeley Latinx and Democracy Speaker Series, Dr. Kristina Lovato, Assistant Professor of Social Welfare, will be hosting the official launch of the Center on Immigration and Child Welfare, which will feature a guest lecture from immigration scholar Dr. Cecilia Ay√≥n on: "Toxic Immigration Stress: The Chronic Exposure to Restrictive Immigration Policy and Enforcement among Immigration-Impacted Families."  Dr. Cecilia Ay√≥n, is a Professor of Public Policy at the University of California, Riverside. 
Details: The event will take place on Tuesday, April 23rd, 12-2pm in the School of Social Welfare, Haviland Commons, 1st Floor. Lunch will be provided.Thank you to the Latinx and Democracy Cluster for generously sponsoring this event. Please RSVP
5. Latinx Social Science Research End-of-Semester Workshop: May 2 at LRC 12 pm
We invite you to attend our End-of-Semester Latinx Social Science Research Workshop, sponsored by the Latinx Social Science Pipeline Initiative, on May 2, 2024, from 12-1:30 pm, at the Latinx Research Center (LRC) (2547 Channing Way, Berkeley, CA 94720). Please RSVP here. Light refreshments will be served.

The Latinx Social Science Research Workshop Series creates mentorship links across faculty, postdocs, and graduate students. During the workshops, graduate students, postdocs, and faculty share research in progress and receive feedback from a community of engaged scholars in the Latinx Social Sciences.
Lorraine Torres-Col√≥n and Miguel Samano are the presenters for this edition. The discussants will be Marvyn Arevalo and Kevin Quintero. We will share the presenters' research materials with the participants who submit their RSVPs so they can review them in advance and provide feedback during the workshop.

["Please see below for announcements from our partners. If you are part of a registered student organization on campus, you are welcome to post your announcements directly to our Ed Discussion without waiting for our weekly announcement recap. This week‚Äôs announcements include:
1.  UJE Submission Final Call
2. Undergraduate Summer Minor: The Developing Child
1.  UJE Submission Final Call
 This is a final call inviting undergraduate students to submit to the UCL Journal of Economics this academic year. The UJE is the official peer-reviewed, student-run journal of the UCL Department of Economics. We publish a yearly issue compiled and edited by students and peer reviewed by postgraduates and other academic experts. We aim to provide a free and reputable platform for undergraduate economists worldwide to begin their academic journeys, regardless of their previous experience, and create a formal record of high quality undergraduate economic research that may otherwise go unpublished.
Across our two issues, we have published 22 articles from students at top universities with a great variety of topics studied and methodologies employed. As a sample of the high quality of papers we seek to publish, please refer to the selection below:
‚ÄúRacial Hate Crime and COVID-19: A Multinomial Choice Study in the US‚Äù: https://student-journals.ucl.ac.uk/UJE/article/id/1403/ 
‚ÄúInsects on our Plates? Potential, Challenges and Opportunities in the Edible Insect Market‚Äù: https://student-journals.ucl.ac.uk/UJE/article/id/1383/ 
‚ÄúMonetary Policy, Portfolio Heterogeneity, and the College Wealth Gap‚Äù: https://student-journals.ucl.ac.uk/UJE/article/id/1388/ 
‚ÄúPolicy Brief: Right-to-Work Legislation 1947‚ÄîPresent in the United States‚Äù: https://student-journals.ucl.ac.uk/UJE/article/id/1398/ 
‚ÄúRacial and Ethnic Disparities in Maternal Treatment and Death: Evaluating the Role of Hospital and Physician Effects‚Äù: https://student-journals.ucl.ac.uk/UJE/article/id/1601/
Your work will be accessible to a global audience, including esteemed academics and industry professionals. In the past, the journal has featured papers from other prominent universities, including Harvard, UC Berkeley, the University of Chicago, and many more.
Submission Details:
Deadline for Submissions: 1st April 2024, 23:59 BST
How to Submit: Please visit https://student-journals.ucl.ac.uk/UJE/submissions/ for submission guidelines and to upload your paper.
The UJE encourages submissions that demonstrate original thought and contribute meaningfully to the field of economics. Your participation in the UJE will not only enrich your academic experience but also contribute to the broader economic discourse.
For more information, and to read previous issues, please visit https://student-journals.ucl.ac.uk/UJE.
2. Undergraduate Summer Minor: The Developing Child
 The Developing Child Summer Minor is currently accepting Declaration Forms for this summer's undergraduate cohort! 
The minor is open to all undergraduate students interested in working with or on behalf of children and families. It is being offered online, with synchronous class meetings and includes a 25-hour practicum in an Early Childhood Education Program (ECEP) classroom where students will have the opportunity to work directly with young children. The courses have been divided into two sessions, Sessions A and D and the minor also qualifies for a $1,500 Summer Sessions Scholarship! 
For more information, contact Luvy Vanegas-Grimaud, Student Advisor: lvanegasgrimaud@berkeley.edu"]

1. Nobels in Economics at the Iseo Summer School
CONTENTS
The I.S.E.O. Summer School in Economics is an international summer course reserved to graduate and postgraduate students (Masters and PhD) notably in Economics, teaching assistants, researchers and young professionals.
SPEAKERS
*Joshua ANGRIST, Nobel Laureate in Economics 2021, professor of Economics at Mit;
*Robert ENGLE, Nobel Laureate in Economics 2003, professor of Finance at NYU Stern School of Business and Co-Director of the NYU Stern Volatility;
*Michael SPENCE, Nobel Laureate in Economics 2001, emeritus professor at Stanford Business School;
*Beata JAVORCIK, professor of Economics at Oxford University and chief economist at EBRD (European Bank for Reconstructions and Development); 
*Kamiar MOHADDES, professor in Economics & Policy at the University of Cambridge; 
*Carl FREY, professor of AI & Work, Oxford University; 
*Elena VERDOLINI, professor of Political Economy at University of Brescia and senior scientist at the European Institute on Economics and the Environment.
APPLICATION 
The application form can be found on the Istituto I.S.E.O website. Deadline to apply is the 5th of May 2024, although early application is highly recommended as places are limited. Summer School admissions work on a rolling basis.
FEE AND SCHOLARSHIPS 
The I.S.E.O. Summer School 2024 fee amounts to 2.800 Euro: however, we award talented students partial scholarships amounting to 1.600 Euro (each), so that the fee can be reduced to 1.200 Euro. Full scholarships are not available.
INFO & CONTACT 
The I.S.E.O. Summer School is organized by the I.S.E.O. Institute, a non-profit cultural association founded in 1998 by prof. Franco Modigliani (Nobel Laureate in Economics 1985) and then chaired by prof. Robert Solow (Nobel Laureate in Economics 1987) until his death. The goal of the association is that of promoting conferences, debates and Summer Schools focused on international Economics.
The course will take place fully in presence in the picturesque and charming town of Iseo, North of Italy.
For further info https://www.istiseo.org/summerschool/summer-school-2024-2/ or summerschool@istiseo.org
2. SU24 Berkeley Engineering Design Scholars Program
The Berkeley Engineering Design Scholar Program is a 10-week summer research program open to all continuing UC Berkeley undergraduates in the College of Engineering or with relevant experience in design innovation. The Scholars actively contribute to the growing design ecosystem at UC Berkeley‚Äîparticipating in seminars, workshops, and special events with members of the design community, including their cohort of fellow undergraduate Design Scholars, graduate students, and faculty. In addition, they learn and practice critical skills of making through the Maker Pass program. Scholars also receive a $6,500 stipend. The per week commitment will fluctuate, but students should prepare to be able to commit at least 20 hours/week towards research.
During the program, each Scholar is matched with a faculty advisor based on their interests, and conducts faculty-guided research in areas such as Engineering Design, Design Methodology, Human Computer Interaction, and Data-driven Design. If there is mutual interest from both the Scholar and faculty advisor, they may have the option of continuing their research beyond the summer.
The program is led by Professor Kosa Goucher-Lambert (Mechanical Engineering), with additional mentorship and project supervision from Professor Hannah Stuart (Mechanical Engineering), and other UC Berkeley faculty.
We are offering the Berkeley Engineering Design Scholar Program as an in-person, on-campus experience in summer 2024, starting June 3rd and ending August 9th.
Apply for the 2024 Berkeley Engineering Design Scholar Program here by Monday, March 18th, 9pm PST. Scholars will be matched with faculty mentors once they are accepted into the program.
To learn more about the program, please contact Janrey Javier (janreyjavier@berkeley.edu). Learn more about the Scholars from prior cohorts here.

At Oxford University Economic Summer Schools, we are really excited to be launching two new courses this year to equip students with the skills they need to pursue graduate study in Economics. To help introduce our new courses, we are organising a webinar to explore both "Treatment Effects: The Basics" and "Fundamentals of Graduate Economics" in more detail.
This webinar is online, free, and open to all ‚Äì we hope you can join us!
Date: 8 March 2024 (Friday) Time: 9:00am - 10:00am (GMT) Location: Online (via Zoom) [Registration Link]
The webinar will be chaired by Professor Abi Adams-Prassl, who is also our Associate Head of External Engagement at the Department of Economics. She will be joined by our Professors who are the course tutors on the following programmes:
Treatment Effects: The Basics by Francis DiTraglia Learn about causal inference using observational data, including topics like selection on observables, bad controls, instrumental variables, and more.
Fundamentals of Graduate Economics by James Duffy and In√©s Moreno De Barreda Discover the foundational tools and concepts necessary for success in a graduate programme in Economics, including mathematical methods and econometrics.

6. UCEAP Study Economics Abroad
UCEAP offers 100 programs worldwide with coursework in economics!
Explore Program Spotlights
Business and Economics, Maastricht, Netherlands. Solve real-world problems while you study in an international hub for trade and education. Choose from a wide array of courses and take advantage of practical training in report writing, project management, and conference presentations. 
University of Chile, Chile. The Faculty of Economics and Business is well-respected and has been training Chilean political and economic thought leaders for decades. Study fascinating courses in English like Environmental Economics, Urban Economics, and Latin America in World's Affairs. 
University of Galway, Ireland. Explore real-world economic challenges in Ireland as you make connections with a vibrant academic community and dedicated faculty. The university has a diverse range of courses, a supportive learning environment, and strong industry connections. 
University of Melbourne, Australia. Immerse yourself in the #1 ranked university in Australia. Take advantage of world-class business and economics courses and gain practical skills through research and internship opportunities all while you explore one of the most livable cities in the world.
These are only a few of the options available to you. Explore more programs with coursework in economics.
Next Steps‚Ä¶
Attend the UCEAP 101: Your Adventure Starts Here virtual info session at 5pm on April 8 for an introduction to UCEAP.
Schedule an office hours appointment with a UCEAP advisor.

Program Dates: July 3 - August 11, 2024
About the BASE Program: Designed specifically for non-business undergraduates and recent graduates, the BASE (Business for Arts, Sciences, and Engineering) Program is a six-week intensive that provides a comprehensive introduction to the business world. Participants will gain valuable insights and skills in:
Business research
Market analysis
Human resource management
Technological proficiency in business applications

Full academic credit for business courses
Custom workshops and company events
Small class sizes with esteemed Haas professors
Access to the extensive Haas Alumni Network
Application Information:

Who Should Apply: Current or recently graduated undergraduates from non-business majors. There is no application fee.
Take advantage of this extended deadline to secure your spot in a program that promises not only to bolster your business acumen but also to expand your professional network.
For more details and application instructions, please visit our website.
Don‚Äôt miss out on this transformative summer experience. Apply now!']

3.  Columbia Bridge to the Ph.D. Program
The Columbia Economics Department is recruiting its sixth cohort of Bridge-to-the-Ph.D. scholars for fall 2024. This program may be of interest to some of your students or recent
graduates.
The Bridge-to-the-Ph.D. program is designed to increase the participation of students from underrepresented groups in Ph.D. programs in STEM fields, including Economics. It is an
intensive research, academic, and mentoring experience for post-baccalaureates seeking to strengthen their graduate school applications and to prepare for the transition into Ph.D. programs. Scholars who apply to and are selected for the economics program will be paired with a mentor in the economics department and take part in activities tailored towards Ph.D. programs in the field.
Apply or to get more information at this website. The application deadline is March 1,2024. Please contact the program director, Richard Hagen by email at rh3224@columbia.edu if you have any further questions.

The program is geared towards equipping graduates with the necessary skills for successful careers in the public and private sectors, as well as in various fields of economic research. Notably, our curriculum is tailored to produce quantitative-focused researchers and analysts who possess robust theoretical knowledge.

6. Summer Opportunity in Washington, D.C.
As educators, we're dedicated to equipping our students for successful futures. I'm excited to share the TFAS Academic Internship Program in Washington, D.C. with you. 
As part of the TFAS program, your students will:
Earn academic credit from George Mason University and gain valuable professional experience through a guaranteed internship in the nation's capital.
Live in furnished housing with other program participants in the heart of Washington, D.C. where they can fully immerse themselves in the city's rich history and culture. 
Access exclusive guest lectures, policy site briefings and professional development events, giving them the opportunity to learn from industry leaders and make connections that will last a lifetime. 
With $1 million+ in scholarship funding available, this opportunity is within reach for many students. Time is running out to apply - the final deadline is March 12, so they'll have to act fast!
7. Data Science/ Statistics Student Work Opportunity
Residential Life is hiring two Student Assistant Analysts for the 2024-2025 academic year. The priority deadline is noon (12pm) on Thursday, 3/7/2024 (link to application). 
Our Student Analyst team gets hands-on data science experience as they assist with the development, analysis, and reporting of various assessment projects. Student Analysts typically compile descriptive statistics for external reports such as the infographic at the bottom of the Residential Life About Us page. For internal reports, analysts typically perform inferential statistical tests using R and R Studio. "]

['Please see below for announcements from our partners. If you are part of a registered student organization on campus, you are welcome to post your announcements directly to our Ed Discussion without waiting for our weekly announcement recap. This week‚Äôs announcements include: 
1. Invitation to Submit to the UCL Journal of Economics
2. Invitation for Spring Invitational Datathon for Department of Economics Students
3. Spring 2024 Fung Fellowship Info Sessions
4. Two Art of Writing workshops for undergraduates
5. 3-Part Series on Undergraduates Interested in Research
6. Global Poverty & Practice Minor Info Sessions
7. 2024 AAPI Media Creatives Fellowship Due March 1
8. Reaching out to students to teach for Splash
1. Invitation to Submit to the UCL Journal of Economics
 The UJE is the official peer-reviewed, student-run journal of the UCL Department of Economics. Submission Details:
Deadline for Submissions: 1st April 2024, 23:59 BST
How to Submit: Please visit https://student-journals.ucl.ac.uk/UJE/submissions/ for submission guidelines and to upload your paper.
For more information, and to read previous issues, please visit https://student-journals.ucl.ac.uk/UJE.
2. Invitation for Spring Invitational Datathon for Department of Economics Students
Spring Invitational Datathon 
Datathons are data science competitions that challenge students from the world's best universities to tackle real-world social challenges in topics such as urban traffic, renewable energy, and education. 
When: April 2 - 9
Where: Virtual
Who: Undergraduates and Master‚Äôs students
Prizes: $15,000 + Exclusive recruiting opportunities with Citadel and Citadel Securities 
APPLY FOR SPRING INVITATIONAL DATATHON
3. Spring 2024 Fung Fellowship Info Sessions
The Fung Fellowship is a unique opportunity to create impact-driven solutions to address real-world challenges alongside our community and industry partners. Fung Fellows utilize an experiential learning process focused on collaboration, interdisciplinary tactics, and emerging technology in both of our offered tracks: Conservation + Innovation and Health + Innovation.
Required qualifications:
Registered student at UC Berkeley
Class of 2026 rising junior or Class of 2025 rising senior (current sophomore or junior standing)
Passion for health, conservation, social impact, design, and/or technology
The Fung Fellowship accepts all majors into this program and there is no GPA minimum requirement. Applications are reviewed holistically.

Information to apply: 
Learn more about the program at: fungfellows.berkeley.edu
Register for an info session: bit.ly/FFInfoSession24
Sign up for our interest form: bit.ly/FFInterest24
Access the application: bit.ly/FFApp24
Deadline to apply: Saturday, March 2, 2024 at 11:59pm PT
4. Two Art of Writing workshops for undergraduates
The Lede and the Kicker: How to Shape an Essay Led by Doreen St. F√©lix
February 23 ‚Äî 25, 2024
Workshop Meetings:
Friday Feb 23, 3 ‚Äì 8 pm
Saturday Feb 24, 10 am ‚Äì 5 pm
Sunday Feb 25, 10 am ‚Äì 2 pm
Sound Stories: An Introduction to Audio Storytelling Led by Benjamin Naddaff-Hafrey
March 8 ‚Äì 10, 2024
Workshop Meetings:
Friday Mar 8, 3 ‚Äì 8 pm
Saturday Mar 9, 10 am ‚Äì 5 pm
Sunday Mar 10, 10 am ‚Äì 2 pm
Workshops are held over a weekend, beginning Friday afternoon and ending Sunday, at the Townsend Center for the Humanities (220 Stephens Hall). Students must commit to participating in the entire workshop over three days.

Space is limited to 15 students per workshop, and is first-come, first-served. All UC Berkeley undergraduates in their sophomore year or above are welcome to register. 

Registration deadline is February 16, 2024. To register for either workshop, please fill out this registration form. 

If you have questions, please contact Jane Liaw at janeliaw@berkeley.edu.
5. 3-Part Series on Undergraduates Interested in Research
Do you want to get involved in undergraduate research? 
Attend a series of events this February that help undergrads get involved in research, including a workshop on finding opportunities, a demystifying research panel, and a research symposium. All events provide free meals! See poster for more information. You must register for each event. 
Discover Your Future: How to Find Your Path at UC Berkeley
Workshops offered Feb 7-22, 12-1pm @ Moffitt 405
See details & registration for this event
Interactive Demystifying Research Panel with Faculty
Tuesday, Feb 20, 12-1:30pm @ ASUC Senate Chambers in Eshleman (5th floor)
See details & registration for this event
UC Berkeley Undergraduate Research Symposium
Saturday, Feb 24, 9am-1pm @ David Brower Center, 2150 Allston Way
See details & registration for this event
6. Global Poverty & Practice Minor Info Sessions
The Global Poverty and Practice Minor introduces students to the frameworks, methods, and practical skills necessary to engage with global poverty and inequality in effective ways.
The minor requires five courses that help students prepare for and reflect on a "Practice Experience." This experience is a central component of the minor in which students intern or volunteer with domestic or international NGOs, government agencies, social enterprises, or other poverty or development programs. Students work on issues such as environmental justice, community health, affordable housing, education, labor rights, and economic development.
Funding is available to support students‚Äô practice experiences.
The deadline to declare the minor this semester is March 12th. There are no prerequisites required to declare.
The Declaration Form and additional information about the minor can be found at: http://blumcenter.berkeley.edu/gppminor.
Information Sessions about the minor will be held at the following times:
Friday, February 9th, from 12:00 to 1:00 pm in Blum Hall B100 A/B
Tuesday, February 27th, from 6:00 to 7:00 pm on Zoom
Wednesday, March 6th, from 12:00 to 1:00 pm on Zoom
RSVP for a session Here
GPP Advising
Schedule an appointment with a GPP Peer Advisor: https://calendly.com/gppminor/gpp-minor-advising.
Contact gppminor@berkeley.edu with any questions.
7. 2024 AAPI Media Creatives Fellowship Due March 1
While the AAPI (Asian American and Pacific Islander) community have helped build America and contributed to culture around the world, until very recently mainstream storytelling from Hollywood has not reflected these contributions or included narratives of the diaspora. We want to change this and create a pipeline of creatives from Cal to Hollywood.
Through our AAPI Media Creatives Fellowship, BCNM aims to transform both how entertainment careers are viewed by students, and how AAPI are viewed within the entertainment industry. Selected fellows will receive a summer stipend of $1,500 plus mentorship from industry professionals. The funding will help fellows pursue their creative passions in media and entertainment over the summer. This may be through an internship at a Hollywood studio, developing a script or videogame, or auditioning for television and movie roles. Fellows will also receive valuable mentorship from industry leaders Jason Lin (Producer, Story Arch Pictures), Lacy Lew Nguyen Wright (Executive Director, Hillman Grad Foundation), and Laura Reddy (Manager, Range Media Partners), which will include four activities, such as lunches, 1-1 meetings, speaker events and more.
We want to build a network of Cal alumni in leadership positions in media who, by developing narratives that feature AAPI and encouraging greater diversity at all levels within studios and agencies, will fundamentally change the ecosystem of cultural production to be more reflective of the AAPI community at large.
This year, BCNM has one Fellowship to award. Students will be selected based on their commitment to developing narratives that feature Asian American and Pacific Islanders and encouraging greater diversity at all levels within media.
Apply today.
8. Reaching out to students to teach for Splash
Splash at Berkeley is an educational outreach event each semester where high school students come to campus for a day of classes taught by undergraduates, graduates, and postdocs. These classes are between 1 and 3 hours (in hour multiples) and can be taught on literally any (appropriate) topic of your interest. Topics in the past have ranged from black holes to crocheting to poker. Anything you want to teach, you can! Our goal is to get high school students interested in the wide range of topics they can explore during college. Additionally, this is a fantastic way to give back to the local Bay community.
This spring, Splash will be on Sunday, April 21, and we would love for you to teach with us! Teacher registration is open until February 26th, so please sign up using the link below.
https://berkeley.learningu.org/teach/splash.html
More info can be found at this link. If you have any questions about the program or teaching, please email me at sajant@berkeley.edu. Also, please encourage your friends to teach as well! We had ~300 students in the Fall and are working to have even more this semester, which will only be possible with the help of enthusiastic teachers like you.']

['Please see below for announcements from our partners. If you are part of a registered student organization on campus, you are welcome to post your announcements directly to our Ed Discussion without waiting for our weekly announcement recap. This week‚Äôs announcements include: 
1. STEM and Business Career Fairs January 30th and 31st!
2. Duke Undergraduate Economics Journal
3. Summer Fellowship Opportunity at the University of Chicago - Energy Policy Institute, 2024
4. Case Study Reinvention at UCLA and NYU
5. It‚Äôs Your Time to Take Your Learning to The Next Level with SLP‚Äôs Newest Service!
6. DPHIE Recruitment
7. Expand & Diversify Cal‚Äôs Curriculum by Creating Your Own DeCal Course!
8. Barings Summer Research Fellowship Position

1. STEM and Business Career Fairs January 30th and 31st!
2024 STEM Career & Internship Fair
Tuesday, January 30th, 2024, 12-4pm | RSF Field House 
Join us at the in-person STEM Career & Internship fair to learn about full-time and internship opportunities. Connect with over 50 employers from various industries including internet & software, Research, Manufacturing, Aerospace, plus more. 
2024 Business & Non-Tech Career & Internship Fair
Wednesday, January 31st, 2024, 12pm-4pm | RSF Field House 
Join us at the in-person 2024 Business & Non-Tech Career & Internship Fair and learn about full-time and summer internship opportunities. Connect with representatives from companies across different industries such as Accounting, Consulting, Tech, Financial Services, Nonprofits, Education, and Government. 
2. Duke Undergraduate Economics Journal
Equilibria, Duke University's Economics Review, cordially invites you to submit your work for consideration in our spring 2024 issue. We welcome original research papers and theses from all disciplines of social sciences and business (economics, public policy, finance, etc.). Information about Equilibria, including our past issues, can be found here.
This is an excellent opportunity for undergraduates to receive recognition for their work by a premier research publication. Even if the author has graduated now (e.g. master students or pre-docs), if the paper was completed in the undergraduate time, we will still consider the paper. For complete submission guidelines, please see this document.  
Submission deadline: Monday, Jan. 29 
3. Summer Fellowship Opportunity at the University of Chicago - Energy Policy Institute, 2024
We are predoctoral fellows working with Michael Greenstone, Professor of Economics at the University of Chicago and director of the Energy Policy Institute (EPIC). Our team is looking for students currently in their penultimate year to join as research fellows for summer 2024. We work on a variety of topics in energy and environmental economics, ranging from solar energy to pollution to the effects of climate change.
The application is open until March 5th. Any students interested in the fellowship are encouraged to apply here.
4. Case Study Reinvention at UCLA and NYU
We‚Äôll hear from UCLA‚Äôs Olav Sorenson, who is chairing our Academic Advisory Board, and UCI‚Äôs Noah Askin, who has authored many cases‚Äîboth in the traditional pdf format and our new AI-powered approach. We've had thousands of students experience our platform, and over 90% prefer it to traditional case studies. We're now working with half of the top-20 ranked business schools, and more are signing on every day. Come see what the excitement is all about!  You can register for the webinar here. 
5. It‚Äôs Your Time to Take Your Learning to The Next Level with SLP‚Äôs Newest Service!
As the new semester unfolds, we believe there's no better time than now to enhance your learning experience. In the SLC Strategic Learning Program, our mission is to empower you with the essential tools, mindsets, and strategies to take ownership of your academic journey. With the semester in full swing, we are excited to announce a brand new service for Spring 2024!
Join us for "It‚Äôs Your Time: Reconnect with Your Most Precious Resource"! In this engaging 1-hour workshop, you‚Äôll rediscover and reconnect with your most valuable resource: time. Whether you consider yourself a seasoned time manager or are exploring new techniques, we guarantee that you'll emerge with a transformed relationship to time, empowered with concrete tools to make the most of your schedule.
Sign up at bit.ly/slp-tmw for one of our first sessions of the semester on Thursday, 1/25, 2 - 3 pm; Monday, 1/29, 11 am - 12 pm; or Thursday, 2/1, 1 - 2 pm. 
Can‚Äôt make it to any of the times? We‚Äôll be offering this workshop on a weekly basis and will be adding new dates.
Stay tuned for more exciting updates as we roll out additional services throughout the semester! We hope to see you at one of our services soon!
6. DPHIE Recruitment
Delta Phi Epsilon (DPhiE) is a co-ed, pre-professional international relations and foreign service fraternity at Cal that focuses on professional development, social bonding, and more! Our fraternity consists of individuals with a wide range of personal backgrounds, academic interests, and career trajectories. We are united by our passion in international relations! Be sure to check out our website at https://dpe.berkeley.edu/ for more information on our rush events and application timeline, as well as follow us on Instagram @caldphie for the latest updates.
7. Expand & Diversify Cal‚Äôs Curriculum by Creating Your Own DeCal Course!
Did you know that UC Berkeley students, just like you, contribute over 300 courses to Cal‚Äôs curriculum every year? You too can expand and diversify UC Berkeley‚Äôs academic landscape by creating a DeCal! 
Creating and facilitating a DeCal is your chance to unleash your creative energy, cultivate an intellectual community with your peers around a shared interest, and make an impact on the college experience of your fellow students. 
Partner with the SLC Undergraduate Course Facilitator Training & Resources (UCFTR) program to learn more about the DeCal proposal process, fulfill mandatory training for facilitators, and explore strategies for effective DeCal facilitation! 
This semester, we are launching monthly drop-in consultations where you can ask questions about all things DeCal, as well as glean best practices and suggestions to craft a winning proposal! Our first monthly drop-in consultation hour will be next Wednesday, January 31, 11 am - 12 pm via Zoom, and we invite you to join us to get started on your Fall 2024 DeCal proposal!
Learn more about consultations and our other services via our website or on the attached flyer, and sign up for our email listserv to receive updates throughout the semester. 
Email us at slc-ucftr@berkeley.edu if you have any questions, and we look forward to partnering with you on your DeCal creation process! 
8. Barings Summer Research Fellowship Position
The Emerging Markets sovereign team is looking for a graduate fellow for the summer of 2024 to be based in Boston or London to work on the following topic: Asset Management Trends.                   The main objective of the summer fellow is to review how the global investor universe has changed over the past 30 years. Specifically, we are interested in:
1). The evolution of geographical distribution of the investor base in Emerging Markets
2). Investment channels (companies)
3). Instruments (Fixed Income, Equity)
4). Distribution of active vs passive investments and crossover funds, with particular emphasis on Emerging Markets Debt
Only graduate applicants will be considered. Deadline for application is Friday, February 23, 2024. Shortlisted applicants will be contacted shortly after deadline and interviews will be held mid-March.
Read more about it here']

['Please see below for announcements from our partners. If you are part of a registered student organization on campus, you are welcome to post your announcements directly to our Ed Discussion without waiting for our weekly announcement recap. This week‚Äôs announcements include: 

1. Accounting@Berkeley: Meet the Firms on February 1
2. Stanford Law School: Research Fellow in Empirical Law and Finance
3. Berkeley Law Project - Student Privacy Form for Undergraduate Students
4. Pathways to Progress Opportunity
5. Undergraduate Research Assistantship Program for Spring 2024: Economics Majors
6. UC Davis Study Abroad - Summer 2024 Enrollment Open
7. UCDC Fall 2024 now accepting applications; deadline February 22
8. Fung Fellowship applications open to rising juniors & seniors
9. Student Opportunity - Pub Pol 98/198: Applied Policy Lab
10. Call for Research Associates - Student Policy Institute at Berkeley
11. Invitation for Undergraduates to Berkeley Social Sciences Townhall Meeting to discuss Strategic Plan
1. Accounting@Berkeley: Meet the Firms on February 1
The Center for Financial Reporting and Management (CFRM) is calling all UC Berkeley students who are interested in learning about the accounting and professional services industry to attend our Meet the Firms event! There will be a number of firms with us.
Please join us to learn about careers in audit, tax, advisory, transfer pricing, information technology advisory, and more! You will have an opportunity to meet recruiters and professionals from accounting firms, ask questions and learn about internships and full time positions.
Here are the details:
Accounting@Berkeley: Meet the Firms, Thursday, February 1, 12:00pm - 2:00pm
Wells Fargo Room/C420, Cheit Hall, 4th Floor, Haas School of Business
Pizza will be provided (first come, first serve)
This event is open to all UC Berkeley students. You may stop by anytime within the two hour window.
Please RSVP here: https://forms.gle/AFdH6SKPNe7CRcCX9
Participating firms: Baker Tilly, Deloitte, EY, KPMG, PwC
For further information contact CFRM@haas.berkeley.edu.
2. Stanford Law School: Research Fellow in Empirical Law and Finance
We welcome you to apply for our fellowship program supporting Professor Robert Bartlett on projects ranging from venture capital finance, corporate governance, and/or equity market structure. If you are exploring the idea of applying to a graduate program (Ph.D./JD) in the future, this could be the next step for you. Read about the fellowship opportunity here and apply:  https://careersearch.stanford.edu/jobs/research-fellow-in-empirical-law-and-finance-24017
3. Berkeley Law Project - Student Privacy Form for Undergraduate Students
‚ÄúWe are Berkeley Law Students who are surveying data privacy of higher education students using courseware. This survey will help make policy recommendations that better protect your privacy and advance the accessibility of instructional materials. We would greatly appreciate your anonymous responses!‚Äù 

Form: https://forms.gle/KdvatkAkyd5TQTXk8
4. Pathways to Progress Opportunity
Hi! We are excited to announce Pathways to Progress, a 10-week reading group and speaker series exploring Progress Studies. We will be running our second fellowship starting at the beginning of February via Zoom. Applications are open until January 23rd, 11:59 PM ET and can be submitted here. 
Pathways to Progress aims to create a community of individuals committed to exploring and contributing to human prosperity. We seek to encourage discussions on technological and scientific innovation and foster a deeper understanding of the mechanisms behind human advancement. Readings will investigate historical examples of progress, the implications of economic growth on moral progress, industrial policy, and the relationship between technological progress and societal change. Fellows will be able to engage in discussions with our speakers: Aria Babu, Matt Clancy, Jason Crawford, Anton Howes, Saffron Huang, Reka Juhasz, Nathan Lane, Xavier Sala-i-Martin, Caleb Watney, and Heidi Williams. 
We would appreciate any feedback on the syllabus or fellowship!


5. Undergraduate Research Assistantship Program for Spring 2024: Economics Majors
The goal of this program is to connect undergraduate students majoring in Economics who are interested in doing research with faculty and grad students. For this edition of the program, we will be focusing on RA arrangements compensated by enrollment in Econ 199 units. Each student can be enrolled in up to three Econ 199 units per semester, and each Econ 199 unit must represent a dedication of at least three hours per week. All units are P/NP. This course cannot be used to fulfill an elective requirement for the major.

To apply for a research assistant position, fill this form: https://forms.gle/kjftq27bkmZGJjWY7 . Faculty and grad students will be able to view applications and will contact undergraduate students on the week starting from 01/21. Notice that the form includes the option to signal particular interest in up to three projects - find a spreadsheet with information about the various projects being offered this term here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1CzGcacsREzFprhdfeYnCVHt7Vpm7QA7uTPY0bctn4B0/edit?usp=sharing

Questions to be sent to ugradraprogram@econ.berkeley.edu
6. UC Davis Study Abroad - Summer 2024 Enrollment Open
We are happy to announce that enrollment is now open for 2024 UC Davis Summer Abroad, Summer Abroad Internships, and Virtual Summer Internships programs. Students across all UCs are eligible to enroll in UC Davis summer study abroad programs. 
Explore our Study Abroad programming for 2024. Enrollment is now open. Create an online profile now and select programs you‚Äôre interested in to receive details about information sessions or program updates. Programs fill on a first-completed, first-reserved basis.
7. UCDC Fall 2024 now accepting applications; deadline February 22
UCDC Now Accepting Applications, Due February 22, 2024
UCDC sends juniors and seniors to Washington, DC each fall and spring to participate in prestigious internships and take exciting courses for a full semester of UCB academic credit. All majors are welcome. UCB financial aid and grants available.
Recent participants have said: "UCDC was instrumental in landing a job after I graduated," and "UCDC was my best semester at Berkeley!"

Questions? Come to an info session to learn more, email, or sign up for an appointment. Also, check the website and facebook page for program announcements and updates.
Upcoming Info Session Dates 
‚Ä¢ Wednesday, January 17, 1-2pm on zoom at https://berkeley.zoom.us/j/5492740547
‚Ä¢ Tuesday, January 23, 11am-noon on zoom at https://berkeley.zoom.us/j/5492740547
‚Ä¢ Wednesday, January 31, 2-3pm in-person in 3401 Dwinelle Hall
8. Fung Fellowship applications open to rising juniors & seniors
We are excited to announce that the Fung Fellowship Application for the 2024-25 academic year is now open! Our applications are due Saturday, March 2, 2024 and we are accepting applications from Class of 2026 rising juniors and Class of 2025 rising seniors.
Check out our Media Kit to learn more about the Fung Fellowship!
Please contact Priyanka Karki (priyanka_k@berkeley.edu) if you have any questions.
9. Student Opportunity - Pub Pol 98/198: Applied Policy Lab
I‚Äôm happy to announce that [Public Policy 98/198: Applied Policy Lab] is now accepting applications! Please use this link https://forms.gle/Qo1q4w8qujZAvAqZA to fill out the application to be considered for enrollment.
Applied Policy Lab is a space for students to analyze and craft public policy to address social issues. Students are free to select any topic that interests them, and they will be taught methods for researching, analyzing, and advocating their chosen policy topics. The class is lightweight and flexible in format. Students may take the course for 1, 2, or 3 units, and only one discussion section per week ‚Äì either, 6-7 PM on Mondays at Dwinelle 229 or 6-7 PM on Wednesdays at Dwinelle 182.
The course is open to all majors and years. Students have the opportunity to explore any policy topic that interests them in a relaxed, supportive setting, and no previous experience with policy or social sciences is required. The course‚Äôs four class assignments center around building a portfolio on the student's policy topic, with one assignment due per month, with the assignments scaling for unit count.
Applied Policy Lab is organized by the Student Policy Institute at Berkeley, a student-led, interdisciplinary public policy think tank. Please reach out to akesavalu@berkeley.edu with any questions.
10. Call for Research Associates - Student Policy Institute at Berkeley
The Student Policy Institute at Berkeley (SPIB), formerly known as the Roosevelt Network at Berkeley, Cal‚Äôs very own student-led, interdisciplinary policy think tank, is recruiting research associates for its Spring 2024 Policy Initiatives. Policy Initiatives are student-led teams of 5-7 research associates that work on a specific topic for the duration of one semester. Detailed descriptions of this Spring‚Äôs four policy topics can be found here. SPIB Spring 2024 Application
11. Invitation for Undergraduates to Berkeley Social Sciences Townhall Meeting to discuss Strategic Plan
Our Social Sciences Division is embarking on a journey to develop a comprehensive strategic plan for the next decade. This plan will not just be a blueprint for our future ‚Äì but a commitment to excellence in research, teaching, and to fostering a culture enriched by diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging.
Your voice is crucial in this undertaking. I invite you to join our team for an in-person town hall meeting on campus at the Social Science Matrix (8th floor of the Social Sciences Building) on Thursday, Feb. 8 at 5 p.m. This session is for undergraduate students only. We are hosting a separate session for graduate students.
Led by my leadership team, this one-hour session is a platform for you to share your insights, ideas and aspirations. Your participation will ensure that we shape a strategic plan that truly reflects our collective vision and values for Berkeley Social Sciences. Please RSVP here. ']

['1. Brilliance of Berkeley
2. National Scholarship Newsletter
3. Berkeley Global Internships Applications Are Open!
4. Call for Submissions: Duke Equilibria 2024 Undergraduate Economics Journal
5. Supercharge your Studying with SLP Power Hours!

6. St. Anthony's Foundation and UC Berkeley Partnership
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Brilliance of Berkeley
We are excited to announce that "Brilliance of Berkeley," a brand-new course offered by the College of Letters & Science, is now open to all undergraduate students. We kindly request your assistance in informing your students about this unique course. 
What Is "Brilliance of Berkeley"?
This 1-unit (P/NP) course offers a unique opportunity for undergraduate students to immerse themselves in and celebrate the diverse academic and cultural landscape of UC Berkeley:
Luminary Guest Lectures: Every week, students will hear from distinguished faculty members representing diverse colleges and schools within Berkeley, including Chancellor Carol Christ. Students will gain insight into UC Berkeley's brilliant faculty - including Nobel Laureates, MacArthur Fellows, and Distinguished Teaching Award recipients - across a wide range of academic disciplines. 
Reflect and Connect: Following each lecture, students will engage in peer and community-building activities. These exercises are designed to facilitate connections and encourage friendships and mentorships that can enhance their overall academic experience.
Celebrate the Campus: "Brilliance of Berkeley" will help students explore the multitude of academic and cultural offerings available at UC Berkeley. It's a window to the exciting world of research and co-curricular learning experiences.
Fostering Community and Connection: This course goes beyond the classroom, and includes a series of out-of-class activities. These activities are aimed at creating a strong sense of community and belonging among students, ensuring that UC Berkeley continues to feel like a place where they can truly thrive.
This signature class both provides our newest students with a comprehensive overview of the Brilliance of Berkeley, while reminding our graduating students of exactly why they chose to come to Berkeley. 
Students may participate in this course online (Section 1) OR in person (Section 2) - a hybrid version is not available. Note that the engagement activities will be offered online, asynchronously. 
In-person (Section 2): LS 110-LEC 002; Fridays 12:00-1:59 PM

Online: LS 110 (Section 1): LEC 001 
Please feel free to reach out to us with questions or comments: brilliance@lists.berkeley.edu.
National Scholarship Newsletter
 
UPCOMING INFO SESSIONS

FULBRIGHT U.K. SUMMER INSTITUTES
Info Session for UC Berkeley Students (Zoom only)
Monday, December 4, 2023, 12:00 pm (Pacific)
Register in advance for this webinar at this link.
See program description in Early 2024 Deadlines section below.

BOREN SCHOLARSHIP
Info Session for UC Berkeley Students (Zoom only)
Thursday, Dec 7, 2023, 1:00pm (Pacfiic)
Register in advance for this webinar at this link.
See program description in Early 2024 Deadlines section below.
LATE FALL APPLICATION DEADLINES

GOLDWATER SCHOLARSHIP
Campus deadline - December 11, 2023
 The Barry M. Goldwater Scholarship provides $7,500 per year for educational expenses to sophomores and juniors majoring in math, science, and engineering. The purpose of the award is to encourage outstanding students to pursue careers and advanced degrees in these fields.
EARLY 2024 DEADLINES

TRUMAN SCHOLARSHIP
Campus deadline - January 11, 2024
 The Harry S. Truman Scholarship provides $30,000 to juniors planning to attend graduate school in preparation for careers in public service. Awardees also receive leadership training, graduate school counseling, preferential admission to premier graduate institutions, and internship opportunities with federal agencies. Each year, 60‚Äì65 scholarships are awarded to juniors from across the country.


BOREN SCHOLARSHIP
Campus deadline - Noon, January 24, 2024
 Boren Scholarships are funded by the National Security Education Program (NSEP), which focuses on geographic areas, languages, and fields of study deemed critical to U.S. national security. They provide up to $25,000 to U.S. undergraduates to study abroad for 8‚Äì52 weeks in areas of the world that are critical to U.S. interests and underrepresented in study abroad, including Africa, Asia, Central & Eastern Europe, Eurasia, Latin America, and the Middle East. Applicants should identify how their study abroad program, as well as their future academic and career goals, will contribute to U.S. national security, recognizing that the scope of national security has expanded to include not only the traditional concerns of protecting and promoting American well-being, but also the challenges of global society, including sustainable development, environmental degradation, global disease and hunger, population growth and migration, and economic competitiveness. In exchange for funding, recipients commit to working in the federal government for at least one year after graduation.


FULBRIGHT U.K. SUMMER INSTITUTES
Deadline - February 1, 2024
 The Fulbright U.K. Summer Institutes are 3‚Äì4-week programs for U.S. undergraduate students who have no, or very little, travel experience outside North America. Participants can explore the culture, heritage, and history of the U.K. while experiencing higher education at a U.K. university. Several U.K. Summer Institutes are available every year. Each is hosted by a different university and focuses on a specific historical or cultural context, or a subject or topic. Applicants do not need to be familiar with these to apply and are encouraged to explore their interests.

STRAUSS SCHOLARSHIP
Campus deadline - February 15, 2024
 The Donald A. Strauss Scholarship provides a $15,000 award, consisting of a $7,000 scholarship and an $8,000 project grant. Applicants must be sophomores and juniors who will use the grant to pursue a self-initiated public service project during the year after winning the award. The project may be a new undertaking or an extension of an existing project. The Strauss Foundation annually awards the scholarship to students from twenty-two eligible California institutions, including UC Berkeley.


UDALL SCHOLARSHIP
Campus deadline - Noon, February 20, 2024
 The Udall Scholarship honors the legacies of Morris and Stewart Udall, whose careers had a significant impact on Native American self-governance, health care, and the stewardship of public lands and natural resources. The scholarship provides $7,000 for educational expenses to 55 outstanding sophomores and juniors who fall into either one of the two following categories:
1. Students who study the environment and related fields; or
2. Native Americans or Alaska Natives in fields related to health care or tribal public policy.



BEINECKE SCHOLARSHIP
Campus deadline - Noon, March 11, 2024
 The Beinecke Scholarship provides 
35,000(5,000 prior to graduate study and $15,000 per year) for two years of graduate study in the arts, humanities, or social sciences. Eighty colleges and universities from across the U.S. (including UC Berkeley) are invited to nominate one student for the scholarship; twenty scholarships are awarded nationwide. Most Beinecke recipients are at the top of their class academically and many plan to pursue careers in college teaching and/or research.

FAQ
Will my placement be in English, or do I need to speak the local language?
All placements are anticipated to take place in English, however additional language skills may be helpful based on job scope. The exceptions include the Paris and Buenos Aires locations, which have limited English placements available. It is suggested that applicants to these programs have a strong grasp of French or Spanish, respectively.

Do I have to enroll in courses? Can I participate in the internship only?
Yes, internships are completed for academic credit and oftentimes, course enrollment is required for visa purposes. To participate in the Global Internships program, you must also enroll in the required course(s).

How does the placement process work?
Each internship is tailored to the student based on their skills, knowledge, industry trends, and availability each year. As a part of the placement process, you will have the opportunity to articulate your preferences to our partners, who will then work with you to find your personalized placement.

Does my financial aid apply to the Global Internships program?
Yes, your financial aid can be packaged for your participation in the Global Internships program. Please keep in mind that in order to qualify for summer aid, you must be enrolled in a minimum of 6 semester units. For more information on financial aid or resources to calculate your estimated aid, please visit the financial aid section of our website.
Call for Submissions: Duke Equilibria 2024 Undergraduate Economics Journal
Dear students, 
Equilibria, Duke University's Economics Review, cordially invites you to submit your work for consideration in our spring 2024 issue. We welcome original research papers and theses from all disciplines of social sciences and business (economics, public policy, finance, etc.). Information about Equilibria, including our past issues, can be found here.
This is an excellent opportunity for undergraduates to receive recognition for their work by a premier research publication. Even if the author has graduated now (e.g. master students or pre-docs), if the paper was completed in the undergraduate time, we will still consider the paper. For complete submission guidelines, please seethis document. 
Please note that work published elsewhere may not be submitted for consideration. Selection criteria are based on strength of analysis and originality of argument, as well as quality of writing. Selected works will go through a rigorous editing process.
The next issue will be published in April 2024, and the submission deadline is January 22nd, 2024. Please email your paper to dukeequilibria@gmail.com for submission, along with your full name and academic background.
Thank you; we look forward to reviewing your work. Please feel free to reach out to dukeequilibria@gmail.com if you have any questions.
Sincerely,
Equilibria: Duke Economics Review Editorial Board
