1. Charles H. Percy Undergraduate Grant for Public Affairs Research 
Every year IGS awards four Charles H. Percy Undergraduate Grant for Public Affairs Research, in the amount of $500 each, to Cal undergraduates who are conducting research on an aspect of American politics, including public opinion, electoral behavior, civic participation, government institutions, social movements, and public policy. Students from a broad range of disciplines are encouraged to apply.
The deadline for receiving applications is Sunday, November 26, at 11:59pm. 
2. Columbia Decision, Risk & Operations PhD program
I‚Äôd like to introduce you to our unique interdisciplinary PhD program in my division (DRO: Decision, Risk, and Operations) at Columbia Business School, combining math, engineering, economics, and data science, to improve decision making and policy via mathematical models and data-driven analytics.
Key differentiators of our program include a low student-to-faculty ratio, full funding, all-star faculty, flexibility to choose an advisor, rigorous coursework, deep and impactful research, an attractive location, brilliant fellow students from diverse backgrounds, and an unparalleled academic placement record. 
The PhD program webpage, including an informational video, is here (application deadline: Dec 15, 2023). There will be multiple opportunities to interact with faculty and students during the admissions process. Please contact Dan Spacher (ds2187@gsb.columbia.edu) if you encounter any logistical issues in submitting your application.
In addition, there are several predoctoral research programs we offer at Columbia Business School. Students will have the opportunity to support the cutting-edge research of renowned faculty and gain valuable experience (email Khaled Hamdykhamdy@gsb.columbia.edu if interested.
3. ORISE Fellowship Roles
Are you passionate ensuring the clean energy transition leads to good jobs and broadly shared prosperity? In DOE‚Äôs Office of Energy Jobs, we advise the Secretary of Energy and senior DOE leaders on labor, workforce, and jobs issues. We design policy and implementation strategies to ensure that the jobs created from historic investments in clean energy are family-sustaining careers, accessible to people from all walks of life. We conduct research to inform policy makers, training providers, and employers on jobs trends in the energy industry. We ensure that working people are at the table when we engage with stakeholders. If this appeals to you, apply to be an ORISE fellow in the Office of Energy Jobs. Reach out to me or Katy Clarke Kathryn.clarke@hq.doe.gov with any questions.  
Energy Jobs Research and Analysis Fellow: Conduct research to help guide policy and workforce strategy
Provide high-quality data analysis and visualization
Write and provide briefings on the US Energy and Employment Report
Workforce Development Fellow: Advance workforce development to meet the changing energy landscape including training and pathways to access high-quality jobs.  
Write briefings OR advise on energy workforce needs and issues for DOE‚Äôs senior leadership
Help develop targeted approaches to reduce barriers and improve access to quality jobs
Labor and Stakeholder Engagement Fellow: Support engagement and site visits with a wide range of stakeholders and communicate DOE priorities. 
Develop series of engagements throughout the country that elevate best practices and partnerships in energy jobs
Track and communicate DOE‚Äôs latest announcements to labor and workforce stakeholders
Quality Jobs and Labor Standards Fellow: Work across DOE program and technology offices to ensure that investments create high-quality jobs.
Develop briefs on the benefits of good quality jobs to the clean energy transition
Support implementation of DOE‚Äôs Community Benefits Plans through education and engagement strategies 
Please apply here and specify the position: Zintellect - Climb Higher
 4. US Department of Energy Jobs 
Energy Jobs Research and Analysis Lead;https://www.usajobs.gov/job/751803800
The Secretary‚Äôs Office of Energy Jobs at DOE is seeking an Energy Jobs Research and Analysis Lead for a permanent career position at the GS-15 level. This is a senior position leading a team of DOE staff and implementers to perform and communicate high-impact economic and employment research and analysis.
Please contact Katy Clarke (Kathryn.clarke@hq.doe.gov) if interested. Please apply to this general announcement, specify the position, and speak to the below job description: USAJOBS - Job Announcement 
Good Jobs and Labor Standards Lead: https://www.usajobs.gov/job/739085100
Come lead a team focused on ensuring that BIL and IRA are creating good, family sustaining jobs and attracting and retaining a skilled energy workforce in the Secretary‚Äôs Office of Energy Jobs. Attention to worker retention in the energy industry to support a just energy transition is critical to DOE‚Äôs mission. The team lead will work with public and private stakeholders to understand how different policy and incentives will shape the U.S. workforce and how good quality jobs are essential to attract and retain the workforce we need. In addition, the lead will coordinate across DOE and the interagency to develop a strong knowledge base of U.S. government employees and source material to support good jobs and represent Office of Energy Jobs equities at interagency and stakeholder meetings. The incumbent will advise senior leaders on the best pathways for promoting good jobs and labor standards and will also promote project labor agreements and collective bargaining agreements and ensure effective implementation of Community Benefits Plans.

6. Berkeley Undergraduate Journal of Classics Calls for Papers Spring 2024
The Berkeley Undergraduate Journal of Classics is now open for our 2024 Spring Issue paper submissions!
Please submit your academic papers and creative writing/art (including poetry and prose) to our website by December 31 at 11:59 pm PST. All written submissions should be no more than 10 pages double-spaced (not including bibliographies), with 12pt font, cited and formatted according to the Chicago Manual of Style, 17th edition.
If you have any questions, please get in touch with us at berkeleyujc@berkeley.edu! 
 7. Bridging and Belonging Course from OBI 
What if you could get credit for connection? Learn how to build a new kind of community? Challenge the power structures that keep us apart? Enroll now in the course: Bridging and Belonging (Ethnic Studies 198 Group 002) and you'll find out! Trust us, you've never taken a UC Berkeley course like this one! 

We are all meaning-making animals. We build our lives out of stories that are rooted in our connections (our past, our families, our cultures, our experiences). Some of these stories bring us closer to other people, encourage us to invite them in and collaborate with them and others lead us to push away those we consider ‚Äúothers‚Äù. By examining the ways people build these narratives and how we can push them outwards to include ever more people in the circle of human concern, we help to build a future we can all exist in.

In this course, an offering from the Othering and Belonging Institute‚Äôs Campus Bridging Project, we will work to integrate the core concepts of bridging and belonging (as well as their counterparts of bonding and breaking/othering) into understanding the work being done on Berkeley‚Äôs campus and the possibility of the work to come. The course will offer opportunities for students to develop their own understandings of bridging and belonging, learn about student groups and campus orgs already doing some of this work, and build towards their own implementation and analysis of the course concepts in real-world contexts.
course link: https://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2024-spring-ethstd-198-002-grp-002 
8. PhD in Population Studies at Princeton University 
The Office of Population Research, founded in 1936, is the demographic research and graduating training center at Princeton University. Building on its historical strengths in signature fields such as demographic methods, fertility, health, and mortality, OPR faculty and students pursue research and teaching on a range of topics, using a range of quantitative and qualitative methodologies in the study of human populations in both the US and around the world. 
To learn more about the program (Ph.D. in Population Studies or Join Ph.D. in Population Studies and Social Policy) and its requirements, use this link https://pop.princeton.edu/graduate-program/prospective-students. 
9. Invitation for Women's Datathon for Department of Economics 
We are excited to announce that this upcoming Spring, we are partnering with Citadel and Citadel Securities to launch the next season of events! Top-performing students can win $15,000 in cash prizes and exclusive recruiting opportunities with Citadel (Both internships and full-time roles). The events are completely free and invite only. 
One event that we would love to highlight is our second-ever Women‚Äôs Datathon. Seeing great success in its pilot season last year, we are excited to share that the event will be returning this upcoming February in Miami. It‚Äôs a data science competition open to all women students across North America. Invited students will be flown out to Miami in an all-expense-paid trip for the two-day long event.
Women‚Äôs Datathon: 
Hosted by Citadel and Citadel Securities in partnership with Correlation One, this event is open to top students across North America who identify as women. Women‚Äôs Datathon takes place this February and invited students will be flown out to Miami in an all-expense-paid trip for the two-day long event.
Our Datathons challenge students from the world's best universities to tackle real-world social challenges in topics such as urban traffic, renewable energy, and education. Women‚Äôs Datathon is a national data science competition, bigger and more exciting than our regional events! More information about our launch and the competition can be found here. 
When: February 9th & 10th
Where: Miami, FL
Who: Undergraduates, graduates, Ph.D., and post-doc researchers who identify as women
Prizes: $15,000 + Exclusive recruiting opportunities with Citadel and Citadel Securities 
APPLY FOR WOMEN'S DATATHON
10. Politics and Culture Magazine Run by University of Chicago Students 
Dear writers,
We are The Harper Review, a review of politics and culture run by University of Chicago students that takes inspiration from publications such as UnHerd, The Baffler, The Point, The New Criterion, Compact, The Drift, The Hedgehog Review, The Atlantic, First Things, Tablet, and The Economist. We are now looking for essays and shorter ‚Äúletters‚Äù for our winter issue. 
We‚Äôre interested in essays that:
Thoughtfully explore cultural and political phenomena
Don‚Äôt rely on academic jargon or vogue
Are written for a general audience without talking down or dumbing down
Are 1,500‚Äì2,500 words‚Äîwe‚Äôre happy to look at longer or marginally shorter pieces, but we want to give writers space to fully flesh out their ideas
Argue something we may not hear from the blue check marks
Connect life on the ground to big ideas and vice versa
Take those that disagree seriously
Note: we don‚Äôt want academic papers‚Äîideas from class papers often inspire our essays, but we are a general-audience magazine, not an academic journal.
We‚Äôre also looking for shorter ‚Äúletters‚Äù (3‚Äì4 paragraphs or 400‚Äì500 words) responding to the statement ‚ÄúWe should never forget the past.‚Äù Argue in favor, against, or that the statement itself is flawed‚Äîwe want to hear it all.
If any of this sounds like your jam, shoot us a draft or a pitch and a writing sample at harperreview@gmail.com. If you are interested in subscribing to our weekly email newsletter or reading pieces we‚Äôve published in the past, please visit our website. We will be accepting drafts for our winter issue until December 17th‚Äîwe hope to hear from you!
11. Fellowship Opportunity at the US Department of the Treasury 
I wanted to reach out regarding the second cohort of the Financial Stability Oversight Council Jr. Fellowship. It is specifically tailored for recent or upcoming graduates of four-year degree programs. I think it could be of interest to your students looking to work in financial or economic policy. 
The role is a two-year, full-time fellowship program at the Office of the Financial Stability Oversight Council (more information about the role here and the Council here). The Financial Stability Oversight Council brings together federal and state financial and insurance regulators to monitor U.S. financial stability and assess and mitigate potential risks to the financial system, and the Council‚Äôs work is supported by our staff at the Treasury. We‚Äôre looking for students with a background in economics, finance, public policy, or similar fields. They‚Äôd likely be helping conduct policy research on some of our larger policy priorities (which currently include issues such as climate-related financial risk and digital assets), potentially working with financial market data, and helping facilitate some of the operational roles of our team, which puts together FSOC Council and committee meetings and would give fellows exposure to a host of staffers and more senior leaders at various FSOC member agencies.
The application materials are listed on the website and are due on December 15, 2023. This would be a great opportunity for students interested in graduate school at a later date (as it‚Äôs only a fixed, two-year term), students who want a taste for federal government work, or just students broadly interested in these policy areas."]

1.  History C1
As you are planning your schedules for Spring 2024, I wanted to bring this course to your attention. History C1: The Survey of World History is a Lower Division History course. The course will be taught by an excellent faculty member, Professor Trevor Jackson! 
Please take a look at the course description. 
This course is an introductory survey of the history of the world over the past half millennium, with a particular emphasis on themes of political economy. It traces the collapse of dynastic empires and the emergence of democracy and nation-states, the rise of global capitalism and its rivals, as well as the spread of and resistance to imperialism and colonialism. The purpose of the course is to gain a better understanding of the rise and decline of political systems, legitimating ideologies, and systems of production and exchange, as well as their interaction and integration across time and space. The class explores the deep roots of our tumultuous times, including the creation of the global monetary system, slavery and wage labor, fossil fuels and industrialization, and mass politics. In addition to expanding your knowledge of world history, it will introduce you to the practice of history, and the subject of political economy.
2. Help Finding a Venue for a Career program
Are you interested in exploring a career in finance and commercial banking? River City Bank will host a ten-week program called Banking Academy this January at UC Berkeley! Banking Academy students explore a new topic in the commercial banking industry each week, and our sessions are led by River City Bank executive leaders. Students who participate in Banking Academy complete a mock underwriting project based on real-world scenarios, while being exposed to different industries, including clean energy and commercial real estate. Top-performing participants are considered for paid internships and full-time associate roles. 
Banking Academy at UC Berkeley will begin on Wednesday, January 17th. Sessions will be held on Wednesdays from 10:00 a.m. to Noon and will conclude just before spring break. This program is a Hybrid learning program, and we will host several sessions at UC Berkeley! Check out our minimum requirements and apply here or on Handshake! If you have questions, don‚Äôt hesitate to email amanda.johnston@rivercitybank.com.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENT RESEARCH
The Matsui Center is now accepting applications for the Charles H. Percy Undergraduate Grant & Mike Synar Graduate Research Fellowship!
Charles H. Percy Undergraduate Grant for Public Affairs Research
The Institute of Governmental Studies will award up to four research grants in the amount of $500 each to UC Berkeley undergraduate students who are conducting research on an aspect of American politics, including public opinion, electoral behavior, civic participation, government institutions, social movements, and public policy. We encourage students from all majors to apply. More information about eligibility and requirements can be found on our website.

Application Deadline: Sunday, November 26 at 11:59pm
Program Contact: Megan Collins, Matsui Program Manager, meganjcollins@berkeley.edu
Mike Synar Graduate Research Fellowship
The Institute of Governmental Studies will award three research fellowships of $3,000 each. The Mike Synar Graduate Research Fellowship is awarded to distinguished UC Berkeley graduate students who are writing their dissertations on an aspect of American politics, including comparative research across nations with the United States as a major case. To be eligible, graduate students must have advanced to candidacy. All award recipients will be invited to the award ceremony during the spring semester.
More information: CLICK HERE

Program Contact: Megan Collins, Matsui Program Manager, meganjcollins@berkeley.edu
4. Pipeline Initiative in Political Science (PIPS)
The Political Science department has created a program, known as the Pipeline Initiative in Political Science (PIPS, for short), which is designed to help students learn about what it means to earn a PhD in political science and how to prepare for and apply to PhD programs. 
The program is open to students who are in at least their second year of college studies. The program is focused on helping students who are first-generation college students, from historically minoritized or underrepresented groups, or from low-income backgrounds. 
Students who are selected for the program will participate in a series of workshops throughout the semester - scheduled for Mondays in the afternoon from 12 to 2:00 pm and will be advised on pursuing research opportunities as an undergraduate. There may also be an opportunity to receive mentoring from graduate students and faculty. Students who pursue this may earn one credit unit for completing the program. Elective credit only.
Please apply here: https://forms.gle/ehn3S2oxCrgynAeWA
For enrollment details, including day/time: 
https://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2024-spring-polsci-192-001-sem-001
Applications will be evaluated on a rolling basis, but to have the best chance and to be considered for the second wave of admissions please submit the application by Monday, Nov 13th, 2023.
5.  Women‚Äôs Datathon
Hosted by Citadel and Citadel Securities in partnership with Correlation One, this event is open to top students across North America who identify as women. Women‚Äôs Datathon takes place this February and invited students will be flown out to Miami in an all-expense-paid trip for the two-day long event.
Our Datathons challenge students from the world's best universities to tackle real-world social challenges in topics such as urban traffic, renewable energy, and education. Women‚Äôs Datathon is a national data science competition, bigger and more exciting than our regional events! More information about our launch and the competition can be found here.

Where: Miami, FL
Who: Undergraduates, graduates, Ph.D., and post-doc researchers who identify as women
Prizes: $15,000 + Exclusive recruiting opportunities with Citadel and Citadel Securities

Considering Berkeley Master of Analytics for graduate school? Attend our information session to learn more about pursuing a Master of Analytics in the UC Berkeley Industrial Engineering & Operations Research department.
At Berkeley IEOR, we harness the transformative power of optimization, stochastics, data science, and other cutting-edge disciplines. Our world-class faculty and stellar students foster an interdisciplinary and enriching academic environment of boundless opportunity, and together, we forge solutions to complex challenges facing our rapidly evolving world.
Join us in person on Monday, November 6, from 2-3 p.m. in Etcheverry Hall Room 1174 to learn about the 11-month Master of Analytics program, the application process, and what a career in IEOR looks like. Register now to save your spot!
See the PDF below for information on this event;
Nov 6 Info Session for current UG Flier.pdf']

['Econ bears, 
Please see below for announcements from our partners. If you are part of a registered student organization on campus, you are welcome to post your announcements directly to our Ed Discussion without waiting for our weekly announcement recap. This week‚Äôs announcements include:
1. Focus Group Research from the Center for Financial Reporting and Management 
2.  Graduate Diversity Admissions Fair 
3. Japan-IMF Scholarship Program
4. Upcoming Berkeley Career Engagement
5. Undergraduate Certificate in New Media Applications Due November 1
6.  Dual Master‚Äôs Degree in Applied Economics (CUHK) and Social and Economic Policy (Northwestern)
7.  J-PAL Careers
8. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), Office of Research (OR), 2024 Summer Pathways Internship
1. Focus Group Research from the Center for Financial Reporting and Management 
The Center for Financial Reporting and Management (CFRM) at Berkeley Haas will be conducting focus groups with Haas and Econ junior students to learn about their experiences making career choices. We will be hosting several 60-minute focus groups on October 6th, 13th and 20th with five or six students in each group. We will ask you questions, listen to your feedback and take notes on your responses. No preparation is required. 

As a token of appreciation, each participant will receive a $20 gift card to Caf√© Think.

If you are interested in participating, please complete this short Google form: https://forms.gle/i1pEatXtpmEuYT1u7
If you have any questions, please contact us at cfrm@haas.berkeley.edu
2. Graduate Diversity Admissions Fair 
Are you considering applying to the Economics PhD program? Our virtual Graduate Diversity Admissions Fair October 30 - November 3 can help you learn more about Berkeley's PhD programs, the application and funding process. 
You can expect a lot to choose from. Over 50 different sessions from UC Berkeley departments and graduate programs in one hour general information sessions, discussion groups.
Register now. After registering for the fair, you can start adding individual sessions to your personal agenda. Be sure to add the Econ PhD session on November 2nd, 11am-12pm.
3. Japan-IMF Scholarship Program
Japan IMF applications are now open for qualified candidates to apply for the 2024 Japan-IMF Scholarship program. 
This opportunity is available to Japanese nationals pursuing an advanced degree in economics at a university outside of Japan. Applicants are expected to complete their degree by the age of 34 and should have an interest in working at the IMF. 
4. Upcoming Berkeley Career Engagement 
Upcoming events 
On this Google Doc, you'll find 15 events which include: 
-- Career Group Chats: Navigating Tech Internship/Job Search for Transfers
Tuesday, October 3rd from 1:00 - 2:00 pm I 2440 Bancroft, Blue Room
-- Career Connections: Non-Tech Roles in Tech 
Tuesday, October 10th from 5:00-7:00 pm I Alumni House, Toll Room
-- 4 Career Fairs: STEM (Oct 3), Master's & PhD (Oct 4), Grad & Law School (Oct 12), and Civil & Environmental Engineering (Oct 25) 
Resume
Students can submit their resume to 22 resume books to gain visibility and connect with employers who are actively hiring. Three quick steps to submit to a resume book through Tuesday, October 31 for the fall semester: 
Update your resume and review resources on our website for samples
Review the books through this link (they are managed through ‚Äòjobs‚Äô in Handshake). We are offering books covering 11 different career field interests, with one book focused on internship-seekers and one book focused on fulltime job-seekers for each career field.
"Apply" to the resume book(s) that match your career interests 
Note: Students should only submit to the book(s) that match our interest and the opportunities you qualify for (e.g. if you‚Äôre a sophomore, you shouldn‚Äôt be applying to the full-time books). 
If you'd like a Handshake courtesy account to view these events in full, click here. 
5. Undergraduate Certificate in New Media Applications Due November 1
Applications Open for the Designated Emphasis, Graduate, & Undergraduate Certificate in New Media
Applications due: November 1, 2023
The Berkeley Center for New Media is an interdisciplinary research center that studies and shapes media transition and emergence from diverse perspectives. Through critical thinking and making, we cultivate technological equity and fairness in our classrooms, in our communities, and on the internet.
Our students are eligible for a host of opportunities through the Center, including conference and summer research grants, our prestigious Lyman fellowship, research support, teaching positions, and unique experiences with the world-class speakers we bring to campus.
We are accepting applications for admission to the Designated Emphasis (DE) in New Media Ph.D. program, the Graduate Certificate in New Media program, and the Undergraduate Certificate in New Media program. All applications for Fall 2023 admittance are due November 1.
Find out more here!
6. Dual Master‚Äôs Degree in Applied Economics (CUHK) and Social and Economic Policy (Northwestern)
The Dual Master‚Äôs Degree in Applied Economics (CUHK) and Social and Economic Policy (Northwestern), is a pathbreaking program jointly developed by the Department of Economics at the Chinese University of Hong Kong and the School of Education and Social Policy at Northwestern University.
Studying on campuses in Sha Tin, Hong Kong, for 10 months and Evanston, Illinois, for 7 months, students receive rigorous training in applied economic science and develop analytical skills to evaluate and design policies and programs in diverse global contexts. Upon completion of the program, students receive two master of science degrees from two top-tier global universities!
Ready to begin your journey? Visit our website to learn more and apply today!

7. J-PAL Careers
Are you passionate about international development and poverty alleviation around the world? Do you love to learn? Are you ready to join a team of supportive, engaging, and fun colleagues?

Check out the current listing of open positions below and be sure to visit the J-PAL Careers page for the most up-to-date information and for our FAQ page. For questions, please contact jobs@povertyactionlab.org.
8. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), Office of Research (OR), 2024 Summer Pathways Internship
The Office of Research (OR) in the Research, Monitoring, and Regulations Division (RMR) is realizing the CFPB‚Äôs mission by bringing an empirical, data-driven approach to the analysis of consumer financial markets. OR provides the main analytics to understand consumer behavior and support the Bureau‚Äôs actions in policy-making, supervision, and enforcement.
 Summer Internship Program 
The Pathways Internship Program is a Summer 2024 opportunity for current (students are eligible if they are enrolled as students before, during, and after Summer 2024) undergraduate and graduate students. Applicants must be a U.S. Citizen or U.S. National to apply. Please see https://www.consumerfinance.gov/about-us/careers/students-and-graduates/pathways-internship-program/ for more information on eligibility.
 Interns work directly with a seasoned member of our team on policy and research projects and are assigned to one project which they are expected to complete during the twelve-week program. Interns will be expected to work independently but will be provided necessary on-the-job training and mentorship to support them in their work. Strong Intern candidates may be considered for possible future Research Assistant opportunities within the Office of Research.  
How to apply to the Pathways Internship:
Visit our website: https://www.consumerfinance.gov/about-us/careers/current-openings/']

1. 2023 Diversity & Entrepreneurship Fellows present: Closing the Wealth Gap: Removing Barriers Faced by Women of Color (10/6 12:00pm - 1:30pm)
This year's Diversity and Entrepreneurship Research Colloquium features a research presentation by 2023 D&E Fellows on the shared experiences of women of color small business owners, followed by responses from key stakeholders. Over the spring and summer of 2023, Fellows conducted 31 interviews with women of color entrepreneurs (based in California and other states) asking about their experiences accessing capital and growing their businesses. This research is unique and groundbreaking in that it places a particular emphasis on examining the role played by intersectionality (race and gender) and lived experience in shaping women-of-color entrepreneur‚Äôs access not only to financial capital, but the human and social capital needed to start and grow a small business. This is a Hybrid Event that will be broadcasted via Zoom.
Date and Time: Friday, October 6 ¬∑ 12 - 2:30pm PDT
Location: Institute of Governmental Studies Library
 109 Philosophy Hall #2370 Berkeley, CA 94720
Register via Eventbrite! 
2.  Pipeline Program to Increase Teachers! Alameda County Office of Education's Substitute Program
The Pipeline to Increase Community Teachers program (PICT) is designed to provide targeted communities with qualified substitutes that are familiar with the community in which they work. PICT will provide qualified community members the opportunity to support their community by playing an integral part in the safety and education of the community‚Äôs students. This program will cover the fees necessary to put qualified substitutes for employment, provide both content and pedagogical support necessary to be successful in a classroom, and connect community members through mentorships with veteran teachers. Our goal is to increase the substitute pool available to support specific sites.
Here is a link to our flyers !
3. Financial Wellness Fall workshops 
Financial Wellness Workshops are designed to provide you with skills and tools to enhance your money management skills. All workshops are organized, designed, and led by Student Financial Wellness Coaches. This semester, the Center for Financial Wellness (formerly Bears for Financial Success) will be hosting a series of six financial wellness workshops.
4. Reduced Cost LSAT and GRE Prep
There will be another set of low-cost, high quality, LSAT and GRE prep courses offered LIVE online this fall. 
You can apply for the LIVE courses (and see schedules, etc.) at campusprep.org. It takes just 45 seconds to apply. 
235‚àí285 LSAT Course 
The live online course, taught by an instructor you can interact with, preps you for the fall and winter test dates. The comprehensive, 27-hour, live course includes 3 practice exams and costs 
285(235 if you qualify for financial aid). 
Payment plans are available. 
The course is taught by a high-scoring, expert instructor. Students who complete the course often get 9-point gains on the LSAT. 
Apply ASAP for the LSAT (or GRE) course at campusprep.org, as there will likely be more applications than there are spaces available. Feel free to email or call with any questions to admin@campusprep.org or (877) 805-2521. 
5. John Gardner Fellowship
Are you interested in public service after graduation? Apply to be a Gardner Fellow! Here are the highlights:
-- Work with a senior-level mentor at the governmental agency (Federal, State or Local) or non-profit organization that best matches your interests
-- Receive a $50,000 stipend for 10 months of work. September/October 2024-June/July 2025. 
-- Eligibility: Any major. Graduating senior summer 2023, Dec. 2023, May 2024, or summer 2024
Information Session #1: Wednesday, September 13, 2023 | 4:00pm Harris Room, Institute of Governmental Studies 119 Philosophy Hall, Berkeley, CA 94720 
Information Session #2: Thursday, September 21, 2023 | 4:00pm 791 Social Sciences Building Berkeley, CA, 94720
Application Deadline: October 18, 2023
Application: https://igs.berkeley.edu/student-opportunities/fellowships/john-gardner-fellowship
Questions: Terri Bimes, bimes@berkeley.edu
6. Charles River Associates Economics Consultant 2024 Positions Are Now Live
Charles River Associates, a global economic consulting firm headquartered in Boston. Our job postings for our North American 2024 full-time and internship opportunities are now live on our Careers Website. We encourage you to apply at your earliest convenience to be considered for all interview opportunities in the coming months. 
Don‚Äôt forget about additional opportunities to connect with our consultants on our events website Careers - Meet CRA! Events include upcoming information sessions, panels and school-based recruiting events.
In the meantime, we encourage you to connect with us via LinkedIn, Facebook, Twitter, YouTube and Instagram. On these sites we will share updates about our consultants, offices, practices, recent cases and clients, and CRA initiatives. If you would like to learn more specifically about the day-to-day CRA experience, check out The Current (our blog about the CRA experience in our various offices and practices).
 To receive future insights and thought leadership produced by our global experts we encourage you to subscribe to CRA Insights.
 7. Benefits of pursuing a graduate degree 
As the fall approaches, so does the exciting opportunity to explore the world of higher education. Are you contemplating whether graduate school is the right choice for you? Our latest article dives deep into the invaluable benefits of pursuing a graduate degree, shedding light on how this journey can profoundly impact your career and personal growth. 
Follow Chris Milan, a premier tutor at Enhanced Prep, as he explores the transformative power of graduate school. Discover the skills that lead to success in graduate programs and allow for informed decision-making and a deep understanding of new topics. 
Upcoming Free Test Prep GRE¬Æ Super Review: September 24 | 4 PM PST
Register Here! 
8. CLIMB Evergreen Talk with David Blei, Fri Sept 29th at 2pm
This event is held virtually and in person
Event will be livestreamed on YouTube
Recordings of previous seminars and links to talks are available at the CLIMB YouTube channel. 
Speaker: David Blei, Professor of Statistics and Computer Science at Columbia University
Title: Hierarchical Causal Models
Abstract:   Analyzing nested data with hierarchical models is a staple of Bayesian statistics, but causal modeling remains largely focused on "flat" models. In this talk, we will explore how to think about nested data in causal models, and we will consider the advantages of nested data over aggregate data (such as data means) for causal inference. We show that disaggregating your data---replacing a flat causal model with a hierarchical causal model---can provide new opportunities for identification and estimation. As examples, we will study how to identify and estimate causal effects under unmeasured confounders, interference, and instruments.
Date and Location: Friday September 29, 2:00pm - 3:00pm PT, 310 Sutardja Dai Hall (Banatao Auditorium)
9. DON'T MISS OUT on Democracy Camp!
The Matsui Center's Democracy Camp in Berkeley program is designed for students who are interested in pursuing a career in public service at the local or state level, both in government and in non-government sectors. Over UC Berkeley's Spring Break, students participate in a series of meetings with local and state leaders and gain exposure to different facets of public service: legislative paths, local and state government, community organizations, legal fields, research, and philanthropy. Participants learn about career opportunities, network with guest speakers, participate in professional development workshops, and take a field trip to Sacramento to visit the state capital. Planned activities allow students to build a cohort that lasts beyond the four-day experience and serves as a vital form of support as they pursue careers in public service. There is no cost to students: all meals and course materials are included.

Program Dates: Monday, March 25 ‚Äì Thursday, March 28, 2024
Eligibility: Click Here
Application Deadline: Sunday, November 5 at 11:59pm
Program Contact: Megan Collins, Matsui Program Manager, meganjcollins@berkeley.edu

11. Cal in the Capital is recruiting!
Cal in the Capital (CITC) is a student-led internship program housed in the Public Service Center that helps Berkeley students secure public service internships in Washington, DC. At CITC, we strive to promote the spirit of public service among the Berkeley community and empower students to prioritize social justice. CITC interns come from all majors and have worked in a variety of positions including research, business development, data analysis, policy, and legislation. Check out the blog posts from past CITC interns to get an idea of what your summer in DC could look like!
Interested applicants can apply here. Applications are due October 8 at 11:59pm PST. 
For more information, contact calinthecapital@gmail.com or attend one of our upcoming info sessions and application workshop.
Wed, September 20, 5:30pm ‚Äì 6:30pm, Senate Chambers (5th floor of Eshleman Hall)
Tue, September 26, 5:00pm ‚Äì 6:00pm, Public Service Center / Eshleman 218
Mon, October 2, 6:00pm ‚Äì 7:00pm, Senate Chambers (5th floor of Eshleman Hall)
RSVP to let us know you‚Äôre attending!
12. Fall 2023 Demystifying Office Hours: Advise from Faculty
An opportunity for undergraduate students to hear first-hand from faculty why attending office hours is something professors look forward to and why it is beneficial to students to establish a relationship with their teachers. 
These panel/workshops run for 1.5 hrs. The first 45 minutes consist of a panel discussion with active and retired faculty followed by small group conversations led by the faculty panelists. After the event, students can request a one-time, 1:1 conversation with an emeritus/a in the student's desired academic field. 
The dates for the two panel/workshops open to all undergraduate students are: 
Thursday, 9/28/23, 12pm to 1pm, in Room 209 at the Golden Bear Center, 1995 University Ave, Berkeley (2nd floor) 
Wednesday, 11/8/23, 4pm to 5:30pm, online (Zoom-registration link: https://tinyurl.com/DemystifyFall23
More information can be found here! ']

1. Data Skills for All Fall Fellowship 2023 Program Launch (deadline: September 10th)
The DS4A Fellowship is a 100% free advancement program designed for aspiring data professionals who are looking to upstart their careers. We invite 200+ Fellows from the world‚Äôs top universities and research institutes and provide them with industry training, resources, and an influential network of industry mentors.
This program is designed for current data professionals with at least 1-3 years of professional experience. Applicants to this program should have the following minimum qualifications:
1-3 years working in a data role (data analyst, BI analyst, Data Scientist, etc.) OR working with data in their current role (Marketing Analyst, etc.)
Proficient in Python AND SQL
Legally reside and authorized to work in the United States
The FINAL application deadline is September 10, 2023. We highly recommend you apply as early as you can because our Admissions Committee works on a rolling basis.
If you have any questions regarding the program or application process, please send an email to our team at ds4a@correlation-one.com
The link to the full program is below:
Data Skills for All - Fall 2023
2. SLC Writing Program: Peer Tutoring Services Now Open!
Happy fall 2023 from the SLC Writing Program! With the fall semester underway, we are thrilled to share that our free peer tutoring services has returned starting Tuesday, September 5th. 
Each of our services provides support to Cal undergraduates in their journeys to become more persuasive and purposeful academic writers. Our services include: 
Drop-in (30 minutes) - students can cover shorter topics, like refining a thesis statement or breaking down a prompt. 
Appointment (50 minutes) - students can work on larger topics, like strengthening a paper‚Äôs structure or analysis. 
Weekly (50 minutes) - students meet weekly with the same tutor to master academic writing conventions and enhance their own writing process. The start of the semester is a great time to sign up!
If you have any questions, or are interested in learning more, we invite you to connect with us. Additionally, we would love to stop by any classes or workshops you might have, to share briefly about our program and services. To schedule a visit, please complete our request form and we will follow up. 
3. UC Center Sacramento -- Internship Semester Infosession
The UC Center Sacramento (UCCS) program is open to UC degree-seeking undergraduate students and runs every semester. Gain hands-on experience, earn transferable units, and create networks that can help launch your career. Come learn about public policy research, undergraduate courses, internship and professional development opportunities.
To learn more, attend the Infosession on Thursday, September 14th, from 5-6pm. You can register for this event on Handshake by searching "UC Center Sacramento" on the events page.
Location: UC Berkeley
Dwinelle Hall 44B (Level C)
4. Discovery Hub Lunchtime Series start 9/12
The Discovery Hub is the campus hub for information and guidance on pursuing experiential learning opportunities.
Discovery Hub Lunchtime Series starts Sept 12th
Want support discovering your path at Cal? The Discovery Hub Workshop Series assists students with every step of their undergraduate journey from navigating campus opportunities to developing your passions to showcasing accomplishments. Open to all UC Berkeley undergraduate students. Lunch provided. Register via this Google form to claim your spot.
5. Research Assistant opportunity at the Brookings Institution (deadline: October 15th)
The Economic Studies Program at the Brookings Institution is conducting our fall Research Assistant recruitment, for positions starting in summer 2024. Each year we employ approximately fifteen research assistants for two year appointments, preferably beginning between June 1 and August 1, 2024. This cycle, we are seeking to hire approximately eight new assistants. This is an excellent opportunity for recent graduates!
Read more here: https://www.brookings.edu/join-the-top-ranked-think-tank-for-domestic-economic-policy/
Apply here: https://careers-brookings.icims.com/jobs/3286/research-assistant-%28job-id%3a-2023-3286%29/job
Applicants should have a Bachelor‚Äôs degree by summer 2024 in Economics, Mathematics/Statistics, Public Policy, or other Social Sciences with a minor in Economics and will need to submit a cover letter, resume, two letters of recommendation, and a transcript. The application deadline is October 15, 2023.
 6. APAPA Virtual Fall Internship (deadline: September 24th)
The APAPA Virtual Internship Program is focused on leadership and professional development, designed for students interested in skills and experiences (such as project management) to help advance their leadership skills in government, industry and community affairs. This nine-week program, taking place during the Fall, is unique because it provides interns opportunities to put into practice skills that are valuable and transferable in multiple industry sectors. 
We're currently recruiting UC Berkeley undergraduates interested in leadership development, civic engagement, and public relations. We are excited to announce that this will be a completely virtual internship program taking place during Fall 2023.  
We are hoping you could forward this opportunity to your students. The application deadline is September 24th @ 11:59pm. With that, early applications will receive an earlier interview and preferred admittance. For any further questions, please contact me at (707) 591-4102 or by email at pcurzon@apapa.org
7. Jacobs Makerspace Campus Makerspace Crawl
If you are interested in joining the vibrant community of makers, designers, and tinkerers at UC Berkeley, then join us on the campus makers‚Äô crawl! We will start at the Jacobs Hall Makerspace and continue to other campus spaces. See the unique resources offered at each location and learn how you can join the campus‚Äôs rich ecosystem of hands-on creativity. Bring your curiosity and comfortable walking shoes.
We will visit the following sites, in this order:
Jacobs Makerspace (Jacobs Hall)
Mechanical Engineering Student Machine Shop
Cory Student Workshop and Supernode (Cory Hall)
UC Berkeley Library Makerspace (Doe Library)
Berkeley Art Studio & Creative Lab (MLK Jr Building, ASUC Student Union)
College of Environmental Design Fabrication Lab (Bauer Wurster Hall)

This event will take place  on Thursday, 9/14/23 from 2PM‚Äì4PM, and will begin at the west lobby entrance of Jacobs Hall: RSVP HERE.
8. Call for Applicants - Student Advisory Council on Financial Aid & Education (deadline: September 17)
The Financial Aid and Scholarships Office is recruiting new members for the Associate Vice Chancellor‚Äôs Student Advisory Council on Financial Aid & Education (SACFAE). Council members help influence decisions that directly impact access and affordability at Cal. 
Eligible students may apply by submitting this application form. For more information on the council, student qualifications, and how to apply, please see call for applicants. The deadline for submission is Sunday, September 17, 2023 @11:59pm
 9. Research Talk: Maya Rossin-Slater on Maternal and Infant Health Inequality
Professor Rossin-Slater will discuss her latest research using linked administrative data that combines the universe of California birth records, hospitalizations, and death records with parental income from Internal Revenue Service tax records to provide novel evidence on economic inequality in infant and maternal health.
Maya Rossin-Slater is an Associate Professor of Health Policy at Stanford University School of Medicine. She is also a Senior Fellow at the Stanford Institute for Economic and Policy Research (SIEPR), a Research Associate at the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER) and a Research Affiliate at the Institute of Labor Economics (IZA). 
September 21 | 4 pm | IRLE Director's Room, 2521 Channing Way
Light refreshments and a reception to follow.

Walmart Economics applies data science, behavioral economics, and experimentation to problems across the company ‚Äì leveraging Walmart‚Äôs vast data to understand causal impacts and influence business strategy. For more information, please see the job posting on Handshake.

1. Volunteering opportunities at Mount Tamalpais College:
Mount Tamalpais College is an independent liberal arts institution dedicated to serving incarcerated students at San Quentin State Prison. 
As we continue our efforts to expand the network of educators who might be interested in learning about, volunteering with, or spreading the word about MTC, I wanted to reach out and let you know that we have just launched our application for Spring and Summer 2024. MTC offers volunteer educators opportunities to teach in our Writing, Science, Math, Humanities & Social Sciences courses; we also also have roles in Student Development, Remote Research, and in our Computer Lab.
1. Apply here! In addition to applying yourself, please feel free to forward this invitation to your networks. 
2. Attend an upcoming virtual info session to learn more about MTC! 
2. Call for Submissions - Penn Undergraduate Law Journal
The Penn Undergraduate Law Journal (PULJ) is soliciting submissions for its twenty-first issue. Please see below for details. 

QUALIFICATIONS FOR SUBMISSION
SUBMISSION DEADLINE: September 3rd, 2023 at 11:59pm EST
PULJ is seeking articles ranging from 20 to 100+ double-spaced pages in length. Our journal is especially receptive to research articles, senior theses, independent studies, and final essays written for courses. Articles need not be written on United States law‚Äîthey can be written on the laws or legal system of any nation. We consider submissions on a rolling basis, so if your piece is not finished by the noted deadline, please still submit it for consideration in our subsequent issue.

Students in any field of study are encouraged to submit their work, so long as their pieces relate to law or legal systems. Possible disciplinary perspectives include, but are not limited to, history, criminology, economics, sociology, anthropology, English, biology, neuroscience, philosophy, linguistics, psychology, and political science.

Please submit your work here: http://www.pulj.org/submissions.html

Selected pieces will be published in our twenty-first issue of the Penn Undergraduate Law Journal. If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to notify us of them through the contact page of our website, which can be accessed here: http://www.pulj.org/contact.html
3. Fashion Case Study Scholarship
The 2024 Case Study Scholarship competition deadline is October 16, 2023.  You may find the FSF Scholarship competition materials here in the FSF Dropbox. The materials include the four case study briefs, the Wizehive submission link, the digital scholarship competition poster, winning 2023 FSF case studies that you may share with your students, and the recordings from the FSF Summer Scholar Series. If you have not already, please disseminate the competition materials to your students, so that eligible students may complete their case studies within the next eight weeks. Occasionally, please check the Named Scholarships and Funds page here on the FSF website for additional scholarship opportunities for applicants. 
4. Berkeley Career Engagement
Upcoming events 
On this Google Doc, you'll find 15+ events in the next two weeks which include:
5 Career Fairs including: Consulting Forum, Biotech & Life Sciences Career & Internship Fair and Business & Public Service Career & Internship Fair
Prepare for Health Professions as a Transfer Student  (Thu, Aug 31 from 12-1pm, Virtual): Understand how to maximize your time as a transfer student as best as possible to prepare to successfully apply to grad programs such as medical school. 
Employer Challenge with the National Counterterrorism Center (Mon, Sept 11 from 12-1:30pm, 2440 Bancroft): A great resume building activity that offers a glimpse into the work of intelligence agencies. 
If you'd like a Handshake courtesy account to view these events in full, click here. 
Resources
How to Prepare for Career Fairs (1 minute video)
Berkeley Career Engagement Overview (flyer)
Navigating Handshake (flyer) 
5. Alternative Breaks Economic Justice Leadership Team
Join the Alternative Breaks leadership team for the 2023-2024 school year! 
Lead our Economic Justice in San Francisco trip and Decal! Apply here!
What is Alternative Breaks? 
Since 2001, Alternative Breaks offers UC Berkeley undergraduates an immersive experiential learning opportunity during academic breaks. Students take a semester-long DeCal to explore social justice issues. During the break, they go on-site and learn from community partners.

As a Break Leader, you'll share your passion and facilitate a 2-unit DeCal course on your trip's social justice issue. You'll also plan and coordinate a spring break service-learning trip in collaboration with community partners. 
S
Scholarshipavailable!
 Apply here!
Who do we serve?
We are honored to serve and learn with community partner Faithful Fools in San Francisco. Faithful Fools' mission: As a non-profit corporation, we intend to foster awareness and analysis of deteriorating social conditions in the United States and the world at large, seen from the level of the streets, and to facilitate individual and collective responses thereto.
Note: No prior Alternative Breaks experience is necessary for these positions. Students should demonstrate curiosity to learn and collaborate with community partners, passion for the particular social issue, and commitment to program requirements.  
 
Questions? Please contact Rosa Enriquez, Interim Program Manager (RosaLeeEnriquez@berkeley.edu)
6. Japan-IMF Scholarship Program for Advanced Studies 
We are happy to announce that applications are now open for qualified candidates to apply for the 2024 Japan-IMF Scholarship program: https://apply.iie.org/apply/?sr=691d0dbb-dee9-47bd-b4ef-a03333d41b4d 

This opportunity is available to Japanese nationals pursuing an advanced degree in economics at a university outside of Japan. Applicants are expected to complete their degree by the age of 34 and should have an interest in working at the IMF.
Please note that applicants have until November 30, 2023 to complete all materials and submit their applications. 

Please share the following details with any possible candidates or suggest that they contact us directly at japanimfscholarship@iie.org for more information.
7. Delta Phi Epsilon
Delta Phi Epsilon (DPhiE) is a co-ed, pre-professional international relations and foreign service fraternity at Cal that focuses on professional development, social bonding, and more! our fraternity comprises of individuals with a wide range of personal backgrounds, academic interests, and career trajectories. We are united by our passion in international affairs, shared commitment in serving the international community, and plans to pursue international careers! We'll help you professionally through our professional development program and give you an opportunity to meet other people in the Cal community you are interested in IR through socials, club-wide debates, active presentations, and more! Be sure to check out our website at https://dpe.berkeley.edu/ for more information on our rush events and application timeline, as well as follow us on instagram @caldphie for the latest updates.
8. Application Open: Matsui Center's 2024 Democracy Camp
The Matsui Center's Democracy Camp in Berkeley program is designed for students who are interested in pursuing a career in public service at the local or state level, both in government and in non-government sectors. Over UC Berkeley's Spring Break, students participate in a series of meetings with local and state leaders and gain exposure to different facets of public service: legislative paths, local and state government, community organizations, legal fields, research, and philanthropy. Participants learn about career opportunities, network with guest speakers, participate in professional development workshops, and take a field trip to Sacramento to visit the state capital. Planned activities allow students to build a cohort that lasts beyond the four-day experience and serves as a vital form of support as they pursue careers in public service. There is no cost to students: all meals and course materials are included.

Program Dates: Monday, March 25 ‚Äì Thursday, March 28, 2024
Eligibility: Click Here
Application Deadline: Sunday, November 5 at 11:59pm
Program Contact: Megan Collins, Matsui Program Manager, meganjcollins@berkeley.edu
Apply Here: https://igs.berkeley.edu/matsui-center/programs-fellowships/democracy-camp/how-apply-democracy-camp?mc_cid=b949dee27e&mc_eid=cab9f6f0d6 
9. Deloitte‚Äôs Transfer Pricing practice recruiting interns and consultants for summer 2024
What is Transfer Pricing?
Transfer Pricing (TP) is the analysis of cross-border transactions between related parties inside a multinational group. We assist our clients in structuring their operations to be tax-efficient and legally compliant. We employ a variety of methods, including benchmarking analyses and valuation estimates, in order to estimate market prices for transactions not typically observed in competitive markets. Our work is challenging and multidisciplinary, and has also served as a strong foundation for careers in finance, law, and academia.
Who should apply?
Students with backgrounds in economics, finance, math/statistics, and business tend to fit well in our team. We seek well-rounded candidates with strong leadership abilities and quantitative/technical skills. 
To apply, follow this link ( Intern | Consultant ), specifying McLean, VA as your preferred location. We will review candidates on a rolling basis, with a final deadline of Sunday, September 17, 23:59 EST.
10. Panel: Advancing Multiracial Democracy in CA
New polling conducted by the Institute of Governmental Studies at UC Berkeley on voter satisfaction, voting rights, misinformation, and election reforms highlights the challenges that persist in achieving an inclusive, multiracial democracy. This panel will examine Californians perceptions of the status quo, support for reforms, and discuss strategies to help California become a national model for inclusive democracy.
J oin us at the Institute of Governmental Studies Library on Thursday, September 21st at 4:00pm for a presentation on the latest round of Berkeley IGS Poll data, conducted in partnership with the Evelyn and Walter Haas Jr. Fund, followed by a moderated discussion on the results and the various conditions that may influence key races, ballot measures, and more with our panel of experts.
Panelists: 
M ark DiCamillo, Director, Berkeley IGS Poll
Gail Pellerin, California State Assembly member, 28th District
Veronica Carrizales, Vice President of Policy & External Affairs, California Calls
M arc Philpart, Executive Director of California Black Freedom Fund
Moderator:
G. C ristina Mora, Associate Professor of Sociology & Institute of Governmental Studies Co-Director
Register here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/advancing-multiracial-democracy-in-california-pathways-to-the-2024-election-tickets-706617912197?aff=oddtdtcreator&mc_cid=0e5fbea95c&mc_eid=edcb97ff27 "]
column11: Institute of Governmental Studies Library, Berkeley, CA

column5:

Open Innovation Squad
My name is Almog, I lead the Open Innovation Squad from the Garwood Center with Professor Henry Chesbrough and Professor Solomon Darwin. The Squad is a cross-functional team of entrepreneurial students dedicated to driving innovation and solving complex business challenges by collaborating with executives of elite global brands from the Berkeley Innovation Forum. Our students gain 100% practical experience in Open Innovation, Product Management, Business Models, and Ecosystems to significantly increase their chances of learning about and finding the full-time job they want. We're eager to continue providing practical experience to both undergrads and grads all over the university and foster collaboration between the schools on campus. Would you be interested in sharing this with your students? They can reach out to me at almogos@berkeley.edu if they have any questions!

ASUC Student Advocate's Office
My name is Antonio Caceres <saochief@asuc.org> and I am the External Chief-of-Staff for the ASUC Student Advocate's Office (SAO). ‚ÄúThe Student Advocate‚Äôs Office (SAO) is a free and confidential resource students can reach out to when experiencing issues with the university. We support students navigating academic, grievance, conduct, and financial aid issues. If you are passionate about advocacy and want to make a tangible impact on students here at Cal, please consider joining our office! Eligible caseworkers may receive funding from our Holistic Caseworker Grant which is meant to provide financial support to students who would otherwise be able to join our office. If you are interested in applying, please go to advocate.berkeley.edu/apply. If you have any questions about our recruitment process, please contact us at recruit@berkeleysao.org and check out our social media accounts for more information (IG @berkeleysao ; FB @ASUC Student Advocate‚Äôs Office). The deadline to apply is Friday, September 1st at 11:59 PM! To stay up to date with our recruitment process, fill out https://forms.gle/mPr7SHREQJjnnq448
And if you, or anyone you know, ever has any issues regarding the University, or wants help being connected to the right campus resources, please don't hesitate to contact us at help@berkeleysao.org or explore our website.‚Äù 

Cornerstone Research, an Economic and Financial Consulting Firm
My name is Angela Li, and I graduated from UC Berkeley in 2022. I currently work as an Analyst at Cornerstone Research, an economic and financial consulting firm that provides expert testimony in high-profile litigation. My experience at Cornerstone has been rewarding in many aspects, as I‚Äôve had the opportunity to work on collaborative teams with leading academic experts while developing relevant quantitative and qualitative skills. 
Cornerstone will be hosting an Information Session and Case Workshop on Tuesday, September 12 from 5:30 ‚Äì 7:00 pm in the Stephens Lounge at MLK Student Union. Students must register beforehand via Handshake here. Additionally, we‚Äôll be attending the Consulting Forum on Wednesday, August 30 from 12:00 ‚Äì 4:00 pm in West Pauley Ballroom at MLK Student Union, as well as the Business and Public Service Career Fair on Thursday, September 14 from 12:00 ‚Äì 4:00 pm at the Recreational Sports Facility. You can find more information about these events on Handshake or by getting in touch with the UC Berkeley Career Center.
Additionally, please be aware of the application deadlines below and click the links for descriptions of the Analyst and Summer Analyst roles.
Analyst: Sunday, September 17 at 11:59 pm
Summer Analyst: Sunday, October 8 at 11:59 pm
Reminder: You must apply directly on our website in order to be considered. If you have any additional questions, please feel free to contact me at angela.li@cornerstone.com.
Economics Pre-Doc Pipeline Workshop -- Friday September 15
From: Puller, Steven L <spuller@tamu.edu>
What: One-day virtual conference with speakers from many of the premier universities and institutions who hire pre-docs. The day concludes with a virtual career fair with representatives from more than a dozen institutions.
Why: To connect promising undergraduate students from around the country with prominent pre-doc hiring institutions
When: Friday September 15, 2023
Where: Virtual on Gather
Who should attend: Students with a strong interest in pre-doctoral jobs and PhD programs in Economics
Cost: Free
How to apply: Send application materials as described in the attached flyer by Tuesday September 5 (flyer is attached below)
p.s. if your institution hires pre-docs and you are not yet a participant, please reach out to me Puller, Steven L <spuller@tamu.edu>
This conference is sponsored by the Texas A&M Department of Economics.

The program consists of the following integrated components‚Äì a Fall semester-long 1-unit professional development course (L&S 198), Spring semester activities to provide sustained support to students preparing to apply for their internships, and a paid, summer-long internship.

column2: ['EXCITING ANNOUNCEMENT: APPLY NOW for Berkeley Accelerator & Startup Incubator in Cognitive Science for 2024-2025 year!!! #798']
column5:
['BASICS (Berkeley Accelerator & Startup Incubator in Cognitive Science) is a hands-on practicum course that fuses cognitive science with entrepreneurship. It offers a unique exploration of artificial intelligence, human cognition, and startup development. This course (formerly called "Startup Battle School") provides a stimulating platform for strategic thinking and the application of cognitive science principles to create AI-powered startups. In teams, you'll embark on the journey of conceiving, refining, and pitching your ventures, guided by AI copilots, human mentors, and your peers.
Cognitive Science majors are encouraged to apply for CogSci 198: BASICS by filling out this form by Monday August 19th, 2024. The course will meet Fridays 12-2 in Wheeler 106. Admitted students will be notified via email by Monday August 26th, 2024. 
This course will be led by Michael Jacobs, CEO of Workflows AI and KDS. Michael's mission is to transform industries with simple and elegant solutions that improve efficiency, profitability, and customer satisfaction. He draws inspiration from his family's legacy of culinary innovation (they invented the bagel) and applies his skills in new business development to create and lead impactful ventures. 
He holds a master's degree in sociology from the University of Arizona, a bachelor's degree in sociology from the University of California, Berkeley, and a certificate in intelligence analysis from the FBI Academy. Michael has over 15 years of entrepreneurial experience creating, running, and selling software companies, including two innovative startups that leverage generative AI to level the playing field for small and medium businesses. 
The teaching team also includes UCB CogSci instructor Uri Korisky and a host of visiting instructors/mentors who are all innovative leaders in industry and academia.  
Details: 
CogSci 198: BASICS. Enrollment details will be provided to students once they are accepted. 
Meetings: Friday 12-2 EVERY Friday of Fall 24 in Wheeler 106
3 Unit Class
Application Due Monday August 19th
Expect a response via email by Monday August 26th 
Questions: reach out to MacKenzie at mackenziemoore@berkeley.edu ']

['Looking to support your fellow Cogsci Golden Bears? Join our Peer Advising Team for the 2024-2025 Academic Year! Our Cognitive Science Peer Advising application is now open to apply. Click HERE to access the Peer Advising Application!
Peer advisors assist the Cognitive Science advising team by providing students with information about the major, major requirements, academic planning (e.g., helping students choose classes, create 4- or 2-year plans, etc.), how to get involved with clubs and research opportunities, and much, much more! 
Currently, our peer advising team offers drop-in services via Zoom. They also answer questions that appear on the CogSci EdStem page and will occasionally take over the CogSci Instagram page. Our peer advising services are held entirely remotely.
In addition to offering drop-in advising and answering questions on our EdStem page, peers also create new materials and resources for their fellow peers. 
A good peer advisor is a student who enjoys helping and has a particular interest in helping fellow students identify their academic interests. In general, peer advisors are friendly, empathic, and eager to support their fellow CogSci Golden Bears. This position is especially great for those who wish to gain experience with advising and/or academic counseling
Advisor Requirements:
Must be a declared Cogsci student
Must have a minimum 3.0 GPA in the major
Must have completed 3+ upper division distributions
Must be available to work 6 hours/week & August Training 
Compensation 2 units of credit available OR $18/hr
The deadline to apply is Friday, April 12th, 2024 @ 11:59 PM PST.
If you have any questions regarding the Peer Advising Program, feel free to email Meagan (meaganmason@berkeley.edu)']

Inspired by "Ender's Game," this course provides a stimulating platform for strategic thinking and the application of cognitive science principles to create AI-powered startups. In teams, you'll embark on the journey of conceiving, refining, and pitching your ventures, guided by AI copilots, human mentors, and your peers.
Cognitive Science majors are encouraged to apply for CogSci 198: Startup Battle School by filling out this form by Monday January 8th 2024. The course will meet Mondays 11-2 in Spring 2024. Admitted students will be notified via email by Friday January 12th 2024. 
This course will be led by Michael Jacobs, CEO of Workflows AI and KDS. Michael's mission is to transform industries with simple and elegant solutions that improve efficiency, profitability, and customer satisfaction. He draws inspiration from his family's legacy of culinary innovation (they invented the bagel) and applies his skills in new business development to create and lead impactful ventures.

column2: ['Message from Dean Raka Ray of the Social Sciences Division #848']
column5:
['Dear Social Sciences Community,

I hope you have had a wonderful and restful summer. I am delighted to welcome you back to UC Berkeley and to our Division of Social Sciences!

To our new first-year students and transfer students, you are now part of a diverse and dynamic academic community that values learning, research, service, collaboration, curiosity and inclusiveness. As you embark on your academic journey in the Social Sciences, I hope you will bring your whole selves to this collective quest. 

To our returning students, faculty and staff ‚Äî welcome back! I hope you will take full advantage of the opportunities Berkeley offers to engage in exciting and, yes, challenging, intellectual discourse; take advantage of research, learning and extra-curricular opportunities; and make new friends as you pursue knowledge and discovery. This is a special year that marks the 60th anniversary of Berkeley‚Äôs Free Speech Movement!

Finally, I want to share with you some exciting developments in our Division this Fall. Our first cohort of the Masters in Computational Social Sciences (MaCSS) program is beginning, and we have launched our Social Sciences Career Readiness Internship Program (SSCRIP). We will soon launch our Global Democracy Commons program, which aims to deepen experiments in democracy. Look out for our analysis of the races and issues during Election 2024 ‚Äî and as always, be on the lookout for our Fall newsletter and a pizza lunch with me (for students) on Oct. 3. 

Welcome back!

Warm regards,

Raka Ray 
Dean | Berkeley Social Sciences


(Follow me on LinkedIn, X and Instagram to get the latest news from Berkeley Social Sciences.)
Support Berkeley Social Sciences']

column2: ['Apply to be a mentor for Computer Science Mentors (CSM) for Fall 2024! #845']
column5:
['Hi! Are you interested in joining the teaching community at Berkeley? Do you want to help support students looking for support in a small group setting, and also find friends and community?
Computer Science Mentors (CSM) is a student-run organization that provides guidance and resources in a smaller classroom environment through group tutoring sessions for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 70, CS 88, EECS 16A, and EECS 16B. Each section has 4-7 students and meets once or twice a week for 1 or 1.5 hours. The goal of CSM is to build a personal learning community and social network so that both students and mentors can comfortably seek and receive support.
For Fall 2024, we‚Äôre recruiting for the following roles:
Junior Mentors (JMs) for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 70, CS 88, EECS 16A, EECS 16B 
Associate Mentors (AMs) for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 88, EECS 16B
Content Mentors (CMs) for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, EECS 16A
This application is available at https://tinyurl.com/fa24-csm-app. Submissions are due Wednesday, August 28 at 11:59pm PT. No late applications will be accepted!
In CSM, we are committed to diversity and inclusion and value applicants of all backgrounds. We consider applications holistically and value passion for mentoring and willingness to learn over your grades and struggles during your time as a student - we do not consider grades in our application process. Overall, we encourage all who are interested to apply and to give the application your best effort!
Want to hear from real mentors what CSM is like? See our info session recording and slides from last semester. 
Visit https://csmentors.studentorg.berkeley.edu/ for more information or reach out to us at mentors@berkeley.edu!']

column2: ['Class Offerings: Psych 115 and Psych 192 Seminar Application Due 8/2! #817']
column5:
['The Psychology Department is offering two seminar courses, and enrollment is by application only. The deadline for submitting the seminar application is this Friday, August 2nd!
Psych 115: Introduction to Brain Imaging Analysis Methods
Instructor: Prof. Kevin Weiner
MW: 5-6:30 in Etcheverry 3109
Apply here: https://forms.gle/iksf8GjRC5LuujTdA
An introduction to brain imaging analysis methods with emphasis on functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) of the human brain. Topics include: Basic MR physics of fMRI signals; linearity of the fMRI signal; time versus space resolution trade offs; noise in neuroimaging; correlation analysis; visualization methods; cortical reconstruction, inflation, and flattening; reverse engineering; relationship between brain activation and cognitive state; multi-voxel pattern analyses; fMRI-adaptation.
Psych 192: Special Topics in Psychology
Course Title: Transdiagnostic Evidence-Based Psychological Treatments
Instructor: Prof. Allison Harvey
M: 2-5pm in Dwinelle 246
Apply here: https://forms.gle/NEeF2QzSf7UfmVX87
In this seminar‚Äîthrough group work, individual written work, lectures and oral presentations‚Äîstudents will gain a comprehensive overview of a range of transdiagnostic evidence-based psychological treatments (EBPTs). We will examine the theory underpinning each EBPT, we will examine the evidence-base, and we will examine whether and how these EBPTs are being implemented. The treatments to be covered include cognitive behavior therapy, dialectical behavior therapy among others. This course will give you training in reading primary research articles and review papers. Primary research articles and review papers are a very different reading experience, relative to reading textbooks, so be prepared to stretch and grow! You will also learn how to review the literature and find relevant peer-reviewed papers. The big picture goal of the course is to impart a sense of urgency in finding new ways to enable access to EBPTs to make a measurable and sizable dint in the current mental health crisis.']
column11: Etcheverry 3109 for Psych 115; Dwinelle 246 for Psych 192

column2: ['Summer 2024 Class Offering: History 100S The History of Silicon Valley #780']
column5:
["Professor Valerie Black is offering History 100S: The History of Silicon Valley, a 4-unit course that fulfills both HS and SBS requirements. There are still plenty of spots available, so this is a great chance to enroll in a fascinating class. Check out the details below and consider signing up!
History 100S The History of Silicon Valley
Valerie Black, 4 units, Session D, Tu, W, Th 2-4:30pm, fulfills HS and SBS breadths
We‚Äôll kick off our exploration of Silicon Valley's history by being ‚Äúdisruptive‚Äù: we‚Äôll start by thinking about its uncertain future. Is it heading towards a decline, as physicist-futurologist Michio Kaku warns, likening it to a ‚Äúrustbelt‚Äù? Or is Silicon Valley already leading the way to the end of capitalism itself, as economist Yanis Varoufakis proposes with his concept of techno-feudalism? We‚Äôll use our thoughts on these questions to guide our examination of Silicon Valley‚Äôs history‚Äîand all that is at stake in it.

Importantly, we‚Äôll examine the stories we've been told about Silicon Valley‚Äôs origins, and explore who and what have been left out of these narratives. By challenging these omissions, we‚Äôll gain a deeper, more powerful understanding of all that Silicon Valley signifies. This will include delving into what has made it simultaneously both a place and a metonym (a shorthand for the technology sector itself)‚Äîand how these aspects interact and sometimes conflict with each other.

Through curated readings and documentaries, we‚Äôll explore the fascinating, contradictory themes that define Silicon Valley: its roots in counterculture and its ties to the military; the principle of technological determinism vs the powerful sphere of venture capital; the tension between precarious labor and the pursuit of endless growth; and the clash between meritocracy and elitism. Join us as we unravel the complex history of this iconic hub of power, innovation, and iconoclasm.

Instructor bio:
Valerie Black is a Lecturer in the Department of History and the School of Public Health at the University of California, Berkeley. She is an anthropologist of human-AI relationships and ethnographer of Silicon Valley (PhD UC Berkeley) who examines technology through the intersection of critical race theory, gender & queer studies, and disability justice."]

Commencement Tickets: Guest tickets can be purchased from the Cal Performances Ticket Office for $10 each (free for children under 2 years) beginning Monday, April 22, 2024. There is no limit on the number of tickets that may be purchased, however, if you want to purchase more than 6 tickets, you will have to do separate transactions.

Online via Cognitive Science Commencement | Ticket Office @ Zellerbach Hall(link is external)
Over the phone at 510-642-9988

At the Greek Theatre on April 22 from 8:00 a.m.-10:00 a.m.
NOTE: Any tickets purchased online, by phone or in person at Zellerbach in advance of the ceremony will be delivered by email only. Tickets will not be available for pickup at the Zellerbach Ticket Office.
Tickets are REQUIRED for guests and no guest will be allowed to enter Zellerbach Hall without a ticket. Children under 2 years of age are also required to have a ticket, which will be free of charge.
