column2: ['UGBA Course offering - NOTE: Does NOT satisfy a cogsci requirement #474']
column5:
['POSTER_UGBA127-MBA296_Financial Literacy for Real Life Success_10.03.2023.pdf
Dear Financial Experts-to-Be,

This message revolves around an extremely worthwhile course that begins instruction for any and all interested University of California, Berkeley students in a few months. It is the combined session of UGBA127 and MBA296: Financial Reporting and Decision Making for Real Life Success. Anyone who takes classes at UC Berkeley can enroll. It doesn't matter if you are a Haas major, a non-Haas major, an undergraduate student, or a graduate student. We are eager to have thoughtful students from a wide variety of backgrounds.

I am Kousha Modanlou, an August 2020 graduate of UC Berkeley and a licensed Certified Public Accountant (CPA) in the state of California as of July 2022. I have been helping teach classes at UC Berkeley's Haas School of Business since January 2020, when I was just a senior undergraduate.

For the following four subjects at Berkeley Haas, I have previously served as either the undergraduate student instructor or the assistant instructor:
Financial Reporting and Decision Making (Springs of 2020-2023)
Federal Income Tax Accounting (Summers of 2021-2023 and Spring of 2023)
Auditing (Summers of 2020-2023)
Intermediate Financial Accounting I (Summers 2022 and 2023).
This upcoming Spring 2024, I will once again be returning as the assistant instructor for "Financial Reporting and Decision Making for Real Life Success" offered through the Haas School of Business.

This course is being taught for only the 5th time in all of UC Berkeley‚Äôs history and you cannot afford to miss it. Taught by an internationally distinguished, award-winning full-time professor, Yaniv Konchitchki, this class provides all the necessary tools, takeaways, and thinking to develop a fully-fledged foundation in financial literacy.

This enrichment will enhance your ability to pursue countless endeavors in the world of business, whether that be public relations, investment banking, consulting, accounting, finance, entrepreneurship, marketing, human resources, real estate, and beyond. Wherever your aspirations may draw you, we shall help take you.

In this day and age of enormous uncertainty, it is imperative to find clarity on the road to economic prosperity. To do so involves a robust grasp of the macroeconomy and capital markets, which in many ways begins from understanding how to read, analyze, and make decisions based on corporate financial statements.

We shall delve into the inner workings of the enterprise and diligently build a fluency that will bolster your confidence when it comes to making investment choices that will ultimately shape your lifestyle, career, retirement, and worldly ambitions.

Over 440 students have resoundingly benefited and passionately attested to the value added to their professional and personal lives after immersing themselves in this offering in the past three spring semesters. Please join us in this journey to fortify and vitalize hundreds more.

Sincerely,
Kousha Modanlou (and Prof. Yaniv Konchitchki)
--
Kousha Modanlou, CPA
-CEO of A1 Deck & Coating LLC
-Assistant Instructor and Reader at UC Berkeley's Haas School of Business
-Courses Taught: Financial Reporting and Decision Making for Real Life Success, Federal Income Tax Accounting, Intermediate Financial Accounting I, Auditing, and Leading People (Reader for this course; Assistant Instructor for all others)']
column11: UC Berkeley, Haas School of Business

column2: ["Please Fill Out the EVCP's 5th Year Review of Dean Raka Ray #416"]
column5:
['Please review this message from the Office of the Executive Vice Chancellor & Provost:
Dear Members of the Division of Social Sciences,
University policy calls for the review of deans who have served for five or more years (APM 240-80). In accordance with this policy, UC Berkeley is undertaking a review for Dean Raka Ray, who has expressed interest in continuing as the Dean of the Division of Social Sciences for a second five-year term. 
Dean Ray has prepared a statement about her service as dean and her plans for the division‚Äôs continued development. Her statement is available to you at this link:
Dean Raka Ray ‚Äî Fifth Year Review Statement  (please note that you will need to be logged into Calnet to view this document)
The views of the community served by a dean are an important component of this process. I invite you, as members of the Division of Social Sciences, to provide your input on Dean Ray‚Äôs accomplishments and her performance as a leader and as a member of the academic community. 
I encourage you to share your thoughts in one or both of the following ways:
Complete the survey (by Monday, October 16). The data collected from this survey are anonymous. Dean Ray will receive summarized results and will be able to see the anonymized comments. Please note that you will need to log into Calnet to access the survey, but your name or Calnet ID will not be recorded in any way. Calnet authentication is done only to ensure that responses are coming from within the Berkeley community and that we receive only one response per person. 
Survey Link: Division of Social Sciences Dean Review - Community Feedback Survey (please log in to CalNet to view the survey)
Submit comments (by Monday, October 16). Please send your comments to Dana Jantz at jantz@berkeley.edu or by mail (200 California Hall, Mailcode 1500). This input will be held in strict confidence; Dean Ray will not receive a summary of any emailed or mailed comments. You may write as briefly or extensively as you wish. In your comments, it would be most helpful if you could address the following:
1.  What strengths have you observed in Dean Ray‚Äôs performance over the course of her term as dean? Are there specific ways that the Division has benefited from these strengths? What recommendations would you give her for leveraging these strengths going forward?
2. What areas for growth have you observed in Dean Ray‚Äôs performance? What specific suggestions do you have for improvement? 
3. What recommendations would you give for addressing the challenges facing the Division of Social Sciences?
4. What are your views on the directions the Division should take in the next five years? How do you think the dean might most effectively lead the Division in these directions?

Your candid feedback is critical to the dean review process. Please note, however, that we do have an obligation to report certain allegations of behavior if we receive them. 
Thank you in advance for your participation, and if you have any questions or concerns about this process, please contact Dana Jantz at jantz@berkeley.edu or (510) 642-1963. 
I look forward to hearing from you.
Sincerely,
Benjamin E. Hermalin
Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost ']

column2: ['Cognitive Science Students Association (CSSA) has our first meeting and info session #390']
column5:
["Are you looking for a strong academic community excited about all things brain-related? Are you interested in participating in fun events to learn more about cognitive science and related disciplines? The Cognitive Science Students Association (CSSA) would love to welcome you to join our vibrant community of passionate minds dedicated to unraveling the mysteries of cognition! 
This semester, CSSA is recruiting both general and internal members. General members are welcome to attend all of CSSA's open events, including general meetings, socials, and workshops. 
As an internal member, you're not just a participant but a contributor! CSSA internal members play an integral role in organizing and hosting our annual CogSci Conference, which provides attendees with a glimpse into the latest research in all Cognitive Science related fields. Internal members also have priority access to professor dinners, lab tours, social events, and more!
Ready to embark on this electrifying journey of mind and discovery? Join us at our first general meeting and info session on Wednesday September 6, from 8-9:30pm in Wheeler 104 for free pizza and a chance to interact with human brains! All majors and years are welcome to join. 
Recruitment Timeline: 
Internal Applications Open: Now! Apply at tinyurl.com/cssa-fa23
General Meeting/Info Session: Wednesday, September 6, 8:00-10:00pm in Wheeler 104
Internal Applications Due: Saturday, September 9, 11:59pm 
Decisions Released: Monday, September 11
Questions? Contact us!
Email: cssa.berkeley@gmail.com
Website: cssa.berkeley.edu
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/groups/Cal.CSSA/
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/cssa.berkeley/
____
Thank you! 
--
Cognitive Science Students Association
at the University of California, Berkeley
cssa@ocf.berkeley.edu 
cssa.berkeley.edu
cogscicon.berkeley.edu"]

['The Cognitive Science Program advisors have some exciting updates regarding enrollment in CS 61A.
This morning we were informed that the CS department was able to enroll all waitlisted students into both sections of CS 61A. They now also have a modest number of unreserved seats available. Continuing students have until this Friday, June 16th, 11:59PM PT to either enroll into or waitlist CS 61A. At this time, waitlisting is going to be the best way to get into the course in Fall 23. 
If you are not able to enroll directly into the course, we are also thrilled to announce that students intending to major in Cognitive Science will have 75 seats reserved in the CS 61A-001 lecture. These seats will become available on July 17th, the first day of Phase 2 for continuing students. 
Continuing students who are unable to enroll and would like to be considered for these seats must FIRST add themselves to the CS 61A-001 waitlist and THEN fill out this form no later than Thursday, June 15th at 11:59PM (PT).  Being on the waitlist is how students will access the 75 seats reserved for Cognitive Science intended majors. You are not guaranteed a spot in CS 61A-001 by filling out this form. However, this will ensure that you will be eligible for the Cognitive Science intended major seat reservations during Phase 2.
If you are not able to get one of the unreserved seats during Phase 1 and you are not able to get one of the 75 reserved CogSci seats in Phase 2, you may still be able to enroll in CS 61A during the adjustment period (start date: August 14th). At that time the CS department plans to release all seat reservations. This applies for both sections. These seats will go to students who are on the waitlist first, thus your best option is still to waitlist. 
Notes for New Incoming First Years
If you are a new incoming freshman, you will not be considered for the reserved seats in CS 61A. New incoming freshmen should prioritize enrolling in a combination of the following:
Math 1A, Math 10A, or  Math 16A
Stat 2, Stat 20, or Data C8
Philos 3, Philos 12A, or Philos 25A
A reading & composition course
CogSci 1B
Breadth requirements not as easily acquired through the major
Physical Sciences
International Studies
Historical Studies
Arts & Lit
Notes for New Transfer Students 
If you would like to be considered for these seats, you must FIRST fill out this form no later than Thursday, June 15th at 11:59PM (PT) THEN add yourself to the CS 61A-001 waitlist when you enrollment appointment begins. Being on the waitlist is how students will access the 75 seats reserved for Cognitive Science intended majors. You are not guaranteed a spot in CS 61A-001 by filling out this form. However, this will ensure that you will be eligible for the Cognitive Science intended major seat reservations during Phase 2.
We thank everyone for their patience during this stressful time. If you have any questions, you can leave them in the comments or you can schedule an appointment with one of the major advisors. ']

['The CogSci Career Catalyst is back! The Catalyst is for Cognitive Science majors nearing the end of their college careers. The intent of the program is to help students launch their careers by supporting them through a summer work experience opportunity. If admitted into the program, students can expect to receive the following benefits: 
Networking, career connections, and professional support including:
Jobs 101: How to Successfully Start My Career ‚Äì Workshop hosted by UC Berkeley CogSci alumni, Phillip Hyun ‚Äò00. Phillip has founded multiple startups, including one of the largest esports companies in the world, Gen.G.
Connections to people and summer internship or job opportunities
Limited financial support for particular professional growth opportunities 
As funding permits and for approved positions that do not pay a living wage, the program may be able to provide a modest stipend to help offset the cost of an underpaid, but professionally valuable opportunity.
Read more about eligibility and requirements here!
The application will be open until February 20th @ 11:59PM PST!']

column2: ['Join the Going Down the EECS Stack Decal! #117']
column5: ['Are you interested in EECS but unsure of what areas you want to focus on? This DeCal is open to all experience levels and all majors. This class will feature guest speakers, field trips, interactive labs, and more.\nLearn more on our website decal.best or sign up at hkn.mu/decalapp. The deadline to apply is Friday, January 27th at 11:59 PM PT. However, please apply as soon as possible; applications will be processed on a first-come-first-serve basis. The first class will be on Monday, January 30th. ']

The deadline to submit an application for the Cal Pride Scholarship has been extended until Sunday, October 9 at 11:59 PM PDT. 
About Cal Pride:
The Cal Pride Scholarship's major objective is to serve as a resource to LBGT undergraduate students and their allies.
The Cal Pride Scholarship is a one-year, merit-based award that recognizes Sophomores, Juniors, and Seniors at UC Berkeley as well as incoming transfer students for their contribution to the LGBT community, academic achievement, leadership, and community involvement.

Berkeley, CA 94720

["Mark your calendars! Enrollment season is upon us and we know you all have questions to get answered. This update is to let you know that all CogSci enrollment advising services will be drop-in from 10/3-10/21. You can drop-in using this link from 10am-12pm & 2pm-4pm. There will be no appointments during this time. 
Also, if you have an undeclared at 90 units hold placed on your account, you can get that released via email. CC all advisors on one email and we will release the hold so long as we see that you are making sufficient progress towards the major. If you have yet to complete any CogSci classes, because you are planning a major change, please meet with an advisor during our drop-in to have the hold removed. 
Some enrollment tips: 
Have back-ups
Have back-ups for your back-ups
Check the enrollment restrictions for each class to identify which classes to prioritize
Berkeleytime is a helpful resource to understand historic trends
Check the enrollment rules for each department you're trying to take classes in
EECS Department rules
Psych Department rules
Use the schedule planner to ensure you have no time conflicts
Set an alarm or reminder 15 minutes before your enrollment appointment
Ensure that you have access to stable wi-fi
If your enrollment appointment is during class, step out of class as a courtesy to other students "]

column5:
['Dear Graduating Students:
Please carefully read the following information regarding the Cognitive Science Department Commencement Ceremony scheduled for Sunday, May 12, 2024, 9AM at Zellerbach Hall. It contains important information for you and your guests to know about the ceremony. 
Congratulations to you all!
The ceremony will last approximately 2 hours. There will be a reception following the ceremony in the Lower Sproul Plaza.
Commencement Registration: Registration for graduating students is closed. If you missed the registration deadline, we are not able to print your name in the program but you can still attend the ceremony and walk across the stage while your name is read. 
Commencement Tickets:  Graduating students walking in the Commencement Ceremony do not need a ticket for themselves. Please wear a cap and gown.
Guest tickets can be purchased from the Cal Performances Ticket Office for $10 each (free for children under 2 years). There is no limit on the number of tickets that may be purchased.
Tickets can be purchased:
Online
Over the phone at 510-642-9988
At the Ticket Office at Zellerbach Hall until May 12th (Tues-Fri, 12 p.m.-5:30 p.m., Sat-Sun, 1 p.m.-5 p.m. Closed on Mondays.)
NOTE: Any tickets purchased online, by phone or in person in advance of the ceremony will be delivered by email only. The email should be printed and brought to the ceremony or can be shown on a smartphone.
Tickets are REQUIRED for guests and no guest will be allowed to enter the Greek Theatre without a ticket. Children under 2 years of age are also required to have a ticket, which are free of charge.
All seating at Zellerbach Hall is general admission and is first-come, first-served (saving seats is not permitted).
 CAPS & GOWNS
Caps and gowns are available for purchase at the Cal Student Store in the Graduation Department. The Cal Student Store can be reached for questions at 510-229-4703, and is located on 2495 Bancroft Way, Berkeley, CA 94720.
ARRIVAL AT ZELLERBACH HALL
Zellerbach Hall will open for guests to enter at 8:00 am, an hour before the ceremony. Graduates and guests are STRONGLY encouraged to arrive early due to commencement day traffic, parking, and increased security clearance procedures.
All graduates must arrive to prepare for the ceremony no later than 8:20 am.  (See Commencement Day Instructions for Graduates section for more information for students)
If guests require special seating, please have them arrive at Zellerbach Hall at 8:00 am so they can be assisted before crowds arrive.
PROHIBITED ITEMS AT THE ZELLERBACH HALL
The following items are PROHIBITED inside Zellerbach Hall:
LARGE BAGS OR BACKPACKS
GLASS BOTTLES / ALUMINUM CANS
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
COOLERS / ICE CHESTS
BABY STROLLERS (designated parking is available)
SKATEBOARDS / BICYCLES / SCOOTERS
MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS
FIREWORKS
NOISE-MAKERS / AIRHORNS
ROLLS OF TOILET PAPER
CONFETTI CANNONS AND/OR POPPERS
COLOR BOMB CANNONS AND/OR POPPERS
BALLOONS (may be tied-off at the entrance gates at own discretion)
UMBRELLAS
SIGNS / BANNERS / FLAGS
TRIPODS FOR CAMERAS
ANIMALS (with the exception of documented service animals)
LAWN FURNITURE OR CHAIRS (small blankets, cushions, and low-backed stadium seats are OK)
ANY ITEMS THAT CAN BE PERCEIVED AS WEAPONS
There is no bag or coat check available. All bags are subject to search.
PARKING
We encourage the use of public transportation or carpooling to the ceremony, if possible. Parking on campus can be limited, and availability and prices may vary. Please note there is a curbside, drop-off area off Gayley Road just north of the Greek Theatre entrance for passengers with mobility concerns. Commencement parking information can be found at https://pt.berkeley.edu/special-events/department-commencements.
UCB Parking for Zellerbach Hall ceremonies is available at the following locations:
Payment for parking is CREDIT or DEBIT CARD ONLY - CASH WILL NOT BE ACCEPTED. Visa, MC, Discover, and AmEx accepted. For more information about parking, see the Parking and Transportation website on Department Commencements here. Please note that our department does not manage event parking.
Directions to the campus
Online Campus Map
Printable Campus Map
Commencement Parking Information 
ACCESSIBILITY
See here for information about accessibility
PICTURES
A professional photographer from GradImages (link is external) will take pictures of graduates as they receive their scrolls, as well as additional pictures prior to and during the ceremony. There is no obligation to purchase these photos, and information will be available if guests who wish to purchase them from GradImages.
If you register with GradImages prior to the ceremony, you save 20%. Click on this link to go directly to our department page. 
After the ceremony, you can find your pictures by going to GradImages and searching under UC Berkeley, and then check under UC Berkeley - Cognitive Science. 

DIPLOMAS
You will only receive a souvenir scroll at the commencement ceremony. Diplomas are mailed about four months after the end of a student‚Äôs graduating term. More information on diplomas, graduation verification, etc. can be found on the Office of the Registrar website here. 
LODGING
Information on lodging near Berkeley‚Äôs campus, and other local accommodations, can be found at Visit Berkeley (link is external). For more information on Berkeley campus tours, maps, and directions, please contact UC Berkeley Visitors Services.
COMMENCEMENT DAY INSTRUCTIONS FOR GRADUATES
All graduates must be at the Zellerbach Hall on the north side between Zellerbach and the Alumni House to prepare for the ceremony no later than 8:20 am. 
IMMEDIATELY upon your arrival, go to the tables between the north side of Zellerbach Hall and the Cal Alumni House to check in.
DO NOT LOSE YOUR NAME CARD. You will hand it to the name reader when you cross the stage.
Department staff will direct you where to line up. 
The Processional will begin at 9:00am. 
Staff will direct you. 
You will follow fellow students through a processional route through the theatre.
You will be led down a center aisle and directed into the seats in front of the stage area. 
DO NOT change your seat. 
DO NOT lose your name card. 
Crossing the stage.
After the speeches and awards, you will be directed to ascend to the stage on your left facing the stage. Staff will guide you.
You will cross the stage first pausing to hand your card to the name reader.
You will then move toward the center of the stage to accept your scroll and be congratulated by faculty with a handshake, fist bump, etc.
Then finish crossing the stage. Look for a staff person to direct you back to your seat.
There will be a photographer who will take your picture at one or more points as you cross the stage.
When all students have crossed the stage there will be a Recessional to leave the Zellerbach Hall. Staff will direct you.
There will be a Reception in the Lower Sproul Plaza after the ceremony. Cookies and refreshments will be served.']

column2: ['CogSci Commencement 2024 date and call for Commencement Speakers #473']
column5:
['Join us for an in-person celebration of the Class of 2024!
Cognitive Science will host its very own Commencement Ceremony
Sunday, May 12, 2024, 9AM at Zellerbach Hall.
The ceremony will last approximately 1 hour. 
Commencement Registration: 
Registration for the 2024 Cognitive Science Ceremony is now open. Please click(link is external) here to register. This is a two-part form. The first part is an exit survey. After completing the exit survey, you will be taken to the commencement registration form. Your name will not be printed in the Commencement Program if you do not register. The deadline for registration is Sunday, April 16, 2024.
Commencement Tickets: 
Graduating students walking in the Commencement Ceremony do not need a ticket for themselves. Please wear a cap and gown(link is external).
More ticketing info will be released later. 
********************************************************
If you are interested in being our Commencement Student Speaker, 
please apply here!(link is external)
***************************************
UC Berkeley will host a Campus-wide Commencement Ceremony(link is external) on Saturday, May 11, 2024, at 10AM in the Memorial Stadium. 
Students in our major and their families may participate in either the Cognitive Science Department ceremony, the campus-wide UC Berkeley ceremony, or both ceremonies, as they prefer. For more information about the campus-wide Commencement Ceremony, go to this link(link is external).
What is the difference between the CogSci Departmental Commencement and the UC Berkeley Commencement?
The CogSci Departmental Commencement will be a smaller, more intimate ceremony with graduates from CogSci only It will be held at the Zellerbach Hall and will feature a student speaker from the major and the presentation of departmental awards. The names of the graduating students will be called out during the Departmental Commencement exercise as they walk across the stage to receive their certificates.
The UC Berkeley Commencement ceremony will be for graduates from all the majors on the campus and it will be held at the Memorial Stadium. It will feature the Chancellor and other campus dignitaries, a special keynote address, and the student speaker. The UC Berkeley marching band usually performs at the festivities. Graduating student names are not called during the campus-wide Commencement Ceremony.']

column2: ['Apply to Generative AI @ Berkeley! Applications Due September 6 #860']
column5:
['We are Generative AI at Berkeley, the first and largest Generative AI focused student organization on campus. 
We focus on exploring the groundbreaking field of Generative AI, as well as its transformative potential applications. This semester we are primarily recruiting for people to join our project teams to work as developers for industry clients. We have some incredible projects lined up and we work with a wide range of companies, big-tech companies that have specific subdivisions that use Generative AI as well as startups whose entire product focuses on Generative AI. We also provide professional development opportunities, networking opportunities with industry leaders, retreats and mixers, etc. 
If any of this sounds interesting or appealing to you, please consider filling out our application by September 6. You can also express your interest here (to receive updates before the application deadline) and check out our website for further information. 
Our entire recruiting timeline is also listed in the flier attached below, so please come to any of our info-sessions or events to find out more information. Feel free to reach out if you have any questions!
P.S. We are hosting a ‚ÄúWomen in AI‚Äù panel tomorrow from 6-7 PM in SOCS 166 where you‚Äôll have the opportunity to talk to our wonderful women officers and learn more about their experiences in the club and in technology. We would love to see some AWEsome members there ']

column2: ['Remote study of Python programmers, recruiting participants! ($30 gift card opportunity!) #841']
column5:
["Hi! I'm a master's student in the EECS department. My colleagues and I are researching how programmers work with unfamiliar programming languages and libraries, and we could use your help!
This study will involve performing programming tasks in Python using an unfamiliar library. The study is fully remote, and all sessions will take place on Zoom. Participants must have access to a laptop or desktop computer. Please budget up to 1.5 hours for the study, although the actual session may be shorter. Participants will be compensated with a $30 Amazon gift card.
If you are interested, please take this screening survey to determine your eligibility.
Thank you! (And apologies if you've already seen this message elsewhere, or if you've already participated!)"]

column2: ['Ideas on Consciousness: DeCal Facilitator Opportunity Fall 2024 #833']
column5:
['Hi everyone!

Do you have ideas on consciousness worth sharing? Are you passionate about neuroscience, philosophy of mind, anthropology, psychology, AI, or meditation? Would you like to present these topics to a crowd of curious undergraduates?
Apply to join the Ideas on Consciousness Club as a Decal Facilitator! 
Our main focus will be to facilitate the IOC DeCal in Fall 2024. In our weekly one hour classes, we will begin with a general introduction to philosophy of mind and eventually range a diverse set of topics including the study of altered states (including psychedelics), the history of our current knowledge frameworks, current developments in neuroscience and AI, panpsychism, and quantum effects on consciousness. Find more details in our Fall 2024 syllabus. Also take a look at our social media and newsletter here.
We are looking for a social coordinator to join our team. We are also seeking a team member who would be interested in continuing our Dialogue Series monthly guest events. 
If you have any questions you can follow up with us at: ideasonconsciousnessucb@gmail.com

‚ÄúOnly you yourself can know yourself who is beyond measure, beyond number, beyond thought, beyond comparison.‚Äù - MƒÅtrceta
Cheers,

Trevor Chadwick
Decal Facilitator, IOC']

['Ever wondered where to take your ideas after the brainstorming ends? Looking for a platform to showcase your creations to the broader Berkeley community, beyond just designathons or the Jacobs internal showcase? Curious about what other student designers, engineers, and entrepreneurs are up to on campus? Now‚Äôs your chance to shine! Innovation Day is not just a celebration of design and technology; it‚Äôs a festivity of creative spirit and innovation at Berkeley. Along with a diverse group of student showcasers from various disciplines who will be tabling along Upper Sproul, the event boasts a lineup of inspiring speakers (including alumni from Jacobs!), a student pitch competition, and ample opportunities to connect with a larger community of driven students, accomplished alumni, and recruiters.\n Apply to table during Innovation Day to showcase your designs, products, or other creations\n Reserve your general attendance ticket now!']

['The California Cognitive Science Conference at UC Berkeley is an annual all-day symposium bringing together hundreds of students, researchers, and members of the general public from around the world passionate about the interdisciplinary field of Cognitive Science for a day of talks and research presentations.

The theme for this year's conference is "Pathways to Purpose: The Cognitive Pursuit of Clarity." Through this event, our speakers will explore perspectives on human purpose amidst the dynamic landscape of our modern world. The conference provides attendees with a glimpse into the latest research in all the fields that comprise Cognitive Science, including but not limited to Psychology, Neuroscience, Computer Science/Artificial Intelligence, Linguistics, Philosophy, and Sociology.

Tickets are on sale now at https://lnkd.in/gpUk8Abg! We are offering FREE tickets for students/faculty and $10 off general admission until March 15, so get your tickets today!

To learn more about the speakers presenting and all the conference has to offer, visit cogscicon.berkeley.edu.']

column2: ['[BASIS]Speaker Event for Evan Hubinger from Anthropic on 2/15 #616']
column5:
['Hey,
The Berkeley AI Safety Initiative for Students (BASIS) is planning to run a speaker event with Evan Hubinger, an ML researcher at Anthropic, which is a leading AI safety research lab. Evan will share his new research on sleep agents and a broad overview of the future of AI Safety. We thought that it‚Äôd be a great opportunity for the Cogsci community. Please note that the event will take place at 310 Jacobs Institute of Design and Innovation from 12:30-2:00 PM. Snacks will be served.
Applications for the BASIS Fellows Program are due on Sun, Feb 18th. The BASIS Fellows Program is a technical AI safety network that will offer exclusive social events (ie. hiking, board games, dinners, etc.) and opportunities (ie. co-working, ) to technically focused members.
Best,
Aakarsh']

column5:
['Hello!
Interested in leveraging technology to save lives and improve medicine on a global scale? Founded in 2017, Medical Technology @ Berkeley (MT@B) is a student organization dedicated to cultivating an interdisciplinary intellectual community to unite future professionals in technology, biomedical and computational science, and medicine. Our past consulting partners, such as Stanford Medicine, UCSF Medical Center, and Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory have facilitated our software engineering products to be deployed internationally. As a community, we are your one-stop shop to get clinically impactful project experience, achieve technical actualization in disciplines across technology and medicine, and contribute to intellectual dialogues across our research and editorial publications community. We welcome partnership inquiries from companies and other student organizations. For more information about MT@B check out our website at https://mtab.berkeley.edu/ or send us an email at ucbmtab@gmail.com.
Infosessions:
Monday 9/4 in Blum Hall (Health Tech Co-Lab) from 6-8pm
Thursday 9/7 in Blum Hall (Health Tech Co-Lab) from 6-8pm
Please check out our card below and fill out our interest form (https://tinyurl.com/mtab-interest) for email updates!']

["Hey guys, hope you're all well! If you're interested in neuroscience, brain computer interfaces, data science, computer-aided design, writing colloquial science papers, and/or applying neurotech to solving problems, check out Neurotech@Berkeley (NT@B)!
We have an infosession on Tuesday(8/28) from 8PM-10PM in Blum 120 and Thursday(8/31) from 8PM-10PM in Blum 120. It will be a great chance to meet current members and leads. You can learn more about our projects spanning across a variety of domains (software, devices, educations, publications, operations, and consulting) at the infosession and interact with current members to learn about what they are working on and what the plans are for this semester.
If you really enjoyed MCBC61 or COGSCI 1b, we do a lot of projects surrounding topics about the brain. with our NMEP (New member enrichment program), you can touch on these topics in depth and have the chance to participate in hands-on labs. 
We‚Äôre looking for members who want to contribute to all of our projects. If you have an interest in developing your own circuits, designing consumer devices, building and testing your own models, researching and writing your own magazine articles, reaching out and building connections within the industry, and teaching the greater public about neurotech, our club is the perfect place for you!please consider applying. Applications are due Friday, 9/1, at 11:59 PM! "]
['Hi! \nWill the ISSP/CogSci Commencement be live-streamed? If so, where can we find the link?  ']

You will have an opportunity to hear about the cognitive science classes that are offered next fall, get tips on how to enroll in your classes, and receive advice on what classes to choose. Sofia, one of our CogSci major advisors, and a peer advisor will also be doing a Q&A at the end. \nJoin us for pizza and to get your questions about enrollment answered! See you then!"]

column2: ['If we are graduating Fall 2023, are we allowed to participate in this Mays ISSP commencement? #190']
column5: ["I am graduating in December 2023 and wanted to know if I can participate in this May's commencement ceremony or if there would be a ceremony in the Winter for those graduating at that time.\nThanks!"]

['Dear Graduating CogSci Students:
This Spring 2023, the Interdisciplinary Social Science Programs (ISSP) will host a joint Department Commencement Ceremony for their three majors - Cognitive Science, Global Studies, and Political Economy. The joint Commencement Ceremony will be held on Monday, May 15, 2023, 9AM at the Greek Theatre.
Commencement Registration: Registration for the 2023 ISSP Commencement Ceremony is now open. Please click here to register. This is a two-part form. The first part is an exit survey. After completing the exit survey, you will be taken to the commencement registration form. Your name will not be printed in the Commencement Program if you do not register. The deadline for registration is Sunday, April 16, 2023.

Commencement Tickets: Graduating students walking in the Commencement Ceremony do not need a ticket for themselves. Please wear a cap and gown.
Guest tickets can be purchased from the Cal Performances Ticket Office for $10 each (free for children under 2 years). There is no limit on the number of tickets that may be purchased.

Tickets can be purchased:
Online via https://secure-tickets.berkeley.edu/20157/20158 (Note that the ticket sales site is titled ‚ÄúISSP‚Äù)
Over the phone at 510-642-9988
At the Ticket Office at Zellerbach Hall (Tues-Fri, 12 p.m.-5:30 p.m., Sat-Sun, 1 p.m.-5 p.m. Closed on Mondays.)
At the Greek Theatre on May 15 from 8:00 a.m.-10:00 a.m.
Tickets are REQUIRED for guests and no guest will be allowed to enter the Greek Theatre without a ticket. Children under 2 years of age are also required to have a ticket, which will be free of charge.

All seating at the Greek Theatre is general admission and is first-come, first-served (saving seats is not permitted).
********************************************************
We are still taking applications for our Commencement Student Speaker, 
if interested please apply here!
***************************************
UC Berkeley will host a Campus-wide Commencement Ceremony on Saturday, May 13, 2022, at 10AM in the Memorial Stadium. Students in our majors and their families may participate in either the ISSP Departmental ceremony or the campus-wide UC Berkeley ceremony, or both ceremonies, as they prefer. For more information about the campus-wide Commencement Ceremony, go to this link.
What is the difference between the ISSP Departmental Commencement and the UC Berkeley Commencement?
The ISSP Departmental Commencement will be a smaller, more intimate ceremony with graduates from only three majors: Global Studies, Political Economy, Cognitive Science. It will be held at the Greek Theater and will feature student speakers from each major and the presentation of departmental awards. The names of the graduating students will be called out during the departmental Commencement exercise as they walk across the stage to receive their certificates.
The UC Berkeley Commencement ceremony will be for graduates from all the majors on the campus and it will be held at the Memorial Stadium. It will feature the Chancellor and other campus dignitaries, a special keynote address and the student speaker. The UC Berkeley marching band usually performs at the festivities. Graduating student names are not called during the campus-wide Commencement Ceremony.']

column2: ['Neurotech Industry Panel Event, hosted by Neurotech@Berkeley #168']
column5:
['Aspiring to pursue the neurotech industry? Come to the Neurotech Industry Panel hosted by Neurotech@Berkeley!!
With featured speakers like Dorion Liston - Founder of neuroFit, Lida Kourita - Chief Business Officer at neuroFit, Ali Marjaninejad - Senior Data Scientist at Ceribell, Abhinav Pottabathula - SWE & ML Operations at Rune Labs, and William Newby - VP of Product at Rune Labs.
These panelists are from a wide range of roles in the neurotechnology industry and give a great perspective in the field as a whole. Come learn about their companies, and ask any questions and advice about their journeys in the neurotech industry. Here are some more details:
When: Wednesday March 22nd from 7-8:30pm
Where: Plant Genetics Bio Room 107
Who: open to all UC Berkeley students!
RSVP: https://forms.gle/mMJxXqAxYAx76AmU7 
We look forward to seeing you all there!!']

["Are you a startup founder itching to meet other Berkeley entrepreneurs? Pear VC is a seed fund hosting a free dinner for Cal founders this Tuesday (3/21) ‚Äî drinks included and yes, dinner's way fancier than pizza üòâ Their early stage investments include Doordash, Guardant Health, & Branch. column2: ['California Neurotechnology Conference at UCLA, Co-Hosted by Neurotech@Berkeley! #160']
column5:
['Are you passionate about neurotechnology? This event is for you!
The first in-person, student-led California Neurotechnology Conference will be held at UCLA on April 29th with participating schools such as UCLA, UCB, UCSD, UCD, UCSC, Stanford, and Caltech.
If interested, please fill out this 5 second interest form here:
https://lnkd.in/ggsBRye3
We will be having a live demo competition, poster session, and welcoming renowned guest speakers and panelists from research and industry. This opens up unparalleled networking opportunities with recruiters and other passionate members of the neurotechnology field.
Mark your calendars and get excited to be a part of the first edition of an annual event that will grow and push the Neurotech community forward!

If you have any questions, email us at cruxucla@gmail.com or check out our website www.cruxucla.com.']

column2: ['Exploring Diversified Pathways: Career Micro Summit - Event Opportunity #141']
column5: [' Are you interested in ‚Äúnon-traditional‚Äù career paths in business other than accounting, banking, and consulting? Companies include: Riot Games, Disney, Google, GenenTech and more. This event is open to all years and majors! Sign up with the following link: https://tinyurl.com/DiversifiedPathwaySignUp']

column2: ['Cognitive Science Students Association (CSSA) Alumni Career Night! #67']
column5:
['Hi all!
CSSA will be holding an Alumni Career Night this Wednesday November 2nd. You will have the opportunity to hear from Angela Drexler, who is working in child trauma research at Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital and Trauma Center, and learn about some career resources! We will be in Wheeler 220 at 5:00pm, so see you then!
Questions? Contact us!
Email: cssa.berkeley@gmail.com
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/groups/Cal.CSSA/

['Patent Pending is a community space by Build the Future for creators.
We believe that ideas flourish in environments that foster human connection, good conversation, and creative play. Patent Pending is a place where all three come together. We host co-working sessions on the first Thursday of every month from 7-10pm on campus.
Whether you‚Äôre hacking away on a side project or drafting a newsletter, you can work on it here alongside other Berkeley students. We‚Äôll have food, drinks, and activities to help you connect with both your work and each other.
Ready to join us? You can fill out our membership application by midnight this Sunday and we‚Äôll be in touch: https://tinyurl.com/patentpendingbybtf']

['The Cognitive Science Student Association (CSSA) is hosting their first meeting tonight, Wednesday September 7th, 8:00-9:00pm. 
Are you looking for an academic community excited about all things brain related? Are you interested in participating in fun events to learn more about cognitive science and in creating a strong community? The Cognitive Science Students Association at Berkeley (CSSA) hosts many engaging events with a community that would love to welcome you in! All majors and years are welcome, and we hope to see you at our upcoming events:
Calapalooza, 9/7 online (Wednesday, 4-6 pm); 9/8 in-person (Thursday, 3-7 pm)

['Cognitive Science Newsletter
Friday, August 2nd, 2024
Cog Sci Department News: 
Phase 2 Enrollment Now Open:
 For continuing UC Berkeley students, Phase 2 Enrollment for the Fall 2024 Academic semester is now open. Please visit your CalCentral account to ensure you are meeting your unit limit requirements and are registered for the incoming school year. 
Psychology Seminar Courses- Applications Due Tonight! 
Psych 115: Introduction to Brain Imaging Analysis Methods
Instructor: Prof. Kevin Weiner | MW: 5-6:30 in Etcheverry 3109
Apply here: https://forms.gle/iksf8GjRC5LuujTd
~
Psych 192: Special Topics in Psychology
Course Title: Transdiagnostic Evidence-Based Psychological Treatments
Instructor: Prof. Allison Harvey | M: 2-5pm in Dwinelle 246
Apply here: https://forms.gle/NEeF2QzSf7UfmVX87
Approaching Deadlines and Important Dates: 
 August 9th: Sessions B, C, D, and E end
 August 18th: Phase 2 Enrollment for Fall 2024 Ends 
 August 21st: Fall Semester Begins
 August 28th: First Day of Instruction
Opportunities: 
ULAB Offering for 2024-2025 School Year!
Want to do research and publish? Our applications are open for the 2024-2025 school-year and available below!
The Undergraduate Lab at Berkeley (ULAB) offers an immersive research experience to all UC Berkeley undergraduate students, and we're recruiting for the 2024-25 school year! 

Take part in a year-long research project on a topic that interests you, whether you'd like to work alongside a group of mentees or lead a group as a mentor. Mentees and mentors will have the opportunity to attend interactive workshops, publish their papers in our journal, and present their findings in our research symposium to faculty members. 

At the end of the year, the goal is to submit an extension model you will write with your group. You will have the support of a fantastic graduate student during your project, and you will be able to publish your final paper in eScholarship (Open Access Publications from the University of California).

Check out our past publications by ULAB CogSci & Psych students on eScholarship!
Applications are now open and available below. Join us to be a part of next year's published projects and gain valuable research experience!

You can also get up to three research units of credit for ULAB (Psych 199). It is not mandatory to take ULAB for units, but you have the choice!
Berkeley Connect Mentoring Program
Whether you are a new or a continuing UC Berkeley student, I invite you to add Berkeley Connect to your schedule when you enroll in your Fall 2024 courses. Berkeley Connect is a great way to find your academic community on campus.
Berkeley Connect is a mentoring program with the motto "you belong here." Our goal is to help you increase your sense of belonging and confidence you can succeed at UC Berkeley. Berkeley Connect is offered as a one-credit Pass/Not Pass course (98BC for freshmen and sophomores, or 198BC for juniors and seniors), designed to enhance your Berkeley experience by creating an intimate and friendly community of students, grad students, and professors. This is a very popular program and sections fill up fast!
When you enroll in a section of Berkeley Connect, you are assigned a graduate student as your personal mentor for the semester, and placed in a small group of students who share your academic interests. You will participate in one-on-one mentoring conversations, small-group discussions, special events with professors and alums, and field trips to explore campus resources. There are no homework assignments, papers, or tests; the goal of the program is community-building. Students tell us they appreciate the personalized attention; the relaxed, supportive environment; and the thought-provoking conversations. Berkeley Connect makes this big university feel a little smaller and more personal. 
Berkeley Connect is based in 16 specific departments, but you don't have to be a declared or intended major in one of those departments in order to join‚Äìyou just have to have interests related to that field of study. This fall, Berkeley Connect is offered through the following departments: African American Studies; Architecture; Comparative Literature; Computational Biology; English; Environmental Science, Policy, and Management (ESPM); Ethnic Studies; Integrative Biology; History; Math; Music; Philosophy; Physics; Political Science; Social Welfare; and Sociology. To see a complete list of Fall 2024 sections with seats available, search the Schedule of Classes for course type "Berkeley Connect," or course number 98BC or 198BC.
Berkeley D-Lab UTech Team Job Positions Open
Apply by August 16, 2024
D-Lab is hiring students for our Undergraduate Technician (UTech) position! We need you if: you are service and detail-oriented; you are a student who is enthusiastic about helping students; you like to be asked questions and look for answers. The UTech role serves as a first point of contact for the wider campus community for accessing D-Lab services which support data, data science, workshops, consulting, and research.
UTechs are the face of D-Lab‚Äôs virtual front desk, offering assistance to anyone who drops-ins by aligning them with the proper service or resource. This position is the frontline support for D-Lab, and is often people‚Äôs first (and lasting) impression of D-Lab. Among other things, UTechs manage the ‚ÄúD-Lab Frontdesk‚Äù email inbox, contribute to our weekly newsletter, contribute to workshop production and video curation, and assist with consultation requests and assignments to the proper resource or consultation service.
D-Lab is an open, inclusive culture that values diversity and open exchange. We will let you develop leadership in your particular area while working collaboratively with other students and staff.
If you have any questions, please email us at dlab-frontdesk@berkeley.edu.
Learn more and apply here by August 16th!
Requirements:
Must be an enrolled UC Berkeley undergraduate student for the Fall 2024 semester
Must be able to commit for at least two full semesters (e.g. Fall 2024 and Spring 2025)
Must be available to work 8-15 hours per week
Ability to work on-site at the D-Lab in the Social Sciences Building (position does NOT offer remote work)
Available Work-Study Funding is REQUIRED
EOP STEM: Mentorship Program Fall 2024
Apply by September 1, 2024
What is the EOP STEM Mentorship Program? 
The purpose of this program is to help connect and build support for 1st generation, low-income, and historically underrepresented college students interested in studying STEM. Our goal is to assist students in STEM with their endeavors to successfully complete their journey from the #1 public institution in the nation. 
As a peer mentorship program, we pair together students who we think will work well together, however, you have a chance to note in your application who you think would make a great mentor for you! 
Requirements
Students must be interested in a STEM-related major/minor
Time commitment for 4-5 hours a month
Mentees are required to meet with mentors at least three times per semester, aside from cohort events
Required to attend the Mentee Orientation on September 16th.
Required to attend the Opening Ceremony on September 20th at 6:00-7:30pm and Closing Ceremony on December 9th
Required to attend at least 1 MP/EOP STEM events a semester 
Mentees are required complete a 15 minute check-in with a member of the EOP STEM Mentorship program team at least twice a semester
No GPA Requirement
Students must be a part of the Educational Opportunity Program (EOP)
EOP Criteria (Any one of the following):
1) Low Income (Pell Grant or Dream Act Scholarship eligible as verified by the Financial Aid and Scholarships Office)
2) First Generation College Student (Parent(s) have not graduated from a four-year college or university in the United States)
3) Historically Underrepresented Students (African American, Chicano/Latino, and Native American Students)
The Bakar Ignite Scholars Program
Apply between July 15, 2024 ‚Äì August 23, 2024 for fa24 
The Bakar Ignite Scholars Program is a paid opportunity for undergraduate students in their 2nd, 3rd, or 4th year at UC Berkeley to gain real-world research experience with Bakar Faculty and Innovation Fellows. Students who are admitted to the program will be provided a stipend of up to $2500 to work in a Bakar Fellow‚Äôs lab part-time during the Fall semester. The estimated time commitment is 10-12 hours a week for 10 weeks from September through December 2024, but the duration of your participation and your weekly schedule can be negotiated with your supervisor depending on your schedule. In addition to participating in research, Ignite Scholars will join an exclusive virtual community of undergraduate innovators. Ignite Scholars will be expected to submit occasional discussion posts regarding what they have learned and what progress they have made.
Eligibility:
Applicants must be enrolled, bachelor‚Äôs degree-seeking students at UC Berkeley in their 2nd, 3rd, or 4th year, and are enrolled for the duration of their time in the Bakar Ignite Scholars Program. International students are welcome to apply as long as they are currently enrolled and plan to earn their degree from UC Berkeley.
Students who have graduated in the spring are not eligible to apply for the following summer or fall semester. Students who have graduated in the fall are not eligible to apply for the following spring semester.
Students of all STEM+ majors and years are eligible to apply. However, desired skills and experience will vary per project. Please read the full project descriptions on the Discovery Hub before you apply to ensure you are a good fit.
Previous Ignite Scholars are not eligible to reapply.
How to apply:
Step 1) Review the available projects listed below, and decide on one project you believe would be the best fit.
Step 2) Submit your application here through our Google Form: https://forms.gle/GXX9XoznMPpnHZNw6
Research Assistants needed at The Harvey Lab
The Harvey Lab is looking to recruit undergraduate research assistants for a study testing a sleep-health intervention that leverages the science of habit formation. The study works with participants aged 18-30.
Research assistants will work in both client-facing and data roles. This position will allow RAs to gain crucial knowledge of the inner processes essential to starting, running, and closing out large-scale clinical trials.
RAs may begin working right away, or starting at the beginning of the Fall semester. All work will be conducted remotely, and research assistants are expected to commit to 10 hours of work per week, although some weeks may be lighter than others. RAs must be organized, punctual, communicative, and excited to gain research experience in the field of psychology!
If you are interested in this position, please reach out to Crystal at the following email with your CV/ resume, as well as a brief statement of interest: crystalw@berkeley.edu 
More information about the Harvey Lab can be found on our website: https://www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~ahsleep/gbsmrc_mock/research/# 
Open Position at PNC, Palo Alto 
The Precision Neuromodulation Clinic (PNC) at the Palo Alto VA is offering a paid, in-person position as a clinical technician. Responsibilities of this position include delivering transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) treatments under the supervision of senior clinicians to patients with psychiatric conditions, administration of symptom scales, entry of electronic medical records notes, administrative duties, and assisting in implementing quality and process improvement projects. The position requires strong interpersonal skills to work effectively with patients, as well as to coordinate care with a multi-disciplinary clinical team, the ability to multi-task, and strong motivation to help patients with different forms of mental illness. The position is ideal for a recent college graduate who would like to gain hands-on experience working with patients in preparation for attending medical school or other allied health professional school. Students who have majored in psychology and related disciplines are particularly encouraged to apply. The attending physicians at our clinic are dually appointed Stanford University School of Medicine professors. This is a full time, full benefits position. This job will be available beginning Fall 2024 and requires at least a two-year commitment. Additionally, this is a federal position and requires US citizenship.
Please send a cover letter, CV and at least two references from prior work experiences to piayoon@stanford.edu and CC Dr. Jong Yoon, jhyoon1@stanford.edu.
NAMI San Francisco - Fall 2024 Internship / Part Time Staff Position
The National Alliance on Mental Illness is the nation‚Äôs largest grassroots mental health organization helping families and individuals affected by mental health conditions build better lives through education, support, and advocacy. Our mission is to decrease stigma, educate communities, and help people find the support they need.
The Lead Educational Presenter is a community-facing position. The intern would serve as a principal community educator and lead in-person educational presentations primarily to high school students. NAMI SF delivers presentations to high school students, parent/caregiver groups, community associations, nonprofits, college students, workplaces, and the general public. The purpose of the presentations is to humanize mental health, reduce stigma, provide foundational community education, and offer personal testimony of living with a mental health condition. Additionally, the educational programs are designed to increase access to local resources and create a space for community members to feel supported via peer sharing.
In addition to presentation execution, the Lead Educational Presenter would conceptualize, research, and deliver a presentation at the end of their internship on a subject related to mental health (see more below). Other responsibilities may include curriculum review and development.
Schedule and Location : Minimum 5 hours per week. Possible 10 hours per week based on experience, interest, and availability. Schedule varies by week - variables include location, time, and number of presentations. Typical presentation hours: between 8a - 4p at high schools. Combination of in-person and virtual work. In person locations include high schools throughout San Francisco, including in the Sunset, Twin Peaks, Mission, and Marina neighborhoods, among others. Remote when not executing in-person presentations.
Internship: August - December 2024 (flexible start / end dates)
Compensation: Paid internship and/or academic credit/volunteer hours. $20/hour.
Project Manager for Social Good in Tech:
Seeking an entrepreneurial student interested in the intersection between tech and social justice to volunteer as a project manager for Bridging Tech, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit dedicated to bridging the digital divide. Founded by two Stanford students in 2020, Bridging Tech promotes tech access in homeless shelters via device donations, hotspot donations, and an education app. The candidate should be able to devote 10 hours / week to Bridging Tech for 12 months. Perks include engaging with VC and nonprofit leaders in the Bay Area and gaining substantive leadership experience. The opportunity is perfect for a student with a lighter course-load or taking a gap year and looking to strengthen their resume before job or graduate school applications. This opportunity is extremely interdisciplinary, exposing leaders to product development, fundraising, operations, and media/journalism. 
If interested, please send your CV and a paragraph of interest to margot@bridgingtech.org.
RA opportunity: Supporting graduate-level research in Oregon (fully remote)
Are you interested in psychology research methods? Planning to apply to graduate school or pursue a career in clinical research? I am looking for 1-3 undergraduate students to support my research projects on visuospatial ability and falling in older adults. This position offers a chance to gain hands-on experience with literature reviews, paper-writing, systematic review methods, and more. 
Who: Melissa Zammitti (she/her), Cornell graduate and 2nd-year Clinical Psychology PhD student at Pacific University, Oregon.
What: Clinical Psychology Research Assistant for graduate-level research. Commitment hours are flexible.
Where: Fully remote.
When: Flexible scheduling with hybrid synchronous and asynchronous responsibilities.
Why: 1) Gain learning and publication opportunities. 2) Enhance your CV. 3) Receive mentorship in psychology research and graduate school, including a potential letter of recommendation. 
To Apply: please email me at melissa_zammitti@pacificu.edu
Scholarship Opportunities:
Rangel Graduate Fellowship
Deadline: September 19, 2024
The Rangel Graduate Fellowship prepares outstanding young people for careers in the Foreign Service of the U.S. Department of State. The program selects 45 outstanding Fellows annually and provides $42,000 in support for completion of 2-year master‚Äôs degree in fields related to the Foreign Service (such as business, economics, management science, organizational development/leadership, public policy, and international relations) at a U.S.-based institution. The program also offers internships, mentoring, and professional development activities. Fellows who successfully complete the program and Foreign Service entry requirements have a 5-year commitment to work as Foreign Service Officers.
Prospective applicants are encouraged to make an individual advising appointment with Keila Diehl, the campus representative for the Rangel Fellowship.
Schwarzman Scholars
Deadline: September 12, 2024, 3:00pm (EST) 
The Schwarzman Scholars Program supports 150 Scholars annually from the U.S., China, and around the world for a one-year M.A. in Global Affairs at Beijing‚Äôs Tsinghua University. The curriculum bridges the academic and professional worlds to educate students about leadership and about China‚Äôs expanding role in the world. The residential program also provides Scholars with learning opportunities with leaders from China and the world through high-level interactions at lectures, an internship program, a mentor network, and intensive deep-dive travel seminars.
Prospective applicants are encouraged to make an individual advising appointment with Keila Diehl, the Schwarzman campus representative.
Schwarzman Scholars Online Application Walk-Through:
Friday, August 9, 8:00‚Äì9:00 am
Pre-registration required (opens form)
For a complete list of summer info sessions, click here.
UC Berkeley Miller Scholars Program
Apply between June 1, 2024 ‚Äì August 23, 2024
The George A. Miller Scholars Program provides outstanding community college transfer students the opportunity to develop leadership, research or community service skills and apply them in practice. Every year ten low-income, first-generation students are selected based on their leadership potential, academic excellence, and commitment to community service and education.
As a close-knit group of students, Miller Scholars participate in the program for two years receiving individualized personal attention and guidance that helps them transition to Berkeley, succeed academically, and develop skills to ensure long term success. Based on financial need, each year, based on financial need, Miller Scholars receive up to $6000 in scholarship for Fall/Spring, and up to $2000 for the summer between year one and year two.
Eligible newly admitted transfer students are contacted via email in early June and asked to complete an online application. If you did not receive an invitation visit the Miller Scholars Program website for more information.
Paul and Daisy Soros Fellowships
The Paul and Daisy Soros Fellowships support new Americans in their graduate study in any subject, anywhere in the United States. Applicants should be leaders who can give evidence of creativity, accomplishment, and commitment to the U.S. Constitution, and for whom graduate education is relevant to their long-term career goals. The merit-based Fellowship provides $25,000 maintenance and up to $20,000 for tuition per annum wherever the Fellow attends, up to 
90,000.Soros Fellowship Online Q&A SessionThursday, August 15, 11:00 am ‚Äì 12:00 noonPre-registration required (opens form)For a complete list of summer info sessions, click here.The USRA Distinguished Undergraduate Awards The USRA Distinguished Undergraduate Awards provide college scholarship awards to students who have shown a career interest in science or engineering with an emphasis on space research or space science education, and aeronautics-related sciences. USRA presents up to four scholarship awards to undergraduate students each fall as part of its Distinguished Undergraduate Award program.Applicants must be full-time undergraduate students attending a four-year accredited college or university that offers courses leading to a degree in science or engineering. Applicants must be within two (2) years of earning a B.S. or a B.A. in a field of science and engineering, including life science and science education by the time the award is received. Scholarship awards are made in the fall, with applications accepted during the summer.Detailed eligibility and application requirements are available here. Applications are now being accepted for the 2024 awards. Film Screening: The Short Films of Vƒõra Chytilov√°
August 14, 2024 at 7 p.m. | Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive | Event Link
An assured mix of New Wave energy and v√©rit√© straightforwardness, Vƒõra Chytilov√°‚Äôs graduation project, Ceiling, involves a young woman who quits medical school to become a model. Drawing on her own experiences as a ‚Äúwalking mannequin,‚Äù Chytilov√° explores a world of repetitive rituals and one woman‚Äôs courage to escape it. ‚ÄúThe themes of anarchy and individualism that run through Chytilov√°‚Äôs work begin [in A Bagful of Fleas,] an almost docu-realist look at women finding freedom and joy amid the rigid conformity of life in a communal factory dormitory‚Äù (BAMcin√©matek). Automat Svƒõt, Chytilov√°‚Äôs contribution to the essential Czechoslovak New Wave omnibus Pearls of the Deep, makes a nocturnal visit to an overrun bar where two female workers try to keep the beer-hungry hordes out and a strange and handsome man meets a soon-to-be runaway bride.
