['Cognitive Science Newsletter
Friday, July 19th, 2024
Cog Sci Department News: 
Important Info Regarding Alumni Emails:
 Class of 2024! - congratulations on your accomplishments and welcome to a thriving, supportive global network of 595k Cal alums. 
After graduating from UC Berkeley, you are granted a 9-month grace period to transition your student accounts. Before expiration, you will receive instructions on how to retain your CalNet ID and access to email. To maintain your CalNet ID and access to email: 
Renewal: Follow the instructions that will be provided before account expiration.
Storage Limit: All alumni must reduce their Google storage to below 5 GB. You will want to start reducing your storage in your @berkeley.edu email account now so you are ready to transition before the grace period ends.
Annual Email Renewal: You will be required to renew your email account annually to keep your alumni account active.
Approaching Deadlines and Important Dates: 
 July 19th: Session F ends 
 July 22nd: Session E ends + Phase 2 FA24 Enrollment begins
 August 9th: Sessions B, C, D, and E end
 August 18th: Phase 2 Enrollment for Fall 2024 Ends 
Opportunities: 
The Bakar Ignite Scholars Program
Apply between July 15, 2024 ‚Äì August 23, 2024 for fa24 
The Bakar Ignite Scholars Program is a paid opportunity for undergraduate students in their 2nd, 3rd, or 4th year at UC Berkeley to gain real-world research experience with Bakar Faculty and Innovation Fellows. Students who are admitted to the program will be provided a stipend of up to $2500 to work in a Bakar Fellow‚Äôs lab part-time during the Fall semester. The estimated time commitment is 10-12 hours a week for 10 weeks from September through December 2024, but the duration of your participation and your weekly schedule can be negotiated with your supervisor depending on your schedule. In addition to participating in research, Ignite Scholars will join an exclusive virtual community of undergraduate innovators. Ignite Scholars will be expected to submit occasional discussion posts regarding what they have learned and what progress they have made.
Eligibility:
Applicants must be enrolled, bachelor‚Äôs degree-seeking students at UC Berkeley in their 2nd, 3rd, or 4th year, and are enrolled for the duration of their time in the Bakar Ignite Scholars Program. International students are welcome to apply as long as they are currently enrolled and plan to earn their degree from UC Berkeley.
Students who have graduated in the spring are not eligible to apply for the following summer or fall semester. Students who have graduated in the fall are not eligible to apply for the following spring semester.
Students of all STEM+ majors and years are eligible to apply. However, desired skills and experience will vary per project. Please read the full project descriptions on the Discovery Hub before you apply to ensure you are a good fit.
Previous Ignite Scholars are not eligible to reapply.
How to apply:
Step 1) Review the available projects listed below, and decide on one project you believe would be the best fit.
Step 2) Submit your application here through our Google Form: https://forms.gle/GXX9XoznMPpnHZNw6
Research Assistants needed at The Harvey Lab
The Harvey Lab is looking to recruit undergraduate research assistants for a study testing a sleep-health intervention that leverages the science of habit formation. The study works with participants aged 18-30.
Research assistants will work in both client-facing and data roles. This position will allow RAs to gain crucial knowledge of the inner processes essential to starting, running, and closing out large-scale clinical trials.
RAs may begin working right away, or starting at the beginning of the Fall semester. All work will be conducted remotely, and research assistants are expected to commit to 10 hours of work per week, although some weeks may be lighter than others. RAs must be organized, punctual, communicative, and excited to gain research experience in the field of psychology!
If you are interested in this position, please reach out to Crystal at the following email with your CV/ resume, as well as a brief statement of interest: crystalw@berkeley.edu 
More information about the Harvey Lab can be found on our website: https://www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~ahsleep/gbsmrc_mock/research/# 
Open Position at PNC, Palo Alto 
The Precision Neuromodulation Clinic (PNC) at the Palo Alto VA is offering a paid, in-person position as a clinical technician. Responsibilities of this position include delivering transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) treatments under the supervision of senior clinicians to patients with psychiatric conditions, administration of symptom scales, entry of electronic medical records notes, administrative duties, and assisting in implementing quality and process improvement projects. The position requires strong interpersonal skills to work effectively with patients, as well as to coordinate care with a multi-disciplinary clinical team, the ability to multi-task, and strong motivation to help patients with different forms of mental illness. The position is ideal for a recent college graduate who would like to gain hands-on experience working with patients in preparation for attending medical school or other allied health professional school. Students who have majored in psychology and related disciplines are particularly encouraged to apply. The attending physicians at our clinic are dually appointed Stanford University School of Medicine professors. This is a full time, full benefits position. This job will be available beginning Fall 2024 and requires at least a two-year commitment. Additionally, this is a federal position and requires US citizenship.
Please send a cover letter, CV and at least two references from prior work experiences to piayoon@stanford.edu and CC Dr. Jong Yoon, jhyoon1@stanford.edu.
NAMI San Francisco - Fall 2024 Internship / Part Time Staff Position
The National Alliance on Mental Illness is the nation‚Äôs largest grassroots mental health organization helping families and individuals affected by mental health conditions build better lives through education, support, and advocacy. Our mission is to decrease stigma, educate communities, and help people find the support they need.
The Lead Educational Presenter is a community-facing position. The intern would serve as a principal community educator and lead in-person educational presentations primarily to high school students. NAMI SF delivers presentations to high school students, parent/caregiver groups, community associations, nonprofits, college students, workplaces, and the general public. The purpose of the presentations is to humanize mental health, reduce stigma, provide foundational community education, and offer personal testimony of living with a mental health condition. Additionally, the educational programs are designed to increase access to local resources and create a space for community members to feel supported via peer sharing.
In addition to presentation execution, the Lead Educational Presenter would conceptualize, research, and deliver a presentation at the end of their internship on a subject related to mental health (see more below). Other responsibilities may include curriculum review and development.
Schedule and Location : Minimum 5 hours per week. Possible 10 hours per week based on experience, interest, and availability. Schedule varies by week - variables include location, time, and number of presentations. Typical presentation hours: between 8a - 4p at high schools. Combination of in-person and virtual work. In person locations include high schools throughout San Francisco, including in the Sunset, Twin Peaks, Mission, and Marina neighborhoods, among others. Remote when not executing in-person presentations.
Internship: August - December 2024 (flexible start / end dates)
Compensation: Paid internship and/or academic credit/volunteer hours. $20/hour.
Project Manager for Social Good in Tech:
Seeking an entrepreneurial student interested in the intersection between tech and social justice to volunteer as a project manager for Bridging Tech, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit dedicated to bridging the digital divide. Founded by two Stanford students in 2020, Bridging Tech promotes tech access in homeless shelters via device donations, hotspot donations, and an education app. The candidate should be able to devote 10 hours / week to Bridging Tech for 12 months. Perks include engaging with VC and nonprofit leaders in the Bay Area and gaining substantive leadership experience. The opportunity is perfect for a student with a lighter course-load or taking a gap year and looking to strengthen their resume before job or graduate school applications. This opportunity is extremely interdisciplinary, exposing leaders to product development, fundraising, operations, and media/journalism. 
If interested, please send your CV and a paragraph of interest to margot@bridgingtech.org.
RA opportunity: Supporting graduate-level research in Oregon (fully remote)
Are you interested in psychology research methods? Planning to apply to graduate school or pursue a career in clinical research? I am looking for 1-3 undergraduate students to support my research projects on visuospatial ability and falling in older adults. This position offers a chance to gain hands-on experience with literature reviews, paper-writing, systematic review methods, and more. 
Who: Melissa Zammitti (she/her), Cornell graduate and 2nd-year Clinical Psychology PhD student at Pacific University, Oregon.
What: Clinical Psychology Research Assistant for graduate-level research. Commitment hours are flexible.
Where: Fully remote.
When: Flexible scheduling with hybrid synchronous and asynchronous responsibilities.
Why: 1) Gain learning and publication opportunities. 2) Enhance your CV. 3) Receive mentorship in psychology research and graduate school, including a potential letter of recommendation. 
To Apply: please email me at melissa_zammitti@pacificu.edu
Forbes Fellowship @ Forbes Media
Apply by July 24, 2024
Forbes is recruiting for Journalists to join our Editorial Fellowship, a nine-month immersive training program for early career business journalists who will rotate through our newsroom in order to learn targeted skills specific to a Forbes career. We are looking for recent college graduates who embody the Forbes entrepreneurial spirit to innovate and who are passionate about learning.
The Fellowship will begin with a week-long business journalism bootcamp, a series of classes taught by top editors. Fellows will then rotate through the newsroom during a series of three, 3-month assignments in order to develop financial analysis, investigations, source development, and news reporting.
We are looking for recent college graduates who are interested in business journalism and have some experience in reporting, including internships and work on college newspapers. People making a career switch to journalism will also be considered, depending on their previous experience, training and education.
Responsibilities:
Develop the skills related to pitching, reporting and writing breaking news, trend pieces, second day takes, and feature length business stories.
Work on wealth valuations and financial investigations focused on the world‚Äôs wealthiest people.
Work alongside veteran reporters to cultivate sources and find scoops.
Conduct research related to list rankings (contact sources, gather documents and data, write short profiles).
Fact-check the Daily Cover Story on Forbes.com and magazine stories.
Collaborate with Forbes staffers on special projects.
Scholarship Opportunities:
UC Berkeley Miller Scholars Program
Apply between June 1, 2024 ‚Äì August 23, 2024
The George A. Miller Scholars Program provides outstanding community college transfer students the opportunity to develop leadership, research or community service skills and apply them in practice. Every year ten low-income, first-generation students are selected based on their leadership potential, academic excellence, and commitment to community service and education.
As a close-knit group of students, Miller Scholars participate in the program for two years receiving individualized personal attention and guidance that helps them transition to Berkeley, succeed academically, and develop skills to ensure long term success. Based on financial need, each year, based on financial need, Miller Scholars receive up to $6000 in scholarship for Fall/Spring, and up to $2000 for the summer between year one and year two.
Eligible newly admitted transfer students are contacted via email in early June and asked to complete an online application. If you did not receive an invitation visit the Miller Scholars Program website for more information.
The USRA Distinguished Undergraduate Awards 
The USRA Distinguished Undergraduate Awards provide college scholarship awards to students who have shown a career interest in science or engineering with an emphasis on space research or space science education, and aeronautics-related sciences. USRA presents up to four scholarship awards to undergraduate students each fall as part of its Distinguished Undergraduate Award program.
Applicants must be full-time undergraduate students attending a four-year accredited college or university that offers courses leading to a degree in science or engineering. Applicants must be within two (2) years of earning a B.S. or a B.A. in a field of science and engineering, including life science and science education by the time the award is received. Scholarship awards are made in the fall, with applications accepted during the summer.
Detailed eligibility and application requirements are available here. Applications are now being accepted for the 2024 awards. The application deadline is August 7, 2024.
Upcoming Info Sessions and Workshops for Scholarships with Fall Deadlines:
McCall MacBain Scholars Online Info Session
Wednesday, July 24, 11:00 am‚Äì12:00 pm
Pre-registration required (opens form)
For a complete list of upcoming info sessions, click here.
The McCall MacBain Scholarship provides a fully funded master‚Äôs or second-entry professional undergraduate program at McGill University in Montr√©al, Canada. The scholarship covers tuition and fees for the full normal duration of the program, a living stipend of $2,000 CAD per month during academic terms, summer funding options, and a relocation grant for moving to Montr√©al.
  -
KHS Application Workshop
Thursday, July 25, 4:00‚Äì5:00 pm
Pre-registration required (opens form)
KHS Information Session
Tuesday, July 30, 5:00‚Äì6:00 pm
Pre-registration required (opens form)
For a complete list of summer info sessions, click here.
The Knight-Hennessy Scholars Program is designed to build a multidisciplinary community of Stanford graduate students. The program, which financially supports up to three years of graduate study at Stanford, annually selects a group of 100 high-achieving students from around the world with demonstrated leadership and civic commitment.
Marshall Scholarship
Campus deadline: August 15, 2024 at 12:00 p.m. noon
The Marshall Scholarship, one of the most competitive and prestigious awards, funds one or two years of post-bachelor study at any college or university in the United Kingdom (England, Wales, Scotland, or Northern Ireland) for up to 50 students in any field of study. The program was created by the British government in 1953 to commemorate the Marshall Plan and is intended to encourage future American leaders to be personal ambassadors to the U.K. The award covers all reasonable educational costs, a personal allowance for living expenses, and travel costs to and from the United States. Nomination by UC Berkeley is required.
Prospective applicants must make an individual advising appointment with Alicia Hayes, the Marshall campus representative.
The Visas for Future Annual Scholarship
The Visas for Future Annual Scholarship program promotes environmental sustainability and education. We assist students globally in their academic pursuits while supporting future environmentalists.
Visas for Future is a travel agency enabling travelers to be climate-active with every trip. For every travel document sold, we plant a tree. We‚Äôre a social enterprise that strives to ensure that all stakeholders of our enterprise are taken care of, including the environment.
To apply for the Visas for Future Annual Scholarship, follow these steps:
Submit a copy of your unofficial transcript, including your GPA.
Craft a 500-word Application Story and save it in PDF format.
Email your Application Story to scholarship@visasforfuture.com with the title of the email being ‚ÄúVisas for Future Annual Scholarship Application‚Äù.
Academic Requirements
We‚Äôve streamlined the requirements to just two academic requirements to be eligible for this amazing scholarship!
Have a GPA of 2.5 or the equivalent in your country‚Äôs grading system.
Be a current student at the time of application and when the scholarship is awarded.
The scholarship deadline is 1 August. The recipient of the scholarship, chosen based on their enthusiasm and dedication, will be contacted via the email address and phone number supplied to begin the educational support made possible by the grant.
Gen and Kelly Tanabe Scholarship
Calling all high school, college, and graduate students, let us help you get the money you need for college. The Gen and Kelly Tanabe Scholarship is a merit-based program that helps students fulfill their dreams of higher education. The scholarship is named for Gen and Kelly Tanabe, best-selling authors on education, whose generous donations fund this program.
The Gen and Kelly Tanabe Scholarship is a merit-based program that helps students fulfill their dreams of a higher education. The scholarship is named for Gen and Kelly Tanabe, best-selling authors on education, whose generous donations fund this program.
Applications are due July 31st!
Rhodes Scholarship
Campus deadline: August 15, 2024 at 12:00 p.m. noon
The Rhodes Scholarship, one of the most competitive and prestigious awards, funds two or three years of post-bachelor study at the University of Oxford in Great Britain. The award covers educational and living expenses. Initiated after the death of Cecil Rhodes in 1902, the scholarships bring outstanding students from nineteen countries and five continents to Oxford University. Thirty-two American Rhodes Scholars are selected each year. Nomination by UC Berkeley is required.
Prospective applicants must make an individual advising appointment with Alicia Hayes, the Rhodes campus representative.

Olympics Opening Ceremony Watch Party @ Edmonds‚Äô Caf√©

Minari: A Friday Farming Flick with Berkeley Food Institute
July 26, 2024 at 6 p.m. | Hearst Field Annex 2545-2581 Bancroft Way Berkeley, CA 94704 | Event Link
Sponsor(s): Berkeley Food Institute
Berkeley Food Institute invites UC Berkeley alumni to an on-campus screening of the critically acclaimed film, Minari (2021) on Friday, July 26 from 6 to 8PM in Hearst Field Annex room A1. Directed by Lee Isaac Chung, Minari is a semi-autobiographical film that captures the experience of an immigrant Korean family in the 80‚Äôs who navigate life and farming in rural Arkansas. We welcome UC Berkeley alumni and current students interested in food systems to hold community together and connect over a shared love of food and farming justice and good movies.
Register here for the event
Doors open at 5:30 PM PST | Runtime 1 hour 55 minutes. 
This event is open to all UC Berkeley alumni, current students, faculty and staff. Due to our venue‚Äôs capacity limit, we can only open this to the UC Berkeley community. Please stay tuned for our upcoming public events to be shared on our website (food.berkeley.edu). We kindly ask for a suggested donation between $10-20 per attendee to help us deliver graduate and undergraduate student research and experiential learning program opportunities. It‚Äôs Your Time: Reconnect with Your Most Precious Resource
July 29, 2024 | 4 - 5 p.m. | C√©sar E Ch√°vez Student Center |Event Link

Join the SLC Strategic Learning Program for this engaging 1-hour workshop to rediscover and reconnect with your most valuable resource: time. Whether you consider yourself a seasoned time manager or are exploring new techniques, we guarantee that you‚Äôll emerge with a transformed relationship to time, empowered with concrete tools to make the most of your schedule.

Check out the dates and RSVP by filling out the form (bit.ly/slp-tmw).
Contact Info: strategiclearningprogram@berkeley.edu, slc.berkeley.edu/slp 510-642-1330']

["Cognitive Science Newsletter
Monday, July 8th, 2024
-
Cog Sci Department News: 
Important Info Regarding Alumni Emails:
 Class of 2024! - congratulations on your accomplishments and welcome to a thriving, supportive global network of 595k Cal alums. 
After graduating from UC Berkeley, you are granted a 9-month grace period to transition your student accounts. Before expiration, you will receive instructions on how to retain your CalNet ID and access to email. To maintain your CalNet ID and access to email: 
Renewal: Follow the instructions that will be provided before account expiration.
Storage Limit: All alumni must reduce their Google storage to below 5 GB. You will want to start reducing your storage in your @berkeley.edu email account now so you are ready to transition before the grace period ends.
Annual Email Renewal: You will be required to renew your email account annually to keep your alumni account active.
Approaching Deadlines and Important Dates: 
 July 19th: Session F ends 
 July 22nd: Session E ends + Phase 2 FA24 Enrollment begins
 August 9th: Sessions B, C, D, and E end
 August 18th: Phase 2 Enrollment for Fall 2024 Ends 
Opportunities: 
Open Clinical Research Position at UCSF
The Clinical Research Coordinator will perform independently or with general direction at the fully operational journey level of the series to execute, manage, and coordinate research protocols, as directed by the Clinical Research Supervisor and/or Principal Investigator (PI); may coordinate the data collection and operations of several concurrent clinical research studies under the guidelines of research protocols, UCSF and regulating agency policies.
Incumbent's duties may include, but will not be limited to supporting the management and coordinating the tasks of single or multiple clinical research studies, depending on their size and complexity; act as intermediary between services and departments while overseeing data and specimen management; manage and report on study results; create, clean, update, and manage databases and comprehensive datasets and reports; coordinate staff work schedules, assist with training of Assistant CRCs, and assist Clinical Research Supervisor and/or PI with oversight of other research staff; manage Investigator's protocols in the Committee on Human Research online system, as well as renewals and modifications of protocol applications and the implementation of new studies; participate in the review and writing of protocols to ensure institutional review board approval within University compliance; help assure compliance with all relevant regulatory agencies; oversee study data integrity; implement and maintain periodic quality control procedures; interface with departments to obtain UCSF approval prior to study initiation; maintain all regulatory documents; report study progress to investigators; participate in any internal and external audits or reviews of study protocols; and perform other duties as assigned.
The final salary and offer components are subject to additional approvals based on UC policy. To see the salary range for this position (we recommend that you make a note of the job code and use that to look up): TCS Non-Academic Titles Search 
Please note: An offer will take into consideration the experience of the final candidate AND the current salary level of individuals working at UCSF in a similar role. For roles covered by a bargaining unit agreement, there will be specific rules about where a new hire would be placed on the range.
To learn more about the benefits of working at UCSF, including total compensation, please visit this link:
Project Manager for Social Good in Tech:
Seeking an entrepreneurial student interested in the intersection between tech and social justice to volunteer as a project manager for Bridging Tech, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit dedicated to bridging the digital divide. Founded by two Stanford students in 2020, Bridging Tech promotes tech access in homeless shelters via device donations, hotspot donations, and an education app. The candidate should be able to devote 10 hours / week to Bridging Tech for 12 months. Perks include engaging with VC and nonprofit leaders in the Bay Area and gaining substantive leadership experience. The opportunity is perfect for a student with a lighter course-load or taking a gap year and looking to strengthen their resume before job or graduate school applications. This opportunity is extremely interdisciplinary, exposing leaders to product development, fundraising, operations, and media/journalism. 
If interested, please send your CV and a paragraph of interest to margot@bridgingtech.org.
LRAP Deadline Coming Up!
LRAP matches Linguistics graduate mentors with undergraduate research apprentices.
Apprentices will:
Get research experience with a graduate student mentor.
Gain skills and experience with independent linguistic research.
Become more competitive candidates for admission to graduate school
Earn 1-3 units (P/NP) toward graduation (Linguistics 197).
Eligibility: 
You must complete Ling 100 with a minimum 'B' grade ('P' grade is acceptable in Sp '20/ Fa '20/ Sp '21/ Sum '21).
You can still apply if you are currently enrolled in Ling 100 ( In-Progress) (The final grade will be verified before a match is made).
LRAP is open to all majors and all class standing (Freshman, Sophomore, Junior and Senior).
Enrollment in LRAP will begin during PHASE 2 of the enrollment period.
Deadline to apply: Monday, July 15, 2024
LRAP Decisions will go out mid-August 2024
COMPLETE THE UNDERGRADUATE APPLICATION HERE | Please use your @BERKELEY.EDU email account. (Returning LRAP students must also re-apply for their project)
DESCRIPTIONS OF FALL 2024 RESEARCH PROJECTS
Shilluk Language Documentation Project - Akil Ismael
Building an Audiovisual Database for Lobi - Amber Galvano
Armenian Language in the Bay Area (ALBA) - Julianne Kapner
Xaitsnue Community Dictionary - Anna Macknick
Typology of Kru Languages - Katie Russell #1
Documenting Atchan - Katie Russell #2
The Sociophonetics of Rap Music - Rhosean Asmah
Database for Analyzing Chalon - Tzintia Monta√±o-Ram√≠rez #1
A Mixtec Talking Dictionary - Tzintia Monta√±o-Ram√≠rez #2
SLC Programming Available for Students:
We‚Äôre thrilled to let you know that our group services are back for Summer 2024! With the dynamic pace and abundant opportunities of summer, now is an excellent time to level up your learning skills. That‚Äôs why this year we‚Äôre expanding our offerings to ensure that you can make the most of these summer months. Read on below for a refresher on our services and learn more about our summer schedules:
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Your Time‚Äù Weekly Tune-Ups: After you attend the ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Your Time‚Äù Workshop, unlock the full potential of your time management by joining our ongoing Weekly Tune-Ups! Become a master time-manager by reflecting on and adjusting your schedule on a consistent basis. For even more practice, we‚Äôve doubled the number of per week! Join us Mondays and Thursdays from 12 - 1 pm starting 6/24. Get started on your time management journey this summer by signing up for a workshop!
SLP Power Hours: Give your summer studying an added boost by joining our SLP Power Hours! These 2-hour sessions incorporate research-backed productivity strategies to help you achieve your study goals. You‚Äôll enhance your study practices AND Get Stuff Done! Sessions will be held every Tuesday from 11 am - 1 pm and Friday from 1 - 3 pm starting 6/25. Sign up to join at bit.ly/slp-ph.
See our full schedule of summer services at bit.ly/slp-services. We look forward to partnering with you this summer, and we hope you have a great week!
Transcending Beyond Berkeley (TBB) Fellowship 
Apply between June 11, 2024 ‚Äì July 13, 2024
Fellowship lasts from August 29, 2024 ‚Äì May 3, 2025 
The TBB Fellowship was created to address the need for professional development and experiential learning opportunities for the undocumented student community at UC Berkeley. Through this program, fellows can gain experience in different areas by working with a campus department on a year-long project. Fellows are eligible to receive a stipend of up to $7,000 upon completing the fellowship requirements, and work authorization is not required. USP students enrolled for the 2024-25 school year (including incoming freshmen, transfer, and graduate students) are eligible!
To be eligible, a student must:
not be eligible for federal financial aid, and
be CA Dream Aid recipients and/or be undocumented, and
be an enrolled student for the 24-25 academic year.
Throughout the year-long fellowship, fellows will be responsible for:
Completing 100-120 hours in their project per semester
Attending one community-building event per semester
Attending two fellow meetings per semester
Attending one EOP, USP, and/or Career Engagement workshop per semester (alternatively, fellows can facilitate a workshop with their host department).
Meeting with a USP Academic Counselor once per semester
Enrolling in Ethnic Studies 197 (Course Number TBD) for 2 units each semester and writing a 5-6 page reflection paper.
Engineering and Science Abroad Programs In Japan

About National Science Foundation (NSF) : The U.S. National Science Foundation is an independent federal agency that supports science and engineering in all 50 states and U.S. territories.
NSF was established in 1950 by Congress to:
Promote the progress of science.
Advance the national health, prosperity and welfare.
Secure the national defense.
We fulfill our mission chiefly by making grants. Our investments account for about 25% of federal support to America's colleges and universities for basic research: research driven by curiosity and discovery. We also support solutions-oriented research with the potential to produce advancements for the American people.
The REU program offers research opportunities to undergraduates in the research areas funded by NSF. REU opportunities usually involve groups of about 10 students who work on research projects at a host institution based in the U.S. or in a foreign location. At each REU site, students work closely with faculty and other researchers, receiving mentorship and building their professional network. REU participants receive stipends and, in many cases, assistance with housing and travel.
Undergraduate students who are citizens or permanent residents of the United States or its territories are eligible to apply.
Students must contact an REU site for information and application materials. Application materials for different REU opportunities can vary: they may require a statement of purpose, transcripts, reference letters or additional materials.
Note: There is a wide variety of REU sites across the country currently available for students to apply to. This newsletter has only listed the opportunities located in Berkeley, CA. For a more comprehensive list of all available REU sites, please consult the official REU Site or sign into the Berkeley Discovery Hub with your CalNet login.

Natoma is a technology platform reinventing the way organizations manage their non-human identities. We are seeking talented and motivated Software Engineers to join our early-stage team and play a pivotal role in shaping the future of non-human identity management in the cloud-native era. Work closely with teammates, design partners to understand requirements and translate them into technical specifications.
Participate in design/code reviews to promote best practices and maintain code quality.
Stay up-to-date with industry trends and emerging technologies to ensure Natoma's platform remains cutting-edge.

 SMA Native American STEM Scholarship
To be eligible for the SMA Native American STEM Scholarship, applicants must: be an enrolled member of federally recognized Pueblo, Nation or Tribe in the United States; be either a high school graduate or a full-time college undergrad student enrolled at an accredited college or university; major in a STEM field; must not have been placed on disciplinary or academic probation at any time; and have maintained a cumulative GPA of at least a 3.00.
Besides completing the application, applicants must also provide: a copy of Certificate of Indian Blood; a transcript; a copy of an acceptance letter; a clear photo (no hats or sunglasses); two letters of reference (at least one from an instructor or advisor, and one from another source not a family member); a one-page, single‚Äìspaced essay that answers the questions listed in the essay instructions; and commitment to completing four hours of community service per academic year.
The Rhodes Scholarship
Campus Deadline: July 15, 2024, Noon
The Rhodes Scholarship, one of the most competitive and prestigious awards, funds two or three years of post-bachelor study at the University of Oxford in Great Britain. The award covers educational and living expenses. Initiated after the death of Cecil Rhodes in 1902, the scholarships bring outstanding students from nineteen countries and five continents to Oxford University. Two Global Rhodes Scholarships will be awarded during the current application cycle.
Prospective applicants must make an individual advising appointment with Alicia Hayes, the Global Rhodes campus representative.
Applicants must:
be from any country that is NOT an existing Rhodes jurisdiction (see list [external site]) U.S. citizens and permanent residents visit the U.S. Rhodes page (opens external site)
have a minimum 3.7 GPA
earn a bachelor‚Äôs degree before beginning at Oxford
have sufficiently high standard of English to meet the language proficiency requirements (at the Higher Level listed) of the University of Oxford
meet either of these criteria by October 1, 2024:
1) be at least 18 and have not reached your 24th birthday OR
2) for older candidates who completed their first undergraduate degree later than usual, you must have
a) not reached your 27th birthday AND
b) have met or will meet the requirements for completion of your first degree on or after October 1, 2024 (subject to change)
GeneTex Scholarship
GeneTex believes in accelerating scientific advancement and the notion that the genesis of future discoveries begins with the support of young scientists now. The GeneTex Scholarship Program will award a $2000 (USD) scholarship to students pursuing a STEM undergraduate or graduate degree. The scholarship will be awarded to one student twice a year. Apply here. 
Applications for Fall 2024 are due July 12th, 2024 at 11:59 PM 
Events and Occasions:
Plant Sale: Perennials, Trees, and Shrubs
10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. June 14 - 23, 2024 
Beautify your home garden with plants from the UC Botanical Garden! Flowering perennials, shrubs, 30-foot-tall trees; come shop an exciting variety of plants, many uniquely from our collection! This sale features a large selection of adaptable and fun plants grown here at the UC Botanical Garden, including specialty Pelargonium primarily from our South African Collection, seldom grown or sold in nurseries. Summer planting works well across all of our Bay Area microclimates. Come on our opening evening and weekend to talk with our volunteer plant propagators to ask questions and get advice.
Visit our sale website here for a plant list and ‚Äúpropagator picks‚Äù
Sale runs Friday early evening, June 14 ‚Äì Sunday, June 23 while supplies last. Friday opening evening: 5:00 pm ‚Äì 6:30 pm. Saturday opening morning, Members hour: 9:00 am ‚Äì 10 pm Shop daily during regular Garden Shop hours, 10:30 am ‚Äì 4:30 pm.
Special sale notes:
- UCBG Members receive a 10% discount.
- The Garden is closed Tuesday, June 18.
- Bring a box to help carry your purchases home.
Buying plants at this sale directly supports the UC Botanical Garden - thank you!
Visit our Pop-Up Plant Sale webpage here.
Contact Info: garden@berkeley.edu , 510-642-2755
Access Coordinator: Marykaren Mrowka, marym@berkeley.edu, 510-644-7606
Blake Garden‚Äôs 100-Year Anniversary Celebration
10 a.m. to 3 p.m. June 22, 2024 | Event Link
Join the Department of Landscape Architecture & Environmental Planning on Saturday, June 22, to celebrate Blake Garden‚Äôs 100 year anniversary! In 1924, Anita Blake and Mabel Symmes had the vision to transform a steep hillside into a magnificent garden; now, with more than 2,500 different species of plants from distinct botanical settings, it‚Äôs a local treasure.
CED‚Äôs Department of Landscape Architecture & Environmental Planning stewards the garden, greets the public, and hosts monthly events. Its landscape and historic structures are maintained by LAEP professors and students, garden staff, and volunteers.
Honor 100 years of landscape architecture at Blake Garden at this celebration featuring storytelling, live music, exhibits, and more. Learn the history of this amazing garden and explore its future possibilities.
Admission Information: Free and open to the public
Contact Info:Kate Lincoln, Blake Garden Manager, 510.524.2449, klincoln@berkeley.edu
T-Rec Movie Premiere at Lawrence Hall of Science
June 29th, Showtimes at 11:00 a.m, 1:00 p.m, and 3:00 p.m | Event Link
Be the first to see a brand-new 3D film about the king of dinosaurs! We‚Äôre rolling out the red carpet forT. REX 3D, which reimagines our understanding of the legendary Tyrannosaurus rex through pioneering visual effects and work with top scientists and paleontologists. The film, which opens nationwide this summer, aims to be the most dazzling and accurate T. rex documentary ever made. And as of May, our screen is twice as big; it‚Äôs mammoth!
The T.Rex 3D premiere kicks off Dinosaur Activity Week at The Lawrence! Learn more about our prehistoric party!
Admission Information: 3D Theater movies are $5 with admission to the science center (Adults & children ages 3+: $20).Admission is free for UC Berkeley students & staff, Members, children 2 and under, Museums for All, and active-duty military. 
Contact Info: lawrenceinfo@berkeley.edu
Access Coordinator: Sue Guevara, lawrenceinfo@berkeley.edu, 510-642-5132

Important Info Regarding Alumni Emails:
 Class of 2024! - congratulations on your accomplishments and welcome to a thriving, supportive global network of 595k Cal alums. 
After graduating from UC Berkeley, you are granted a 9-month grace period to transition your student accounts. Before expiration, you will receive instructions on how to retain your CalNet ID and access to email. To maintain your CalNet ID and access to email:

Opportunities: 
MIT Haystack Observatory
Apply by June 30, 2024
Location: Westford, MA 01886, USA 
Contact: Nancy Kotary - reuhaystack@haystack.mit.edu
About National Science Foundation (NSF)
The U.S. National Science Foundation is an independent federal agency that supports science and engineering in all 50 states and U.S. territories.
NSF was established in 1950 by Congress to:
Promote the progress of science.
Advance the national health, prosperity and welfare.
Secure the national defense.
We fulfill our mission chiefly by making grants. Our investments account for about 25% of federal support to America's colleges and universities for basic research: research driven by curiosity and discovery. We also support solutions-oriented research with the potential to produce advancements for the American people.
Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU)
The REU program offers research opportunities to undergraduates in the research areas funded by NSF.

REU opportunities usually involve groups of about 10 students who work on research projects at a host institution based in the U.S. or in a foreign location. At each REU site, students work closely with faculty and other researchers, receiving mentorship and building their professional network.

REU participants receive stipends and, in many cases, assistance with housing and travel.
Eligibility: Undergraduate students who are citizens or permanent residents of the United States or its territories are eligible to apply.
How to apply: Students must contact an REU site for information and application materials. Application materials for different REU opportunities can vary: they may require a statement of purpose, transcripts, reference letters or additional materials.
CS Scholars Deadline Coming Up!
Apply between May 17, 2024 ‚Äì June 21, 2024
The UC Berkeley Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences invites you to apply to the CS Scholars Program! CS Scholars offers a learning community for Computing Data Science and Society (CDSS) students admitted for the high demand computer science major, engineering undeclared, and declared EECS majors. In this program, students will receive comprehensive, tailored support based on their individual needs, including cohort-based discussion sections for CS 61A, CS 61B and CS 70, advising, study groups and a community of fellow students interested in computer science. CS Scholars is a diverse community of Berkeley students committed to the success of one another. Priority is given to intended CS majors, applicants who have participated in academic development programs (including Summer Bridge, EAOP, Upward Bound, MESA, CS Kickstart, PREP) and students with a demonstrated commitment to providing service to under-served communities. There are no requirements for GPA or exam score to apply to the CS Scholars Program.
Requirements
CDSS students admitted for the computer science major, OR
Undeclared College of Engineering students interested in studying computer science, AND
Have limited or no exposure to Computer Science, AND
Identify as a member of any one of the following groups:
Low Income (Pell Grant or Dream Act Scholarship eligible as verified by the Financial Aid and Scholarships Office), or
First Generation College Student (Parent(s) have not graduated from a four-year college or university), or
Historically under-represented (African American, Chicano/Latino, and Native American Students) and/or women students
Research Fellow at The Good Food Institute 
Apply by June 3rd
The Good Food Institute (GFI) is a nonprofit think tank working to make the global food system better for the planet, people, and animals. Alongside scientists, businesses, and policymakers, GFI‚Äôs teams focus on making plant-based, fermentation-derived, and cultivated meat delicious, affordable, and accessible. Powered by philanthropy, GFI is an international network of organizations advancing alternative proteins as an essential solution needed to meet the world‚Äôs climate, global health, food security, and biodiversity goals.
In this role, you will have the opportunity to apply your scientific background to review major topics in fermentation to share with the alternative protein (AP) ecosystem. Your research will be crucial in informing the AP ecosystem on fundamental knowledge in the space as well as identifying further opportunities for growth and innovation. The Research Fellow will be responsible for:
Requirements:
A successful candidate for the Research Fellow position will have experience that reflects the following:
Ph.D. preferred; candidates currently pursuing a Ph.D. in microbiology, molecular biology, biochemistry, or aligned fields may also be considered. Candidates with a B.S. or M.Sc with at least 2 years of relevant experience can also apply.
A strong understanding of fermentation bioprocesses, as well as coursework or other experience with microbiology, biochemistry, and molecular biology. 
Strong scientific writing and presentation skills. 
Ability to perform independent, self-paced work.
A commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion.
Strong support for GFI‚Äôs philosophy and mission; demonstrated interest in plant-based & other alt proteins, public health, environmentalism, climate change, animal protection, or hunger relief.
A commitment to GFI‚Äôs values: believe change is possible, do the most good we can, share knowledge freely, act on evidence, and invite everyone to the table.
Software Engineering Fellow @ Natoma Labs, Inc.
Apply by July 1, 2024
Natoma is a technology platform reinventing the way organizations manage their non-human identities. We are seeking talented and motivated Software Engineers to join our early-stage team and play a pivotal role in shaping the future of non-human identity management in the cloud-native era. Founded by a team of identity experts from Okta, Google, & Salesforce, and backed by top-tier VCs and prominent industry leaders, we are well-poised to drive innovation in the field.
As a Software Engineering Fellow at Natoma, you will be a key contributor on a fast moving startup team. You will own features and learn from experienced teammates about the software development lifecycle and what it takes to deliver an identity and security product to market. This role is targeted at new and recent university graduates and lasts 3 months with the possibility to convert to a full-time role after the fellowship.
Responsibilities:
 Design, build and drive key features in the first iteration of the product.
Develop scalable and efficient full-stack solutions, with a focus on Typescript, Node.js, MongoDB, React, and Google Cloud Platform.
Contribute to overall system architecture and design decisions.
Work closely with teammates, design partners to understand requirements and translate them into technical specifications.
Participate in design/code reviews to promote best practices and maintain code quality.
Stay up-to-date with industry trends and emerging technologies to ensure Natoma's platform remains cutting-edge.
Forbes Fellowship @ Forbes Media
Apply by July 24, 2024
Forbes is recruiting for Journalists to join our Editorial Fellowship, a nine-month immersive training program for early career business journalists who will rotate through our newsroom in order to learn targeted skills specific to a Forbes career. We are looking for recent college graduates who embody the Forbes entrepreneurial spirit to innovate and who are passionate about learning.
The Fellowship will begin with a week-long business journalism bootcamp, a series of classes taught by top editors. Fellows will then rotate through the newsroom during a series of three, 3-month assignments in order to develop financial analysis, investigations, source development, and news reporting.
We are looking for recent college graduates who are interested in business journalism and have some experience in reporting, including internships and work on college newspapers. People making a career switch to journalism will also be considered, depending on their previous experience, training and education.
Responsibilities:
Develop the skills related to pitching, reporting and writing breaking news, trend pieces, second day takes, and feature length business stories.
Work on wealth valuations and financial investigations focused on the world‚Äôs wealthiest people.
Work alongside veteran reporters to cultivate sources and find scoops.
Conduct research related to list rankings (contact sources, gather documents and data, write short profiles).
Fact-check the Daily Cover Story on Forbes.com and magazine stories.
Collaborate with Forbes staffers on special projects.
Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*STAR) Singapore International Pre-Graduate Award (SIPGA)
Apply by June 15, 2024
Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*STAR) is Singapore‚Äôs lead public sector agency driving economic-oriented research, advancing scientific discovery, and developing innovative technology.
The Singapore International Pre-Graduate Award (SIPGA) gives international students the unique opportunity to experience the vibrant scientific environment and work with world-renowned researchers at A*STAR‚Äôs Research Entities. Students who are pursuing their bachelor‚Äôs or master‚Äôs degree in Computing and Information Science, Biomedical Science, Physical Science or Engineering-related disciplines can apply for attachments of two to six months in duration. 
Research areas available under SIPGA fall broadly into four categories ‚Äì Biomedical Sciences (BMS), Physical Sciences (PS), Computing and Information Sciences (CIT), and Engineering and Technology (E&T). As research is increasingly interdisciplinary, we encourage you to consider projects in all categories regardless of your prior research experience.
Please click the link below for the list of SIPGA projects available that you may apply for: SIPGA Projects List. (Having issue with this link? Click here to receive it via email)
Please note that you are required to indicate the SIPGA project you are applying for when submitting your application through the SIPGA Online Application Form. 
SLP Peer Academic Coach Positions Available:
This is an opportunity for undergraduate students to support their peers in developing the strategies, skills, and mindsets to thrive at Cal, all while honing their own learning processes.
Minimum Qualifications
MUST be available in-person
Cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher
No more than two ‚ÄúIncomplete‚Äù grades
Not on academic probation
Alignment with SLC Core Values
Ability to communicate effectively in oral and written modalities
Ability to engage in reflective practice
Satisfactory completion of application
Responsibilities
Attend weekly seminar
Prepare for weekly seminar
Provide individual academic coaching
Facilitate group services, including SLP Power Hours and ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Your Time‚Äù Tune-Ups
Foster an inclusive and welcoming learning environment
Perform other tasks as assigned: Observations of the services, meetings with more experienced coaches, supervisor meetings, work performance conference(s), event planning/coordination, data entry, presentations, and support for professional staff, as needed
Requirements for selected candidates
Attend an in-person weekly seminar, scheduled for Wednesdays 4 - 6PM starting week 3 of instruction
Commit to a minimum of 10 hours per week (may increase during midterm seasons)
Compensation: All positions start at $19.53/hour
*Note: Students may not be employed by the University more than 50% time during the fall or spring semester in any combination of titles. Students may work up to 100% time during the summer and during the winter break.
The Global Undergraduate Awards
Apply by June 7, 2024
The Global Undergraduate Awards is the world‚Äôs leading undergraduate awards programme which recognises top undergraduate work, shares this work with a global audience and connects students across cultures and disciplines. Submit to The Global Undergraduate Awards today to see your work recognised by an international programme, judged by professional academics from the world's top universities, and join a network of fellow undergraduates delivering top research in your chosen field.

Workamajig Generative AI + Human Design Scholarship
Are you a high school or college student pursuing a marketing, business, or graphic design-related certification or degree? Further, do you have an interest in generative AI? If so, consider applying for the Workamajig Generative AI + Human Design Scholarship! Each year, the scholarship awards $5,000 to the top applicant who either (1) creates an overview video that will be used to promote this contest in the future, (2) creates a stunning visual portrait of a college student at graduation, or (3) visually depicts the revolutionary new technology (Generative AI) in a picture or video. In addition, all applicants must write a 500-word essay (not using Generative AI) to describe ‚Äúwhy companies should use human graphic designers alongside Generative AI, instead of only using Generative AI design tech, or only using traditional graphic designers without incorporating Generative AI.‚Äù If this sounds like a good opportunity for you, we encourage you to apply! Keep on reading to learn more.
About Workamajig: Workamajig, over 30 years ago, started out as a management consultancy to help creative companies achieve the excellence they deserved. They worked with businesses of all shapes and sizes to streamline their operations and find the tools they needed to unclog creative bottlenecks.
Due June 30th 
Mays Mission Scholarship:
Mays Mission offers scholarships to deserving students with physical and/or mental disabilities.
To qualify for a Mission scholarship one must be able to document a significant disability, score of 20 or better on the A.C.T or 970 on S.A.T., be enrolled in a four-year study program (under-graduate only) working toward a baccalaureate degree and provide proof of enrollment.
Upon acceptance to our program, recipients agree to provide proof of full-time enrollment each semester, submit grades, maintain a GPA of 3.0 and write an ‚Äúupdate letter‚Äù providing the Mission with information pertaining to grades, struggles, triumphs, campus life and a general ‚Äúhow are you doing‚Äù letter.
June 30th at apply here

Applications for Fall 2024 are due July 12th, 2024 at 11:59 PM Events and Occasions:2-Day Summer Aerospace Summit8:30 a.m. to 6:45 p.m. June 5 - 6, 2024 June 5th: Chabot Space & Science Center - 10000 Skyline Blvd, Oakland CA 94619 | June 6th: Spieker Forum, Chou Hall, Haas School of Business, UC Berkeley - 2220 Piedmont Ave, Berkeley, CA 94720 Copy LinkIn a world where the limits of innovation and exploration are constantly being stretched, the forthcoming Aero+Space & Beyond Summitstands out as a unique opportunity to unite minds, technologies, and visions for the future.The Fisher Center for Business Analytics is organizing this event in a powerful collaboration with the Office for Science and Technology of the Consulate General of France in San Francisco, theChabot Space & Science Center, France Science,Berkeley Space Center, and UC Berkeley Extension. This collective effort is aimed at charting a course for sustainable progress in the fields of Aero+Space & Beyond, underlining the importance of community and shared purpose in our journey. Set to unfold over two stimulating days, June 5 at the Chabot Space & Science Center and June 6 at Spieker Forum, UC Berkeley Haas School of Business, the summit is poised to explore the vast realms of AIR, SPACE, & BEYOND, tackling the diverse challenges and opportunities within each. It aspires to be a melting pot for nurturing French-American and global scientific collaborations and to provide a platform for innovative startups and pioneers in this field.Admission Information: One Summit - Two Dates - Two Locations:June 5th - Chabot Space & Science Center - 10000 Skyline Blvd, Oakland, CA 94619June 6th - Spieker Forum, Chou Hall, Haas School of Business, UC Berkeley - 2220 Piedmont Ave, Berkeley, CA 94720Contact Info:Gauthier Vasseur, gauthier.vasseur@berkeley.edu, - See available tickets on Eventbrite: https://summit-aerospace-and-beyond.eventbrite.comThe Center for African Studies presents the 2nd West African Research Association West Coast Regional Conference9 a.m. to 6 p.m. June 10 - 11, 2024 | Event LinkKeynote speaker: Rachel Jean-BaptisteMichelle Mercer and Bruce Golden Family Professor of Feminist and Gender Studies, Department of History and Department of African American and African Studies, Stanford UniversityRachel Jean-Baptiste is a historian of 20th and 21st century French-speaking Central and West Africa, and the Atlantic World. ["Cognitive Science Newsletter
Tuesday, April 30th, 2024
Cog Sci Department News: 
Cogsci Commencement Tickets Now Available for Purchase:
Commencement Tickets: Guest tickets can be purchased from the Cal Performances Ticket Office for $10 each (free for children under 2 years) beginning Monday, April 22, 2024. There is no limit on the number of tickets that may be purchased, however, if you want to purchase more than 6 tickets, you will have to do separate transactions.
Tickets can be purchased:
Online via Cognitive Science Commencement | Ticket Office @ Zellerbach Hall(link is external)
Over the phone at 510-642-9988
At the Ticket Office at Zellerbach Hall (Tues-Fri, 12 p.m.-5:30 p.m., Sat-Sun, 1 p.m.-5 p.m.)
At the Greek Theatre on April 22 from 8:00 a.m.-10:00 a.m.
NOTE: Any tickets purchased online, by phone or in person at Zellerbach in advance of the ceremony will be delivered by email only. Tickets will not be available for pickup at the Zellerbach Ticket Office.
Children under 2 years of age are also required to have a ticket, which will be free of charge. All seating is General Admission. SEATS ARE ON A FIRST COME, FIRST SERVED BASIS. Graduating students walking in the Commencement Ceremony do not need a ticket for themselves. Please wear a cap and gown(link is external).

 May 3rd: End of RRR Week + Last day of instruction

UC Berkeley D-Lab Data Science Fellows
Apply by May 5, 2024
Data Science Fellows are an integral part of the D-Lab community. They largely support the D-Lab‚Äôs instruction program, while additionally bolstering the D-Lab‚Äôs interdisciplinary research mission by delivering talks and writing blog posts.
The D-Lab Data Science Fellowship is intended for Berkeley students who wish to provide sizable and wide-ranging contributions to the D-Lab community. Those interested in the fellowship are expected to have high technical competency and be ready to instruct and deliver research talks.
Data Science Fellows receive a stipend of $2400 at the conclusion of each semester subject to satisfactory completion of the above requirements and participation in D-Lab activities.
Apply here by the deadline: Sunday, May 5 at 11:59 PM PDT
Responsibilities: The D-Lab Data Science Fellowship is a 2 consecutive semester commitment. The time commitment for a Data Science Fellow is approximately 5 hours a week for the 16 week semester, totaling around 80 hours each semester.
UC Berkeley‚Äôs New Edtech Community: BELinnovators
You're invited to join Berkeley's new edtech community ‚Äì BELinnovators! UCEAP France: Field Research & Internship in Paris or Strasbourg
Apply between April 15, 2024 ‚Äì May 15, 2024
Work directly with local faculty to produce a specific research project linked to your major or interests. The Rhodes Scholarship
Campus Deadline: July 15, 2024, Noon
The Rhodes Scholarship, one of the most competitive and prestigious awards, funds two or three years of post-bachelor study at the University of Oxford in Great Britain. The award covers educational and living expenses. Initiated after the death of Cecil Rhodes in 1902, the scholarships bring outstanding students from nineteen countries and five continents to Oxford University. Two Global Rhodes Scholarships will be awarded during the current application cycle.
Prospective applicants must make an individual advising appointment with Alicia Hayes, the Global Rhodes campus representative.
Applicants must:
be from any country that is NOT an existing Rhodes jurisdiction (see list [external site]) U.S. citizens and permanent residents visit the U.S. Rhodes page (opens external site)
have a minimum 3.7 GPA
earn a bachelor‚Äôs degree before beginning at Oxford
have sufficiently high standard of English to meet the language proficiency requirements (at the Higher Level listed) of the University of Oxford
meet either of these criteria by October 1, 2024:
1) be at least 18 and have not reached your 24th birthday OR
2) for older candidates who completed their first undergraduate degree later than usual, you must have
a) not reached your 27th birthday AND
b) have met or will meet the requirements for completion of your first degree on or after October 1, 2024 (subject to change)
New Scholarship for UC Berkeley Students Interested in Marketing, Media, Advertising, and/or Analytics! 
The Advertising Research Foundation Workforce Initiative for Diversity and Excellence (ARF WIDE) is awarding 
9,500scholarshipstoUCBerkeleyJuniorsfora4‚àísemesterprogram(2,375 per semester). The deadline to apply is Wednesday, May 15th at Noon/12 pm PST. 
APPLY HERE
The ARF Workforce Initiative for Diversity and Excellence was created to encourage college students from disadvantaged backgrounds to complete their schooling and pursue careers in Advertising/Marketing/Data Analytics disciplines, thereby improving the quality and diversity of the future workforce available to these industries. For students in their junior year, the ARF-WIDE Scholarship (Advertising Research Foundation Workforce Initiative for Diversity and Excellence) provides up to a maximum of $9,500 in scholarship support beginning in the 2024-25 academic year (starting this Fall). UC Berkeley students will be selected to participate in a cohort joining students from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, Ohio State, Baruch, and CUNY. Awardees will have access to workshops, training, career services, all leveraging the 400 top global companies that participate in ARF. The program is intended to last two years and will end in May 2026.
Criteria for students applying for the Scholarship include: 
Currently enrolled in a full-time program leading to a Bachelor‚Äôs Degree.
Maintaining at least a 3.0 average in coursework.
Interested in potentially working in the fields of advertising, marketing, media, media research, market research, consumer insights, data analytics, or similar topics. 
Agreeing to complete, at the end of each academic year, a letter describing how the scholarship funds and the contacts with ARF have affected their academic experience and/or their future plans.
From a disadvantaged background as defined by ARF Charitable Foundation, the markers of which may include: 
Low-income family
Underrepresented minority
From a low-income, low-mobility urban, suburban, or rural area
First generation to attend college
Qualifies for any financial aid
A recent transfer to a 4-year institution from a community college
Financially impacted by COVID-19
Other institutional barriers
All Students who meet the above criteria are encouraged to apply, regardless of major. 
ARF Mission: To further, through research, the scientific practice of Advertising and Marketing. Learn more about the Advertising Research Foundation: https://thearf.org/, and the Workforce Initiative for Diversity and Excellence: https://thearf.org/about-arf/wide/

Call for Papers for the Journal of Cognitive Science at Seoul National University, South Korea 
Journal of Cognitive Science is an official journal of the International Association for Cognitive Science (IACS, http://www.cogsci.org.cn/iacs) and the Institute for Cognitive Science at Seoul National University. It is published quarterly by the Institute for Cognitive Science at Seoul National University, located in Seoul, Korea. The Association currently consists of member societies of different countries such as Australia, China, Japan, Korea, and European Union. However, paper submission by anyone in the whole world is welcome at any time. Its main concern is to showcase research articles of the highest quality and significance within the disciplines of cognitive science, including, but not limited to, philosophy, psychology, linguistics, artificial intelligence, neuroscience, aesthetics, anthropology, and education, insofar as it is deemed to be of interest to those who pursue the study of mind. In particular, we would like to encourage submissions that cross the traditional disciplinary boundaries.
Submission Guidelines:
All submissions must be in English, written clearly and in sufficient detail so that referees can assess the merits of the work. Papers should be no longer than 10,000 words and should conform to the JCS style guide. (JCS style guide is distributed, if requested, via email.) Papers will be received anytime and processed as promptly as possible. All authors should send an electronic copy (MS word) to j-cs@j-cs.org. Each submission will be sent to two or three reviewers. The reviews will be forwarded to the authors, who will then have an opportunity to make revisions if warranted.

Postdoctoral Fellowship: STEMEdIPRF: The Longitudinal Development of Students' Cognitive and EpiSTEMological Knowledge about Bonding Models
Apply by April 21, 2024
The proposed project aims to serve the national interest by improving undergraduate student learning in chemistry. The project plans to look at students‚Äô understanding of chemical bonding, a core concept in chemistry. The project is designed as a qualitative longitudinal study to provide insight into the strategies, approaches, and mechanisms students use when engaging in tasks that require them to reason, predict, and explain phenomena related to chemical bonding. The project hopes to understand how students develop and use knowledge about chemical bonding as they progress from introductory chemistry through more advanced organic chemistry.
Two research aims will be addressed in this project: 1) to investigate the development of general and organic chemistry students‚Äô understanding of bonding, and 2) to explore the interplay between students‚Äô ideas and epistemological beliefs about bonding and bonding models. The project is guided by Coordination Class Theory, which frames cognition as a network of fine-grained knowledge elements that are activated in context by the salient features of a task, activity, or problem. Elements of the individual development plan, including training in research methodology, literature review and proposal writing, mentoring, and teaching are intended to support the PI‚Äôs career goal of becoming a tenure-track faculty member in a chemistry department.
This project is funded by the STEM Education Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (STEM Ed PRF) program that aims to enhance the research knowledge, skills, and practices of recent doctorates in STEM, STEM education, education, and related disciplines to advance their preparation to engage in fundamental and applied research that advances knowledge within the field.
This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Cog Sci Department News: 
15th Annual California Cognitive Science Conference
The California Cognitive Science Conference at UC Berkeley is an annual all-day symposium bringing together hundreds of students, researchers, and members of the general public from around the world passionate about the interdisciplinary field of Cognitive Science for a day of talks and research presentations.

Tickets are on sale now at https://lnkd.in/gpUk8Abg! We are offering FREE tickets for students/faculty and $10 off general admission until March 15, so get your tickets today!
To learn more about the speakers presenting and all the conference has to offer, visit cogscicon.berkeley.edu.
Peer Advisor Applications Now Open!
Looking to support your fellow Cogsci Golden Bears? Join our Peer Advising Team for the 2024-2025 Academic Year! Our Cognitive Science Peer Advising application is now open to apply. Click HERE to access the Peer Advising Application! Peer advisors assist the Cognitive Science advising team by providing students with information about the major, major requirements, academic planning (e.g., helping students choose classes, create 4- or 2-year plans, etc.), how to get involved with clubs and research opportunities, and much, much more! Currently, our peer advising team offers drop-in services via Zoom. They also answer questions that appear on the CogSci EdStem page and will occasionally take over the CogSci Instagram page. Our peer advising services are held entirely remotely.
In addition to offering drop-in advising and answering questions on our EdStem page, peers also create new materials and resources for their fellow peers. 
A good peer advisor is a student who enjoys helping and has a particular interest in helping fellow students identify their academic interests. In general, peer advisors are friendly, empathic, and eager to support their fellow CogSci Golden Bears. This position is especially great for those who wish to gain experience with advising and/or academic counseling.
Compensation:
2 units of credit available
OR $18/hr
The deadline to apply is Friday, April 12th, 2024 @ 11:59 PM PST.
If you have any questions regarding the Peer Advising Program, feel free to email Meagan (meaganmason@berkeley.edu).

SLP Power Hours: 
Greetings Cal learners,
With midterm season starting up, we‚Äôre excited to launch our next service for Spring 2024: SLP Power Hours! Drawing on research-backed productivity strategies, these high-intensity working sessions will give you just the boost you need to stay focused and get stuff done. We guarantee you‚Äôll come away with a sense of accomplishment and the momentum to take on any tasks!
What can you expect at SLP Power Hours? For each 2-hour session, you will:
Set intentions and plan out achievable steps to accomplish your goals.
Connect with peers to provide mutual support, encouragement, and accountability.
Engage in wellness breaks to recharge before getting back into the groove.
Celebrate your successes and make concrete plans for improvements to your next session.
Best of all, we‚Äôll be hosting Power Hours every week from now until the end of the semester! Check out the schedule and sign up to attend at bit.ly/slp-ph.
Undergraduate Writing Support for Midterm Season
With midterm season in full swing, and deadlines approaching, we know students will be looking for in-depth conversation to support them with their academic writing. Our goal is to provide Cal undergraduates the transformative opportunity to dive deeply into their writing process with an experienced peer.
We want to remind you that we offer multiple formats of service so students can choose what is right for them. Our Drop-in service is our most flexible service‚Äìstudents can come by anytime we are open for a 30-minute session, and they can always sign in again if they want to continue the conversation. 50-minute Appointments can be booked in advance, so students can plan ahead. In either format, students can talk with a tutor at any stage of their writing process.
Additionally, if students have a lot of writing throughout the semester, our Weekly service allows them to build consistency into their writing process by meeting with a tutor on a weekly basis. Through these longer-term partnerships, students can bolster their academic writing process, plan effectively as they navigate multiple or major assignments, and cultivate habits that support their long-term writing goals.

Past students have interned on Capitol Hill, federal agencies, think tanks, the Smithsonian, nonprofits, and international organizations. All majors are eligible, financial aid and grants are available. 
For more information, visit the UCDC website at https://research.berkeley.edu/ucdc/

Postdoctoral Fellowship: STEMEdIPRF: The Longitudinal Development of Students' Cognitive and EpiSTEMological Knowledge about Bonding Models
Apply by April 21, 2024
The proposed project aims to serve the national interest by improving undergraduate student learning in chemistry. The project plans to look at students‚Äô understanding of chemical bonding, a core concept in chemistry. The project is designed as a qualitative longitudinal study to provide insight into the strategies, approaches, and mechanisms students use when engaging in tasks that require them to reason, predict, and explain phenomena related to chemical bonding. The project hopes to understand how students develop and use knowledge about chemical bonding as they progress from introductory chemistry through more advanced organic chemistry.
Two research aims will be addressed in this project: 1) to investigate the development of general and organic chemistry students‚Äô understanding of bonding, and 2) to explore the interplay between students‚Äô ideas and epistemological beliefs about bonding and bonding models. The project is guided by Coordination Class Theory, which frames cognition as a network of fine-grained knowledge elements that are activated in context by the salient features of a task, activity, or problem. Elements of the individual development plan, including training in research methodology, literature review and proposal writing, mentoring, and teaching are intended to support the PI‚Äôs career goal of becoming a tenure-track faculty member in a chemistry department.
This project is funded by the STEM Education Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (STEM Ed PRF) program that aims to enhance the research knowledge, skills, and practices of recent doctorates in STEM, STEM education, education, and related disciplines to advance their preparation to engage in fundamental and applied research that advances knowledge within the field.
This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
Fung Fellowship:
The Fung Fellowship Application for the 2024-25 academic year is now open! Applications are due Saturday, March 2, 2024 and we are accepting applications from Class of 2026 rising juniors and Class of 2025 rising seniors. The Fung Fellowship is a unique opportunity to create impact-driven solutions to address real-world challenges alongside our community and industry partners. Fung Fellows utilize an experiential learning process focused on collaboration, interdisciplinary tactics, and emerging technology in both of our offered tracks: Conservation + Innovation and Health + Innovation. 
As a Fung Fellow you will:
Explore and solve real-world problems in your chosen track
Experience the innovation and design process from prototype to product
Embed within communities and work with partner organizations to co-create solutions
Refine your leadership skills through immersive learning experiences
Fung Fellows attend a 3-unit course each semester and have access to experiential and professional development opportunities throughout the year, such as networking events, workshops, career services, community building events, and much more! 
Required qualifications:
Registered student at UC Berkeley
Class of 2026 rising junior or Class of 2025 rising senior (current sophomore or junior standing)
Passion for health, conservation, social impact, design, and/or technology
The Fung Fellowship accepts all majors into this program and there is no GPA minimum requirement. Applications are reviewed holistically.

Astronaut Scholarship
Campus deadline - Noon, March 1, 2024
The Astronaut Scholarship Foundation awards up to $15,000 to sixty rising juniors and seniors majoring in STEM fields. Applicants are evaluated based on their exemplary academic performance and on the quality and amount of work conducted outside the classroom in their chosen field of study. The ASF scholarship award is the beginning of a life-long relationship with astronauts, alumni, and leaders who span academia, technical research, and corporate leadership.
Rose Hills Summer Scholarships
Generously sponsored by the Rose Hills Foundation, Rose Hills Summer Scholarships enable UC Berkeley students from select STEM disciplines to immerse themselves in full-time summer research for seven weeks. Open to sophomores, juniors, seniors, and graduating seniors, the funding will support projects that are either faculty-led or independent. To be eligible, students must be US Citizens with permanent residency established in Southern California and be majoring in one of the designated STEM majors. The scholarship provides students with $5000 in summer funding. To receive consideration for a Rose Hills Summer Scholarship, applicants must prepare a research proposal as part of their application, and are therefore strongly encouraged to attend one of OURS's "How to Write a Research Proposal Workshops" in January and to participate in a draft workshop in February. Applications due March 1st!
Judith Lee Stronach Baccalaureate Prize
The Judith Lee Stronach Baccalaureate Prize supports intellectual and creative pursuits that heighten awareness of issues of social consciousness and contribute to the public good. The award gives motivated students the opportunity to extend and reflect upon their undergraduate work at Berkeley by undertaking a special project after their graduation. Winning projects are creative in the broadest sense, explore themes of significant interest to holders of the Prize, and strive to further understanding of what constitutes humane and effective participation in our worldwide community.
Application Deadline: March 1, 2024

January 26, 10-11am on zoom at https://berkeley.zoom.us/j/5492740547
February 1, 4-5pm in-person in 3401 Dwinelle Hall

SURF L&S 
SURF L&S provides undergraduates in the College of Letters and Science with funding to undertake concentrated summer research in preparation for a senior thesis or similar major capstone project in their final semesters at Cal. Fellows receive a summer stipend of $5,000 for seven weeks of research. In addition to the funding, students benefit from regular meetings with their research cluster cohort and from numerous workshops. To qualify, students must have the support of a UC Berkeley affiliated faculty member and the application requires students to prepare a research proposal related to their project. The application deadline is March 1, 2024, and applicants are strongly encouraged to attend one of OURS's "How to Write a Research Proposal Workshops" in January and to participate a draft workshop with one of the SURF mentors in February.
