['Cognitive Science Newsletter
Thursday, June 22nd, 2023
Cog Sci Department News:
CogSci Group Advising Event:
Do you have questions about how to create an academic plan? Confused about how to create a balanced schedule? This upcoming group advising session for CogSci students may be a great opportunity for you! Join Sofia Vita-Casquejo for a group advising session focused on academic planning. This remote session will take place on July 5th from 1pm-2pm (Pacific Time) via Zoom. To receive the bCal invite and Zoom link, you must fill out this RSVP. 
This event will not be recorded. If there are less than 3 students interested, the event will be canceled. If there are more than 15 interested students, additional group advising sessions will be offered. 
Developments on Enrollment for CS61A: 
The CS department was able to enroll all waitlisted students into both sections of CS 61A. If you are not able to get one of the unreserved seats during Phase 1 and you are not able to get one of the 75 reserved CogSci seats in Phase 2, you may still be able to enroll in CS 61A during the adjustment period (start date: August 14th). At that time the CS department plans to release all seat reservations. 
Approaching Deadlines and Important Dates: 
 June 30: Summer Session A Ends
 July 3: Summer Session D and F Begins 
 July 17: Phase 2 Enrollment Begins
 July 21: Summer Session F Ends
Opportunities:
 UC Berkeley BASE Summer Program (Business for Arts, Sciences and Engineering)
Apply by Jun 29, 2023
Jul 3, 2023 ‚Äì Aug 11, 2023
UC Berkeley, Oxford Street, Berkeley, CA
The Haas School of Business invites you to consider the BASE Summer Program (Business for Arts, Sciences and Engineering). BASE is a six-week business boot camp that enables non-business majors and recent graduates to take business courses while earning full academic credit. BASE students will experience custom workshops, company events, small class size with top professors and Haas Alumni Network benefits.
The ideal participant of the BASE Program is an undergraduate student majoring in liberal arts, sciences or engineering. BASE is the only premier business summer program or institute where students can earn units.
Check out the BASE website for more information, and email BASE@haas.berkeley.edu if you have any questions.
 SERC Science Scholars
The Student Environmental Resource Center (SERC) at UC Berkeley is UC Berkeley‚Äôs main hub for environmentalism. We serve 10,000+ students each year with our programming, outreach, and peer education centered around sustainability and environmental justice.
We are excited to offer our first SERC Science Scholars program with the theme of "Simplify Science". As climate change impacts every facet of our lives, equipping all individuals with the fundamentals of science and its analytical tools provides the launchpad for newfound, interdisciplinary applications to emerge. This program strives to support each scholar's natural learning style in an intellectually inspiring environment.
We've designed an original curriculum to make mathematics, ranging from precalculus to multivariable calculus, and coding accessible to all students, regardless of their prior knowledge. Our approach to STEM education prioritizes intuition-based understanding over rote memorization and centers on applying this knowledge to climate issues, such as air pollution and wildfires.
We highly encourage students who come from first-generation, low-income, and underserved backgrounds or have simply struggled to learn STEM to apply to be a scholar. Graduate and undergraduate students of any academic year are eligible to apply. Applicants must submit this application by 11:59pm on Sunday, July 2nd.

Professor Assistant Position (Research and Professional Communication) 
This position is intended to facilitate the research and professional communication of a Distinguished Professor of Psychology who has retired because of loss of eyesight due to glaucoma. The paid position involves 5 ‚Äì 10 hours/week (proposed: 10% in-person/90% over the phone) involving the following activities: 
‚óè Taking dictation from the professor to be sent by email/other correspondence.
 ‚óè Reading professional literature such as manuscripts to be evaluated for publication and hence are timely and typically of good quality. 
‚óè Reading specific articles from journals or from Handbooks including some from unpublished compendia that the publisher has requested evaluations from leading figures in Emotion and Developmental Psychology. 
‚óè Facilitate grant reviews and structuring letters of recommendation. 
About working with Prof. Campos: 
‚óè He is the recipient of a Lifetime Scientific Contribution for the study of Human infancy. 
‚óè He was recently noted as being in the top 1% of developmental psychologists by the Library of Congress. 
‚óè He is blind, but his mind is far from blind
 ‚óè He has received two distinguished teaching contributions attesting to an ability to relate well to students. 
What you'll get out of it: 
‚óè Rate offered is $20/hr + travel reimbursement for undergraduate seniors. Paid bi-weekly after filing an invoice/hours worked. 
‚óè Excellent opportunity to work closely with a distinguished faculty member and potentially publish with him.
 ‚óè Previous students who worked with Prof. Campos say he was an active mentor, humorous and good-natured teacher and a pleasure to work with.
SFVAMC Volunteer RA Position San Francisco VA Hospital PTSD Research Program Volunteer Sleep and PTSD Research Assistant:
 The Stress and Health Research Program at the San Francisco VA Medical Center and the University of California San Francisco is seeking volunteer Research Assistants to assist with research studies focused on PTSD. The Research Assistant will be responsible for assisting with the day-to-day operations of research projects on PTSD and sleep. Commitment to assisting with evening research activities involving data collection is required. The research assistant will perform duties including: primarily telephone screenings with potential participants for eligibility purposes; cleaning and organizing self-report and physiological data; data entry; recruitment procedures such as preparing and sending recruitment messages; and assisting in tracking participants participating in studies.
The ideal candidate will: 
‚óè Be in a BA/BS degree program in psychology, pre-med or related field 
‚óè Possess strong interpersonal and oral communication skills ‚óè Possess similarity with diagnostic and therapeutic issues related to PTSD 
‚óè Possess prior research experience
‚óè Preference will be given to student with a strong interest in pursuing undergraduate research 
‚óè Prior experience in clinical settings is desirable 
‚óè Commitment to working four weekend evening per month is required (Two Saturday evenings and other evenings would be a Friday or Sunday evening depending on staff/study participant needs) 
‚óè Ability to work flexibly in-person and remote with the needs of the lab 
‚óè Minimum time commitment is 8 hours per week 
‚óè 1-year commitment is required (this includes during summer and winter break)
 If you are interested in applying for this position, please email a cover letter and resume to miles.kovnick@va.gov with the subject heading PTSD Volunteer Research Assistant. 
Volunteers for a UCSF Study Volunteer Research Assistants Needed 
Volunteer research assistants are needed for a study funded by the National Institute on Drug Abuse (Grant R21DA050038), which is titled ‚ÄúExpanding Access to Buprenorphine Treatment among Homeless Persons with Opioid Use Disorder.‚Äù The principal investigator of the study is 4 Internship and Volunteering Opportunities: Week of June 19, 2023 Carmen L, Masson, Ph.D., a clinical psychologist and Professor, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, University of California, San Francisco. In this volunteer position, volunteer research assistants work with a study Clinical Research Coordinator and Principal Investigator to recruit, interview, and collect survey data for a study of people who are both homeless and have opioid use disorders. The research position entails going out into the homeless community in San Francisco and recruiting participants from places, such as homeless shelters and syringe exchange programs. Buprenorphine is a partial mu agonist medication used for the treatment of opioid use disorder. People who are homeless may not have the personal resources, such as a stable place to store medications, to use buprenorphine effectively, and one of the main aims of the study is to find ways that people who are homeless and use opioids can fit buprenorphine treatment into their lifestyle. Research assistants will be given volunteer positions at the University of California, San Francisco. To apply, contact Dr. Michael Shopshire at Michael.shopshire@ucsf.edu
National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowships
The purpose of the National Science Foundation (NSF) Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP) is to help ensure the quality, vitality, and diversity of the scientific and engineering workforce of the United States. The program recognizes and supports outstanding graduate students who are pursuing full-time research-based master's and doctoral degrees in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) or in STEM education. The GRFP provides three years of support over a five-year fellowship period for the graduate education of individuals who have demonstrated their potential for significant research achievements in STEM or STEM education. NSF actively encourages women, persons who are members of groups historically underrepresented in STEM, persons with disabilities, veterans, and undergraduate seniors to apply. The five-year fellowship provides three years of financial support inclusive of an annual stipend of $37,000. Applications for GRFP 2024 will open in July. More information about the fellowship can be found here. 
Undergraduate Internship Program Application Extension: 
Internship Prep & Connect Applications Are Now Open! The Cal Career Center is piloting an exciting new equity-oriented program aiming to prepare undergraduate students to work in an internship by boosting their Career Readiness and connecting them with employers that offer internship opportunities. The program consists of five robust modules that address aspects of Career Readiness as defined by the National Association of Colleges and Employers (NACE). Upon completion of the program, students will receive a certificate of completion and attend an exclusive networking event. In order to be eligible to participate, students should hold 2nd or 3rd year status, enrolled for Fall-23 semester and in good standing (preference given to A&H or So-Sci majors and under-served students with high need). Interested students should apply by July 31; questions may be directed to Shana Love.
Full Time RA Position in Cognitive Neuroscience at UCSB:
The Jacobs lab at UCSB is recruiting a full time RA/lab manager, effective immediately. Come join us in gorgeous Santa Barbara to learn multimodal neuroimaging and endocrinology, while advancing women's brain health. This is a perfect stepping stone to a PhD in cognitive neuroscience. Link to apply: https://recruit.ap.ucsb.edu/JPF02503 
Open Slots for Readers, Tutors and GSIs for INFO Courses:
We are currently accepting applications for our Fall 2023 INFO positions. Please review the important eligibility for these positions below.
Data Science (DATASCI) and Cybersecurity (CYBER) courses follow the MIDS & MICS program academic calendar. Data Science and Cybersecurity courses are online; readers and tutors hired in those programs do not need to be physically in Berkeley, but do need to be physically in the United States and eligible to work in the United States (see below).
Information (INFO) courses follow the UC Berkeley academic calendar. Unless stated on the application, all Information courses are in-person held on the UC Berkeley campus; GSIs, readers, and tutors hired in this program need to be physically located in Berkeley for in-person employment and eligible to work in the United States (see below).
Positions less than 25% (10 hours per week) do not include fee remission. Apply for Fall 2023 Positions here. 
Scholarship Opportunities:
Leon M. Poe Scholarship 
The Leon M. Poe Scholarship promotes diversity, equity and inclusion of college minority students majoring in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) to successful career selection by providing tools, mentorship and scholarship. Students must be enrolled or accepted to a 4-year accredited college or university, as a full-time student, in the United States as of September following the awarding of the scholarship. Students must have a minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4-point scale.

Students must be obtaining a degree in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering or Mathematics) fields. Students must be considered a minority, i.e., gender, race or ethnicity. Application must be completed in 280 characters or less per prompt. Application is due by August 4th. The Leon M Poe Scholarship Foundation was founded by Edana Jones. She is a graduate of Alabama A&M University, where she obtained a Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering.
GeneTex Scholarship 
GeneTex believes in accelerating scientific advancement and the notion that the genesis of future discoveries begins with the support of young scientists now. The GeneTex Scholarship Program will award a $2000 (USD) scholarship to students pursuing a STEM undergraduate or graduate degree. Scholarship funds will be paid directly to the university at which the recipient is enrolled. The university will then distribute the funds to the recipient.
Each eligible application will be reviewed by a committee of three to five GeneTex employees. The selection of the scholarship recipient will be based on the committee's determination of the application that best aligns with GeneTex's values and mission statement. We require your most recent transcript (an unofficial transcript is acceptable) to show that you are in good academic standing. If you are an incoming university student or transfer student, please provide a letter of acceptance or some equivalent form of documentation to show that you will be attending that university. The winner will be chosen and contacted 1-2 weeks after the deadline has passed and announced on our website shortly after.
Power Life Sciences Scholarship
This scholarship is our way to support talented university and college students who are passionate about biomedical and biopharmaceutical innovation. Clinical trials surface a ton of data every year‚Äìbut aspiring innovators and clinicians need to learn how to contextualize, interpret, and dig deeper into that information in order to make sound decisions. Clinical Trial Data Notes is our peer-reviewed journal with the mission to improve outcomes for patients and sponsors by increasing the volume, quality, and utility of data available to all members of the clinical trial ecosystem.

This scholarship will not be awarded on the basis of academic performance; the selection will be based on an ability to critically analyze real clinical trial data in the style of our journal. Importantly, scholarship winners will be eligible for publication in our journal if that is of interest to them. Applicants must submit a Data Note analysis of clinical trials in the style of our journal (max 5 pages).
Ella Lyman Cabot Trust Grants:
The Trust was established in 1939 by Dr. Richard C. Cabot , a pioneering and innovative Boston physician, to honor the memory of his wife, Ella Lyman Cabot, and the work of the Trust is carried on today by the Trustees of the Ella Lyman Cabot Trust. Dr. and Mrs. Cabot believed strongly in the individual‚Äôs ability to make a positive difference in the world. The criteria by which the Trustees make decisions on grants are based on the lives and ideals of the Cabots, who, during their lives, contributed greatly to the fields of medicine, social work, ethics, education and religious studies.
While there is no formal limit on the size of an individual grant, the trustees expect grants to be in the range of $15,000 per applicant, and do not anticipate granting any individual support in excess of $25,000. The ELCT does not grant renewals or follow-up grants.
Applications can be submitted throughout the year, although grants are made only twice: in the Spring (usually May) and the Fall (usually December). Applications for Fall open early October.
The Gates Scholarship:
The Gates Scholarship (TGS) is a highly selective, last-dollar scholarship for outstanding, minority, high school seniors from low-income households. Each year, the scholarship is awarded to exceptional student leaders, with the intent of helping them realize their maximum potential. Scholars will receive funding for the full cost of attendance* that is not already covered by other financial aid and the expected family contribution, as determined by the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA), or the methodology used by a Scholar‚Äôs college or university.
Luce Scholars:
Established in 1974, the Luce Scholars Program is a nationally competitive fellowship that offers early-career leaders immersive, professional experiences in Asia. We aim to forge stronger relationships across geographic borders by creating opportunities for young Americans to deepen their ties and understanding of the countries, cultures, and people of Asia. Open to U.S. citizens and permanent residents, the Luce Scholars Program provides stipends, language training, and individualized professional placement in Asia for 18 Luce Scholars each year. We welcome applications from college seniors, graduate students, and young professionals in a variety of fields, with a range of backgrounds and experiences, who have had limited exposure to Asia. 
Applications for the 2024‚Äì2025 Luce Scholars competition will open on April 25, 2023. The application deadline is October 16th at 5:00 pm ET.
Global Rhodes Scholarship:
The Rhodes Scholarship, one of the most competitive and prestigious awards, funds two or three years of post-bachelor study at the University of Oxford in Great Britain. The award covers educational and living expenses. Initiated after the death of Cecil Rhodes in 1902, the scholarships bring outstanding students from nineteen countries and five continents to Oxford University. Two Global Rhodes Scholarships will be awarded during the 2022‚Äì2023 application cycle.
Apply by July 20, 2023
Rhodes Scholarship:

 Campus Deadline - Noon, August 15, 2023

Opportunities:
National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowships
The purpose of the National Science Foundation (NSF) Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP) is to help ensure the quality, vitality, and diversity of the scientific and engineering workforce of the United States. The program recognizes and supports outstanding graduate students who are pursuing full-time research-based master's and doctoral degrees in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) or in STEM education. The GRFP provides three years of support over a five-year fellowship period for the graduate education of individuals who have demonstrated their potential for significant research achievements in STEM or STEM education. NSF actively encourages women, persons who are members of groups historically underrepresented in STEM, persons with disabilities, veterans, and undergraduate seniors to apply. The five-year fellowship provides three years of financial support inclusive of an annual stipend of $37,000. Applications for GRFP 2024 will open in July. More information about the fellowship can be found here. 
Open Cognition and Language Position at Northwestern University:
The Cognition and Language Lab at Northwestern University, headed by Dedre Gentner, is seeking a postdoctoral fellow to collaborate on research on analogical processing and on how analogical skills can be improved. Qualifications: Knowledge of analogical research and of cognitive processing in general; proficiency in experimental design & statistical analysis; excellent scientific writing skills. In addition, knowledge of linguistics, including corpus tools, is desirable. Knowledge of and/or experience with cognitive development is a plus. Please provide three references. Desired start date: Summer or Fall 2023 The official NU listing isn‚Äôt up yet. Please send an email to gentner@northwestern.edu. 

NSF: Research Experiences for Undergraduates:
NSF funds a large number of research opportunities for undergraduate students through its REU Sites program. An REU Site consists of a group of ten or so undergraduates who work in the research programs of the host institution. Each student is associated with a specific research project, where he/she works closely with the faculty and other researchers. Students are granted stipends and, in many cases, assistance with housing and travel. Undergraduate students supported with NSF funds must be citizens or permanent residents of the United States or its possessions. An REU Site may be at either a US or foreign location.
By using the web page, search for an REU Site, and you may examine opportunities in the subject areas supported by various NSF units. Also, you may search by keywords to identify sites in particular research areas or with certain features, such as a particular location.
Students must contact the individual sites for information and application materials. NSF does not have application materials and does not select student participants. A contact person and contact information is listed for each site.
Undergraduate Internship Program Application Extension: 
Internship Prep & Connect Applications Are Now Open! The Cal Career Center is piloting an exciting new equity-oriented program aiming to prepare undergraduate students to work in an internship by boosting their Career Readiness and connecting them with employers that offer internship opportunities. The program consists of five robust modules that address aspects of Career Readiness as defined by the National Association of Colleges and Employers (NACE). Upon completion of the program, students will receive a certificate of completion and attend an exclusive networking event. In order to be eligible to participate, students should hold 2nd or 3rd year status, enrolled for Fall-23 semester and in good standing (preference given to A&H or So-Sci majors and under-served students with high need). Interested students should apply by July 31; questions may be directed to Shana Love.

Full Time RA Position in Cognitive Neuroscience at UCSB:
The Jacobs lab at UCSB is recruiting a full time RA/lab manager, effective immediately. Come join us in gorgeous Santa Barbara to learn multimodal neuroimaging and endocrinology, while advancing women's brain health. This is a perfect stepping stone to a PhD in cognitive neuroscience. Link to apply: https://recruit.ap.ucsb.edu/JPF02503 
UCEAP Opportunities for Spring and Fall:
 UCEAP or the University of California Education Abroad Program offers internship opportunities for your desired field of interest in a wide variety of international and domestic territories. The list below denotes the STEM focused opportunities but should not be considered a complete list. To see a comprehensive list of the available UCEAP Opportunities, log in with your CalNet to the Berkeley Discovery Hub. Due to processing time and officialization, it is advised to apply early for these life-changing study abroad opportuinties. 
UCEAP China: Summer Global Internship, Shanghai: Skyscrapers and high-speed transportation strike a balance with ancient cobbled streets and tea houses in Shanghai, a global economic hub. Build professional work experience interning with an organization on a project that matches your career goals. Many organizations welcome interns to technology, health or life sciences, communication, and social development projects. 
UCEAP Taiwan: Research in Taipei: Gain research skills over the summer at the prestigious National Taiwan University in Taipei. Working in ultramodern labs with local faculty, complete a research project and acquire experience that you can take anywhere after graduation. Areas of research include agriculture, biotechnology, computer science, engineering, law, liberal arts, management, medicine, public health, and science. Take an engaging course exploring the island of Taiwan and its people. With other students, you‚Äôll visit a night market, mountain-top village, Chinese temples, and other cultural sites. Experience Taipei‚Äôs cuisine at night markets and street stalls. On weekends, soak in the hot and cold springs, and discover blue-water beaches perfect for swimming and surfing.
UCEAP Hong Kong: Research in Hong Kong: Spend the summer developing hands-on research skills and knowledge at the Chinese University of Hong Kong. An excellent starting point for graduate work or a professional career, research areas in science, engineering, humanities, or social sciences. Throughout your project, interact with a faculty supervisor experienced in international research. Rather than formal courses or lectures, you‚Äôll conduct analysis work in the lab or the field. Hong Kong is an expatriate-friendly city and major travel hub to neighboring Asian countries. The campus is in a beautiful area with panoramic views of the harbor and the mountains. During downtime, you can climb Victoria Peak or treat yourself to some delicious local cuisine.
UCEAP Czech Republic: Summer Internship, Prague: Give your career a boost with an 8-week internship in Prague, one of Central Europe‚Äôs economic and cultural capitals. Gain marketable skills in fields such as STEM, humanities, and social science, while experiencing the city‚Äôs Old World ambiance. A multicultural workplace course helps you make the most of your internship with coaching sessions and assignments. Program excursions introduce you to business centers and cultural sites. Discover Prague‚Äôs gothic architecture, ice pubs, and medieval castles. Wander cobblestone streets to experience its caf√© culture, expansive parks, and rich arts scene.
UCEAP United Kingdom: Summer Research in Glasgow: Got a research topic you've always wanted to pursue? Take your curiosity and ideas to Scotland, where you'll build a strong relationship with faculty mentors on a program that mimics graduate school. No large lecture halls and no anonymity. You'll focus on a single research topic in life science, chemistry, or history and present your results in the form of a research article at a mock conference. On weekends, dance the lively Scottish c√®ilidh to traditional folk music, visit a 13th-century castle, hike in Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park.
UCEAP Singapore: Undergraduate STEM Research in Singapore: Singapore, one of the world‚Äôs most futuristic cities, is a dream location for this high-level STEM internship. Pursue your passion for research and answer the most pressing questions in your field. Contribute to project phases from the development of research plans and proposals, to data analysis and results presentations. Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) has a vibrant innovation and entrepreneurship culture fostered by the SUTD Entrepreneurship Centre. Outside the lab, a world of cultural adventures await as the island state has seen a mass transformation. Autonomous taxis cruise the streets, solar-celled super trees grow plants for food, and a glass biome houses a cloud forest.
Volunteer Research Assistants and Data Analysts Needed for Substance Use Disorders, Digital Mental Health, and Health Disparities Research:
Research assistants are needed for several ongoing projects at the VA Palo Alto Healthcare System. Opportunities for remote work are available. The PI of the projects is Natalia Van Doren, a former Cal Bear and current PhD candidate at Penn State University. She is currently a clinical psychology intern at the VA Palo Alto Healthcare system and will be transitioning to a NIDA T32 postdoctoral research fellowship at UCSF in Oct 2023. She is looking for several volunteer research assistants to help with ongoing projects, as described below: Virtual Reality Mindfulness Training Study: This project will examine the feasibility and acceptability of a novel mindfulness training platform delivered via VR headsets for veterans undergoing residential substance use treatment. Research assistants will have the opportunity to test the VR headsets, guide veterans through the research protocol, gather feedback from veterans via focus groups, and engage in qualitative coding of the data. In addition, there are opportunities for quantitative data collection and analysis, literature review, and drafting the paper. Data analysts are needed to assist with analyzing data across 5 timepoints using latent transition analysis. Preference for those with experience using MPlus, but training is available for those that do not. To apply, contact Natalia Van Doren at nzv7@psu.edu, with the following information: ‚óè Current year at Cal ‚óè Prior research experience (not required) ‚óè Career goals/aspirations ‚óè Which of the studies you are interested in ‚óè Time commitment (minimum of 3 hours/week is preferred).
Open Slots for Readers, Tutors and GSIs for INFO Courses:

Data Science (DATASCI) and Cybersecurity (CYBER) courses follow the MIDS & MICS program academic calendar. Data Science and Cybersecurity courses are online; readers and tutors hired in those programs do not need to be physically in Berkeley, but do need to be physically in the United States and eligible to work in the United States (see below).

Unless stated on the application, all Information courses are in-person held on the UC Berkeley campus; GSIs, readers, and tutors hired in this program need to be physically located in Berkeley for in-person employment and eligible to work in the United States (see below).
Positions less than 25% (10 hours per week) do not include fee remission. Apply for Fall 2023 Positions here.

Ella Lyman Cabot Trust Grants:
The Trust was established in 1939 by Dr. Richard C. Cabot , a pioneering and innovative Boston physician, to honor the memory of his wife, Ella Lyman Cabot, and the work of the Trust is carried on today by the Trustees of the Ella Lyman Cabot Trust. Dr. and Mrs. Cabot believed strongly in the individual‚Äôs ability to make a positive difference in the world. The criteria by which the Trustees make decisions on grants are based on the lives and ideals of the Cabots, who, during their lives, contributed greatly to the fields of medicine, social work, ethics, education and religious studies.
While there is no formal limit on the size of an individual grant, the trustees expect grants to be in the range of $15,000 per applicant, and do not anticipate granting any individual support in excess of $25,000. The ELCT does not grant renewals or follow-up grants.
Applications can be submitted throughout the year, although grants are made only twice: in the Spring (usually May) and the Fall (usually December). Applications for Fall open early October.
The Gates Scholarship:
The Gates Scholarship (TGS) is a highly selective, last-dollar scholarship for outstanding, minority, high school seniors from low-income households. Each year, the scholarship is awarded to exceptional student leaders, with the intent of helping them realize their maximum potential. Scholars will receive funding for the full cost of attendance* that is not already covered by other financial aid and the expected family contribution, as determined by the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA), or the methodology used by a Scholar‚Äôs college or university.
Luce Scholars:
Established in 1974, the Luce Scholars Program is a nationally competitive fellowship that offers early-career leaders immersive, professional experiences in Asia. We aim to forge stronger relationships across geographic borders by creating opportunities for young Americans to deepen their ties and understanding of the countries, cultures, and people of Asia. Open to U.S. citizens and permanent residents, the Luce Scholars Program provides stipends, language training, and individualized professional placement in Asia for 18 Luce Scholars each year. We welcome applications from college seniors, graduate students, and young professionals in a variety of fields, with a range of backgrounds and experiences, who have had limited exposure to Asia. 
Applications for the 2024‚Äì2025 Luce Scholars competition will open on April 25, 2023. The application deadline is October 16th at 5:00 pm ET.
A remote Luce Scholars Info Session will be held on Wednesday, June 14, 2023 from 12:00-1:00 pm (PDT) Pre-registration is required.

Dr. Wilsaan Joiner's Sensorimotor Integration (SMI) Laboratory at the University of California, Davis in Sacramento invites qualified candidates to apply for positions as junior specialists for an ongoing grant awarded to Dr. Wilsaan Joiner. The junior specialist position is fantastic for those interested in more research exposure. 
For more information about the lab, please visit https://joinermotorlab.weebly.com/
Please complete the application at: https://recruit.ucdavis.edu/JPF05660
Applications can only be accepted via the UC Davis Recruit website. Positions have a one-year appointment with an additional year based on performance, and we strongly consider applicants who can consider a two-year commitment. For any additional questions about the positions, please contact Lindsey Young at lcyoung@ucdavis.edu. 
The Self, Identity, & Relationships (SIR) Lab is recruiting RAs for a Sleep and Social Interactions (SASI) Study
This study is ideal for undergraduates who are curious about social psychology research, particularly in the domains of interpersonal relationships, identity, and sleep. RAs will receive valuable training and mentorship that will contribute to their preparation for graduate school or other career aspirations.
The ideal applicant will meet the following criteria:
Able to commit a minimum of 6 hours per week (sessions are scheduled Tuesday through Friday 9:00-2:00 only).
Commitment of a minimum of two semesters (can start this summer and then continue into the academic year)
Enthusiastic about interacting directly with participants ‚Äì our RAs tend to be sociable, creative, and quick on their feet.
No prior research experience is required, just a good attitude and willingness to learn!
Lab Manager Position Open at Cornell University: 
The Lab Manager position at the Business Simulation Lab of SC Johnson College of Business, Cornell University is opening. This job is a great opportunity for anyone considering a PhD in business schools, social psychology and behavioral sciences! Here is the job link posting with more information: https://cornell.wd1.myworkdayjobs.com/en-US/CornellCareerPage/job/Business-Simulation-Lab -Manager_WDR-00036483-1. 
We will begin reviewing applications on May 15. So, all interested applicants should submit their materials by this date. 
Course Coordinator Positions Open: 
The Sutardja Center for Entrepreneurship & Technology (SCET) is currently seeking Course Coordinators for our Fall 2023 courses. These positions are open to both undergraduate and graduate students. These are hourly paid positions that will support accomplished industry instructors and their curriculum and they will get exposure to successful industry professionals and entrepreneurs. Specific responsibilities will vary by class and instructor. Students can learn more and about the positions and apply HERE. And can see our Fall 2023 classes HERE. If there are any questions please have them email SCET at scet-academics@berkeley.edu.
The Walker Lab (Psychology Department) is looking for Research Assistants:
The Walker Lab is looking to build a team of research assistants, to assist with our sleep study. Primarily, this study is focused on understanding the role of sleep in healthy aging, versus what goes wrong in Alzheimer's disease. We are looking for RAs who are motivated, enjoy in-person interactions with our participants (who are usually so kind, and have awesome life stories and wisdom!), and willing to learn some fundamental neuroscience training - primarily gaining experience with EEG methods, and in some cases, in addition - assistance running participants in an MRI scanner. All training will be provided by our lab members, assuming no baseline knowledge, so this is a great starter position. Knowledge of basic psychology/neuroscience concepts from undergrad classes, or past RA experience, is a plus and would help with the ramp up! Please feel free to reach out at vyoma@berkeley.edu with any questions!
CER Summer Workshop:
The Center for Ethnographic Research (CER) Summer Workshop provides mentorship, hands-on research experience, and advanced training in designing and executing a project using qualitative methods for motivated undergraduates and beginning graduate students. The CER Summer Workshop will provide students with six weeks of intensive accelerated methodological training in the design and practice of qualitative methods in weekly seminars. The topics in the seminars include the following:
The Logic and Practice of Qualitative Research Design
Participant Observation
In-Depth Interviewing
Qualitative Data Analysis
In addition to these group meetings, each participant will meet individually with the instructor and receive feedback on research project development and design. 
During the CER workshop, students develop an empirical research project proposal for an honors thesis, masters thesis, advanced methods class, scholarly article, or conference presentation. In this process, students develop hands-on research and logistical experience and receive structure and guidance in the development of an independent and original project. Students will walk away with a refined 6-page research proposal for an honors thesis, masters thesis, graduate school, or fellowship application. They will also gain first-hand experience in qualitative research data collection and analysis methods through a collective research project conducted during the six weeks of the workshop (May 22 - June 29).
There will be six hours/week of group meetings. In addition, participants are expected to meet weekly with the instructor on their individual projects. Participants should expect to spend about 20 hours per week in seminars, meetings, and completing assignments.
Click here for program details and application
Summer research assistant position focusing on Neurobiology: 
Investigation of the mechanism of sleep pressure and its dysregulation in Parkinson's disease:
Sleep problems are a common symptom of Parkinson‚Äôs disease (PD) and in some cases an early warning sign before movement deficits. Sleep problems in PD are diverse and can be made worse by medications that treat other PD symptoms by affecting dopamine or norepinephrine levels in the brain. While dopamine- and norepinephrine-releasing neurons (DA and NE neurons) are involved in regulating sleep and are among the first neurons to degenerate in PD, it is unknown if sleep and degeneration have common molecular components. Emerging evidence has shown that reactive oxygen species (ROS) accumulate during steady DA and NE neuron activity and that these neurons are inhibited by elevated ROS. It remains to be determined if ROS levels accumulate during prolonged wakefulness and if sleep helps to recover from the cellular oxidative stress imposed by ROS. The proposed research will employ cutting-edge imaging of DA, NE, and ROS dynamics using fiber photometry, optical stimulation of ROS production, and genetic manipulations in mouse models. This project will advance our understanding of how ROS affect sleep quality and whether sleep is protective against the unabated oxidative stress associated with PD.
The project will involve 1) brain sectioning, histology and fluorescent imaging to identify crucial redox enzymes in monoaminergic neurons, 2) constructing EEG/EMG electrodes for sleep recording in mouse models and 3) PCR genotyping to identify mice for experiments 4) analysis of sleep recording data using Matlab (programing experience is not a requirement).
The student can start working in the laboratory as soon as they would like (hopefully before June) and continue working with us throughout the summer. At the end of the summer we will discuss whether they would like to join the lab through the URAP program in the fall and spring
If interested, please contact Daniel Silverman at dsilverman@berkeley.edu to schedule a brief interview.
Psych 101 GSI/UGSI Summer Positions Still Available
Do you love data? Are you thinking about applying for a PhD? Consider teaching on the Psych 101 team this summer! We have an open position to serve as a GSI/UGSI for Psych 101 this summer.
Term: Summer 2023
Instructor: Ryan Lundell-Creagh
Course #: Psych 101
Course Title: Research and Data Analysis in Psychology
Lecture Day/Time: M, W, F 4:00-6:00pm
If you are interested, please apply here!
If you have any questions about this, you can reach out to Christine Mullarkey at
psychgradadvisor@berkeley.edu.
2023 EBI Internship Program:
The Energy & Biosciences Institute (EBI) collaborates with local biotech and venture capital (VC) companies to offer hands-on, paid summer internships to undergraduate and master's students from UC Berkeley and UIUC. EBI is actively seeking outstanding applicants to fill 8-week internship positions that will provide students with training and experience in scientific techniques or VC investment strategies as part of interdisciplinary projects. Successful interns will have the opportunity to become part-time or full-time paid employees of the biotech company for the duration of the internship. Description of intern opportunities linked at the bottom of the page.
Interns will:
Acquire valuable, real-world industry experience and training on a long-term project;
Earn a competitive salary;
Explore career options and define the direction for graduate studies;
Network with a variety of industries, EBI, and student participants;
Develop new technical, communication, time management, and leadership skills
Participating Companies:
Izote Biosciences is a dynamic startup at the forefront of revolutionizing the field of industrial fermentation, spun out from the world-renowned John Coates lab at UC Berkeley. Our innovative precision fermentation technology removes the requirement for oxygen in the fermentation process, enabling us to produce high-quality, sustainable products with reduced costs and environmental impact. We seek a talented and enthusiastic Microbiology Research Intern to join our team and contribute to our exciting, paradigm-shifting work. As a Microbiology Research Intern at Izote Biosciences, you will work alongside a team of experienced researchers, gaining hands-on experience in molecular biology and fermentation techniques. You will have the opportunity to contribute to cutting-edge research, including developing new fermentation technologies and optimizing our precision fermentation process. We offer a competitive hourly wage of $22 per hour for this paid internship position and a supportive work environment. We are committed to fostering a diverse and inclusive workplace and welcome applicants from all backgrounds. 
Fortiphyte develops disease resistant crop varieties to improve the safety, productivity, and environmental sustainability of agriculture. We use a variety of methods including high-throughput sequencing, genetic screens, proteomics, bioinformatics and genome engineering to discover and deploy naturally occurring disease resistance traits.
Little Green Bamboo is a silicon-valley outsider venture fund focused on social impact and deep science. Our goal is to align impact with profit, because we believe that impact is ultimately not sustainable and scalable without profit. The two must go hand in hand. The way we achieve this is by investing in the right people at the right time. This is why we invest in diverse scientists who are both humble and bold, in the pre-seed stage.
      Apply between Apr 14, 2023 ‚Äì May 14, 2023
      Jun 1, 2023 ‚Äì Aug 16, 2023
      Job Descriptions linked Here and more information can be found here
Scholarship Opportunities:
PG&E Better Together STEM Scholarship Program:
The PG&E Corporation Foundation is currently offering Better Together STEM Scholarships of $2,500 or $10,000 to students pursuing STEM-related studies at universities in California and Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) in the United States. Students must be California residents and PG&E customers at the time of application.
Applications are open to graduating high school seniors, current college students, veterans and adults returning to school who plan to enroll in full-time undergraduate study in an eligible STEM field at an accredited four-year college or university in California or an HBCU in the United States for the entire 2022-2023 academic year.
Apply by June 1st, 2023. 
Collegiate Inventors Competition:
The Collegiate Inventors Competition is designed to encourage college students to be active in science, engineering, mathematics, technology, and creative invention while stimulating their problem solving abilities. The competition recognizes the working relationship between a student and his or her advisor who is involved in projects leading to inventions that can be patented. One undergraduate winner or team will receive $15,000; their academic advisors will each receive $5,000. One Grand Prize student will receive $25,000; the advisor will receive $15,000. Check back in the spring for information on the 2023 competition.
Individual Eligibility: Any part-time or full-time student enrolled in a U.S. college or university is eligible to enter. Students must have been enrolled at least part-time during the academic year in which they are competing.
Team Eligibility: In the case of a team, all team members must be enrolled as either part-time or full-time students. Students must have been enrolled at least part-time during the academic year in which they are competing.
Citizenship Non-U.S. citizens are eligible, as long as they are enrolled in a U.S. college or university and can meet the student eligibility status.
Patent Entries are ineligible if (1) the invention has already been patented or disclosed by another party/inventor, or (2) you have been issued a patent for the invention more than one year prior to the date of submission to the competition.
Apply by June 5, 2023
Global Rhodes Scholarship
The Rhodes Scholarship, one of the most competitive and prestigious awards, funds two or three years of post-bachelor study at the University of Oxford in Great Britain. The award covers educational and living expenses. Initiated after the death of Cecil Rhodes in 1902, the scholarships bring outstanding students from nineteen countries and five continents to Oxford University. Two Global Rhodes Scholarships will be awarded during the 2022‚Äì2023 application cycle.
Apply by Jul 20, 2023
TBB Fellowship: 
Transcending Beyond Berkeley (TBB) Fellowship 23-24 Applications Are Open: The Transcending Beyond Berkeley (TBB) Fellowship provides students with tools to present their education, experience, and skills effectively in a professional environment and to thrive, regardless of immigration status. Fellows are paired with a campus department to complete a project that aligns with the department's mission and receive a scholarship for their participation in the fellowship. To be eligible, students must not be eligible for federal aid; be CA Dream Aid recipients and/or be undocumented; and must be a continuing student for the 2023-24 academic year. Students should submit their application by May 12.
Generation Google Scholarship: 
The Generation Google Scholarship was established to help aspiring students pursuing computer science degrees excel in technology and become leaders in the field. Selected students will receive $10,000 USD (for those studying in the US) or $5,000 CAD (for those studying in Canada) for the 2023-2024 school year. The Generation Google Scholarship will be awarded based on the strength of each candidate's commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion, demonstrated leadership, and academic performance.
Deadline closes May 19th!
AIAS Foundation Scholarship: 
Applicants to the AIAS Foundation Scholarship must intend to pursue a career or working as an early professional in any aspect of game development including but not limited to: art, animation, programming, engineering, game direction, game design, sound design, law, marketing, and business administration.
General Eligibility
‚Ä¢ Must be a full-time undergraduate student or a graduate student attending an accredited college or university during the 2023-24 academic school year OR or working as an early professional (within their first two years in the industry).
‚Ä¢ Must be 21 years or older by February 1st, 2024. If under 21, must acknowledge that they are not eligible to participate in activities during D.I.C.E. Summit including the mentor program on site.*
‚Ä¢ Major: Any field
‚Ä¢ GPA: 3.3 minimum on a 4.0 scale
Applications must be submitted by May 31, 2023.
AFCEA Stem Major Scholarship: 
As a conduit to the advancement of STEM education, the foundation cultivates and perpetuates funding that supports its mission, making a difference in all areas of education, from the students to the teachers to the workforce. Our programs exist to ensure tomorrow‚Äôs workforce has the necessary technical skills to be competitive in the fast-paced, ever-changing global security arena. 
Eligibility:
Must be a U.S. citizen or permanent resident. 
Undergraduate candidates must be at least second-year college students enrolled as sophomores or juniors full-time in a four-year college or university at the time of application. 
Must have a current overall GPA of 3.0 or higher.
Students must major in a STEM-related area of study in support of the mission of AFCEA. 
Qualifying STEM majors related to the mission of AFCEA include: astronomy, biometry/biometrics, computer engineering, computer forensics science, computer programming, computer science, computer systems, cybersecurity, electrical engineering, electronics engineering, geospatial science, industrial engineering, information science, information technology, information resource management, intelligence, mathematics, mechanical engineering, network engineering, network security, operations research, physics, robotics engineering, robotics technology, statistics, strategic intelligence and telecommunications engineering.
Applications Due: May 31st
Events and Occasions:
The Call of Things:
All Day - May 15th
 Environmental Design Library - 210 ‚Äì Bauer Wurster Hall
 Repeats daily (to May 19) ‚Äî Event Link
The Call of Things uses ‚Äòtalking objects‚Äô to challenge anthropocentrism, foregrounding the entanglement of advanced capitalism, colonialism, and environmental injustice in the North and South Poles. Viewers can ‚Äòcall‚Äô objects with their phones and listen to oral narratives and field recordings related to each polar artifact. The contributors range across disciplines, including ecologists, Indigenous leaders, sea ice, philosophers, poets, whales, and writers. Speaking to the variety of interventions that privilege the human over the beyond-human spaces and species, many voices offer alternative possibilities for stewardship and sustainability.
The contributors range across disciplines and life forms, including former chair of the Inuit Circumpolar Council, Okalik Eegeesiak; Berkeley Scholar-in-Residence and author Lisa E. Bloom; glaciologist Dr. Richard Alley; sea ice; and whales. The Call of Things situates the climate crisis in relation to social justice, questions of sovereignty, Indigenous rights, and political histories of land. It creates a platform for non-anthropocentric experiences, where stories are also told through animal songs and sounds of ice. Knowledge is situated and embedded in its polar contexts, drawing upon the convergences of multiple perspectives and temporalities needed to collectively re-imagine our world. - Jessica Houston, artist
Contact Info: deifler@berkeley.edu
Integral Taiji and Qigong:
May 19, 2023 11 a.m. - Noon
 UC Botanical Garden at Berkeley ‚Äì Event Link
Join us for a Friday late morning Integral Taiji & Qigong class. This class focuses on embodied, psycho-spiritual, ecological, and cosmological dimensions of qigong and taiji (tai chi). We will practice standing meditation, walking meditation, the Microcosmic Orbit, Taiji Ruler, the Eight Treasures, cleansing the internal organs, embodying the elements, and more. Everyone is invited to participate, regardless of prior experience. Children are welcome if accompanied by an adult (with Garden admission). Please wear comfortable clothes and shoes, and bring layers for warmth and sun-protection. Space is limited; registration required.
Class will be on the Oak Knoll at the Garden. While we plan to hold this event outdoors, weather may require us to move indoors. Per UC policy, masks are optional indoors. Please let us know if you have accessibility questions.
Information: Register Here
Contact Info:
Garden Programs
 510-664-7606
 gardenprograms@berkeley.edu
BCORE Workshop V: Master Your Story in the Interview:
May 24, 2023, 9 a.m. - Noon
 Virtual Classroom ‚Äî Event Link
Welcome to the Berkeley Career Opportunities and Resources for Equity pilot program! This program is designed to support you in your career aspirations as a part of an overall strategy by the university to increase diversity in leadership as expressed in the public commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion. BCORE is an eight-week experience made up of a series of virtual convenings focused on different aspects of realizing career aspirations. It is designed to support you in gaining an understanding of how to navigate the culture, structures, practices, and processes at the university that serve to perpetuate and sustain inequity that can be predicted by race. This pilot program will complement the numerous professional development resources available to the UCB workforce.
Speaker: Pcyeta Stroud, MBA, RSS Consulting
Contact Info: (510) 642-7053
Access Coordinator: Justin Dunbar, justin3030@berkeley.edu, 559-817-0033
L&S Student Support & Advocacy
The College of Letters & Science is committed to helping provide a safe and supportive environment for all students at UC Berkeley, free of bias, harassment, violence, and discrimination. The L&S Student Support & Advocacy page contains resources related to campus grievance procedures and other useful information. 
UHS LGBTQ+ Mental Health Resources
Group counseling is available on a drop-in basis through UHS for a number of populations, including the LGBTQIA+ Support Group, the Gender Support Group, and the BIPOC Queer Womxn‚Äôs Support Circle. Group counseling offers the opportunity for students to learn new skills, to share concerns as well as inherent wisdom in a facilitated environment with other students. Visit the UHS Group Counseling webpage for information about all available groups and referral pathways to get started. 
Student Technology Equity Program (STEP)
UC Berkeley provides technology support for undergraduate and graduate students that may prove valuable for your students, including free software, device lending, and the student tech support helpdesk. The Student Technology Equity Program (STEP) continues to provide long-term loans for laptops, Wi-Fi hotspots and other tech hardware to students with need (e.g. financial need, instructional role, etc.).
Staying Connected
Instagram @calcogsci 
Twitter @calcogsci
Click here for CogSci mailing list on Piazza

["Cognitive Science Newsletter
Monday, May 1st, 2023
Cog Sci Department News
Commencement is nearly here!
A sincere congratulations to all Graduates! You should all be extremely proud of yourselves and you all have a bright future ahead. We will be missing you very much and wish you the best as you embark on your career journey!
Campus-wide commencement will take place on Saturday, May 13 at 10:30 am in the California Memorial Stadium. The Cognitive Science (ISSP) Commencement will take place on May 15th, 9 am at the Greek Theatre. 
See you there! 
Pre-orders available now for 2022-2023 Yearbook!
The Blue & Gold yearbook has been preserving snapshots of UC Berkeley culture, student life, facts, figures, and historical moments since 1875. Our mission is to truthfully encapsulate the current, unique Berkeley identity‚Äì as students, for the students. Don‚Äôt miss out on having a physical copy of memories, events and highlights of the school year all packed into one single book. You can now Pre-Order the book by visiting our shop, yearbook.berkeley.edu/shop. Questions? Email us at info.bgyearbook@gmail.com!
**Graduating students can have their portraits taken and can find more information on the Blue & Gold Official Website.**

May 12th: End of the Semester
May 22nd: Summer Session A begins. 
 Opportunities:
Research Opportunity regarding Child Psychology/Social Development:
Cooperation and Social Reasoning in Children
Jan Engelmann, Professor 
 Psychology 
Open. Apprentices needed for the spring semester. Enter your application on the web beginning January 10th. The deadline to apply is Monday, January 23rd, at 4 PM.
How do children reason? How strongly is reasoning embedded in social, cognitive processes?The goal of this project is to investigate how children‚Äôs tendencies for reasoning and cooperation inform one another. We aim to understand how the interplay of these processes develops, from early childhood into middle childhood. The subset of studies involved in this project focus on children's reasoning, beliefs, and interactions with others. Research assistants will be hired to work on one of these studies.
Role: Research assistants will be involved in data collection, coding video data, and assisting with administrative tasks. Students should expect to be heavily involved in multiple aspects of the research projects and gain a well-rounded understanding of the research process..

Required time commitment is approximately 9hrs/wk for at least two semesters.
Previous research experience beneficial but not required
Day-to-day supervisor for this project: Eliza Swindell, Staff Researcher
Related website: https://socialorigins.berkeley.edu/
Collider Cup XII:
 Collider Cup XII is a program that will feature Berkeley students (with most colleges and schools and dozens of majors represented) pitching their unique venture projects to panels of industry judges. There will be networking and free food at the event as well as information about SCET Fall 2023 courses. (Our courses are open to all majors and levels at Berkeley and count towards the Certificate in Entrepreneurship & Technology.).
SCET is excited to announce registration is open for this semester's Collider Cup! The competitive showcase pitch event will feature student venture pitches from Berkeley SCET courses, networking and free lunch with faculty, investors, students, and public, and information about Fall 2023 courses and our Certificate in Entrepreneurship & Technology.
Student venture teams will compete to win the Collider Cup and for prizes from TechCrunch, SkyDeck, AWS, Aura Tea, and SCET!
Learn more about this semester's event, including judges, emcee and prizes here.
Register now to reserve your spot. The event will take place on May 5 at 9 a.m. in-person at Sibley Auditorium. The venue has limited seating, so be sure to reserve your ticket ahead of time if you are able to attend.

Click here for program details and application
Cancer Therapy Research Opportunity at UCSF
Informatics for personalized cancer therapy (data science, machine learning, natural language processing, imaging analytics)
Julian Hong, Professor 
 UC San Francisco 
Open. Apprentices needed for the spring semester. Enter your application on the web beginning January 10th. The deadline to apply is Monday, January 23rd, at 4 PM.
The Hong lab is part of the UCSF Department of Radiation Oncology and Bakar Computational Health Sciences Institute. We focus on combining clinical domain knowledge with data science to generate insights from real world data, develop actionable computational tools, and evaluate the benefit of these advances for personalized cancer care. We have a specific interest and expertise in machine learning, natural language processing, computational data extraction, and imaging analytics. We apply these methods to identify new knowledge regarding clinical practice and patient outcomes, make actionable predictions, and identify new interventions. Our lab works from end-to-end along the development and implementation pipeline to develop tools for clinicians to make a meaningful difference in patient care.

The undergraduate apprentice will perform informatics research to develop computational tools and analyses related to personalized oncology care. Specific research topics can be based on the individual's interests and experience but may include wrangling and analyzing clinical (or other) data, developing predictive machine learning algorithms, natural language processing pipelines, or quantitative imaging data extraction.

They will work closely with other lab members and will be expected to conduct data analyses and prepare for presentations at lab meeting and journal clubs as appropriate. The undergraduate will join a multidisciplinary team of clinicians and scientists in the Department of Radiation Oncology and the Bakar Computational Health Sciences Institute. They will also be encouraged to take advantage of other training and learning opportunities within the UCSF Helen Diller Family Comprehensive Cancer Center, the Bakar Computational Health Sciences Institute, and other related entities at UCSF. We hope this experience will prepare the applicant for future opportunities in medicine and informatics.

Qualifications: Currently studying in a quantitative/computational/scientific discipline.
Strong programming skills, with a preference for experience in Python, R, SQL (but flexible).
Strong problem-solving skills.
Related website: http://honglab.ucsf.edu

BIM 88V: UC-wide course: Introduction to Research 
Offered fully online to students of any major from any UC. This course represents and exciting collaboration that crosses multiple UC campuses and your online instruction will include interviews with many faculty across these campuses. Your classmates will be students from UC campuses all over California! The aim of the course is to provide a broad overview about research so you can better understand how being enrolled in the UC system can enable you to engage in cutting edge research, and how research experiences will position you to succeed in college and in your future career.
BIM 088V: Introduction to Research at UC Davis
For the next few offerings:
Spring 2023: starts April 3, last day of classes June 8
Winter 2024: starts Jan 8, last day of classes March 15
Spring 2024 (might not have) Start April 1, last day June 6
Apprentices needed for Research on Children's Linguistic and Cognitive Development
Mahesh Srinivasan, Professor 
 Psychology 
Open. Apprentices needed for the spring semester. Enter your application on the web beginning January 10th. The deadline to apply is Monday, January 23rd, at 4 PM.
The goal of this program is to provide a comprehensive, hands-on research experience to highly motivated students, while making valuable contributions to cognitive science.
Our lab's research explores how linguistic, cognitive, and social abilities arise during human development. A central goal of our research is exploring how these different aspects of development interact with one another. This program is ideal for students who are highly motivated in going to graduate school in psychology, cognitive science, linguistics, or related fields and/or students who are interested in working toward an undergraduate honors thesis.
Role: Students will work closely with the lab manager, graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and each other, and will be involved in many facets of the research process.

This will include reading relevant theoretical and empirical papers, assisting with data collection, assisting with stimuli creation and preparation of study materials, recruiting participants, and processing or analyzing data. Students may also test participants online and in-person. Lastly, students will have the opportunity to attend lab meetings and to present on the projects they are assigned.
Qualifications: SEVEN REQUIREMENTS (Please talk about these in your application):

1) Strong interest in language acquisition and/or cognitive development.
2) Have taken coursework in at least two of the following: Linguistics, Cognitive Science, Computer Science, Psychology, Philosophy, or Statistics.
3) Strong attention to detail.
4) Strong organizational skills
5) Strong communication skills, and a native level of fluency in spoken and written English.
6) Weekend availability to test participants.
7) Have visited our lab website and read about our research before applying

Related website: http://lcdlab.berkeley.edu/

Fung Fellowship:
We are excited to announce that the Fung Fellowship is accepting additional applications for the 2023-24 Conservation + Innovation track. The applications will be reopening today on Friday, April 14 and the deadline to apply is Sunday, May 7.
The Fung Fellowship is a unique opportunity to create impact-driven solutions to address real-world challenges alongside our community and industry partners. Fung Fellows utilize an experiential learning process focused on collaboration, interdisciplinary tactics, and emerging technology.
If you‚Äôre passionate or curious about the natural world and the extraordinary diversity of life on Earth and want to contribute to keeping our planet a healthy, life-sustaining home for millions of species, then the Conservation + Innovation (formerly Conservation + Tech) track may be for you! 
A partnership with the Rausser College of Natural Resources, this track follows the Fung Fellowship model of experiential, team and project-based learning focused on innovating solutions for conservation and environmental health challenges 
As a Fung Fellow in the Conservation + Innovation track you will:
Engage with stakeholder communities to better understand and address their needs for living more harmoniously with nature.
Experience the innovation and design process from prototype to product.
Embed within communities and work with partner organizations to co-create solutions.
Establish yourself as a leader in an emerging field in biodiversity and environmental conservation.
Have access to professional development and exploratory opportunities, such as conferences, site visits, networking events, workshops and other career development resources.
Required qualifications:
Registered undergraduate student at UC Berkeley
Class of 2025 rising junior or Class of 2024 rising senior (current sophomore or junior standing)
Strong passion for conservation, social impact, design, and/or technology
The Fung Fellowship accepts all majors into this program and there is no GPA bracket. Applications are reviewed holistically.
Information to apply: 
Learn more about the program at: fungfellows.berkeley.edu.
Check out a recording of this year‚Äôs info session at: youtu.be/pK7ggsbu76M.
Access the application:
Rising junior or sophomore: bit.ly/FFConservation.
Transfer student: Applications will open on Friday, Apr 24, 2023.
Deadline to apply: Sunday, May 7, 2023 at 11:59pm PT.

Schwarzman Scholars supports up to 200 Scholars annually from the U.S., China, and around the world for a one-year M.A. in Global Affairs at Beijing‚Äôs Tsinghua University. The curriculum bridges the academic and professional worlds to educate students about leadership and about China‚Äôs expanding role in the world. The residential program also provides Scholars with learning opportunities with leaders from China and the world through high-level interactions at lectures, an internship program, a mentor network, and intensive deep-dive travel seminars. Each cohort of Schwarzman Scholars will join a global network of the young leaders who are helping to build stronger links between China and a rapidly changing world.

AFCEA Stem Major Scholarship: 
As a conduit to the advancement of STEM education, the foundation cultivates and perpetuates funding that supports its mission, making a difference in all areas of education, from the students to the teachers to the workforce. Our programs exist to ensure tomorrow‚Äôs workforce has the necessary technical skills to be competitive in the fast-paced, ever-changing global security arena.

Undergraduate candidates must be at least second-year college students enrolled as sophomores or juniors full-time in a four-year college or university at the time of application. 
Must have a current overall GPA of 3.0 or higher.
Students must major in a STEM-related area of study in support of the mission of AFCEA. 
Qualifying STEM majors related to the mission of AFCEA include: astronomy, biometry/biometrics, computer engineering, computer forensics science, computer programming, computer science, computer systems, cybersecurity, electrical engineering, electronics engineering, geospatial science, industrial engineering, information science, information technology, information resource management, intelligence, mathematics, mechanical engineering, network engineering, network security, operations research, physics, robotics engineering, robotics technology, statistics, strategic intelligence and telecommunications engineering.

Scientific Writer Internship at Princeton University: 
The Princeton University Office of the Dean for Research intern is responsible for writing about Princeton University research for a non-technical audience. The intern writes news articles, feature articles, web content and other items in the style used by major newspapers and magazines. Responsibilities include reading scientific papers, interviewing faculty members, writing, rewriting, compiling information for reports, and acquiring illustrations.
Dates: Eight weeks (approximately early-June to early-August; exact dates are flexible)
Time: Full-time (40 hour/week)
Location: In-person work at the Princeton University campus is preferred, but a remote working arrangement may be possible.
Compensation: $22/hour
Deadline to apply: Position is open until filled.

Open Positions and Opportunities at UC Berkeley Restorative Justice Center
The UC Berkeley Restorative Justice Center offers a variety of community-building and conflict-resolution circles and training opportunities for UC Berkeley students, student organizations, staff, and faculty. Our goal is to help you and your organization learn the skills to navigate difficult conversations and transform your approach to conflict and harm. If you'd like to learn more about our services, you can fill out the intake form on the flyer below, or reach out to us via email at rjcenterberkeley@gmail.com. In addition, we are looking to hire undergraduate students who are interested in learning about restorative processes and becoming a part of our team. Simply fill out our application, and we will reach out with the next steps. We look forward to connecting with you, and please don't hesitate to contact us with any questions!
Research Opportunity at UCSF: 
Professor McNamara: UCSF Ophthalmology- This is an excellent opportunity for a student who would like to assist with the development of novel therapeutics for autoimmune-mediated dry eye disease. The student will assist and independently conduct numerous laboratory techniques alongside experienced researchers including: genotyping, tissue processing, cryosectioning, immunofluorescence, RNAscope, high resolution confocal microscopy, image analysis, PCR, RNA extraction, and other basic and advanced laboratory techniques.
Qualifications: Eligible students must have a desire to participate in a translational research project with the goal of developing novel therapeutics. Applicants should have some experience conducting basic molecular and cell biology research techniques as well as a solid understanding of general biological concepts. The applicant must be detailed oriented, reliable, and able to work collaboratively with other research personnel. Interest in microscopy, imaging, and bioinformatics is preferred.
Hours: 10 hrs/week
Off-Campus Research Site: UCSF Parnassus Heights Campus, 511 Parnassus Ave, HSE 1510, San Francisco, CA 94143
Please contact Professor McNamara at nmcnamara@berkeley.edu if you are interested, and include a statement of interest to let us know more about you.

The Betty Stevens-Frecknall Scholarship
The Betty Stevens-Frecknall Scholarship is a prestigious national academic scholarship that is not limited to a particular college or university. Recipients must be full-time university students pursuing an academic degree in an information technology field. The selection committee will choose the scholarship recipients on the basis of scholastic ability, leadership potential and financial need.
Betty Stevens-Frecknall began her career in computers as a cardpunch operator. She trained in the 1940's as a keypunch clerk, a computer repair technician, and a systems analyst. Starting as a civilian employee of the Navy in Seattle, Betty was soon recruited to a position at Long Beach. Following this, she obtained a position as a systems analyst with the Department of Housing and Urban Development. From this point on, Betty proved herself with a series of successes on major projects, saving the taxpayers millions of dollars and gaining a promotion with each success.
Applications for the 2023-2024 academic year will be accepted between January - May 2023. Please return any time during that period if you are interested in applying for this prestigious scholarship.

The UC Washington Program
The UC Washington Program (UCDC) is a residential, instructional, and research center that provides students and faculty from all 9 UC campuses with opportunities to study, research, work, and live in the nation's capitol.
