Academic Writing Support Returns This Week! 
Starting Monday, January 30, the SLC will be offering free peer tutoring and support for students. Students are welcome to stop by and get to know the space, even if they don‚Äôt have a paper due. 
Visit Drop-In: Stop by virtually or in-person for 30 minutes of focused feedback on you assignments. No scheduling needed!
Make an appointment: Book a 50 minute virtual or in person session to discuss your ideas and refine your assignments in-depth.
Meet weekly: Work with a tutor on a weekly basis to start your projects early, hone your writing skills and finish strong!
For more information: visit the SLC website or visit in-person at Cesar E. Chavez Atrium. 
Undergraduate Summer Brain Research Program
Are you interested in learning about cutting-edge neuroscience research and gaining hands-on research experience? Are you considering applying to medical or graduate school in neuroscience, psychology, healthcare, or other related fields? If so, our summer program is perfect for you.
The Institute for Human Neuroscience at Boys Town National Research Hospital is inviting applications to our Undergraduate Summer Brain Research Program. Our 10-week paid intensive research opportunity begins on June 5, 2023, and ends on August 11, 2023. Housing is provided for students from outside of the Omaha metro area. Students accepted to our program will be matched with our experienced and well-funded faculty mentors to conduct in-depth research and data analysis in human neuroscience. Accepted students will also attend a variety of learning activities, including professional development workshops, journal clubs, lab meetings, and summer retreat presentations. Please see our program flyer for more details: Summer_2023 (squarespace.com)
Apply now for the Summer 2023 cohort! Application deadline: February 16, 2023
Cogsci Career Catalyst
The CogSci Career Catalyst is back! The Catalyst is for Cognitive Science majors nearing the end of their college careers. The intent of the program is to help students launch their careers by supporting them through a summer work experience opportunity. If admitted into the program, students can expect to receive the following benefits:
Networking, career connections, and professional support including:
Jobs 101: How to Successfully Start My Career ‚Äì Workshop hosted by UC Berkeley CogSci alumni, Phillip Hyun ‚Äò00. Phillip has founded multiple startups, including one of the largest esports companies in the world, Gen.G.
Connections to people and summer internship or job opportunities
Limited financial support for particular professional growth opportunities
As funding permits and for approved positions that do not pay a living wage, the program may be able to provide a modest stipend to help offset the cost of an underpaid, but professionally valuable opportunity.
Read more about eligibility and requirements here!
The application will be open until February 20th @ 11:59PM PST!
SURF - Summer Undergraduate Research and Fellowship Program
The Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship Program, otherwise known as ‚ÄúSURF‚Äù, provides $5,000 stipends to students carrying out substantial research projects over the summer months. There are two different scholarships available: SURF L&S and SURF Rose Hills. 
SURF L&S: Provides stipends to UC Berkeley students who are currently enrolled in the College of Letters & Sciences with a minimum of a 3.0 GPA. These awards support the preparation of a senior thesis or capstone project.
Surf Rose Hills: supports both independent and faculty-led research projects in select STEM disciplines. Fellows must be US citizens with residency established in Southern California and have a minimum of a 3.0 GPA.
To support students applying to SURF, OURS is offering a number of workshops throughout the month of February that will help applicants prepare a strong research proposal. The deadline for the program is March 1, 2023 so students should get started on their applications today or as soon as possible. 
Haas Scholars Program: $13,800 to carry out a final project in *ANY* major. 
Every year, the Haas Scholars Program funds 20 students for up to 
13,800tocarryoutacapstoneprojectinthesummerprecedingandduringtheirfinalyearoncampus.HaasScholarsalsoreceiveguidancefromfacultymentors(whoalsoreceiveastipend)andfromafull‚àítimestaffmember,membershipinaclose‚àíknitinterdisciplinarycommunityofscholars,andconnectionstoanetworkof500+alumni.Eligibility:3.450+UCBgpa,GraduatingF‚Äô23orSpr‚Äô24,andfinancialneed(EFC<26,000); open to undocumented students, permanent residents, and US citizens. interested students should attend an upcoming info session and/or proposal workshop and contact the Program Manager for an appointment. The deadline for this program is fast approaching‚Äì at noon on February 15th, 2023. 
Underrepresented Researchers of Color (UROC) Spring Symposium
UROC works to increase the representation of historically marginalized students in research programs and grad schools. Because research can be an extremely isolating and exclusive process, UROC seeks to demystify the research process and build a community of researchers of color. On March 17, 2023, UROC is hosting an all-day symposium, "Celebrating Diversity and Excellence in Research at Cal," and is inviting undergraduate students to submit proposals for lightning talks based on their research experiences and graduate students to serve in afternoon mentoring panels. Students whose papers are selected for presentation will receive stipends. RSVP or submit a paper proposal today; The deadline to RSVP or submit a proposal is February 10th, 2023, at 9 AM PST.
Special Opportunity for recently Graduated Bears: 
The Stronach Baccalaureate Prize supports recent Cal graduates to undertake a public service, creative, or community-based research project in the year following graduation (fall 22, spring and summer 23 graduates eligible). Recipients are awarded up to $25,000 for projects that serve the public good and heighten awareness of social issues. Application deadline: Wednesday, March 1, 2023. The dates and times of upcoming information sessions are posted on the website. Interested students are highly encouraged to make an appointment with the program manager to discuss their project ideas. 
Scholarship Opportunities:
Voyager Scholarship
The Voyager Scholarship (Obama-Chesky Scholarship for Public Service) was created by Michelle and Barack Obama and Brian Chesky, Airbnb CEO, who believe that exposure to new places and experiences generates understanding, empathy, and cooperation needed to equip the next generation to create meaningful change. Each year, this $50,000 scholarship aims to help shape 100 young leaders who can bridge divides and help solve our biggest challenges by giving college students financial aid to alleviate the burden of college debt, meaningful travel experiences to expand their horizons, and a network of mentors and leaders to support them. Recipients will also receive a $10,000 stipend and free Airbnb housing to pursue a summer work-travel experience between their junior and senior year of college, as well as a $2,000 travel credit for the next ten years.
Prospective applicants should make an individual advising appointment with Keila Diehl (ourschol-coordinator@berkeley.edu) in the OURS National Scholarships Office.
Eligibility Requirements:
Applicants must:
be a U.S. citizen, U.S. permanent resident (holder of a Permanent Resident Card), or an individual granted deferred action status under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals Program (DACA)
 plan to enroll full-time in their junior year of study at an accredited four-year college or university in the U.S. in Fall 2023. Eligible students are 1) finishing sophomore year in Spring 2023 (considered ‚Äújuniors‚Äù based on the total number of earned credits at their institution by Fall 2023), OR 2) transferring from a 2-year to a 4-year college for their 2023‚Äì24 junior academic year.
have a minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale, or equivalent
have demonstrated a commitment to public service
plan to pursue a career in public service* upon graduation
Public service includes careers in government, non-profits, or the private sector. A career in public service includes a range of occupations‚Äîfrom community organizing to social work and from entrepreneurship to the arts.
 Next Deadline: March 22, 2023, 1:00pm (PDT)
Samvid Scholars
The Samvid Scholars Program seeks to empower future leaders and changemakers by providing financial support for graduate study and leadership development. Scholars receive $50,000 for tuition and fees each year for two years in an eligible graduate program; two years of leadership development programming; and access to an active alumni community.
Prospective applicants should make an individual advising appointment with Keila Diehl in the OURS National Scholarships Office.
Eligibility Requirements
Applicants must: 
be a U.S. citizen or DACA recipient
be starting one of the following graduate programs in 2023: MD, MBA, JD, MPP/MPA, MPH, or MA/MS in Social Sciences or STEM*
have a 3.5 minimum GPA
maintain good academic standing to remain eligible for the second year of the scholarship
If starting a PhD program, the MA portion of the degree must take two years.
Selection Criteria
Applicants will be evaluated based on the following criteria:
 Academic Excellence: You have an excellent academic record, reflecting your critical thinking ability, your drive, and your interest in your academic field.
Leadership: You have an outstanding track record of leading efforts that deliver results. When you see problems, you not only seek to understand them, you take action to drive change. You also have a leader‚Äôs mindset: you are optimistic, self-reliant, and strive to learn from and inspire those with whom you work.
 Service Focus: You are committed to driving change for society through your leadership; you are focused on the impact of your achievements principally on others.
Determination: You have worked steadfastly over the long term to make an impact on the issues and/or communities that matter to you, even in the face of setbacks.
Application Requirements
Transcripts from all degree-granting higher education institutions
Standardized test scores (only if required by graduate program you are applying to)
Information about planned graduate study
Three 500-word essays, plus an optional diversity statement
Two recommendations (academic or professional)
For more information about this opportunity, visit the Samvid Scholars website.
Next deadline: April 19, 2023 (application opens February 13, 2023)
Astronaut Scholars
Campus Application Form + Previous UCB recipients! 
The Astronaut Scholarship Foundation awards more than sixty scholarships valued up to $15,000 for each selected scholar, as well as a paid trip to ASF‚Äôs Innovators Weekend. The ASF scholarship award is the beginning of a life-long relationship with astronauts, alumni, and leaders who span academia, technical research, and corporate leadership.
Prospective applicants must make an individual advising appointment with Keila Diehl, the Astronaut Scholarship campus representative.
Eligibility Requirements
Applicants must:
be a U.S. citizen, either native born or naturalized
be a STEM major going into their junior or senior year
have completed two years of full-time study at an ASF-affiliated university or institution
be enrolled for both semesters of the ASF-supported year as a full-time student
intend to pursue research or advance their field upon completion of their final degrees (note: Students intending to pursue a practice in professional medicine are not eligible for the scholarship. However, those intending to perform biomedical research are eligible)
Selection Criteria
Applicants will be evaluated based on the following criteria:
exemplary academic performance, as evidenced by application materials
the quality and amount of work conducted outside the classroom in student‚Äôs chosen field of study (may include laboratory research, cooperative education.
internships, relevant military experience, entrepreneurial endeavors, and/or documented independent work resulting in technical papers, patents, or similar work product)
Note: Students who received the Astronaut Scholarship during their junior year may reapply through their university for consideration for a second year of funding.
Application Requirements
Campus Application Form
Two letters of recommendation, including one from student‚Äôs P.I. at UC Berkeley
Personal statement (1 page)
Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended
C.V. or resume
For more information about this opportunity, visit the Astronaut Scholarship Foundation website.

Linguistics Research Apprentice Practicum for Spring 2023

Social Developmental Neuroscience Fellowship Opportunities for Seniors and Recent Graduates
The Marcus Autism Center, in conjunction with the Emory University School of Medicine and Children‚Äôs Healthcare of Atlanta, is offering six fellowships: the Cohen Fellowship in Developmental Social Neuroscience, the Simons Fellowship in Computational Neuroscience, the Education Sciences Fellowship, the Sally Provence Fellowship in Clinical Research, the Roger Glass Fellowship in Implementation Science, and the David Satcher Fellowship in Community Engagement.
Students who will receive a bachelor‚Äôs degree by June 2023 will be eligible for the positions. The fellowships will commence in July 2023, and they are 2 years in duration. Students can find further details here.
The Cohen Fellowship in Developmental Social Neuroscience will involve cutting-edge social neuroscience research in infants, toddlers, and adolescents. Fellows will work to further the understanding of autism through eye-tracking research, guiding a project from the point of data collection to publication of results.
The Simons Fellowship in Computational Neuroscience will involve integrating computational strategies with clinical research goals. Fellows will develop methods for the analysis of visual scanning and eye-tracking data, computational models of visual salience, and data visualization techniques, all with the aim of advancing the understanding of autism and efforts at early diagnosis.
The Education Sciences Fellowship will involve research in educational innovations in autism, from early child care through high school. Fellows will learn about classroom-based interventions to increase social emotional engagement and inclusion, gaining experiences with observational research methods, cutting-edge intervention research, and implementation science approaches.
The Sally Provence Fellowship in Clinical Research will select fellows for a two-year training in clinical assessment measures and research methodologies to better understand ASD and related disabilities.
The Roger Glass Fellowship in Implementation Science will select fellows for a two-year training in research focused on translating evidence-based treatments for autism into community settings, as well as the processes and partnerships that support these efforts.
The David Satcher Fellowship in Community Engagement will select fellows for an opportunity to spend two years engaged in training in community engaged participatory research methods as they relate to ASD.
SLC Writing Program is Hiring for Spring 2023
We are thrilled to announce that the SLC Writing Program is hiring peer writing tutors and program ambassadors for Spring 2023! 
Ideal candidates are dedicated undergraduates who value collaboration and are enthusiastic about writing and working with their peers. Tutors provide one-on-one support to their peers on any aspect of the academic writing process, while program ambassadors help us foster a welcoming and inclusive environment in our service spaces. In both positions, students have the opportunity to hone their communication skills, cultivate their professional acumen, and contribute to a transformative writing culture at Cal.
Starting pay is $17.03/hr and we are accepting applications through 12/19 (with priority given to applications submitted by 12/14). Multilingual, multidisciplinary, and BIPOC applicants are strongly encouraged.
Exciting Course Opportunity for Cognitive Science Students
Dear Financial Experts-to-Be, 
This message pertains to an extremely worthwhile course that begins instruction for any and all interested University of California, Berkeley students in a few months: UGBA127/MBA296 Financial Reporting and Decision Making for Real Life Success. It is available for non-Haas and Haas majors alike.
I am Kousha Modanlou, an August 2020 graduate of UC Berkeley and a current senior tax professional with the multinational Big Four firm Deloitte. I graduated with a major in Sociology and minors in Journalism and Education. I became a licensed Certified Public Accountant (CPA) in the state of California in July 2022 while I was working for my previous employer Ernst & Young (EY). 
I have previously served as either the undergraduate student instructor or assistant instructor for four subjects offered at the Haas School of Business: Auditing (Summers of 2020-2022), Federal Income Tax Accounting (Summers of 2021-2022), Financial Reporting and Decision Making (Springs of 2020-2022), and Intermediate Financial Accounting I (Summer 2022).
This upcoming Spring 2023, I will once again be returning as the assistant instructor for "Financial Reporting and Decision Making for Real Life Success" offered through the Haas School of Business.
Open to students of all backgrounds -- undergraduate and graduate -- this enrichment will enhance your abilities to pursue countless endeavors in the world of business, whether that be public relations, investment banking, consulting, accounting, finance, entrepreneurship, marketing, human resources, real estate, and beyond. Wherever your aspirations may draw you, we shall help take you.
In this day and age of enormous uncertainty, it is imperative to find clarity on the road to economic prosperity. To do so involves a robust grasp of the macroeconomy and capital markets, which in many ways begins from understanding how to read, analyze, and make decisions based on corporate financial statements. 
Over 300 students have resoundingly benefited and passionately attested to the value added to their professional and personal lives after immersing themselves in this offering in the past three spring semesters. Please join us in this journey to fortify and vitalize hundreds more.
Sincerely,
Kousha Modanlou (and Prof. Yaniv Konchitchki)

Job Openings with United We Dream!
United We Dream is currently hiring for three positions: Administrative Marketing Assistant, Digital Organizing Manager, and a National Communications Manager. ‚ÄúUnited We Dream is the largest immigrant youth-led community in the country. We create welcoming spaces for young people ‚Äì regardless of immigration status ‚Äì to support, engage, and empower them to make their voice heard and win! Over 60% of our members are womxn and 20% identify as LGBTQ. We are made up of fearless youth fighting to improve the lives of ourselves, our families and our communities. Our vision is a society which celebrates our diversity and we believe in leading a multi-ethnic, intersectional path to get there. Whether we‚Äôre organizing in the streets, building cutting edge technology systems, opening doors for LGBTQ immigrant youth, clearing pathways to education, stopping deportations or creating alliances across social movements, United We Dream puts undocumented immigrant youth in the driver‚Äôs seat to strategize, innovate and win.‚Äù See their official webpage for more information about each of these positions and to apply.
Job Opportunity: CALPIRG Campaign Associate
CALPIRG‚Äôs Beyond Plastic campaign is working to eliminate the single-use plastics we‚Äôve known for decades we can all live without.
We are seeking a Campaign Associate who will spearhead this campaign and work with our experienced team of advocates, researchers, and digital and communications experts.
Entry-level candidates are encouraged to apply; we provide training on advocacy and organizing skills, as well as oversight and on-the-ground training by an experienced advocate. Ideal candidates will have leadership experience, top-notch written and verbal skills, an eagerness to learn, and be ready for a challenge. We value organizing experience, including building campus or community groups.
Learn more and apply here 
Master of Addiction Science at USC 
The USC Master of Addiction Science (MAS) is designed for students interested in transdisciplinary and inter-professional approaches to the study of addiction. We offer courses across multiple disciplines designed to expose students to an array of science and policy perspectives in addiction. By interacting with instructors and peers from a variety of disciplines and professions, students in the MAS program will obtain a broader and deeper understanding and set of skills that considers addiction from the ‚Äòcell to society perspective.‚Äô As such, MAS graduates are poised to take the knowledge and skills gained in the program back to their respective current or future professions to enhance interdisciplinary and interprofessional collaboration.
We are now accepting applications for the Fall 2023 cohort. For more information on the Master of Addiction Science classes and curriculum, please visit the USC Catalogue. 
The early admission deadline is February 1, 2023 and the final deadline is May 1, 2023 for Fall 2023 enrollment. 
Students can learn more about the work we do at the USC Institute for Addiction on our general website or by subscribing to our monthly Newsletter.
L&S Student Support & Advocacy
The College of Letters & Science is committed to helping provide a safe and supportive environment for all students at UC Berkeley, free of bias, harassment, violence, and discrimination. The L&S Student Support & Advocacy page contains resources related to campus grievance procedures and other useful information. 
UHS LGBTQ+ Mental Health Resources
Group counseling is available on a drop-in basis through UHS for a number of populations, including the LGBTQIA+ Support Group, the Gender Support Group, and the BIPOC Queer Womxn‚Äôs Support Circle. Group counseling offers the opportunity for students to learn new skills, to share concerns as well as inherent wisdom in a facilitated environment with other students. Visit the UHS Group Counseling webpage for information about all available groups and referral pathways to get started. 
Student Technology Equity Program (STEP)
UC Berkeley provides technology support for undergraduate and graduate students that may prove valuable for your students, including free software, device lending, and the student tech support helpdesk. The Student Technology Equity Program (STEP) continues to provide long-term loans for laptops, Wi-Fi hotspots and other tech hardware to students with need (e.g. financial need, instructional role, etc.).

John Gardner Public Service Fellowship
The John Gardner Fellowship at UC Berkeley selects three seniors and provides each a $47,000 stipend to work in the governmental or nonprofit organization that most closely fits their public-sector interests for 10 months after graduation.
The goal of the Fellowship is to encourage UC Berkeley's best students to pursue a career in public service. We welcome applicants from a diverse pool of students with a wide variety of service experiences. If you are committed to public service and have leadership experience, we urge you to apply.
INFORMATIONAL MEETINGS:
Thursday, December 8th, 2022 at 4:00 p.m, on Zoom: https://berkeley.zoom.us/j/92842011800 
Wednesday, January 18, 2023, at 4:00 p.m. 119 Moses Hall, Institute of Governmental Studies, In person.
QUESTIONS? Contact the program director Terri Bimes: bimes@berkeley.edu
APPLICATION DEADLINE: FEB. 9, 2023

Master of Addiction Science at USC 
The USC Master of Addiction Science (MAS) is designed for students interested in transdisciplinary and inter-professional approaches to the study of addiction. We offer courses across multiple disciplines designed to expose students to an array of science and policy perspectives in addiction. By interacting with instructors and peers from a variety of disciplines and professions, students in the MAS program will obtain a broader and deeper understanding and set of skills that considers addiction from the ‚Äòcell to society perspective.‚Äô As such, MAS graduates are poised to take the knowledge and skills gained in the program back to their respective current or future professions to enhance interdisciplinary and interprofessional collaboration.

Students can learn more about the work we do at the USC Institute for Addiction on our general website or by subscribing to our monthly Newsletter.
Research Experience Pathways (REP) in Psychology!
We‚Äôd like to introduce a new undergraduate research program called Research Experience Pathways (REP) in Psychology! This program will offer underrepresented students with little or no experience in research the chance to get started and earn wages to work as a research assistant (RA) on a research project alongside a graduate student mentor and faculty sponsor! Underrepresented undergraduate students meeting all of the following criteria are eligible to participate in the REP in Psychology program:
California residents
Enrolled in 6 or more units
Filed a FAFSA or CADAA and have work-study eligibility
Eligible to work in the U.S., including current DACA holders
The application for REP in Psychology will open up on Oct 21st and close on November 22nd! Once the application is open, you can use this link to apply to the program. If you have any questions about the REP in Psychology program please email us at: REPpsych@berkeley.edu
Black Engineering and Science Student Association (BESSA) Tutoring Program
Through the end of the semester, BESSA is offering tutoring services to students in need of additional support in their STEM prerequisite courses. Tutoring support will be offered for the following classes: Math 1 series, Math 10 series, Chem 1A/L, Chem 3 series, Physics 7 series, Physics 8 series, CS61 series, Data C8, and Bio 1 series. This is an amazing opportunity for students to receive quality tutoring services from fellow black community members. Interested students are requested to fill out the BESSA Tutoring Interest Form.
Cultivating Community and Conversation for Cal Writers!
The SLC Writing Team has been thrilled to have students back in their in-person and virtual spaces this semester. With midterms ongoing and final papers on the way, we hope you will feel inspired to join us for community and support throughout your writing process. You needn‚Äôt have anything written to sit down for a conversation, and our peer tutors are prepared to meet you at every stage.
If you have any questions, please come by the V√®V√® Writing Lounge, located in the C√©sar Ch√°vez Student Center Atrium, either virtually or in-person during our open hours: Monday-Thursday 11AM-6PM & Fridays 11AM-4PM. You can also reach out to us via email slcwritingprg@berkeley.edu 
L&S Student Support & Advocacy
The College of Letters & Science is committed to helping provide a safe and supportive environment for all students at UC Berkeley, free of bias, harassment, violence, and discrimination. The L&S Student Support & Advocacy page contains resources related to campus grievance procedures and other useful information. 
Discovery Hub
The Discovery Hub, campus's gateway to experiential learning, is launching a new series of workshops that are geared toward acclimating and supporting undergraduate students to take advantage of opportunities in project-based learning. Check out the Discovery Hub Fall 2022 Workshops flier!
UHS LGBTQ+ Mental Health Resources
Group counseling is available on a drop-in basis through UHS for a number of populations, including the LGBTQIA+ Support Group, the Gender Support Group, and the BIPOC Queer Womxn‚Äôs Support Circle. Group counseling offers the opportunity for students to learn new skills, to share concerns as well as inherent wisdom in a facilitated environment with other students. Visit the UHS Group Counseling webpage for information about all available groups and referral pathways to get started. 
Art of Writing Tutoring Program support
The Art of Writing Tutoring Program supports students taking Reading & Composition (R&C) courses in all departments. Tutors are available Sunday through Thursday evenings, and R&C students can sign up for a 30-minute online appointment. Tutoring is targeted and disciplinary-specific, responding to the parameters of R&C instruction and the challenges faced by R&C student writers in each department. Students can learn more and sign up here
Student Technology Equity Program (STEP)
UC Berkeley provides technology support for undergraduate and graduate students that may prove valuable for your students, including free software, device lending, and the student tech support helpdesk. The Student Technology Equity Program (STEP) continues to provide long-term loans for laptops, Wi-Fi hotspots and other tech hardware to students with need (e.g. financial need, instructional role, etc.).

column2: ['Apply to Cal in the Capital today! #193']
column5:
['Cal in the Capital (CITC) is a student-led internship program housed in the Public Service Center that helps Berkeley students secure public service internships in Washington, DC. At CITC, we strive to promote the spirit of public service among the Berkeley community and empower students to prioritize social justice. CITC interns come from all majors and have worked in a variety of positions including research, business development, data analysis, policy, and legislation. Opportunities for CDSS students include internships at the Democratic and Republican National Committees, Apple, Google, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. Check out the blog posts from past CITC interns to get an idea of what your summer in DC could look like!
Interested applicants can apply here. Applications are due September 28th at 11:59pm PST. 
For more information, contact calinthecapital@gmail.com or attend one of our upcoming info sessions and application workshop.
Thur, September 12, 6pm ‚Äì 7pm, Public Service Center / Eshleman 218 (5th floor of Eshleman Hall)
Tue, September 17, 7pm ‚Äì 8pm, Senate Chambers (5th floor of Eshleman Hall)
Tue, September 24, 7pm ‚Äì 8pm, Senate Chambers (5th floor of Eshleman Hall)
RSVP if you‚Äôre attending!']
column11: Public Service Center / Eshleman 218 (5th floor of Eshleman Hall)

column5:
['Spend the Spring 2025 SEMESTER IN WASHINGTON, DC!
UCDC Now Accepting Applications, Due Sept 19

UCDC sends juniors and seniors to Washington, DC each fall and spring to participate in prestigious internships and take exciting courses for a full semester of UCB academic credit. All majors are welcome. UCB financial aid and grants available.

Recent participants have said: "UCDC was instrumental in landing a job after I graduated," and "UCDC was my best semester at Berkeley!"

Questions? Come to an info session to learn more, email, or sign up for an appointment. Also, check the website for program announcements and updates.

Upcoming Info Session Dates 

‚Ä¢ Thursday, August 29, 2-3pm, 3401 Dwinelle Hall
‚Ä¢ Tuesday, September 3, 1-2pm, 1229 Dwinelle Hall
‚Ä¢ Friday, September 6, 11am-noon, on zoom at https://berkeley.zoom.us/j/5492740547
‚Ä¢ Wednesday, September 11, 4-5pm, 3401 Dwinelle Hall
The deadline to submit an application for the SP25 semester is Thursday, September 19. ']

column2: ['Apply to Alternative Breaks: Critical Service Learning Trips #217']
column5:
['Interested in learning more about immigration policy, farm worker rights, public health, sustainability, wealth disparity, housing, and more?
Join the Alternative Breaks community and explore these social justice issues through community partnership supplemented with education and reflection. Participants enroll in a 2-unit DeCal course in Spring 2025 to prepare for their spring break trip to work with one of our various community partners. 
Our Spring 2025 experiences include:
Central Valley - Farmworker & Immigration Rights
San Francisco - Economic Justice
San Diego - Immigration Rights
Puerto Rico - Community Building & Sustainability
Los Angeles - Urban Health
Oakland - Environmental & Food Justice
Priority deadline: Oct 23 at 11:59pm
Final deadline: Oct 26th at 11:59pm 
The application can be found on our website!
Our program is open to undergraduate and graduate students in all fields of study.
Learn more about our trips and community partners here, and find information about our upcoming info sessions.
Contact us at berkeleyaltbreaks@gmail.com if you have any questions ‚Äî we‚Äôre always happy to chat!']

column2: ['Berkeley IEOR MS & PhD Information Session Registration #206']
column5:
['Date: Tuesday, October 1
Time: 4:00 ‚Äì 5:00 PM
Location: 1174 Etcheverry Hall
Enjoy light refreshments and enter our raffle for a chance to win exclusive Berkeley IEOR swag!
Register Here
Curious about solving the world‚Äôs toughest problems? Join us at 4:00 PM on Tuesday, October 1, to discover how MS and PhD students at Berkeley IEOR are transforming industries using advanced Operations Research, Optimization, AI, and more. From streamlining disrupted supply chains to creating algorithms that boost revenue, improve transportation, and tackle housing and food insecurity, Berkeley IEOR students drive real-world impact.
Berkeley IEOR grads are in high demand, securing top roles in academia, tech, finance, healthcare, and more‚Äîwith many earning impressive salaries. Hear directly from our students and faculty about what sets our Master‚Äôs and PhD programs apart, get insider tips on the application process, and explore the incredible career paths in IEOR.
Enjoy refreshments, connect with peers, and enter to win awesome prizes! Register now and take the first step toward your future with Berkeley IEOR.']

Dinner will be provided. \nCome hang out and get more involved with CSUA! React to RSVP on the CSUA Discord (csua.org/discord).\nHope to see you there!']

column2: ['Apply to the "Introduction to Real World Data Science" Decal!!! #201']
column5:
["If you want to learn how to build a data science project from start to finish, enroll in Data Science Society's 2-unit P/NP DeCal, Data 198: Introduction to Real World Data Science! 
Throughout the semester, you'll work with a small group to build a project of your choosing, receiving mentorship from our Decal's committee members. We will cover every stage of the data science lifecycle ‚Äì from formulating a data-centric project proposal, to discovering insights through exploratory data analysis, and concluding with the engineering and evaluation of machine learning models.
This introductory course is designed for students with little to no data science experience. It covers a wide variety of data science concepts, including topics both traditionally and not traditionally taught in the lecture halls of Berkeley. Students will not only develop and refine their technical skills, but also learn from real-world data scientists through panels and speaker events.
There's a mandatory weekly lecture on Mondays from 6:30-8:30 PM (in-person), as well as outside meeting times with your mentor to reinforce lectures and advance your project. At the end of the semester, you'll get to present your project in front of the class in our Symposium!
If you're interested in applying, submit this form by midnight, 9/13. You can also read our syllabus here!
Drop any questions you have below!"]
column11: In-person at a specified location (not provided)

column5:

This the last opportunity to begin with the CCPHIT program and start your journey toward a Summer 2025 PHIT internship. We look forward to seeing you!
For any questions, email us at phinformatics@berkeley.edu']

['We‚Äôre excited to share that applications are now open for the 2024-25 UC Advocacy Network (UCAN) Student Ambassador Program! 
Through virtual monthly meetings led by UC Office of the President staff, Ambassadors will learn about advocacy and the legislative process, and the critical role that advocates play in advancing UC‚Äôs mission with lawmakers. Working with UC advocacy teams, Ambassadors will come to understand how state and federal legislation and policies impact the University and its students. Ambassadors who meet key program criteria will be eligible to join advocacy trips to Sacramento and/or Washington, D.C., with their eligible expenses covered. During these events, Ambassadors will meet directly with legislators and their staffs ‚Äì sharing their story while advancing UC priorities! 
We would appreciate your help in sharing this exciting opportunity across your campus. Applications are due on Wednesday, Oct. 9, 2024. 
Application Link: http://ucal.us/ucanapply
Program Homepage: https://bit.ly/AmbassadorsForUC 
Detailed Program Information: https://universityofcalifornia.edu/get-involved/advocate/student-ambassadors/about-program ']

['Partner with the Student Learning Center (SLC) through the following program offerings: 
Craft an individualized road map to achieve your learning goals through Academic Coaching! This dynamic, collaborative service is designed to help you cultivate the habits, skills, strategies, and mindsets essential for success at Cal and beyond. Whatever you hope to accomplish, you and your coach will work together to create actionable plans and reflect on your progress toward achieving your academic and personal goals. Learn more and join at bit.ly/slp-ac. 
Elevate your study sessions with SLP Power Hours! These intensive 2-hour working sessions are crafted to supercharge your productivity and focus. By working in a structured environment with supportive peers, you‚Äôll make tangible progress toward your study goals. Check the schedule and secure your spot at bit.ly/slp-ph! 
Become a master of your time by joining "It‚Äôs Your Time: Reconnect with Your Most Precious Resource" Workshops and cultivate strategies to boost your skill of time management! Find upcoming dates and RSVP at bit.ly/slp-tmw. 
Explore the SLC full slate of services and their schedules at bit.ly/slp-services. Feel free to email the SLC at strategiclearningprogram@berkeley.edu with any questions. ']

column2: ['Mathematics Undergraduate Student Association | First GM Thursday, 9/5 6:30pm @ Evans 1015 #174']
column5: ['The Mathematics Undergraduate Student Association (MUSA) is holding its first general meeting on Thursday, 9/5, at 6:30pm in Evans 1015! There will be pizza, board games, and a brief introduction of what we do. MUSA aims to create a warm, inclusive environment in the math department by hosting weekly events such as Math Mondays, trivia nights, LaTeX workshops, and the BUMP mentoring program that pairs under and upperclassmen. For those interested in taking upper-division math courses or proof intensive courses we offer the MUSA 74 Decal ‚Äì a 2 unit PNP course that introduces rigorous proof writing and fosters familiarity with the objects encountered in advanced courses such as Abstract Algebra and Analysis. \n\nKeep in touch with us via our newsletter or Discord server, both found at https://linktr.ee/berkeleymusa.']

['Explore how to critically and effectively engage in poverty action through the Global Poverty & Practice (GPP) Minor!
The GPP Minor gives students from majors across campus an understanding of the frameworks, methods, and practical skills necessary to address poverty and inequality, both locally and globally. There are five course requirements for the Minor - 3 core courses and 2 electives. One course may overlap with your major requirements and several of the courses fulfill campus breadth requirements. 
The courses help students prepare for and reflect on a "Practice Experience" in which they intern or volunteer with local or international NGOs, government agencies, health clinics, social enterprises, or other poverty or development programs. Students study and work on critical issues such as environmental justice, community health, affordable housing, education, labor rights, and economic development.  GPP Advisors guide students on identifying a practice experience that is relevant to your skills and interests, and funding is available to support your experience.
The deadline to declare the minor this semester is October 14th. There are no prerequisites required to declare.
The Declaration Form and additional information about the minor can be found at: http://blumcenter.berkeley.edu/gppminor.
Information Sessions about the minor will be held at the following times:
Thursday, September 5th, 5-6 pm in Blum Hall B100 A/B
Friday, September 13th, 12-1pm  in Blum Hall B100 A/B
Wednesday, October 2nd, 5-6pm on Zoom
Thursday, October 10th, 4-5 pm on Zoom
RSVP for a session Here
GPP Advising
Schedule an appointment with a GPP Peer Advisor: https://calendly.com/gppminor/gpp-minor-advising.
Contact gppminor@berkeley.edu with any questions.']

["Hope you all have a good start to the semester! 
We're happy to offer the Extended Reality Development DeCal (XR DeCal) this semester, and we are now accepting applications for Fall 2024.
Interested in Virtual/Augmented Reality? Want to learn Unity? Looking for some extra units? 
Similar to how mobile devices revolutionized the way we interact with our electronic devices, Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality represent another exciting paradigm shift in human computer interaction. XR stands for Extended Reality, which is the realm that encompasses both Virtual and Augmented Reality.
Students will get exposure to different kinds of XR apps and design frameworks, and work in teams to build their own from scratch. After completion of the course, we welcome interested students to join an existing project team with XR@Berkeley or pitch their own project.
This 2-unit course will be held on Monday‚Äôs and Tuesday‚Äôs 5:00 - 7:00 PM PST in-person at Jacobs 10C. (Only need to attend one of the sections - either Monday OR Tuesday)
Apply by Saturday, September 7th @ 11:59 PM PST!
Feel free to contact decal@xr.berkeley.edu with any questions or concerns!
Whether you're interested in the technical/implementation of XR systems or interested in the design side of things, we encourage everyone to apply!
Important Links:
Application: http://tinyurl.com/xr-decal-fa24
Official Course Listing: https://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2024-fall-compsci-198-80-grp-80, https://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2024-fall-compsci-198-808-grp-808
XR DeCal Website: https://xr.berkeley.edu/decal/"]

['Are you ready to take your entrepreneurial journey to the next level? We‚Äôre excited to invite you to join our Fall 2024 decal course, Innovators in Residence: Decoding Entrepreneurship Success through Peer Mentorship!
Course Details: Units: 2 | P/NP
Day/Time: Mondays, 5:00 pm to 7:00 pm

This unique course is designed for those with startup experience or a strong interest in entrepreneurship. You‚Äôll have the opportunity to collaborate with experienced peers, hear from inspiring guest speakers, and develop practical skills in entrepreneurial leadership, coaching, and team building. Through workshops, mentorship, and hands-on projects, you‚Äôll learn how to navigate challenges, leverage the Silicon Valley ecosystem, and refine your startup strategies.

Highlights Include:
Counts towards the SCET certificate!
Peer Mentorship and Workshops: Lead and participate in workshops, share your experiences, and learn from others in the SCET Innovation community.
Guest Speakers: Gain insights from successful entrepreneurs and innovators across various industries.
Hands-on Learning: Work on your own projects and ideas, applying proven frameworks and methodologies in real-world settings. Don‚Äôt miss this chance to deepen your entrepreneurial skills and connect with a network of like-minded innovators!
Interested? 
Apply here ASAP before September 6th (spots are limited) or reach out to Danica Tang (danicat@berkeley.edu) or Hannah Kang (hkang02@berkeley.edu) for more information. Looking forward to seeing you there!']

column2: ['Apply to be a mentor for Computer Science Mentors (CSM) for Fall 2024! #60']
column5:
['Hi! Are you interested in joining the teaching community at Berkeley? Do you want to help teach students looking for support in a small group setting, and also find friends and community? 
Computer Science Mentors (CSM) is a student-run organization that provides guidance and resources in a smaller classroom environment through group tutoring sessions for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 70, CS 88, EECS 16A, and EECS 16B. Each section has 4-7 students and meets once or twice a week for 1 or 1.5 hours. The goal of CSM is to build a personal learning community and social network so that both students and mentors can comfortably seek and receive support.
For Fall 2024, we‚Äôre recruiting for the following roles:
Junior Mentors (JMs) for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 70, CS 88, EECS 16A, EECS 16B 
Associate Mentors (AMs) for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 88, EECS 16B
Content Mentors (CMs) for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, EECS 16A
This application is available at https://tinyurl.com/csm-app-fa24. Submissions are due Wednesday, August 28th at 11:59pm PT. No late applications will be accepted! In CSM, we are committed to diversity and inclusion and value applicants of all backgrounds. We consider applications holistically and value passion for mentoring and willingness to learn over your grades and struggles during your time as a student ‚Äî we do not consider grades in our application process. Overall, we encourage all who are interested to apply and to give the application your best effort!
Want to hear from real mentors what CSM is like? See our info session recording and slides from spring 2024. 
Slides: https://tinyurl.com/csm-infosession-sp24
Recording: https://tinyurl.com/csm-infosession-sp24-recording
Visit https://csmentors.berkeley.edu for more information or reach out to us at mentors@berkeley.edu!']

["CSUA is excited to announce our upcoming summer mentorship program, designed to pair you up with a compatible mentor/mentee for the summer! 
This program is open to any major - as long as you're interested in tech! We really appreciate your interest and look forward to getting to know you all better before school starts!

While more details will be given during the first Meet & Greet meeting (date TBD), mentors are typically experienced upperclassmen (pre-sophomore and above) who can provide valuable insights/advice into navigating Berkeley, getting involved in recruiting/research/clubs, or simply be a friendly presence to connect with!

Please note that mentorship applications are accepted on a first-come first-served basis, so if you're interested, don't miss out! The form for mentees can be found here: csua.org/mentee24 and the form for mentors is available here: csua.org/mentor24 . Share this with anybody you know who may be interested!

These forms will close 07/21/24 at 11:59 PM PT. We will announce additional details regarding pairings/meetings shortly after! "]

column2: ["Peer Advisor's Blog: A Senior's Random Yapping (about Being Unique, DSP, and Friends!) #300"]
column5:
["Hi everyone!
A few weeks ago, I was on a bus to Emeryville with a friend, and we overheard someone else talking about how one of their friends is one of the sweetest people they know, but complained that they yap too much. If anyone here is also anti-yapping, I apologize in advance because I will be yapping in this post. \U0001faf6
As this may be my last post before I graduate, I figured that I might as well try and share as much as I can!
I actually struggled a lot to think of what to write in this blog post because I think of myself as having a very bland & generic personality; I doubt I‚Äôve ever had a single unique experience or thought. Whenever it‚Äôs my turn to write a post, I feel this pressure to try and share something that is unique to me because what else am I here for? If anyone else has seen the subway take tiktok about the ‚Äúcandid girlfriend,‚Äù I feel like that sentiment perfectly encapsulates the pressure to be super interesting and unlike anyone else. However, it‚Äôs the very fact that none of us are completely unique that reminds me that I‚Äôm never truly alone in my worries, doubts, and fears! So, with the hope that my random yapping may help someone feel less isolated, I will be yapping about a few things that have been on my mind recently.
As a second semester senior, I am finishing up the last of my required courses and trying to apply for a teaching credential. On top of all of my student teaching hours, classwork, and the credential application, as a senior, I still want to explore the Bay Area and spend time with my friends before I no longer get the chance to. Although I am having a lot of fun, I am also feeling very stressed, tired, and overwhelmed. One thing about me is that, when I have a super important deadline coming up, and/or I‚Äôm feeling super overwhelmed with all of the things that I have to do, I freeze and cannot get anything done. Two nights before I taught my first lesson for my teaching credential application, I was so anxious that my body went into shock and I was shaking all night. Ever since the start of our spring break, I have not been able to make a sizable dent in my laundry list of things to do because it feels like I‚Äôm standing so close to the base of a really tall mountain that I can‚Äôt even see the peak. So, if anyone else is also feeling overwhelmed and extremely anxious about everything coming up, a lot of us are here with you!
I did also want to share that, if anyone here believes that receiving accommodations may improve their quality of education and have not yet thought about DSP accommodations, it has been so helpful for me these past 3 years and I strongly recommend it. In my sophomore year, I had scheduled an online appointment with CAPS because of my anxiety going out of control during the pandemic, and I was recommended a second session in order to complete a form together to request DSP accommodations. After receiving the appropriate accommodations, it has helped my academic experience here at Cal so much! (It‚Äôs crazy how much better I can focus during exams when my hands aren‚Äôt shaking too much to write legibly!)
However, despite all of my nerves, I am still enjoying myself this semester‚Äîmostly thanks to my friends! Quite a few of my friends have already graduated, so it has been harder to spend time with everyone, but two things that we have started doing now that we‚Äôre long distance are (after being inspired by others online): weekly photo dumps and an email newsletter! For the weekly photo dumps, every Sunday in our group chat, we will each send a compilation of some photos that we‚Äôve taken throughout the week to share with each other a bit of our current lives. Our email newsletters are less frequent because it does require a bit more coordination, but we do compile a newsletter at least for each of our birthdays! For the newsletter, one of us will create a Google Form with random questions and send it out to all of us to respond, and then compile all of our responses and photos into an email. We actually just sent out a birthday newsletter a few days ago, and I can confirm that each one of us has cried (happy tears) reading our birthday newsletters. We‚Äôve also used this to keep each other updated on both the more significant and fleeting aspects of our lives (gossip, drama, family, health, and more)!
Some other fun things that I've been up to this semester have been: taking sunset walks/jogs with my friends and picking up crafts-related hobbies! Since I now find myself inside a building for 8+ hours a day, I have been trying to take sunset walks/jogs at least twice a week with a friend in order to make sure I spend some time outside. This has also helped me explore a lot of places around Berkeley that I have been meaning to visit! Sometimes we walk up to Northside and look at all of the pretty views & houses around us, or we go down College to explore some restaurants on our bucket list, or we jog to a nearby grocery store to try out some interesting ice cream flavors we found online! I have also started a shared bullet journal with a friend that we try to trade off each month, so that we can share about our lives and yap even when we don't see each other! Another crafts-related hobby that I've recently picked up is making phone charms. Although I'm not very good, it is fun to think about color schemes that remind me of my friends when I'm trying to make one for them. We're also trying to find one day to have a picnic where we all just teach each other how to make different crafts!
Well, if you‚Äôve read all of this, thank you for somehow bearing all of my yapping! If you would ever like to yap more about anything, feel free to drop by our office hours! If you would like to yap or hear others yap about Fall 2024 Math courses, please drop by our Peer Advising Night on Tuesday, April 9th, at 5:30 in Evans 1015!
Have a great weekend!
~ Audrey

Mondays: 12-1 pm (Daniel), 1-2 pm (Kaya)
Tuesdays: 2-3 pm (Izzy)
Wednesdays: 2-3 pm (Leo)
Thursdays: 2-3 pm (Audrey)

You can also yap to the peer advisors directly at peeradvisors@math.berkeley.edu or follow us on Instagram @mathpeeradvisng!"]

['Hello everyone!
 I don‚Äôt know about you but this point in the semester, in the thick of midterm season, is the time when I usually start questioning everything. Maybe the stress and lack of sleep due to staying up studying for exams is to blame, but for whatever reason, I know many tend to feel an increased sense of impostor syndrome around now. So, to lift up our spirits in these trying times, I wanted to talk about the concept of a ‚Äúmath person‚Äù and why I think you shouldn‚Äôt worry about being one.
 Last year, I attended the Research in Undergraduate Mathematics Education (RUME) Conference in Nebraska. One of my favorite presentations was a study on how students describe a ‚Äúmath person‚Äù and what causes them to perceive specific peers as math people. One major takeaway from this study was that students tend to view a math person (which is someone who loves math and is very gifted in mathematical ability) as inherently mathematically-minded. Students in the study tended to suggest that people are either born mathematically inclined or not. I did not find this result to be too surprising since I have read a lot about the emphasis on brilliance in mathematics. I have found that people truly believe the ability to be highly successful in math and other mathematical sciences is attributed to some sort of raw talent or mindset you are born with. One student in the study said math people are born ‚Äúleft-brained,‚Äù further emphasizing this idea that math ability is predetermined.
 This misconception about the need for inherent brilliance to be a successful mathematician is obviously harmful because it discourages learners from an early age. It tells students that if you do not succeed initially, you should stop trying. In addition, there has been shown to be a bias against minorities in the field. If you are a woman, ethnic minority, or identify with any other underrepresented minority in math, you probably know firsthand that it is much less likely that people will expect you to be brilliant compared to your peers. The gender and racial disparities in math are tied to this brilliance culture in mathematics.
 Another result from the presentation at RUME that I thought was interesting was the traits students used to identify certain peers as math people. A lot of their identifications were based on how much they perceived their peers speaking in math classes and helping others with math questions. This showed students were much more likely to be viewed as math people if they were more vocal and interactive. I thought this was very important to note as those who are more social and comfortable speaking in class are much more likely to be seen as math people than those who may be quieter or more reserved, even though these personality traits have nothing to do with mathematical abilities. Thus, I want you to question your beliefs about any peers in your math courses that seem more like ‚Äúmath people‚Äù than you. Regardless of how smart or talented some people may appear, I promise they were not born with any of these abilities and there is no reason you cannot achieve the same level of mathematical ability as them. 
If math is something you love and want to pursue, then you can do it. Struggling and working hard at it does not make you any less of mathematically inclined. If you decide to keep persisting in spite of any discouragement because you love the subject, then you are a math person.
~ Kaya
Follow us on Instagram @mathpeeradvising and drop in to our office hours at Evans 947 or via zoom!
Office Hours:
Mondays: 12-1 pm (Daniel)1-2 pm (Kaya)
Tuesdays: 2-3 pm (Izzy),
Wednesdays: 2-3 pm (Leo)
Thursdays: 2-3 pm (Audrey)']

column2: ["Peer Advisor's Blog: Happy Last Day of Instruction! #234"]
column5:
['Hi everyone! Before I get into the blog post, we have a new podcast episode out about building equity in math with a guest speaker, Catherine Cannizzo! We also have a rough transcript of the audio!
I hope everyone‚Äôs last day of instruction has been going well so far! As this semester‚Äôs classes come to an end and we start heading into RRR week, some of us (I know I am) may be feeling a little burned out even though we know we really need to hold on and pull through for this final stretch. So, here are some ideas for how to work on recovering from burnout based on what tends to work for me (and hopefully for some of you, too)!
1. Reflect on why you‚Äôre feeling burned out so that you can address it.
Are you feeling burned out from just the sheer exhaustion of nonstop work, or is it because of the pressure and expectation you feel attached to the work that you do? Are you feeling burned out because you feel like you‚Äôre putting in so much time and effort with no visible progress or achievement? Or is it a completely different reason? Depending on why you‚Äôre feeling burned out, there may be different steps you can take to prevent feeling even more burned out as time goes on!
I know that personally, my burnout tends to stem from either putting too much pressure on myself, or feeling that the time and effort I put into something isn‚Äôt reflected in my progress. When I‚Äôm feeling a lot of pressure, sometimes it helps to just talk about it with my classmates, friends, and/or family (whoever you consider to be your support system); it can be helpful to just share your worries with someone else, but it can also help open the floor for those around you to also share their own worries, and you may learn that you‚Äôre not alone in your struggles! However, sometimes we struggle with being vulnerable with those around us, or we struggle with finding the right words to describe our feelings. Another thing that helps me when I realize that I‚Äôm feeling too much pressure is to recognize and stop myself when I find myself comparing‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs with other people or with a version of myself that I think I should be. I try to not be disappointed in myself when I don‚Äôt finish all the work that I wanted to in one day. By the time that it‚Äôs happened, it‚Äôs already too late to change it, and all that I can do moving forward is start the day anew and try again (maybe with a plan better suited for the current me). Emotional exhaustion is real! I also try to remind myself that there‚Äôs no point in comparing myself because our lives shouldn‚Äôt be a race, and we don‚Äôt need to stick to this mindset of being on a path of consistent, endless growth. We are meant to be people and live our lives the way we want to‚Äînot just to be productive cogs in a machine.
2. Remind yourself of why you wanted to do this in the first place!
What drew you to this? What made you love this at first? And, if it has gotten to the point where you find yourself burned out beyond just an academic setting, what did you used to love to do as a hobby? What did you used to love about the world? What used to have you in so much awe that you wanted it to be forever etched in your memory? It‚Äôs a lot harder than I‚Äôm making it sound, but try to fall in love with the world around you again by starting with small, specific things.
For me, sometimes it‚Äôs recognizing when I‚Äôm going through my day as if I‚Äôm racing through it, and choosing to take a minute to stop and slow down to notice the world around me. Maybe it‚Äôs noticing how full or bright or big the moon looks tonight, or how pretty it is to see the colors of the sunset paint the sky! Maybe it‚Äôs spending time with those you love; taking the time to take care of yourself with a meal you love; playing a game you love; watching a show; closing your eyes and listening to a song that scratches an itch in your brain you didn‚Äôt know you had; going on a drive with the windows down and the music blasting; or so much more!
3. Take a break.
Before you start thinking about how much you need to get done during RRR week, maybe consider giving yourself time to reset. I know that sometimes the thought of taking a break also feels like a chore (especially if you‚Äôre scheduling it in), but now that we have the next 9 days with no instruction, some of us have more opportunities to take a break. Maybe this break comes in the form of an entire day set aside to reset from the rush of classes and work that we‚Äôve been struggling through this past semester, or maybe it comes in the form of setting aside some time every day to rest and relax. And no, eating while doing work is not a break. If you‚Äôre like me and you also feel the strain on your eyes, try to dedicate some time to resting your eyes as well!
I know all of this is easier to say than do, but I hope that this semester ends on a good note, and good luck on finals! We will continue to host office hours through RRR week if anyone would like to stop by!
Follow us on Instagram @mathpeeradvising
Peer Advisor Office Hours
Mondays: 1-2 pm (Kaya)
Tuesdays: 12-1 pm (Audrey), 1-2 pm (Daniel)
Wednesdays: 2-3 pm (Leo)
Thursdays: 2-3 pm (Izzy)']

column2: ["Peer Advisor's Blog: Being a TA (Why you should be one!) #217"]
column5:
["Happy Monday! :D
With ASE applications being due I thought it might be a good time to think about being someone on coursestaff. This summer I was a reader for Math 54 and I graded hws along with taking a CS class. It was a pretty easy job that helped me then this semester get a GSI role for math 1b under Professor Haiman.  I like teaching and it's nice to have a paid job on campus. 
I think the main reason to become a GSI is to have an impact on your community. Teaching someone something and having them say they get it after is a great feeling and leading a discussion section is a good way to build social skills and even learn things yourself. I haven't taken 1B here at Berkeley and each time before discussion I need to make sure I know the content at a level that I can then teach it and answer any questions. Getting a calculus refresher is fun, especially now that my brother in high school is taking it I can help him better. Also, it's interesting to see some of the content they do as sometimes it's similar to upper div content just without justification. In fact, one of the GSIs made a worksheet that loosely used complex analysis (singularities) but presented it in a very 1b level-digestible format. I'm taking 185 and it helped me see a bigger picture application.
Overall course staff is a great way to be a part of the math community and help people. I encourage everyone to apply.  For those interested here's the link to read up about the job and apply. Good luck! 
That's it for now. Make sure to follow us on IG: @mathpeeradvising

Tuesdays: 12-1 pm (Audrey), 1-2 pm (Daniel)
Wednesdays: 2-3 pm (Leo)
