['Good morning y‚Äôall!
Reminder to please follow @mathpeeradvising on Instagram for updates on all our math peer advising events and other information for math majors!
We have a peer advising podcast! Stay tuned for the next episode where we will be discussing the experiences of women in math.
As this is my first blog post and first semester as a peer advisor, I wanted to share my insights on a fundamental topic that I wish I had known about much earlier in my mathematical journey: what it means to identify as an algebraist vs. an analyst. I learned about the terms ‚Äúalgebraist‚Äù and ‚Äúanalyst‚Äù for the first time as a junior at Berkeley and ever since then I noticed that I hear about these mathematical subcultures seemingly all the time. Thus, I want to go into a brief explanation of these two types of math in order to demystify these foundational categories and give other students some insight into this aspect of math community culture. 
From my understanding, algebraists prefer topics related to abstract algebra and broadly tend to focus on operations which have already proven to be valid and effective and attempt to find different contexts in which these operations can be utilized effectively. Algebra encompasses areas of study such as linear algebra, abstract algebra, elementary algebra, and algebraic geometry. Some structures and concepts algebraists focus on are groups, rings, fields, and algebraic equations. 
Analysts prefer topics related to real analysis and broadly tend to focus on forming mental models of a system from which intuitions can flow which allow valid calculations. Analysis encompasses areas of study such as real analysis, complex analysis, harmonic analysis, and functional analysis. Some structures and concepts algebraists focus on are limits, derivatives, integrals, series, and topological spaces.
How do I know if I am an analyst or an algebraist?
Aside from the desire to help students learn a bit about their identities in the math world, I was inspired to write on this topic because a friend recently told me about a sure-fire way to tell if someone is an analyst or an algebraist. It all comes down to one question: How do you eat your corn? If you google anything along the lines of algebraists vs. analysts, you will find many references to a 2010 blog post called ‚ÄúAnalysis vs Algebra predicts eating corn?‚Äù which details one mathematician‚Äôs observation at a department lunch in graduate school. Corn on the cob was served at lunch and he observed that everyone in the department was eating the corn in one of two ways. Some were eating the corn in a ‚Äútypewriter‚Äù fashion (eating along the length of the corn in a straight line before moving on to the next row) while the others were eating the corn ‚Äúvertically‚Äù in a spiral before moving on to the next spiral column. All of the algebraists were eating their corn in rows while all of the analysts were eating their corn in spirals. My friend told me about this article and surveyed some math students. So far, this theory seems to hold true so if you would like to quickly find out which label you want to claim, just think back to the last time you had corn on the cob. By the way, if you come to my peer advising office hours, you will get more extremely helpful advice like this. You‚Äôre welcome.
Who cares?
I truly think it is perfectly fine to not care at all about this topic. In fact, I encourage you to not overly invest yourself in the mission to find what category you fit into best as there is no need to limit yourself with such labels. Though it can be fun to discover a new aspect of your mathematical identity, know that these labels are not definite or all-encompassing and I encourage you to find love for both algebra and analysis. However, I think figuring out which topics you find more interesting is quite helpful (especially earlier on in your college career) since it can help you figure out which classes you might enjoy more. Notice, of course, that algebra and analysis are mandatory classes on the math major curriculum. This reflects the fact that mathematicians are generally expected to be experts in both fields. However, if and when you decide which area of math you would like to specialize in as well as what math electives you would like to take, finding your broad preference for analysis vs. algebra is a good place to start.
 I also want to emphasize that a major reason I thought this topic was so intriguing when I first learned about it is that I felt like I had been let in on a small secret in the math community culture. A big issue I have with the math community is this habit of gatekeeping so I wanted to work towards combating this by openly sharing the fact that I learned about these categories rather late in my math career and giving a (hopefully) clear and accessible explanation of what it means to identify with these labels.
-Kaya
Peer Advisor Office Hours:
Mondays: 1-2pm (Kaya)
Tuesdays: 12-1pm (Audrey), 1-2pm (Daniel)
Wednesdays: 2-3pm (Leo)
Thursdays: 2-3pm (Izzy)']

column2: ["Peer Advisor's Blog: Reflections on Starting my Last Year as a Senior #195"]
column5:
['Happy Sunday!
We had Peer Advising Night this past Thursday! Thank you to everyone who came out! For those who couldn‚Äôt make it, or would like to see the information on the slides once more, here are the slides!
Follow us on instagram @mathpeeradvising for information on all math peer advising events and general advice for math majors!
With midterm season descending upon us, I‚Äôve been having some conflicting feelings regarding my last year in college. I can‚Äôt wait until I graduate and no longer have to go through rolling waves of midterms that extend throughout the entire semester, but at the same time, I find myself hesitant to grow up and graduate. On one hand, I feel so burned out and ready to stop dreading deadlines. But on the other hand, at least the deadlines that we‚Äôre chasing in college are more explicitly defined, and I‚Äôm surrounded by a supportive community that helps me get through all of it. After we graduate, we‚Äôre all going to separate and have to form new friendships without having classes in common as a convenient medium through which to bond. Because of this, I really dug my heels in the ground for this semester and resisted against letting go of college life by getting involved in as much as I could before I no longer had the chance to: that‚Äôs how I ended up applying to become a peer advisor! Even if this may be the last time I get to lay down on the glade enveloped by the warmth of the Berkeley summer sun, dance under the blinding lights on the Zellerbach stage with the music vibrating through my entire body, enjoy a picnic on the grass near West Crescent with pastries from the Berkeley farmer‚Äôs market, admire the fleeting beauty of the cherry blossom petals falling all around campus, stop to look at the view of the bay when I walk past the Campanile, explore the seemingly never-ending sections of the Botanical Gardens, and so much more, maybe at least I can preserve these memories that I will undoubtedly forget eventually by passing my experiences on to those around me. So, without further ado, although it‚Äôs been done so many times before, here are some tips based on my experiences in Berkeley:
1. Get involved and/or build your own community & support system
If I could only offer one piece of advice, I would say to get involved, or build your own community & support system in a way that works for you! When I first became a UC Berkeley student, it was during the pandemic, so I had stayed at home for my entire first year. I honestly didn‚Äôt even feel like a Cal student; I felt so isolated when the extent of my interactions with the UC Berkeley community mainly boiled down to the blue light from my laptop screen (though it was minimal when the professor stopped sharing their screen and became drowned out in a sea of black squares), and the voices of people coming through my earbuds. However, my experience completely changed after a friend suggested that I attend a GEM meeting to see how it was. Once I started getting involved in GEM, I found my own community of friends and the confidence I needed to develop more friendships across campus! I have realized that personally, one of the easiest ways for me to find close friends is by finding a community space that I feel comfortable in and enjoy, and then finding ways to get involved. This realization is partially the reason some of you may know me as your Stat 20 tutor, your Math 151 reader, or even the person who used to spam you with weekly newsletter emails from GEM!
However, the main point is not about arbitrarily signing up to participate in as many organizations possible! Getting involved in these activities is just the way in which I found it easiest to find my own support system‚Äîwhich is what truly helped me feel at home in the Cal community. Classes feel so much more manageable (and sometimes even enjoyable) when I have someone else in the class to talk to, struggle with, ask questions to, and attend office hours with! As someone who gets in her head very frequently and easily, feeling isolated in my struggles in a course is probably one of the most stressful experiences I have had as a student. When I felt like I was the only one who was struggling, I became unable to focus during lectures because all I could think about was how behind and lost I was‚Äîtrapping myself inside a cycle of self-doubt and anxiety that snowballed until either the final is over, or I drop the class. What I hope to hold onto the most is not the proofs that I‚Äôve learned from lecture, but these memories and friendships that I have made. I truly could not have made it through all four years at Berkeley without all the times that I‚Äôve gone to cafes to study and do homework with friends, treated ourselves to some dessert and/or boba after a devastating midterm, and just struggled together & helped each other figure out what we‚Äôre stuck on. Even outside the scope of our classes, just being able to work together to overcome rough moments in our lives and share in our celebrations has truly made me so grateful for my time here.
2. Fall in love with the small things
As it is very easy to feel burned out from all of the constant sea of deadlines, projects, exams, and responsibilities, whenever I find myself dreading the start of each coming day and feeling stuck in this monotonous routine of bleh, I try to remind myself to appreciate the small things that I‚Äôve come to take for granted, and recall why I chose to follow this path in the first place.
Personally, I love taking note of the nature around me in order to fall in love with life again. Especially when it feels like my eyes are constantly glued to some sort of electronic screen as a college student, it feels nice to disconnect for even a few seconds to appreciate what is around me. As the weather starts to cool down, I find a sense of serenity in feeling the ripples of the wind across my skin and hearing the rustling of the trees as I walk to class each morning, when the rainy season comes as the leaves start to change color, when the cherry blossoms bloom momentarily and flitter to the ground almost immediately, and when the sun provides some warmth as I lay down on the grass with my earbuds in and close my eyes.
I have also started a personal Notion page to keep track of cafes that I have visited around Berkeley to commemorate my experiences. It‚Äôs very easy for me to quickly forget how much I enjoyed the avocado toast and iced honey latte from States Coffee, the Thai iced coffee from Royal Ground Coffee, the soup of the day‚Äôs from the Musical Offering Cafe, the black sesame latte from CoRo Coffee Room, and etc. By keeping notes on my first thoughts, I can reminisce in the joy I felt when I first experienced these cafes.
3. Take the time to learn more about yourself
Take the time to learn more about what environments you tend to study best in, what tends to drain your energy easily, where and when you need to draw your boundaries for time commitments & friends, what brings you joy, what makes you feel like all of this is worth working for, and anything else you can learn about yourself!
College is a unique period of time in our lives where we enjoy some sense of independence, without being simultaneously bombarded with all of the responsibilities that come with being an adult. With this freedom and capacity to explore as a college student, I have learned so much more about myself that helps better inform how I should plan my days and spend my time so that I don‚Äôt feel too overwhelmed and/or drained at the end of the day. Moreover, taking the time to learn about myself and reflecting on how I can work towards being a version of myself that I am proud of has also helped me grow as a person, friend, and daughter.
So, if you ever want to hear more about my experiences here at Berkeley, talk more about cafes & study spots, freak out about upcoming deadlines and exams, ask for some advice regarding Stat 20, Math 151, or any other classes that I am familiar with, feel free to drop by during office hours!
Peer Advisor Office Hours:
Mondays: 1-2 pm (Kaya)
Tuesdays: 12-1 pm (Audrey), 1-2 pm (Daniel)
Wednesdays: 2-3 pm (Leo)
Thursdays: 2-3 pm (Izzy)']

column2: ["Peer Advisor's Blog: Being a Woman in Math #193"]
column5:
["Happy Friday everyone!  
Peer Advising Night will be taking place next Thursday, October 12 in Evans 1015. Doors will open at 5:30pm and pizza will be served. If you‚Äôre feeling overwhelmed with choosing courses for next semester or just looking for more information on them, come join us for a good time. The peer advisors and MUSA will be going through each of the courses offered next semester and giving our thoughts. Hope to see you there!
Follow us on instagram @mathpeeradvising for information on all math peer advising events and general advice for math majors.
The peer advisers will be posting every week on some topics relevant to math majors. To start this semesters‚Äô posts I wanted to talk about something that has been on my mind a lot this year, which is my feelings about being a woman in math. 
The gender gap in my classes feels far more extreme and evident than my classes last year. Because there are so few women present, I feel that I am unwillingly being made a representative of the gender. Maybe others don‚Äôt see it that way, and this is my self-consciousness speaking, but it seems that if I always notice when one of the very few women in a lecture asks a question, others notice when I do as well. This has also made my already present feelings of imposter syndrome and shyness stronger. I still feel set apart from many of my peers because I‚Äôm a transfer, and now I feel further set apart due to my gender. Consequently, it's hard for me to ask questions in class or to discuss homework with my peers because I‚Äôm afraid to be a poor representative for women in math as a group. If I ask an obvious question or talk about a bad homework grade, people will not only think that I‚Äôm bad at math, but they will think that all women are. I think this might hold, at least in some way, for the other women in my classes as well since often none of us ask questions or participate. 
I‚Äôm sure many people here experience imposter syndrome and feel like they stand out by being a part of an underrepresented group in their major. I‚Äôve been trying to talk about this experience more since I don‚Äôt think I took it seriously enough last year. I‚Äôve always known there was a gender gap in the math department here, but it was close enough in my previous classes that it didn‚Äôt bother me as much and I didn‚Äôt realize how extreme it could get. 
With this topic in mind, we (the math peer advisors) plan to host a panel on gender equity in November. Please reach out if you have any specific questions you want us to cover!
-Izzy

column2: ["Peer Advisor's Blog: Reflections on Being a Transfer #121"]
column5:
["Happy Friday!
We had Peer Advising night this Tuesday, thank you to everyone who came. For those who couldn't make it, here are the slides. 
We made a Math Peer Advising instagram! Follow us @mathpeeradvising for information on all math peer advising events and general advice for math majors.
This week, as I finish up my first year at Berkeley, I wanted to talk about my experiences as a transfer student so far. These are my unique experiences, but they may resonate with some of you. 
When I first came to Berkeley I was very worried about only having two years here before graduating and I was concerned I wouldn‚Äôt be successful in my classes as there was a significant jump in difficulty between community college courses and upper division courses here. Everyone told me Berkeley would be hard and to take my first semester easy, so I took some classes I wasn‚Äôt particularly interested in because they seemed easier. While this did make my first semester easier, it also made me feel more behind and like I was wasting my time when I was doing work for a class I didn‚Äôt care about. This semester, I‚Äôm taking mostly upper-division math classes and I‚Äôve found that I‚Äôm much more willing to put in the necessary work when I care about the class, and as a result, I‚Äôve been more successful in these classes so far. The first semester at Berkeley can be a shock and I don‚Äôt want to recommend overdoing it to anyone, but I also think that some of us get scared and hold ourselves back. 
Another fear I had was that I would never get to know any professors or be able to be involved in the math community here. These seemed to me like things I needed to have started freshman year, and that I was coming in too late. As far as getting to know professors, just showing up during office hours does so much, depending on the size of your class. Knowing my professors has vastly improved my experience here as I enjoy going to class more and I‚Äôve become far more comfortable asking for help on the homework or asking for class or reading recommendations. For getting involved in the math community, going to club meetings and talks has been very helpful for me. I was scared to go to any talks last semester because I felt so unqualified to even listen to somebody talk, but once I let go of trying to understand everything I found it much easier. Sometimes I just recognize a few words of a talk, and I‚Äôm okay with that. I think of it as something to be excited about that I might one day understand more and I find it very motivating. 
In conclusion, what I‚Äôve learned so far at Berkeley is to just put myself out there and pursue what I‚Äôm interested in. I wish I could tell past me to not be so scared of this school and to take advantage of everything I can since I only have two years here. 
Peer Advisor Office Hours:
Mondays: 9:30-10:30 AM (Leo)
Tuesdays: 2-3 PM (Daniel)
Wednesdays: 3-4 PM (Isabella)
Thursdays: 10-11 AM (Sophia), 2-3 PM (Vanessa)"]

https://berkeley.zoom.us/j/95991674380?pwd=bnVHQUhFdjhLNi9DVFNnQ3hoZEg3Zz09
-Vanessa"]

["Happy Friday everyone! To start with, I have some very important announcements from the Peer Advising Team. 
Peer Advising Night will be taking place next Tuesday, April 11 in Evans 1015. Doors will open at 5:30pm and pizza will be served. If you‚Äôre feeling overwhelmed with choosing courses for next semester or just looking for more information on them, come join us for a good time. The peer advisors and MUSA will be going through each of the courses offered next semester and giving our thoughts. Hope to see you there!
We made a Math Peer Advising instagram! Follow us @mathpeeradvising for information on all math peer advising events and general advice for math majors.
Now, let‚Äôs get into the blog post. As a graduating senior, I wanted to use this post to reflect on the lessons I've learned as a math major and a college student in general.
--
I‚Äôve always been guilty of failing to appreciate the now‚ÄìI‚Äôve spent a good amount of time in college complaining about all the p-sets I have due and never ending midterm season and waking up for my early classes. But as graduation looms, when I glue myself to a library seat to work on a p-set, I find myself just enjoying the process because it‚Äôs probably going to be one of the last times I‚Äôll ever do this. It‚Äôs crazy how quickly it happened, but soon I won‚Äôt be a math student anymore. In about 5 weeks, many of us will be graduating and starting anew. Maybe it‚Äôs because of how the pandemic dominated our college exp, or maybe I was always going to feel this way, but there‚Äôs still so much I want to do. Throughout this semester, I‚Äôve found myself reflecting on my experiences at Berkeley and thinking about how to make the most of the time I have left. 
Back when I was a freshman admit, a very wise math major imparted on me two pieces of advice that he claimed were the sole ingredients in the recipe for collegiate success. All throughout college, making those two things my priority has guided a lot of my smarter decision-making and now I suppose it‚Äôs my turn to impart them on you:
Get eight hours of sleep a night.
Go to office hours. 
It‚Äôs hard to overstate the importance of sleep in maintaining mental health. On the academic side of well-being, office hours keeps you engaged in courses and as an added bonus is an opportunity to get to know some of the really cool people of the math department. Since the math major requirements are not too extensive, another piece of advice I have is to take some classes just for fun. Classes like intro to astronomy, logic, and history of math didn‚Äôt fulfill any requirements for me, but have had the biggest impacts on how I view the world of math. 
Looking back, I wish I knew not to place too much pressure on myself to know exactly who I was or where I was going. I remember hearing the phrase ‚Äúcollege is the best time of your life‚Äù and feeling inordinate pressure to be having a good time all the time. And throughout much of the transition to college and during the isolation of the pandemic, I felt like a failure for feeling lost and uncertain about myself. It took me a while to learn that the reality is there‚Äôs always going to be highs and lows. To realize that it‚Äôs okay if my college experience didn‚Äôt go the way I expected, or if I‚Äôm still unsure of what I‚Äôm doing with my life. That allowing myself the space to change plans and figure it out is part of the fun. I‚Äôm a different person than I was when I arrived at Berkeley, and I want to celebrate that. If you‚Äôre also graduating, congratulations on what has probably been a pretty wild ride. And whether or not you are graduating, I hope you always remember to take the time to celebrate yourself and your journey so far.
Thanks for reading and feel free to stop by office hours for advice or just to chat :)
Best,
Sophia
--

Wednesdays: 3-4 PM (Isabella)
Thursdays: 10-11 AM (Sophia), 2-3 PM (Vanessa)"]

column2: ["Peer Advisor's Blog: Recap and Associated Thoughts from our Event #106"]
column5:
['Hi everyone, it's Leo. This is already my second peer advising post and I thought I would write a mini reflection on our panelist event with Persson, Webb, and Kuan. Firstly, I'd like to thank all the panelists for joining and making it a fun night filled with pizza and discussion.
Secondly, I myself have been very indecisive on whether or not I want to go to grad school. My dad did a physics Ph.D. in Italy before moving to the States, so I've always wanted to mimic that. I consistently asked my GSIs throughout the lower divs about whether or not to do a Ph.D. and most of them say something similar. "You really need to want to do a Ph.D. to do a Ph.D., after all in general it's 4+ years of your life."
As of now, Im looking at the year in the industry before I decide whether or not to go to grad school. Currently, I quant jobs and things more in the applied sector are something I hope to get an internship for the summer of junior year. The cool thing about the math major which I remember Persson touching on during the panel is that math is very versatile. People want you in the tech sector, the sciences, etc. You can do a lot with it and if you are unsure about what you want to do after college like me it is a comfortable place to be.
Another point Id like to touch on is the difference between research math and the math you learn in say upper div. Rachel Webb mentioned that the transition between undergrad and graduate math wasn't difficult but that going from doing math in classes to working on a hard problem for months is a hard transition. She wished that she had been more social and active as it could have made that change easier. I asked my friend who is in a physics lab here at Berkeley and she said that she realized how useless some of the derivations and equations really are and that research is about making approximations and tinkering with people as real-world problems are generally not "in a vacuum".
Ph.D. Why or why Not? : (some bullet points from random testimonies Ive read on the internet)
The program can take several years, and the work is often challenging, the pressure to succeed is intense.
Research in mathematics is often done alone, with long periods of time spent working on complex problems by yourself. If you like working with people a math Ph.D. may not be the best idea.
In conclusion, while pursuing a Ph.D. can be rewarding, it is not for everyone. It is important to carefully consider your options, career-wise, and personally before continuing. Remember, there are many other ways to engage with math, outside of a Ph.D. and no one is really forcing you to do it unless they are somehow. Hope this helps someone even though it is very rambly. :D  
Office Hours
Leo Villani: Monday 9:30-10:30 am
Isabella Arcoleo: Monday 3-4 pm 
Daniel Tsan: Tuesday 2-3 pm
Sophia Xiao: Thursday 10-11 am
Vanessa Li: Thursday 2-3 pm']

['Hi everyone, Daniel here. 
I hope all of you are staying strong as we head into the 8th week of instruction this semester. For many of us, this is a stressful period of the semester that's plagued with midterms (my Math 113 midterm is next week). It can be overwhelming and leave you overly fatigued and stressed to the point where you don't even feel anything anymore.
As a result of the influx of midterms during this current stretch of the semester, I feel like a lot of students (me included) find themselves trapped indoors. We're stuck in our rooms, in libraries, in cafes, or any studying location of our choice for hours on end, staring at our computer screens and textbooks in hopes of understanding everything in time for the midterm.
So, today I'd like to encourage a little bit of (healthy) procrastination and share some beautiful photos of nature. But, these aren't any old photos of the outdoors. This is a math blog after all. These photos capture natural occurrences of fractals.
If you haven't heard of a fractal before, here's a bit of context. According to Wolfram MathWorld, a fractal is "an object or quantity that displays self-similarity, in a somewhat technical sense, on all scales". In other words, these geometric shapes have patterns that repeat infinitely. Perhaps one of the most famous examples of this is the Mandelbrot set, named after French-American mathematician Benoit Mandelbrot, who first visualized the set.
Fractals structures with a lot of interesting characteristics to explore. If you are interested, I'd love to share this video series by 3Blue1Brown on fractals and this video by Numberphile on the Mandelbrot set.
Okay, that's enough background. Onto pretty nature photos!
First up, we have the snowflake. We weren't as lucky here in Berkeley, but in other parts of California, the recent storm cycle brought actual snow to cities that haven't seen it in years. Note the "branches" of the snowflake have their own similar "branches".
Next, we have something that you CAN find in Berkeley: trees (more specifically, tree branches). Similar to above, tree branches have similar patterns at each scale level, creating a beautiful fractal structure.
One more photo. If you're a fan of broccoli or cauliflower, you've probably heard of Romanesco broccoli. This half-broccoli, half-cauliflower has really fascinating fractal structures in its spiral buds. Another interesting fact about this type of broccoli is that it's related to another famous mathematical figure: the Fibonacci sequence  (requires its own blog post). 
If you made it this far, thank you so much for taking a break from your busy schedule to read my post. I hope this has inspired you to look at nature with a mathematical lens and to perhaps go outside and touch some grass. 
As always, if you have any math-related questions, feel free to stop by our drop-in office hours! We also have a wonderful panel event for math majors happening TODAY, March 7th, at 6:30 pm in Evans 1015. Check out Hanh's post for more information.
Office Hours

Tuesdays:
2-3 PM (Daniel)
Wednesdays:
3-4 PM (Isabella)
Thursdays:
10-11 AM (Sophia), 2-3 PM (Vanessa)
That's all from me. Good luck with your midterms!!
~ Daniel Tsan']

["Here are some resources and advice to help you get started on your summer research position/job search. 
[I realize that the current summer recruitment season is coming to an end, but for those of you looking for a position for the summer of 2024 and beyond, I hope this post helps you]
REUs
REUs are summer undergraduate research projects in colleges and universities across the US that are (usually) funded by the National Science Foundation. Many REU programs have pre-determined research topics (e.g. ‚ÄúStatistics and applications in forensic science,‚Äù ‚ÄúAlgebraic curves,‚Äù ‚ÄúGraph theory and Lie theory‚Äù); you write one application per program. Participants work in small groups in conjunction with faculty members and may produce papers at the end of the summer. If you're looking for a more traditional/conventional academic research position, you should start here. REUs are a great route to take if you are looking to apply to Ph.D. programs in the future. Here are some sites to help you with your search.
Math REU Programs -- a nice comprehensive list of programs which gets updated fairly consistently.
NSF list of REUs -- the NSF pays for most (but not all) REUs so this is a good source; particularly for new REUs. NSF-funded REUs provide participants with stipends.
AMS list of REUs -- put together by the American Mathematical Society.
When applying, keep a few things in mind:
Apply to multiple programs. Programs are highly competitive, with hundreds of (highly qualified) students competing for 10-20 slots. 
Letters of recommendation matter‚Äîgive your letter writers an adequate heads up and enough time to write a good letter. 
If possible, try to get someone with a senior position to write your letters. Like it or not, a letter from a professor takes precedence over a letter from a GSI.
Start your application early. Postings come out towards the end of the fall semester; applications are due mid-January to early February. Notify your letter writers before the fall semester ends and work on your application over the winter break. 
There are programs that look for students from traditionally underrepresented groups in math, including ROMUS at Ohio State and MSRI-UP here at Berkeley.
Some programs accept seniors who will have graduated by the summer they take place. So for those of you in the class of 2024, it is not too late to apply to an REU next semester. From my personal inquiry, the University of Chicago and Ohio State University (ROMUS) programs accept seniors/folks who have not gotten into grad school and the Texas State program accepts seniors with extenuating circumstances.
Other Research.
National laboratories like the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory and the Los Alamos National Laboratory host post-doctoral researchers and staff researchers who may be open to hosting/mentoring undergraduate research interns over the summer. Many of the researchers work in math-related fields (like graph theory). It is worth noting that most of these programs are paid ($20-$30/hour). 
There are specific internship programs that you can apply to (such as the Summer Undergraduate Computing Internship at LLNL or one of the applied mathematics internships at LANL), but it is also worth cold-emailing researchers whose work you are interested in. In the latter case, if a researcher agrees to host you for the summer, the laboratory can create a position for you. Here‚Äôs a list of researchers from the Lawrence Livermore‚Äôs Center for Applied Scientific Computing; you can start there and look at some of the papers produced by the researchers. Many of the research projects at LLNL/LANL are student-driven, meaning your research mentor will work to help you accomplish a goal you want to achieve by the end of the program. Like the REUs above, there is a chance that you will produce a paper at the end of this program.
Other opportunities.
The NSA (National Security Agency) offers summer internship programs for statistics and mathematics undergraduates, including the Director‚Äôs Summer Program and the Cryptanalysis and Signals Analysis Summer Program. 
For more information, I‚Äôll direct you to the Career Center here at Berkeley. It is a great resource to use for your job/internship search. They host career fairs, help with interview prep, and more.
Note: programs with the NSA and any national laboratory may require security clearances, which can take months to process, so apply as early as possible
---

Thursdays: 10-11 AM (Sophia), 2-3 PM (Vanessa)"]

column2: ["Peer Advisors' Blog: Summer classes as a Math Major - Are They Worth It? #76"]
column5:
['Happy Friday! I‚Äôm Sophia, one of your resident math peer advisors. Registration for the summer session is now open, so I thought I‚Äôd answer some common questions math majors may have about enrolling in summer classes at UC Berkeley. 
What are the benefits of summer classes?
Taking summer classes can be helpful if you want to graduate early or need to catch up on classes, especially if you didn‚Äôt do well in a course and want to retake it. The classes are smaller, so you can get to know your professors better. The campus overall is much less crowded, so the atmosphere is more relaxed and peaceful. However, that doesn‚Äôt mean your classes or professors will be more ‚Äúchill,‚Äù which leads us to‚Ä¶ 
How many classes should I take? What is the workload going to be like?
Summer classes condense 15 weeks of school into 6 or 8 weeks, depending on the session so the pacing is almost 2-3 times faster than a normal semester. All math classes are offered in the same 8 week long session C. While it‚Äôs definitely doable to take two classes at the same time, the pacing can be overwhelming. At most, you should plan to take half of what you would normally take in a semester. With two technicals, you can basically expect to not do much else that summer since it‚Äôs the equivalent of taking 4 technicals in a normal semester, with even less flexibility in due dates. A common pairing of classes that will give you a more manageable and relaxing summer is a technical and an easier breadth. Pay attention to the hours & workload listed in the catalog when planning your schedule and bear in mind that just because you can take on a certain workload doesn‚Äôt mean you should. Having a stressful summer can cause burn out, especially going straight into the fall semester without a real break. Try to pick a schedule that still allows you the time to enjoy your summer!
Which math classes should I take?
Some math classes lend themselves better to the hypersonic style of the summer session than others. For example, Math W128a with Persson is a very popular and doable math course to take over summer. On the other hand, I generally don‚Äôt recommend taking a core requirement like 104 or 113 over the summer unless you have a lot of time to dedicate to the course. These classes are really important prerequisites for other math classes, and they introduce new topics that can take time to really internalize. 
So are they worth it?
Taking summer classes can be a great way to have fun on a beautiful campus while being productive. However, it‚Äôs important to maintain a schedule that allows for good work/life balance and plenty of time to relax. As we all know, the spring and fall semesters can get intense, so over the summer it‚Äôs okay to take on a less intense course workload or take a break from studying altogether and focus on other things that are important to you! 
I hope this is helpful to any of you considering enrolling in summer sessions. Stop by OH if you want to chat or get some personalized advice! 
Office Hours
Leo Villani: Monday 9:30-10:30 am
Isabella Arcoleo: Monday 3-4 pm 
Daniel Tsan: Tuesday 2-3 pm
Sophia Xiao: Thursday 10-11 am
Vanessa Li: Thursday 2-3 pm']

["This post is for everyone wondering how they will keep up with studying for all their classes and corresponding midterm. 
In high school, like most people I was a procrastinator. I rarely took notes as there weren't many tests and I was extremely lazy when studying for AP exams. Somehow I ended up at Berkeley anyway (this is a bit facetious) but during the first midterm season, I was punished for my sluggishness. After a rough first couple of midterms, I decided to make some changes to my study habits. I found Tau Beta Pi, and started doing practice exams before tests and would either read the textbook or review my notes if I had them. The second midterms went better and finals even more so. Now as a sophomore, it has become more of a habitual process to find practice tests and read the class notes. 
One of the best tips I can give is to tailor your studying to the professor. For different math classes, I have had very different methods. Take 110, Linear Algebra Done Right by Sheldon Axler was an insightful textbook so for each test, I would review all the homework problems and copy down the lemmas to get accustomed to the content. I would only start doing the practice tests one or two days before the exam and then go back and review the concepts I wasn't comfortable with. Writing a cheat sheet even if you can't bring it to the test is very helpful. There was a question on the first 110 midterm that I wouldn't have had the slightest of idea how to do without my cheat sheet.
On the other hand, when taking math 54, Professor Paulin's practice exams gave me a comprehensive overview of the content. This class also had 3 discussion sections a week so talking with my GSI on topics I was struggling with made the studying process much faster.
What Im saying boils down to the conclusion that there are many ways to study and that adapting to the class and professor can make things easier and faster. Stop by during office hours if you want more tips! :D
OH:
Isabella Arcoleo: Monday 3-4 pm 
Vanessa Li: Thursday 2-3 pm
Daniel Tsan: Tuesday 2-3 pm
Leo Villani: Monday 9:30-10:30 am
Sophia Xiao: Thursday 10-11 am"]

column2: ["Peer Advisors' Blog: What I'm Thankful for This Year #47"]
column5:
["Hello everyone! This is Daniel, one of your math peer advisors. Just a reminder that my weekly office hours are on Wednesdays from 1-2 pm in Evans 947 (I also open up a zoom meeting if you want to drop-in virtually). Please come if you have any questions about the math department or want to hang out and get to know me! I'm always open to questions and you can direct them to either the peer advisors' email or my Berkeley email. With that, let's get started with today's blog!
With Thanksgiving literally right around the corner, I wanted to take a moment and discuss the things I'm thankful for. 
#1 I have to start off with my family. Without them, I definitely wouldn't be where I am today. Thanks to my family, I found a passion for mathematics from a very early age that still drives my desire to study math at a university level today.
#2 I'm thankful for math! Math has given me a path in life to follow. It's a beautiful subject that keeps surprising me with everything I learn. While it can be frustrating when I run into a difficult problem, finally solving it brings satisfaction like nothing else. I think a lot of people who love math can agree with me on this point.
#3 I'm thankful for Leonhard Euler. Why? While many mathematicians have contributed to it over time, it's a known fact that graph theory was introduced by Euler! Graph theory has some sentimental value to me because it was the first math topic I did a research project on (I researched how Google Maps uses graph theory to give you the shortest route to your destination). While graph theory proofs can be a real pain, graph theory's applications are so vast that I'll be able to solve a lot of real-world problems in the future with the help of graph theory. Thanks, Euler!
#œÄ I'm thankful for pumpkin pie. Man, Thanksgiving dinner is not complete without pumpkin pie, and that's a fact.
#4 I'm thankful for my friends in math. Shoutout to Andrew! I'm always able to ask my math friends for advice, whether it's about what professor to take a class with or how to word a proof clearly. It's so important to have a network that you can rely on for help! I hope you all can use resources (like peer advisors) in the math department to build your network of friends. 
#5 Finally, I'm thankful for my math peer advisors team! Shoutout to Hanh and all the peer advisors that I work with. They're encouraging, thoughtful, and very knowledgeable in mathematics. I've had a really good time working with them this semester and I hope to work with them on more projects in the future.
Those are a couple of things I'm thankful for this Thanksgiving. Take some time to think about what you're thankful for, and go and thank them! Stay tuned for more weekly blog posts and a special present from the peer advisors team soon!!
Enjoy your break,
Daniel"]

column2: ['Research Study on AI Learning Tool, Looking for Participants! #343']
column5:
["Participants Needed for Research Study on AI learning tool!
The Vive Center at UC Berkeley is looking for participants for an innovative research study on an AI learning tool. This project aims to help students with their course learning through various features and academic planning. We want to get your input on what helps you! 
Study Details:

Must be a Berkeley student

column5:
["Why are most voice assistants female? Who owns AI-generated art?

We often push the bounds of technological advancement without considering the ethical implications and consequences of our actions. From the rise of performative activism to internet sovereignty and the various ethical issues surrounding Zoom proctoring and the COVID crisis, this DeCal explores the above questions and a variety of other current topics spanning social media, bioethics, education, AI, data science, and the environment. We will analyze how technology has evolved to become intertwined with our society as well as the morals that we harbor.

This is a 1-unit P/NP class that meets once per week for 12 weeks. Each class will be 1 hour and 20 minutes. Attendance is mandatory. Besides attendance, class participation, monthly reflections and a final presentation would count towards your grade.

If you're interested, please show up to our first session on Wednesday, 31st January from 5:00 to 6:30 pm in Dwinelle 235 and enroll on CalCentral (CCN: 16758)!

If you have any questions, feel free to contact tsi.decal@gmail.com :)"]

["Hi! I want to advertise the Introduction to Poker DeCal my friends and I are teaching this semester. The course is worth 2 upper division statistics units, open to all experience levels, and is a great opportunity to get good at texas hold 'em!
Here's part of the blurb from the course page:
The purpose of this course is to teach students poker fundamentals, both to help them improve at the game and learn wider applications of the game theory found in poker. While we believe students of all skill levels will benefit from the course, it is primarily targeted at beginners and those with an advanced understanding of the game may already be familiar with most material. The course will focus on 6-max No Limit Texas Hold‚Äôem, the most popular variant of Poker played today. We will begin by covering the rules of the game, basic strategic principles, before diving into the mathematics and heuristics used by strong players. While not the focus of the course, we will additionally briefly touch on the psychological aspects of poker, including some common tells and reads found in live play. Disclaimer: At no point during this course will you wager real money. We understand that betting is a sensitive topic for some and you might have issues with the ethical implications, please let us know. We will be focusing on the probability and statistics behind betting.
Attendance is mandatory (sections meet twice a week for two hours). The majority of one's grade comes from attendance. This year, three sections will be offered: MW 5-7pm @ Hearst Mining 390, TTh 5-7pm @ Moffitt 101, and WF 6:30-8:30pm @ Wurster 102. You will only register for one section (two classes) to attend per week.
You can apply for the DeCal here: https://forms.gle/mPyDPQ7F7EKdQrbV7. The application is rolling and will close on Friday, February 2nd at 11:59pm. More information can be found on our decal page here: https://decal.berkeley.edu/courses/7447.
Please email ucberkeleypokerdecal@gmail.com if you are interested in joining the DeCal or have any questions! Thanks!"]

column2: ['Join AWE, the Association of Women in EE&CS! #256']
column5:
["Interested in joining a community of female-identifying and nonbinary undergraduate students interested in tech? Join AWE!
AWE, or the Association of Women in EE&CS, is a student-run organization at UC Berkeley that seeks to empower female-identifying and nonbinary undergraduate students in electrical engineering, computer science, and related disciplines (including math!).
We host a variety of academic, industry, and social events throughout each semester. Some of the events we host include Breaktimes (casual lunches for members to chat with company recruiters), along with technical and recruiting resources if you're looking to hone your skills. We also host fun socials to interact with other members of the community, as well as engaging social programs such as mentorship, which connects you with another member from AWE.
Ready to join? Our membership form is at https://tinyurl.com/AWE-membership-sp24!
Learn more at our website, follow us on Instagram (@awe.berkeley), and check out our Facebook page to keep in touch. 

Upcoming Events:

column2: ['[Berkeley Math Tournament] Join Our Problem Writing or Logistics Team This Fall! #170']
column5:
["TLDR: Join BMT! No math/contest experience required https://bmt.berkeley.edu/join

Berkeley Math Tournament is recruiting Berkeley students for both our logistics and problem writing teams! BMT is a registered 501c3 dedicated to mathematics education and building interest in STEM by running some of the largest student-run math tournaments in the USA. 
We prioritize creating holistic events that make math more accessible and engaging to middle and high school students compared to what is usually presented in the classroom. Our problem writing team  is responsible for putting together the contest rounds of BMT. 
If you are interested in coming up with fun, challenging problems then you should check out our problem writing meetings!  No formal experience in competitions, problem-writing, or even math is required to make a meaningful impact in BMT. 
Our logistics team  handles all other aspects of running the tournament. If you are interested in: planning large events and fun activities; fostering community; managing tech; working to attain the diversity, equity, and inclusion goals of our organization; marketing to new audiences; collaborating with our international partners; designing graphics, merchandise, etc.; or bringing in sponsorships to help expand our potential impact -- you would be a great fit for our logistics team!  
To anyone interested, fill out our interest form https://bmt.berkeley.edu/join where you'll find a link to join our discord server! While now is an ideal time to join, members will be able to join on a rolling basis at any point throughout the year -- happy Fall semester!! 
Email: questions@bmt.berkeley.edu
Web: https://bmt.berkeley.edu
Instagram: @berkeley_mt"]

['Hi everyone! The Association of Women in EE&CS (AWE) runs a mentorship program every semester where we pair underclassmen and transfer students with upperclassmen - especially if you‚Äôre new to Berkeley, it‚Äôs a great way to make friends, talk to someone else about classes, and get tips on how to find internships or research. We also host various events throughout the semester so you‚Äôll have the opportunity to meet other mentorship pairings.\nIt can be super intimidating navigating Berkeley, but mentorship is a great way to feel more welcome at such a big school. Please don‚Äôt hesitate to apply, we accept everyone - the application is just a way for us to gauge interest and help us form pairings. \nFeel free to email mentorship@awe.berkeley.edu with any questions! Apply at the following link by Friday, September 8th at 11:59 pm: tinyurl.com/fa23mentorship']

column2: ['Join the Berkeley AI Safety Initiative for Students (BASIS)! #166']
column5:
['Join the Berkeley AI Safety Initiative for Students (BASIS)!
‚ÄúMitigating the risk of extinction from AI should be a global priority alongside other societal-scale risks such as pandemics and nuclear war.‚Äù
You may have seen the above statement from the Center for AI Safety, signed by top AI scientists and influential figures such as Geoffrey Hinton, Yoshua Bengio, Dawn Song, Sam Altman, and Demis Hassabis. The statement mirrors growing public sentiment: a recent poll found that 61 percent of Americans believe AI threatens humanity‚Äôs future.
The Berkeley AI Safety Initiative for Students is a student organization focused on mitigating catastrophic risks from advanced AI systems. We‚Äôre supporting students through four programs this semester:
Our Introduction to AI Safety Decal, a technical overview of AI safety and the alignment problem, sponsored by Professor Stuart Russell. We‚Äôll cover topics like neural network interpretability, learning from human feedback, goal misgeneralization in reinforcement learning agents, and eliciting latent knowledge from large language models. Our curriculum was first developed by an AI safety researcher at OpenAI. See here for more details (e.g. curriculum, application, FAQ).
The Supervised Program for Alignment Research (SPAR), an opportunity to do guided research under a AI safety researcher. Some of the projects (including the one I did last semester) are heavily theoretical and mathematical or apply math to model ML systems. Students have the opportunity to receive units and publish their work.
Our AI Governance reading group, an 8-week program to read about and discuss governance solutions with free food!
Our Paper Reading Group, where students with technical experience discuss recent ML safety papers each week over snacks! This is open to all members; sign up on our interest form to stay posted!
We‚Äôll be having two info sessions on August 31st and September 1st (location TBA) ‚Äî sign up on our interest form to stay tuned!. If you have any questions, please feel free to contact us at aisafetyberkeley@gmail.com, join our Discord server, or reach out/book a meeting with any of our board members. Thanks so much, and we look forward to seeing y‚Äôall around!
INTEREST FORM: https://airtable.com/shrwLNx78Ymus0ojp
Check out our website to keep track of our recruitment timeline! https://berkeleyaisafety.com/']

['Heard about ‚Äúquant‚Äù and want to learn more? Enjoy puzzles and games?
Traders at Berkeley is the premier quantitative finance organization at UC Berkeley. We are dedicated to cultivating professional and academic interest in quant development, trading, and research.
We‚Äôre excited to announce that applications for our DeCal and the club are open!
IEOR 198: Introduction to Quantitative Finance DeCal
We invite all undergraduate and graduate students with any quantitative background to apply! Applications will close next Friday, September 1st 2023.
This is a 2-unit course that teaches fundamentals of quant finance, including topics from market microstructure, market making (options and ETFs), statistical modeling in finance, how to enter the industry, and high frequency trading.
Students will build trading intuition via games, learn how to design predictive models, and build trading bots in Python. The DeCal covers a broad set of topics and aims to reduce the barrier of entry into the field. Guest lectures may be given from traders at companies like Citadel and Headlands to provide perspectives into the industry. Grading is based on attendance, weekly quizzes, and a final project involving real world data.We recommend that students have Python programming experience and a basic probability/statistics knowledge. Locations and times will be finalized but will likely be Thursday evenings (6pm-8pm or 8pm-10pm) on campus.
Club Recruitment
We‚Äôre seeking new club members with an aptitude for quantitative careers and an interest in the industry. All grade levels and backgrounds are welcome to apply. As a member, you‚Äôll help us engage sponsors, plan events, and develop trading games. You can find more about our process on our website. Applications for club membership are open and will close at 11:59 pm PST, September 1st 2023.
Questions?
Please email us if you have any questions. We look forward to seeing your application!
Links
Website
Instagram
DeCal application
Club application
Coffee chats']

['Hi! Effective Altruism at UC Berkeley is organizing high-impact student projects (check them out here)! Notably, we‚Äôre collaborating with Solar4Africa to develop a GPS-data collection app that could provide operational data on solar vehicles being used in rural Malawi.
Other project examples include:
 research on dual-use research policies in biotech (ie research with unintended harms)
visualizations of ideas about long-term future trajectories/longtermism
AI Safety research for students.

-----
Effective altruism is a philosophy and social movement focused on answering one question: how can we help others as much as possible? We‚Äôre a community that rigorously considers the most effective causes and interventions, and take action to make an impact.']

column2: ['Join the Berkeley AI Safety Student Initiative (BAISSI)! #65']
column5:
[' Hello everybody! 

BAISSI is a community of students interested in developing robust, interpretable, and safe machine learning systems. We‚Äôd like to support students towards high-impact technical careers and research in this field. Our club membership is open to all, and we will be organizing socials, hackathons, and workshops!
We‚Äôre also offering two programs this semester:
Our Intro to AI Safety Decal, sponsored by Prof. Stuart Russell. We provide a technical and career/research overview for students interested in technical AI safety research. There will be weekly classes on Mondays at 5-7 PM in Hearst Annex B1, beginning on 1/30. Apply by Wed, 1/25!
The Supervised Program for Alignment Research (SPAR), where students conduct part-time research under an experienced AI safety researcher. Depending on the project, this may culminate in a write-up, published paper in ML venues, or another deliverable. SPAR participants can receive independent research credits (CS 199), and will primarily be students in our DeCal. Apply by Wed, 1/25!
AI Safety needs YOUR MATH SKILLS  to build out its theoretical foundations! For example, check out Erik Jenner‚Äôs or Juan Rocamonde‚Äôs research projects on our SPAR page! And here‚Äôs some examples of theoretical research in the field: 1 (algo info theory), 2 (transformers - mathematical framework), 3 (naturalized induction), 4, 5 (reward hacking), and 6 (logical induction).

If you have any questions, please feel free to contact us at aisafetyberkeley@gmail.com, join our Discord server, or reach out/book a meeting with any of our board members. Thanks so much, and we look forward to seeing y‚Äôall around!
Helpful links: Website, Interest form, Discord server, Linkedin, Facebook']

column2: ['Apply to be a mentor for Computer Science Mentors (CSM) for Spring 2023! #59']
column5:
["Computer Science Mentors (CSM) is a student-run organization that provides guidance and resources in a smaller classroom environment through group tutoring sessions for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 70, CS 88, EECS 16A, and EECS 16B. Each section has 4-7 students and meets once or twice a week for 1 or 1.5hrs. The goal of CSM is to build a personal learning community and social network so that both students and mentors can comfortably seek and receive support. 
For Spring 2023, we're recruiting for the following roles:
Junior Mentors (JMs) for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 70, CS 88C, EECS 16A, and EECS 16B
Associate Mentors (AMs) for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 70, CS 88C, EECS 16A, and EECS 16B
Content Mentors (CMs) for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, and EECS 16A
The application is available at https://tinyurl.com/csm-sp23-app and is due Wednesday January 18th at 11:59PM PT. No late applications will be accepted! 
In CSM, we are committed to diversity and inclusion and value applicants of all backgrounds. We consider applications holistically and value passion for mentoring and willingness to learn over your grades and struggles during your time as a student - we do not consider grades in our application process. Overall, we encourage all who are interested to apply and to give the application your best effort!
Visit https://csmentors.berkeley.edu for more information or get in touch with us at mentors@berkeley.edu!
*Note that CS 70 is the Computer Science equivalent of Math 55. Math Majors who have taken Math 55 are especially encouraged to apply to be a Junior Mentor for CS 70!  "]

['Heard about ‚Äúquant‚Äù and want to learn more? Enjoy puzzles and games?
Traders at Berkeley is the premier quantitative finance organization at UC Berkeley. We are dedicated to cultivating professional and academic interest in quant development, trading, and research.
We‚Äôre excited to announce that applications for our DeCal and the club are open!
IEOR 198: Introduction to Quantitative Finance DeCal
We invite all undergraduate and graduate students with any quantitative background to apply! Applications will close this Friday, January 26 2024.
This is a 2-unit course that teaches fundamentals of quant finance, including topics from market microstructure, market making (options and ETFs), statistical modeling in finance, how to enter the industry, and high frequency trading.
Students will build trading intuition via games, learn how to design predictive models, and build trading bots in Python. The DeCal covers a broad set of topics and aims to reduce the barrier of entry into the field. Guest lectures may be given from traders at companies like Citadel and Headlands to provide perspectives into the industry. Grading is based on attendance, weekly quizzes, and a final project involving real world data.We recommend that students have Python programming experience and a basic probability/statistics knowledge. The class will be on Wednesdays from 5-7pm in Latimer 120 on campus.
Club Recruitment
We‚Äôre seeking new club members with an aptitude for quantitative careers and an interest in the industry. All grade levels and backgrounds are welcome to apply. As a member, you‚Äôll help us engage sponsors, plan events, and develop trading games. You can find more about our process on our website. Applications for club membership are open and will close at 11:59 pm PST, January 26th 2024.
Questions?
Please email us if you have any questions. We look forward to seeing your application!
Links
Website
Instagram
DeCal application
Club application
Coffee chats']

['Interested in leveraging technology to save lives and improve medicine on a global scale? At Medical Technology @ Berkeley (MT@B), we develop medical software, devices, educational tools, scientific writing, and clinical skills to cultivate an interdisciplinary intellectual community uniting future professionals in technology, biomedical and computational science, and medicine. 
Our past consulting partners, such as Stanford Medicine, UCSF Medical Center, and Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory have facilitated our software engineering products to be deployed internationally. We are your one-stop shop to get clinically impactful technology development experience, achieve technical actualization in disciplines across technology and medicine, and contribute to intellectual dialogues across our research and editorial publications community. 
Join one of the fastest growing communities at Berkeley dedicated to building technologies to save patient lives and improving the delivery of medicine internationally. We look for passionate and committed contributors from a multitude of disciplines in any year of education at Berkeley!
Check out our website at mtab.berkeley.edu or send us an email at ucbmtab@gmail.com
For email updates please fill out our interest form at tinyurl.com/mtabsp24 and check out our flier below with more details on our Spring 2024 recruitment cycle. ']

['Berkeley math majors might be interested in serving as counselors at PROMYS this coming summer.  You can read about the program at https://promys.org and especially https://promys.org/programs/promys/for-counselors/ .  The "campers" are high school students who are taking courses in college-level mathematics (e.g., number theory).  The bullet points on the flyer for counselors are as follows:
* Immerse yourself for six weeks in challenging and collaborative mathematics.
* Take advanced seminars and engage in mentored research.
* Each counselor supervises the Number Theory work of 3 or 4 highly motivated high school students.
* Counselors are also encouraged to run their own minicourses, seminars, and guest lectures.
* PROMYS creates an inspiring mathematical community of high school students, undergraduate counselors, faculty, research mentors, visiting mathematicians and guest lecturers.
* Founded in 1989, PROMYS has a large and involved alum community.
Berkeley math majors have been hired by PROMYS pretty much every year in the recent past.  Students who have served as counselors have been happy with their choice.']

["MUSA 174 being offered for the fifth time in Fall 2024. MUSA 174 is a DeCal which covers the fundamentals of category theory, a foundational subject necessary to study most modern fields of math with an algebraic or topological flavor. In particular, we will discuss the basic theory of functors, natural transformations, limits, and the calculus of adjunctions, as well as some additional topics if time permits. We will be following the first four chapters of Emily Riehl's Category Theory in Context.\nThe class is 2 units P/NP, and there will be short-ish weekly homeworks. Students should have already taken Math 110 and Math 113 (or equivalents) and be very comfortable reading and writing proofs to be maximally successful. This class will be especially useful for students considering taking grad courses like Math 250AB, Math 215AB, or Math 256AB, although anyone is welcome to take it regardless of their intentions to take a graduate class.\nWe will be meeting Mondays, Wednesday, and Fridays from 4-5 PM. You can find a link to our interest form, course discord, and syllabus at https://linktr.ee/musa174. Feel free to join the discord to ask any questions! We hope to see you in class!"]

column2: ['Math Monday 04/22: The cobordism hypothesis in low dimensions with Peter Haine #311']
column5:
['Join us for Math Monday with Peter Haine Today at Evans Hall, Room 1011 @ 5 PM (04/22)!
Speaker: Peter Haine 
Title: The cobordism hypothesis in low dimensions 
Full-Length Abstract: In this talk, we‚Äôll introduce cobordisms and talk about topological quantum field theories (TQFTs) in low dimensions. Though these words might sound intimidating, we‚Äôll keep things concrete by sticking to dimensions 1 and 2 where we can draw pictures of everything. Only a good understanding of linear algebra should be necessary to enjoy the talk. The main result we‚Äôll explain is how a 2 dimensional TQFT is determined by a single piece of algebraic data. This result led Baez and Dolan to conjecture that the same is true in all dimensions. This is referred to as the cobordism hypothesis; it was recently proven by a number of mathematicians. We‚Äôll give a hint at how the cobordism hypothesis is related to many interesting areas of math. 
Background: Linear algebra (linear transformations, tensor products, pairings, dual vector spaces, etc.). Knowing what a category is would be helpful, but is not necessary. 
Location: Evans 1011 @ 5PM']
['Join us for Field Games TODAY at Hearst Mining Circle at 6:30 PM!']

column2: ['Math Monday 04/15: A Model theorist looks at familiar mathematical systems with Carol Wood #306']
column5:
['Join us for Math Monday with Carol Wood Today at Evans Hall, Room 1015 @ 5 PM (04/15)!

Speaker: Carol Wood 
Title: A Model theorist looks at familiar mathematical systems
Full Length Abstract: Model theory is a relatively young branch of logic, not much older than I am (but I am old). I would like to give a taste of its flavor by describing a consequence of the compactness theorem, a basic result in logic. Compactness allows nonstandard analogs e.g. of integers and real numbers. In these nonstandard structures we find infinitely large integers and both infinitely large and infinitesimally small real numbers.
Prerequisites: No prerequisites are required. It could be helpful if you ever wondered why the concept of limit in calculus is hard to understand, or maybe it was easy for you!']

column2: ['Math Monday 03/18: Representations of groups and tensor categories with Aleksandra Utiralova #291']
column5:
["Join us for Math Monday with Aleksandra Utiralova Today at Evans Hall, Room 1015 @ 5 PM (03/18)!
Speaker: Aleksandra Utiralova
Title: Representations of groups and tensor categories.
Full-Length Abstract: To any group G one can associate the category Rep(G) of its finite-dimensional representations. It turns out that it is possible to reconstruct G from just this categorical data but to do this one should take into account the tensor product structure on representations of G, which turns Rep(G) into the so-called tensor category. I will give a brief description of this construction and then proceed to discuss tensor categories without the underlying group. The examples I'm interested in include the category of super vector spaces and Deligne categories Rep(S_t), which give interpolations of the category of representations of the symmetric group S_n to complex values of the parameter n.
Preliminaries: Math 110, 113. Also some exposure to the language of category theory (doesn't have to be advanced) and to the notion of the tensor product of vector spaces (I'll give a quick definition, but I'm afraid it will be quite difficult to follow if you've never seen this before)."]

column2: ['Math Monday 03/11:Physics of flows for most efficient heat transfer between two walls with Anuj Kumar #285']
column5:
["Join us for Math Monday with Anuj Kumar Today at Evans Hall, Room 891 @ 5 PM (03/11)!
Speaker: Anuj Kumar
Title: Physics of flows for most efficient heat transfer between two walls
Full Length Abstract: We are interested in the design of forcing in the Navier‚ÄìStokes equation such that the resultant flow maximizes the heat transfer between two differentially heated walls for a given power supply budget. Previous work established that heat transport cannot scale faster than 1/3-power of the power supply. Recently, Tobasco & Doering (PRL'17) constructed self-similar two-dimensional steady branching flows, saturating this upper bound up to a logarithmic correction to scaling. We present a construction of three-dimensional 'branching pipe flows'' that eliminates the possibility of this logarithmic correction and for which the corresponding heat transport scales as a clean 1/3-power law in power supply. Our flows resemble previous numerical studies of the three-dimensional wall-to-wall problem by Motoki, Kawahara & Shimizu (JFM'18). However, using an unsteady branching flow construction, it appears that the 1/3 scaling is also optimal in two dimensions. After carefully examining these designs, we extract the underlying physical mechanism that makes the branching flows 'efficient,'' based on which we present a design of mechanical apparatus that, in principle, can achieve the best possible case scenario of heat transfer. We will further discuss some interesting implications of branching flows, for example, anomalous dissipation in turbulent flows and Rayleigh--B'enard convection."]
['Join us for a Scavenger Hunt TODAY in Evans 748 at 6:30 PM!']

column2: ["Math Monday 03/04: Nash's C1 isometric embedding theorem with Sung-Jin Oh #280"]
column5:
["Join us for Math Monday with Sung-Jin Oh Today at Evans Hall, Room 1015 @ 5 PM (03/04)!

Speaker: Sung-Jin Oh

Title: Nash's C¬π isometric embedding theorem

Full Length Abstract: The goal of this talk is to present a proof of the remarkable Nash C¬π embedding theorem, which states, for instance, that the unit sphere S¬≤ can be 'crumpled' in a C¬π fashion into an arbitrarily small ball in R¬≥. Note that such a statement is obviously false if one replaces `C¬π' by 'smooth', by consideration of curvature. This theorem turned out to be more than a mere curiosity; its proof foreshadowed an important technique called 'convex integration', which found remarkable applications in a wide array of fields, such as symplectic topology, calculus of variations, and fluid dynamics."]

column2: ['Math Monday 02/26: An overview of microlocal geometry with Kendric Schefers #277']
column5:
['Join us for Math Monday with  Kendric Schefers TODAY at Evans Hall, Room 1015 @ 5 PM (02/26)!

Speaker:  Kendric Schefers
Title: An overview of microlocal geometry?
Full Length Abstract: Notions of "smoothness" and "singularity" exist for a wide variety of objects in geometry. The first example one encounters in life are the notions for real-valued functions, where a smooth function is one which is differentiable and a singular one is one which is not. There are also such notions for distributions, D-modules, coherent sheaves, etc. Working microlocally in each of these setting means trying to get a handle on the singularities in question by looking not only at where singularities occur, but also in what direction they arise. In this talk, I will try to give an impression of how the microlocal philosophy is implemented in modern geometry.
Recommended Prerequisites: Linear algebra and multivariable calculus, but truthfully, the talk is going to be very impressionistic. Most of what I talk about would require a lot of advanced material to fully understand, but I'll be sort of hand-waving the whole time. No one who shows up will fully understand the talk, but conversely, anyone who shows up will understand at least the gist of it.']

column2: ['Math Monday 02/12:Generalized Parking Function Polytopes with Andr√©s R. Vindas Mel√©ndez #268']
column5:
['Join us for Math Monday with Andr√©s R. Vindas Mel√©ndez TODAY at Evans Hall, Room 1015 @ 5 PM (02/12)!
Speaker: Andr√©s R. Vindas Mel√©ndez
Title: Generalized Parking Function Polytopes
Abstract: A classical parking function of length n is a list of positive integers (a_1, a_2, ..., a_n) whose nondecreasing rearrangement b_1 <= b_2 <= ... <= b_n satisfies b_i <= i. The convex hull of all parking functions of length n is an n-dimensional polytope in R^n. We generalize this family of polytopes by studying the geometric properties of the convex hull of x-parking functions.']
["Join us TODAY in Evans 1015 @ 6:30 PM for MUSA x GEM's Board Game Night!"]

column2: ['Math Monday 02/05: Can we use math to improve traffic flow? with Franziska Weber #263']
column5:
['Join us for Math Monday with Franziska Weber TODAY at Evans Hall, Room 1015 @ 5 PM (02/05)!

Speaker: Franziska Weber
Title: Can we use math to improve traffic flow?
Full length abstract: Braess‚Äôs paradox is a proposed explanation for when the modification of a road system by for example adding a new road, leads to a worse traffic situation instead of an improvement. It was proposed in 1968 by the mathematician Dietrich Braess and can mathematically be formulated as a Nash Equilibrium that is a worse situation than the best overall flow through the road network. In this talk, we review Braess‚Äôs paradox and its emergence in real life situations and then explore whether it can be observed in traffic flow models involving partial differential equations.']
['Join us TODAY in Evans 740 @ 6:30 PM for our LaTeX Workshop!']

column2: ['Math Monday 01/29: A mirror into the higher dimensional world with Catherine Cannizzo #254']
column5:
['Join us for Math Monday with Catherine Cannizzo this Monday at Evans Hall, Room 1015 @ 5 PM (01/29)!
Speaker: Catherine Cannizzo

Title: A mirror into the higher dimensional world
Full length abstract: We live in a three dimensional world. If we consider time as a fourth ‚Äúcoordinate‚Äù, we have four dimensions. These four dimensions are known as ‚Äúspace-time.‚Äù In physics, string theory conjectures that, at scales much smaller than an electron (of a similar order of magnitude of the universe to the atom), there are small strings vibrating. For the theory to work, the strings must vibrate in 6 compact extra dimensions, for a total of 10 dimensions! It turns out that two geometric models for the strings give the same physics. These pairs opened up mathematicians to the notion of ‚Äúmirror symmetry‚Äù which gives us a lot of interesting information about geometric spaces. In this talk, I will define a ‚Äúgeometric space‚Äù, give some examples, and illustrate how to visualize higher dimensions as well as touch on the connection to my research in homological mirror symmetry.']
['Join us for our first general meeting of the semester TODAY in Evans 1015! We will have free food!']

['Join us for Math Monday with Martin Olsson tomorrow at Evans Hall, Room 1015 @ 5 PM (01/22)!
Speaker: Martin Olsson
Title: Moduli
Abstract: One of the key notions in modern mathematics is the notion of moduli. It arises in algebraic geometry from the fact that classification of various objects of interest often leads to the exploration of other spaces (called moduli spaces).  I will discuss some elementary examples of moduli in this talk.']
['Join us for our Summer Panel TODAY in Evans 1015 at 6:30 PM!']

column2: ['Math Monday 11/27: Mathematics in Condensed Matter Physics with Mengxuan Yang #231']
column5:
['Join us for Math Monday TODAY in Evans Hall, Room 1015, from 5 - 6 PM
Speaker: Mengxuan Yang
Title: Some Mathematics in Condensed Matter Physics
Abstract: Discovery of superconductivity and its physics theory has led to interesting mathematical studies of condensed matter physics. In this talk, I will introduce some mathematical ideas behind condensed matter physics and will tell you some mathematical story behind "magic angles", at which you may find superconductivity.

Recommended Prerequisites: My talk only needs some linear algebra background. Some functional analysis would be helpful but that should not be necessary']

["MUSA's own math class, MUSA 174, is priming to return for another semester! 

The subject of the class is Category Theory, an emerging and‚Äîcrucially‚Äîvery neat field of mathematics. Rather than studying a particular domain, Category Theory aims to provide a unifying language for existing fields of math. Its constructions tend to be extremely general, and its theorems tend to trivially imply existing results of, for instance, algebra, topology, and/or logic. 

At higher levels of mathematics, the language of Category Theory becomes highly prevalent. Despite this, classes on the subject are hard to come by. Here's your chance to take one! 

If this all sounds interesting to you, please fill out the interest form to let us know and to help us choose our class schedule. You can find the form, as well as a tentative syllabus, at https://linktr.ee/musa174. Please email musa174decal@gmail.com with any questions."]

column2: ['Math Monday 11/20: Differential Geometry of Surfaces with Alexander B. Givental #225']
column5:
["Join us for Math Monday with Alexander B. Givental tomorrow at Evans Hall, Room 1015 @ 5 PM (11/20) !
Speaker: Alexander B. Givental
Title: Differential Geometry of Surfaces
Abstract: In one hour, I'll try to formulate and prove the main result of Math 140, the celebrated Gauss--Bonnet theorem. The lecture will be very elementary; in particular, knowledge of calculus will not be assumed.
Recommended Prerequisites: None! "]
['Join us for Arts and Crafts Night TODAY in Evans 1015 @ 6:30 PM!']

column2: ['Math Monday 11/13: Ruler and Compass Constructions and Abstract Algebra with Emiliano Gomez #221']
column5:
['Join us for Math Monday tomorrow with Emiliano Gomez at Evans Hall, Room 1015 @ 5 PM (11/13)

Speaker: Emiliano Gomez
Title: Ruler and compass constructions and abstract algebra
Abstract: We will see why some of the famous classical Greek ruler and compass constructions are impossible, eg: doubling the square, squaring the circle, trisecting the angle. These problems were open for 2000 years, and their solution exemplifies the beauty and power of the interaction between geometry and algebra.
Recommended Prerequisite: Math 110, Math 113']

column2: ['Math Monday 11/06: Algebraic Curves and the Riemann-Roch theorem with David Eisenbud #216']
column5:
["Join us for Math Monday TODAY in Evans 1015 at 5 PM!
Speaker: David Eisenbud
Title: Algebraic Curves and the Riemann-Roch theorem
Abstract: The Riemann-Roch theorem is probably the most important single result in algebraic geometry. I'll try to explain what it says, and why it is important, without too many technical details. 
Recommended Prerequisite: Math 113 "]

column2: ['Math Monday (10/30): Quantum Matter With Colleen Delaney #209']
column5:
['Join us for Math Monday with Colleen Delaney TODAY at Evans 1015 @ 5 PM and discover more about quantum matter
Speaker: Colleen Delaney
Title: The math behind a periodic table for 2-dimensional quantum matter
Abstract: When particles are stuck in 2d, their physics can be completely understood using topology and category theory. We will learn to visualize these "anyons", and will explore connections to knot theory, category theory, and (time permitting) quantum computing.
Prerequisites: Accessible to everyone!']
['Join us for Halloween Trivia TODAY in Evans 1015 @ 6:30 PM, and wear a costume if you would like!']

['Join us for Math Monday TODAY in Evans 1015 at 5 PM!
Speaker: Yegor Zenkevich 
Title: Triple Symmetric Functions 
Abstract: Symmetric functions play a major role in representation theory. A mysterious generalization - triple symmetric functions - seems to exist, but they are poorly understood. We peek at this problem by introducing and playing with triple symmetric functions.']
