column2: ["Math Monday (10/2): Falconer's distance set conjecture and its many faces with Ruixiang Zhang #189"]
column5:
["Join us for Math Monday with Ruixiang Zhang TODAY at Evans 1015 @ 5 PM and discover more about the Falconer's distance set conjecture.

Speaker: Ruixiang Zhang
Title :Falconer's distance set conjecture and its many faces
Abstract: In 1985, Falconer made the conjecture that whenever E ‚äÜ ‚Ñù¬≤ has dimension >1, its distance set Œî(E) = {|x-y|: x, y ‚àà E} will have positive measure. Despite its innocent appearance, this conjecture remains unsolved as of today. We will introduce this conjecture and three interesting results towards it. The methods to prove these results are related to Fourier analysis, classical algebraic geometry/topology and geometric measure theory.
Recommended Prerequisites: Math 104 and Math 110"]
['Join us TODAY in Evans 1015 at 6:30 to watch Spaceballs!']

column2: ['Math Monday (9/25): Large cardinal hypotheses and new axioms for set theory with Gabriel Goldberg #179']
column5:
["Join us for Math Monday with Gabriel Goldberg TODAY at Evans 1015 @ 5 PM and discover more about the fundaments of set theory

Speaker: Gabriel Goldberg 
Title : Large cardinal hypotheses and new axioms for set theory 
Abstract: In this talk I will introduce the ZFC axioms of set theory, which serve as an adequate foundation for almost all of mathematics but are inadequate to resolve many fundamental problems in set theory itself. I'll then turn to extensions of the ZFC axioms obtained by adding large cardinal hypotheses, also known as strong axioms of infinity, and finally I'll discuss axioms that are inspired by the ongoing search for canonical models of set theory."]
['Join us TODAY in Evans 1015 at 6:30 PM for Pancake Charades!']

column2: ['Math Monday (9/18): The spectrum of an infinite product and the Stone-ƒåech compactification of N with Owen Barrett #175']
column5:
[' Join us for Math Monday with Owen Barret TODAY at Evans 1015 @ 5 PM and find out more about some outrageous spaces!

Speaker: Owen Barrett

Title: The spectrum of an infinite product and the Stone-ƒåech compactification of N

Abstract: Consider the spectrum of a countable product of a fixed field k. Mumford wrote the following in his Red Book: ‚ÄòThose familiar with ultrafilters and similar far-out mysteries will have no problem proving that this topological space is the Stone-ƒåech compactification of N. Logicians assure us that we can prove more theorems if we use these outrageous spaces.‚Äô This talk is about these outrageous spaces and their natural appearance in the study of commutative rings']
['Join us for our Board Game Night TODAY in Evans 1015 at 6:30 PM! We are hosting it in partnership with GEM!']

column2: ['Math Monday (9/11): Crystals in Graph Theory with Nicolle Gonz√°lez #172']
column5:
[' Join us for Math Monday with Nicolle Gonz√°lez TODAY at Evans 1015 @ 5 PM and find out more about Crystals in graph theory!

Speaker: Nicolle Gonz√°lez 

Title:  Crystals 

Abbreviated Abstract: How can we find the coefficients of a polynomial vector with respect to a given basis? It turns out that we can answer this question by studying directed graphs known as crystals. We build up a theory of crystals from scratch - tying them to representation theory and the algebraic properties of the polynomials they come from.']

["TODAY we will be hosting a LaTeX workshop in Evans 1015 at 6:30 PM! LaTeX is a mathematical typesetting language that you can use to format documents, papers, and homework. If you're in a proof-based math class or an upper-division math class, you can use LaTeX to produce beautifully formatted math notes and homework solutions!"]

['Join us for our FIRST Math Monday of the semester with Richard Borcherds TODAY in Evans 1015 @ 5 PM!

Title: Monstrous Moonshine 
Abstract: Learn about the monster group of order 808,017,424,794,512,875,886,459,904,961,710,757,005,754,368,000,000,000, and its relation to a special elliptic modular function']

["Still looking for two more units to round out your fall schedule? Well, look no further!
MUSA 174 being offered for the third time in Fall 2023. MUSA 174 is a DeCal which covers the fundamentals of category theory, a foundational subject necessary to study most modern fields of math with an algebraic or topological flavor. In particular, we will discuss the basic theory of functors, natural transformations, limits, and the calculus of adjunctions, as well as some additional topics if time permits. We will be following the first four chapters of Emily Riehl's Category Theory in Context. 
The class is 2 units P/NP, and there will be short-ish weekly homeworks. Students should have already taken Math 110 and Math 113 (or equivalents) and be very comfortable reading and writing proofs to be maximally successful. This class will be especially useful for students considering taking grad courses like Math 250AB, Math 215AB, or Math 256AB, although anyone is welcome to take it regardless of their intentions to take a graduate class.
You can find a link to join a Discord server for the class, an interest form, and a tentative copy of the syllabus all at linktr.ee/musa174. If you have any questions, don't hesitate to reach out to the instructors on Discord or at musa174decal@gmail.com!"]

['Proofs are tricky! This can make the transition between lower division (primarily computational) and upper division (almost entirely proof-based) mathematics quite difficult. To this end, this Fall semester MUSA will be running MUSA 74: Intro to Upper Division Mathematics! Through examples in class and group work during discussion, this 2-unit course will build your proof-writing skills and introduce you to a sampler of upper division topics.\nThe course will be held 4PM to 5PM on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays. You can find all relevant links for the course here: https://linktr.ee/musa74.']

["Pending approval from the academic senate, MUSA will run MUSA 154: Diophantine Equations! In this 2-unit DeCal, we will approach abstract mathematics---in particular number theory---with an eye to computation. The hope is that students leave the course with a wide range and great appreciation of examples, ready to see more number theory. We'll talk about coding with SageMath, continued fractions, the local-to-global principle, elliptic curves, and all that.\nNo number theory will be assumed in advance, but we require abstract algebra on the level of Math 113. The course will be held 12PM to 1PM on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays. You can find all relevant links for the course here: https://linktr.ee/musa154."]

['Join us for Math Monday with Kevin Yang TODAY in Evans 891 at 5:30 PM
Speaker: Kevin Yang
Title: DLA, KPZ, and probably no other acronyms for stochastic growth
Abstract: Here's an example of random growth. Take a sheet of printer paper, light the bottom edge on fire, and look at the "moving front" (i.e. what is currently on fire). This is "KPZ-type growth". Here's another one. Take an insulating material, introduce a strong electric field, and look at the resulting "conducting regions". This is "DLA-type growth". It turns out KPZ-type growth describes much more than just paper on fire. Unfortunately, DLA-type growth is much less understood. This talk is about discussing these problems, what people can prove, and the relationship between KPZ and DLA growths. No prerequisites beyond multivariable calculus will be necessary (though familiarity with real analysis and differential geometry may be relevant to some minor details). The talk will be quite informal.
*Please take note of the new time and location of today‚Äôs event!']

["MUSA 174 is almost certainly going to be offered for the third time in Fall 2023, pending the approval of the academic senate. MUSA 174 is a DeCal which covers the fundamentals of category theory, a foundational subject necessary to study most modern fields of math with an algebraic or topological flavor. In particular, we will discuss the basic theory of functors, natural transformations, limits, and the calculus of adjunctions, as well as some additional topics if time permits. We will be following the first four chapters of Emily Riehl's Category Theory in Context. \nThe class is 2 units P/NP, and there will be short-ish weekly homeworks. Students should have already taken Math 110 and Math 113 (or equivalents) and be very comfortable reading and writing proofs to be maximally successful. This class will be especially useful for students considering taking grad courses like Math 250AB, Math 215AB, or Math 256AB, although anyone is welcome to take it regardless of their intentions to take a graduate class.\nYou can find a link to join a Discord server for the class, an interest form, and a tentative copy of the syllabus all at linktr.ee/musa174. If you have any questions, don't hesitate to reach out to the instructors on Discord or at musa174decal@gmail.com!"]

['Join us for Math Monday with Martin Olsson TODAY in Evans 1015 at 5 PM!
Speaker: Martin Olsson 
Title: Differential Equations in Algebraic Geometry 
Abstract: In Math 1b, we study ordinary differential equations in one variable, and these equations are normally viewed as in the domain of analysis. However, such differential equations also have a rich connection to algebraic geometry and arithmetic. In this talk I will discuss some of these algebraic and arithmetic aspects of differential equations, and the role they play in these more algebraic fields.']

column2: ['Volunteers Needed for Shadow a Math Major Day #111']
column5:

If you're interested in volunteering, please fill out this form before Saturday, April 15th at 11:59 PM and look out for further information from us. If you have any questions, please contact Lakshay at (lakshay@berkeley.edu). "]

['Join us for Math Monday with Lin Lin TODAY in Evans 1015 at 5 PM!
Speaker: Lin Lin
Topic: Quantum Advantage
Abstract: Quantum computers offer the potential to compress 2^n bits of classical information using only n qubits. While this may suggest exponential quantum advantage across various applications, it is important to recognize the limitations of this perspective. In this talk, I will delve into these limitations and explore different approaches towards realizing quantum advantages in scientific computation. The discussion will be relatively informal, and no previous knowledge of quantum computation is required to understand most of the content.']

['Join us for Math Monday with McFeely Goodman TODAY in Evans 1015 at 5 PM!
Speaker: McFeely Goodman
Title: Curvature and the Dirac Operator
Abstract: The Dirac operator is a differential operator on a Riemannian manifold which can be used to relate the curvature - a local notion of shape - of a manifold to its topology - a global notion of shape. I will illustrate that story with concrete examples and computations. I will then discuss the implications to the following questions: Can a given manifold be deformed to have some notion of ‚Äúpositive curvature‚Äù everywhere? When can one manifold with positive curvature be deformed into another, maintaining positive curvature along the deformation?']

['Join us for Math Monday with Jackson Morrow TODAY in Evans 1015 at 5 PM!
Speaker: Jackson Morrow
Title: Hyperbolicity from Two Perspectives
Abstract: I will begin with a gentle survey about the arithmetic of algebraic curves describing when algebraic curves have infinitely many rational solutions and when they only have finitely many solutions. Next, I will transition to talking about how the arithmetic of curves is related to the space of maps between them, and to conclude, I will state some of my own results in this area.']

['Join us for Math Monday with Florian Sprung TODAY in Evans 1015 at 5 PM!
Speaker: Florian (Ian) Sprung
Title: Three Short Stories about Numbers and Logic: How imperfection can lead to beauty
Abstract:
The first story: In the year 1900, people dreamed up machines that could do calculations. They asked if those machines would one day learn how to think and feel. An easier question they asked was whether they could solve polynomial equations. (The answer, found in 1970, was 'no!' So machines won't replace us.)
The second story: The simplest equations ("elliptic curves") humanity does not understand look deceivingly simple, but have been a riddle for more than a century now. One major piece of light has been shed on this riddle in 1922 using a really simple idea.
The third story: Some equations don't have formulas for finding x, but this imperfection leads to something new -- we can still 'find' x by using x to make up new numbers instead.
If time permits, I will mention a result from about a decade and a half ago that weaves these three stories together.']

['The Integration Bee is on Saturday in Physics 4 at 1pm Come watch the top 16 qualifiers compete to see who can integrate the best. You should all come to watch in person this year, you may learn a few integration tricks yourself.']

['Math Monday today in Evans 1015 at 5 pm!
Speaker: Christopher Ryba
Title: Diffusion Curves: Images via Differential Equations
Abstract: Properties of image formats (e.g. raster vs vector, lossy vs lossless, compression, ...) determine their best use cases. We will discuss an unusual format: Diffusion Curves. Colour discontinuities in the image are stored, and the rest of the image is interpolated using the Laplace equation or biharmonic equation. There will be some discussion of the underlying mathematics, practical considerations, and examples. Prerequisites: There will be a few moments where knowing some further topics (e.g. group theory) might be helpful, but these are not needed for the talk itself.']

column5: ["This Thursday, 2/16, we will be hosting a LaTeX workshop in Evans 1015 at 6:30pm! LaTeX is a typesetting system that mathematicians use to format books, papers, etc. If you're in a proof-based math class like most upper-divs, you're usually encouraged to do your homework in LaTeX. Even if it's not required, it'll impress your graders and professors because it makes math look nice!\n\nWe will be giving a short introduction to typesetting with LaTeX both online with Overleaf and locally, so whatever your level is, you're welcome to bring some homework and get your questions answered in an informal lab environment."]

['Join us for Math Monday TODAY in Evans 1015 at 5 PM! 
Speaker: Connor Halleck-Dub√© 
Title: The Mathematics of Cake-Cutting 
Abstract: "Fair division problems," that is, algorithmic questions of equitably dividing valuable resources, have a history stretching into antiquity and widespread applications to the real world. Focusing on the well-studied problem of cake-cutting, we'll discuss a variety of mathematical frameworks for handling the (surprisingly subtle!) question of what makes a division "fair" or "equitable," and some cases of solutions to these problems. ']

['We are hosting a Math Monday today (2/6) in Evans 1015 at 5pm!
Speaker: Andr√©s R. Vindas Mel√©ndez
Title: An Invitation to Enumerative Geometric Combinatorics 
Abstract: Enumerative geometric combinatorics is an area of mathematics concerned with counting properties of geometric objects described by a finite set of building blocks. Lattice polytopes are geometric objects that can be formed by taking the convex hull of finitely many integral points. In this talk I will present background on polytopes, lattice-point enumeration, and share some results on a special family of polytopes that can be further studied. Throughout the talk I will present questions and open problems. (No prior knowledge will be assumed, and I will attempt to explain all concepts.)']

['Interactive Workshop with Claire Mirocha
Monday, April 10th, from 6:30 pm to 8:00 pm in Evans 1015
Claire Mirocha is a 3rd-year PhD candidate and GSI in the math department of UC Berkeley studying Algebra and Geometry/Topology. Come join us to hear her talk about the following:
Springer Theory for SL3 or; the Hardest I've Ever Worked to Compute a 2x2 Matrix
"In the field of geometric representation theory, a result called the "Springer correspondence" tells us that if we start with a reductive group, its Weyl group has an action on the cohomology of the fibers of a special map, called the Springer resolution. I'll lead us through a rich example of this for the group SL3, telling a story that weaves together geometry, representation theory, and topology, while attempting to explain most of the words that I've used in this paragraph!"']

["Hey everyone! If you're part of a startup or club organization and need help with UX design, redesign, or research, UX@Berkeley is here to assist. As UC Berkeley‚Äôs dedicated UX consultancy, we offer expertise in mobile design, web design, product design, and user research. \nWe‚Äôre UC Berkeley‚Äôs first dedicated UX community, focusing on making design accessible and providing opportunities through a network of passionate designers. If you're interested in learning more, let‚Äôs set up a meeting! You can schedule a time through my Calendly link. Looking forward to our chat! uxab.org [https://calendly.com/maryzo/ux-at-berkeley-collaboration?preview_source=et_card&month=2024-09]"]

column2: ['[Career Fair] AI & EECS Career Fair @ UC Berkeley #4446']

We strongly encourage all UC Berkeley undergraduate and graduate students interested in advancing data driven technologies to come out and explore industries! We look forward to seeing you on campus!

column2: ['CSM Weekly Section Sign Ups Open This Week! #4433']
column5:
['Hi everyone! 
For those of you who are looking for extra tutoring in your lowerdiv EE/CS courses, Computer Science Mentors (CSM) is an organization that runs small group tutoring sections to supplement lecture, lab, discussion, and tutorials. You may receive 1 unit for being in a CSM section. Section signups are open this week! 
Tuesday: Priority Enrollment for SEED, EOP, CS SCHOLARS, HES, BESSA.
Wednesday at 12PM: Enrollment opens for 16A/61C/88
Wednesday at 5 PM: Enrollment opens for 61A
Thursday at 12 pm: Enrollment opens for 16B/61B
Thursday at 6 PM: Enrollment opens for 70
Sign up at https://scheduler.csmentors.org/! Sections start the week of Monday 9/16. 
Computer Science Mentors (CSM) is a student organization with the goal of creating a supportive community among the lower-division CS courses (CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 70, CS 88 (now DATA C88C), EECS 16A, and EECS 16B). We offer small (4 to 7 students), 1 or 1.5 hour long sections each led by a mentor that you regularly attend to review the past week‚Äôs material. You should sign up for a section if you‚Äôd like to work with others and receive extra practice and guidance with the course material for the entire semester. Detailed information on logistics and expectations for students can be found here. We ask that all students read this document in full, carefully before enrolling in a CSM section. 
Can I get units for attending a CSM section?
Students enrolled in a CSM section may optionally enroll for 1 P/NP unit on CalCentral. To get a permission code for enrolling in CSM for a unit, please fill out this form after enrolling in a section on Scheduler: https://tinyurl.com/csm-unit-fa24
Enrollment in the unit on CalCentral is not automatic for students who enroll in a section on Scheduler. If you wish to enroll in the unit, you should first enroll in a section on Scheduler, then refer to the unit enrollment information in the student expectations doc and fill out the permission code request form: https://tinyurl.com/csm-unit-fa24. Note that the deadline to enroll in units is 9/18, but the deadline to enroll in units without a fee is 9/13, 11:59 PM.
Looking forward to seeing you in section!']

['Hi everyone!
Starting today (09/09), HKN, the EECS honors society, is offering free in-person, drop-in tutoring hours daily, Monday through Friday, from 1 PM to 5 PM. These tutoring sessions will take place at our offices in Soda 345 and Cory 290. Feel free to just walk in and ask for tutoring from a tutor on duty! You can find out more at hkn.mu/tutor. While you‚Äôre there, we recommend hovering over the tutors‚Äô names to see which classes they have completed and what their tutoring preferences are.

Please note that HKN will not assist with course projects in any way due to course policies.

We will also be hosting midterm and final review sessions throughout the semester. More information on individual review sessions will be posted approximately 1-2 weeks before the exam on the respective course Ed. Be on the lookout for these!
Lastly, if you‚Äôre ever interested in checking out the variety of fields that our EECS courses have to offer, check out our course guide at hkn.mu/courseguides. You can see which classes in the department fall under which fields and get an idea of the classes that you may be interested in taking. You can also click on a class bubble to get a detailed overview about what to expect from the class: mini-syllabi, breakdowns of the class‚Äôs workload, usefulness in industry, research, and more!

If you ever have any questions, we will be more than happy to answer! Please email current-tutoring@hkn.eecs.berkeley.edu with any questions that might arise.
Happy studying!
Eta Kappa Nu‚Äôs (HKN) very own Tutoring Committee']

["The Esperanto DeCal is back for its second semester!
Time: Wednesdays & Fridays 1500‚Äì15:59 (3‚Äì3:59 pm), first class 11 September!
Application: None! Enroll for 2 units with CCN 34426.
Context: This class aims to take students from 0 to intermediate in Esperanto, the international language, in one semester. (It's not as hard as it might sound!)
Side effects might include (1) boosting your language-learning skill by getting familiar with language-learning techniques, grammatical ideas, and Esperanto words shared by other languages and (2) connecting with an international community which cares about bringing peace through mutual understanding.
More info: decal.berkeley.edu, classes.berkeley.edu, and feel free to reply with questions!
If you can't make the course but want to hear about Esperanto events, including a recurring conversation hour, a≈≠ se vi jam parolas Esperanton (!), take a look at Eventa Servo and/or sign up for announcements here!
(Like last semester: technically not EECS-related, but I know a lot of STEM people are interested in languages and conlangs.)"]

column2: ["We're Still Accepting Applications for the Full Stack Decal! #4425"]
column5:
["Hello everyone!
We're still accepting applications for the Introduction to Full Stack Development DeCal on a rolling basis until September 13th! 
If you would like to learn more about the DeCal and review the course schedule and logistics, please refer to our website: https://fullstackdecal.com/
Here's our listing on the DeCal website: https://decal.studentorg.berkeley.edu/courses/7638
Please submit an application at https://fullstackdecal.com/enroll. If you submit an application at this point, you'll have a pretty much guaranteed shot of securing a spot so- we're looking forward to hearing from you!"]

["We're BASIS, a community of students interested in ensuring that AI systems are transparent, robust, controllable, and ethical.

We have FOUR programs this semester:
Our Speaker Series: Speakers from OpenAI, DeepMind, Anthropic, and more! These ongoing events are open to everyone and are a great way to learn more about the field of AI Safety. Fill out the interest form to get notified.
Our Tech Ed Program: This will teach you the entry-level skills required to do technical AI safety research! We'll be going through a modified version of the ARENA curriculum. Apply by THIS Monday, 9/9.
Our AI Policy Group: Members will discuss the emerging AI Policy field and get experience reading and writing about AIS legislation. We'll be going through an adapted version of the curriculum linked here. No policy background required. Apply by THIS Monday, 9/9.
Our Project Track: This is where you can do supervised research with an experienced AI safety mentor who will lead you on their project! Fill out the interest form to get notified. Applications open Friday 9/13, Applications due 9/20.
Please fill out our interest form!
Helpful resources:
Club Slack
Website"]

column2: ['Exciting Opportunity: Join Our Technical Project with Piedmont Consulting Group #4411']
column5:
['Hello everyone,
Our consulting club, Piedmont Consulting Group, is collaborating on an exciting technical project with a startup backed by Sequoia Capital, focusing on Generative AI. We are seeking enthusiastic juniors and seniors majoring in CS or EECS who are passionate about software development and actively coding.
We are looking for individuals who:
Enjoy explaining technology to others
Have prior experience with:
Using software APIs
Building APIs (ideal)
Cloud and virtualization technologies (e.g., virtual machines, cloud services, AWS)
Kubernetes and containerization technology (ideal)
This project could also lead to an internship opportunity with the company.
Applications are due by September 6, 2024. It‚Äôs a simple resume drop. To apply, please submit your resume using the following link: Application Form.
If you are interested or know someone who might be a great fit, please apply!
Best regards,
Piedmont Consulting Group']

column2: ['Why solve problems when you can create them instead???? #4406']
column5:
["The California Informatics Competition (CALICO) is a club that creates original algorithmic problems and hosts programming contests to help students grow their problem-solving skills and learn algorithms in a fun and exciting way! Our main event is a team contest for high schoolers with a broad range of topics and challenges. Last year, we hosted our contest in a hybrid format for the first time ever, with many students from across the Bay Area coming to the UC Berkeley campus for the contest. Learn more at our website: https://calico.cs.berkeley.edu/ 
From problem writing to event logistics to contest infrastructure, we can really use your help! Joining CALICO is a great way to learn algorithms, meet friends, and have fun! There is NO APPLICATION PROCESS--anyone is welcome to join, regardless of background or prior experience! 
We will be having TWO intro meetings: 
September 6, 2024 6:00 PM to September 6, 2024 7:30 PM at Cory 293 
At this meeting, we will be having CAKE to celebrate the birthday of our mascot, Big Ben. Drop by to help us decorate and eat his cake!
September 12, 2024 6:00 PM at September 12, 2024 7:30 PM Cory 293 
We will also be having our VERY FIRST GM (General Meeting) OF THE SEMESTER from September 14, 2024 6:00 PM to September 14, 2024 7:30 PM! All new members are highly encouraged to drop by and see what we've got planned for the semester. 
üçïüçïüçïFREE FOOD (Mostly Pizza) üçïüçïüçï will be served at all intro meetings AND GMs! In the meantime, please join our Discord server. We'll post announcements and more info about the club there (such as relevant updates and meeting slides too if you can‚Äôt make it!).
See you Then! 
Discord Server Link: https://discord.gg/fpZbXsGrRT"]

["Interested in STEM education? Looking for meaningful software or electrical projects to be a part of? Join Pioneers in Engineering this semester! PiE builds and runs a robotics competition for local high schools at a low cost to the 15-20 schools that participate annually. Our competition gives low-income students who are underrepresented in STEM an opportunity to explore engineering, while being introduced to the UC Berkeley campus, students, and faculty.
To keep the competition up and running, we have a combination of software and hardware teams that are looking for new membersüëÄüëÄ
Here are our software teams:
Dawn: builds the code editor the HS students use to program their robots
Runtime: writes programs pertaining to the network of student computers, motors, servos, & competition code
Shepherd: creates field control software - automates part of the competition. (e.g. last year, when the high schooler's robots were able to press a combination of buttons in a row, their scoreboard automatically updated. The buttons lit up in the order they were supposed to be pressed, and if the high schooler pressed the wrong button/took too long to complete the task, the game would disable itself for a period of time.)
And here is our electrical team‚ö°:
Electrical: builds power distribution boards (PDB's), printed circuit boards (PCB's), & solders other components. Many on our electrical team who put the fact that they designed & created a PDB on their resume find companies interested in this project of theirs.
If you have an interest in mechanical engineering, electrical engineering, and software applications for STEM education, you're highly encouraged to join! 
No application involved: To join us this fall, fill out our Interest Form and you're all set!
[Optional] If you would like 2 units for your work with us, email us at education@pierobotics.org and we'll send you an enrollment code for ELENG 198 006."]

column2: ['Mathematics Undergraduate Student Association | First GM Thursday, 9/5 6:30pm @ Evans 1015 #4400']
column5: ['The Mathematics Undergraduate Student Association (MUSA) is holding its first general meeting on Thursday, 9/5, at 6:30pm in Evans 1015! There will be pizza, board games, and a brief introduction of what we do. MUSA aims to create a warm, inclusive environment in the math department by hosting weekly events such as Math Mondays, trivia nights, LaTeX workshops, and the BUMP mentoring program that pairs under and upperclassmen. For those interested in taking upper-division math courses or proof intensive courses we offer the MUSA 74 Decal ‚Äì a 2 unit PNP course that introduces rigorous proof writing and fosters familiarity with the objects encountered in advanced courses such as Abstract Algebra and Analysis. \n\nKeep in touch with us via our newsletter or Discord server, both found at https://linktr.ee/berkeleymusa.']

column2: ['Join the Introduction to Full Stack Development Decal! #4389']
column5:
['In this course we cover the basics of web development. This includes everything from the fundamental frameworks that ground web development, the inner workings of the Internet itself, and many of the frameworks, technologies, and best practices that are used in the industry today.
No prior CS experience is required to participate and succeed in this course, but we do acknowledge that we cover a fairly large amount of material and that makes this course fairly heavy, even for those with prior CS experience.
In the spirit of full-stack development, we cover the three main pillars of modern web development: backend development, frontend development, and design.
Every week you will attend 2 lectures, each 1.5 hours. Most lectures will have a short vitamin assignment accompanying them and you will typically have a project due every 3 weeks to a month. Course staff will be holding office hours regularly throughout the week to provide guidance and feedback on the assignments. Towards the end of the semester your work in this class will culminate in a final project with a project group.
By going through this DeCal, you‚Äôll learn
- Full-stack web development
- Software engineering principles
- The basics of the internet and cloud technologies
- How to create large software projects from scratch
- How to navigate and use popular web design software
- How to work in a team of cross-functional engineers and much more!
Feel free to check out https://fullstackdecal.com/ for more information and to get a preview of our course content! We will be hosting infosessions on September 3rd and September 5th at 8 pm PST at Dwinelle 242 and Dwinelle 234 respectively. Feel free to come and learn more about our decal and speak to course facilitators!

Please submit an application at https://fullstackdecal.com/enroll. The application deadline is September 7th, 2024 at 11:59 pm. Accepted students will receive an enrollment code over the following weekend. If we have spots remaining after this deadline, we will send out additional enrollment codes over the following week until September 13th, in order to comply with the course add deadline.']

column2: ['Interested in AI? Apply to Generative AI at Berkeley! #4387']
column5:
['Hi everyone!

We are Generative AI at Berkeley, the first and largest Generative AI focused student organization on campus. We focus on exploring the groundbreaking field of Generative AI, as well as its transformative potential applications. This semester we are primarily recruiting for people to join our project teams to work as developers for industry clients. We have some incredible projects lined up and we work with a wide range of companies, big-tech companies that have specific subdivisions that use Generative AI as well as startups whose entire product focuses on Generative AI.

We also provide professional development opportunities, networking opportunities with industry leaders, retreats and mixers, etc. If any of this sounds interesting or appealing to you, please consider filling out our application by September 6. You can also express your interest here (to receive updates before the application deadline) and check out our website for further information. Our entire recruiting timeline is also listed in the flier attached below, so please come to any of our info-sessions or events to find out more information. Feel free to reach out if you have any questions!']

["Visit the course site at ocf.io/decal for more info! We will also hold infosessions this week from 7-8PM on Tuesday, September 3rd and Thursday, September 5th. You can attend in-person at the OCF Lab in 171 MLK, or online on ocf.io/meet.
We will be covering the basics of administering a Linux-based server environment in the manner of the EECS Instructional Servers (hivexx.cs.berkeley.edu) and the Open Computing Facility (tsunami.ocf.berkeley.edu, etc.). By the end of this course, you'll be comfortable using GNU/Linux, understand in a broad sense how the system‚Äôs various parts work together, e.g. init, filesystems, services, daemons, etc., understand basic networking, have a good sense of how to maintaining system security, and have a practical taste of what sysadmins do in industry.
We know potential students will have differing backgrounds in terms of CS and sysadmin experience. The OCF will provide support for students of all levels by being available for drop-in help during staff hours and of course during lab time. Everyone is welcome!

To enroll, you must complete Lab 0 by Saturday, September 7th 11:59PM, which serves as your application. We will try to enroll as many people as we can! "]

column2: ['Join the Going Down the EECS Stack Decal! #4369']
column5: ['Are you unsure what areas of EECS you want to focus on? Are you curious about what EECS is in the first place?\nHKN is excited to be hosting its DeCal, Going Down the EECS Stack, which explores various fields within EECS and provides guidance as to how you can dive deeper into these fields as a Berkeley student. This DeCal is open to all experience levels and all majors, but we will prioritize enrollment for those who have little to no experience in EECS. This class will feature guest speakers, field trips, interactive labs, and more.\nLearn more on our website decal.best or apply at hkn.mu/decalapp. The deadline to apply is Friday, September 6th at 11:59 PM. However, please apply as soon as possible; applications will be processed on a first-come-first-serve basis. The first class will be on Wednesday, September 11th.']

["Join us for a chill evening in the Cory Courtyard on Tuesday, September 10 from 5-7 PM to kick off the semester! Connect with fellow students, hang out, and enjoy some snacks. Plus, don't miss your chance to win some awesome free merch in our raffle. See you soon!"]

['UPE is excited to kick-off our first info session with Verkada, a Bay Area based start-up in San Mateo focusing on the physical security space.
Date: Tuesday, 9/10, 8-10pm
Location: Wozniak Lounge
Food will be provided. Learn more about Verkada here: www.verkada.com. ']

column2: ['Interested in the Brain? Apply to Neurotech@Berkeley!!! #4359']
column5:
["Hi everyone! If you're interested in neuroscience, brain-computer interfaces, machine learning, computer-aided design, writing colloquial science papers, or finding modern neurotech solutions to modern problems, check out Neurotech @ Berkeley (NT@B)!
We also want to highlight our three diverse engineering divisions:
Software Division
Are you interested in developing futuristic biotechnology? Interested in using AI, cybersecurity, database engineering to combine neuroscience and technology to create awesome projects using that spawn cutting edge technologies like neurosymbolic AI models, medical diagnosis tools, and even a mind-controlled car? Join the Software division of Neurotech@Berkeley! Anyone can apply, regardless of year, major, or experience level, so don‚Äôt hesitate to submit an application!
Devices Division
Have a passion for hardware and want to make medical devices that can enhance our understanding of the brain and increase the ways we can control technology? Or maybe you want to work on prosthetics and wearable robotics? Neurotech@Berkeley‚Äôs Devices Division makes in-house hardware for neurotechnology - including biosensing, stimulation, prosthetic devices, and more!
Join Neurotech@Berkeley‚Äôs Devices Division to gain unique skills in
Biosignal acquisition and processing
Advanced Circuit Design
BCI Product Design
and work on projects spanning:
Sensory Augmentation
Wearable Prosthetics
Modular neuroimaging
Wetware Division
Want hands-on experience interfacing with living neural networks? The Wetware Computing team is seeking innovative minds to help train and interface with real primary rat cortical neurons. Join Neurotech@Berkeley's Wetware Computing Division!
What you'll do:
Design and implement neural interfaces
Be heavily involved in the development and execution of the wetlab culturing protocol
Reading and learning from many breakthrough papers with a talented & ambitious group
Develop algorithms for neural signal processing
Train biological neural networks for computation
We have an infosessions on Tuesday (09/03) 8PM-10PM in Blum 120 and another on Wednesday (09/04) 8PM-10PM in . It will be a great chance to meet current members and leads. You can learn more about our projects spanning across a variety of domains (software, devices, education, publications, operations, and consulting).
If you're interested in getting hands-on experience in this cutting-edge field, we encourage you to apply! Applications are due Friday, 09/06, at 11:59 PM."]

['Are you ready to take your entrepreneurial journey to the next level? We‚Äôre excited to invite you to join our Fall 2024 decal course, Innovators in Residence: Decoding Entrepreneurship Success through Peer Mentorship!
Course Details: Units: 2 | P/NP
Day/Time: Mondays, 5:00 pm to 7:00 pm

This unique course is designed for those with startup experience or a strong interest in entrepreneurship. You‚Äôll have the opportunity to collaborate with experienced peers, hear from inspiring guest speakers, and develop practical skills in entrepreneurial leadership, coaching, and team building. Through workshops, mentorship, and hands-on projects, you‚Äôll learn how to navigate challenges, leverage the Silicon Valley ecosystem, and refine your startup strategies.

Highlights Include:
Counts towards the SCET certificate!
Peer Mentorship and Workshops: Lead and participate in workshops, share your experiences, and learn from others in the SCET Innovation community.
Guest Speakers: Gain insights from successful entrepreneurs and innovators across various industries.
Hands-on Learning: Work on your own projects and ideas, applying proven frameworks and methodologies in real-world settings. Don‚Äôt miss this chance to deepen your entrepreneurial skills and connect with a network of like-minded innovators!
Interested? 
Apply here ASAP before September 6th (spots are limited) or reach out to Danica Tang (danicat@berkeley.edu) or Hannah Kang (hkang02@berkeley.edu) for more information. Looking forward to seeing you there!']

["Hi everyone!! We're a tech social club, and we're kicking off the semester with a back-to-school hike up the Big C Monday, 9/2 at 6:30 PM! If you‚Äôre new to CSUA, it‚Äôll be a great opportunity to meet the club. Plus, we‚Äôll grab boba afterward to cool down so definitely show up! üßã"]

['Computer Science Mentors (CSM) is a student-run organization that provides guidance and resources in a smaller classroom environment through group tutoring sessions for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 70, CS 88, EECS 16A, and EECS 16B.
We are reopening the application for EECS 16B, EECS 16A, and CS 70 for Junior Mentor (JM), Associate Mentor (AM) and Content Mentors (CM).
This application is available at https://tinyurl.com/fa24-csm-app. The extended deadline is Sunday, Sept. 1 at 11:59pm PT. In CSM, we are committed to diversity and inclusion and value applicants of all backgrounds. We consider applications holistically and value passion for mentoring and willingness to learn over your grades and struggles during your time as a student - we do not consider grades in our application process. Overall, we encourage all who are interested to apply and to give the application your best effort!
Want to hear from real mentors what CSM is like? See our info session recording and slides from last semester. 
Visit https://csmentors.org for more information or reach out to us at mentors@berkeley.edu!']

["Hope you all have a good start to the semester! 
We're happy to offer the Extended Reality Development DeCal (XR DeCal) this semester, and we are now accepting applications for Fall 2024.
Interested in Virtual/Augmented Reality? Want to learn Unity? Looking for some extra units? 
Similar to how mobile devices revolutionized the way we interact with our electronic devices, Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality represent another exciting paradigm shift in human computer interaction. XR stands for Extended Reality, which is the realm that encompasses both Virtual and Augmented Reality.
Students will get exposure to different kinds of XR apps and design frameworks, and work in teams to build their own from scratch. After completion of the course, we welcome interested students to join an existing project team with XR@Berkeley or pitch their own project.
This 2-unit course will be held on Monday‚Äôs and Tuesday‚Äôs 5:00 - 7:00 PM PST in-person at Jacobs 10C. (Only need to attend one of the sections - either Monday OR Tuesday)
Apply by Saturday, September 7th @ 11:59 PM PST!
Feel free to contact decal@xr.berkeley.edu with any questions or concerns!
Whether you're interested in the technical/implementation of XR systems or interested in the design side of things, we encourage everyone to apply!
Important Links:
Application: http://tinyurl.com/xr-decal-fa24
Official Course Listing: https://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2024-fall-compsci-198-80-grp-80, https://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2024-fall-compsci-198-808-grp-808
XR DeCal Website: https://xr.berkeley.edu/decal/
Also join our club if you are interested in forming your own project! We are open membership - anyone who submits to the application form is accepted into the club. However, if someone is interested in an existing project in the club, those may be more selective on a project by project basis. But once in the club, anyone is able to pitch their own AR/VR related ideas to the other club members and we will try to provide/point them to all the resources they may need for their project. https://xr.berkeley.edu/"]

column2: ['Open Computing Facility is looking for volunteer staff! #4289']
column5:
["If you‚Äôre interested in Linux, Kubernetes, free and open-source software, getting hands-on experience managing industrial-grade servers, or helping fulfill the computing needs of the wider UC Berkeley community, consider joining us at the Open Computing Facility! We‚Äôre a group of volunteer staff who both maintain a physical computer lab (located at 171 MLK) and provide services such as web hosting, software mirrors, an HPC cluster, and one-on-one staff hours for all UC Berkeley students and faculty. 
We hold general meetings in the fall and spring on Wednesdays at 8-9 PM (starting September 4th) in the lab. Anyone can attend at any point in the semester to participate in staff trainings and work on OCF projects. No application or prior experience is required to join; we welcome all majors and backgrounds, and there is lots of both technical and administrative work to be done. Even if you‚Äôre not interested in joining the staff team, feel free to stop by to use our desktop computers, scanners, and printers (all students get 20 free pages per day), or to just hang out and study!

If you'd like to be added to our mailing list and updated on future events for OCF staffers, fill out our Fall 2024 interest form.

We also have a super cool DeCal on Linux System Administration! Visit ocf.io/decal for more information, and fill out Lab 0 if you'd like to enroll."]

["CSUA is excited to announce our upcoming summer mentorship program, designed to pair you up with a compatible mentor/mentee for the summer! 
This program is open to any major - as long as you're interested in tech! We really appreciate your interest and look forward to getting to know you all better before school starts!

While more details will be given during the first Meet & Greet meeting (date TBD), mentors are typically experienced upperclassmen (pre-sophomore and above) who can provide valuable insights/advice into navigating Berkeley, getting involved in recruiting/research/clubs, or simply be a friendly presence to connect with!

Please note that mentorship applications are accepted on a first-come first-served basis, so if you're interested, don't miss out! The form for mentees can be found here: csua.org/mentee24 and the form for mentors is available here: csua.org/mentor24 . Share this with anybody you know who may be interested!

These forms will close 07/21/24 at 11:59 PM PT. We will announce additional details regarding pairings/meetings shortly after! "]

["Join The UC Berkeley Summer Community!!

column2: ['Apply to be a mentor for Computer Science Mentors (CSM) for Fall 2024! #3713']
column5:
['Hi! Are you interested in joining the teaching community at Berkeley? Do you want to help teach students looking for support in a small group setting, and also find friends and community? 
Computer Science Mentors (CSM) is a student-run organization that provides guidance and resources in a smaller classroom environment through group tutoring sessions for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 70, CS 88, EECS 16A, and EECS 16B. Each section has 4-7 students and meets once or twice a week for 1 or 1.5 hours. The goal of CSM is to build a personal learning community and social network so that both students and mentors can comfortably seek and receive support.
For Fall 2024, we‚Äôre recruiting for the following roles:
Junior Mentors (JMs) for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 70, CS 88, EECS 16A, EECS 16B 
Associate Mentors (AMs) for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 88, EECS 16B
Content Mentors (CMs) for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, EECS 16A
This application is available at https://tinyurl.com/csm-app-fa24. Submissions are due Wednesday, August 28th at 11:59pm PT. No late applications will be accepted! In CSM, we are committed to diversity and inclusion and value applicants of all backgrounds. We consider applications holistically and value passion for mentoring and willingness to learn over your grades and struggles during your time as a student ‚Äî we do not consider grades in our application process. Overall, we encourage all who are interested to apply and to give the application your best effort!
Want to hear from real mentors what CSM is like? See our info session recording and slides from spring 2024. 
Slides: https://tinyurl.com/csm-infosession-sp24
Recording: https://tinyurl.com/csm-infosession-sp24-recording
Visit https://csmentors.berkeley.edu for more information or reach out to us at mentors@berkeley.edu!
Well done on finishing finals, and have a great summer!']

column2: ['Prof. Adhikari Event Today|Careers, Research, Data Science & more #3421']
column5:
['Speaker Series: India at Berkeley, SAAS, Big Data at Berkeley, Data Science Society, and Data Good are thrilled to present an exclusive event featuring Professor Ani Adhikari! 
In a time when we students are busy turning in that next assignment on Gradescope or recruiting for that next opportunity, we lose sight of what our larger goals were when we first entered Berkeley. Through this audience-centered interaction with Prof. Adhikari, we hope to help you visualize your aims, understand the mindset that helps us make the most use of our classes for our careers, and have some fun+banter along the way.  
Prof. Adhikari is the Recipient of the Distinguished Teaching Award at Berkeley and celebrated as the ‚Äúbest professor‚Äù in The Daily Californian‚Äôs 2019 Best of Berkeley, she has been instrumental in both designing and popularizing the data science division and major.
During this event, Professor Adhikari will share her journey into academia, her approach to teaching, and her strategic insights into the evolving field of data science. Learn about her key role in developing and popularizing Berkeley‚Äôs renowned undergraduate Data Science program as Professor Adhikari shares her thoughts on topics like teaching inferential thinking, deciding course content and depth, and preparing students for technical conversations in their careers. üß† Join us TODAY to hear from one of the most influential figures in the field! ‚ú®
Date: üìÖ Friday, April 19
Time: üïí 6-7 PM
Location:üìçVLSB 2040
RSVP Here: https://tinyurl.com/RSVPAniAdhikari']

column2: ['Interview with the founder of a unicorn startup "Physics Wallah" TOMORROW! #3327']

['Join us for a captivating interview this Friday with Alakh Pandey, the founder of the unicorn startup ‚ÄúPhysics Wallah‚Äù.
Alakh Pandey brings invaluable expertise on the nuances of education in India, from the challenges of school curriculum to the intense competition of college entrance exams. During the interview we hope that you are able to gain profound insights into the educational landscape of India, offering a comparative perspective for students studying here at Berkeley.

["Interested in Tech, Biotech, Startups, and Healthcare consulting? The Bio-Business Initiative is hosting our annual Biotech Symposium on Monday, April 8th, from 8-10 pm at Genetics and Plant Biology Room 100. This year‚Äôs symposium will focus on Artificial Intelligence (AI).
Join us and learn from five industry professionals from NVIDIA, Databricks, 310.ai, SynBioBeta, Pinnacle Healthcare Consulting, and more! Our speakers have unique experiences in the Bay Area's science and business industries and can provide excellent advice for those interested in exploring academia, research, or cutting-edge industry opportunities. The event will include a speaker panel session, followed by Q&A and networking.
We are excited to announce our esteemed speakers as our guests : 
Kooshiar Azimian, a former Machine Learning Engineer at Facebook, is now the founder of 310.ai, a platform dedicated to biomolecule design.
John Cumbers. is a former NASA bioengineer, the founder of SynBioBeta, and an Investor at the deep tech investment fund (DCVC). 
Mehrzad Samadi, founder of the scalable genomics analysis software Parabricks (acquired by NVIDIA), currently serves as a Senior Engineering Manager at NVIDIA, focusing on GenAI.
Reza Zadeh, an adjunct professor at Stanford, the founder of Matroid a key member of the founding team of Databricks, will share his experiences in helping to launch the company.
Janelle Anderson, a healthcare and business development professional with over 20 years of experience in this field and the manager of Pinnacle Healthcare Consulting.
Don't miss this opportunity to connect with industry leaders and expand your professional network. Join us for an evening of learning and networking at the Biotech + AI Symposium.

RSVP link: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdmp0d2kYvJcAfQOpYu-Pu75Jgf3n-KLw7RpUyBR6qgBVxP2Q/viewform

['Hey guys!
Delta Consulting (Berkeley's Ed-Tech Consulting Club) is hosting weekly Leetcode workshops on Fridays 3 - 4 PM (subject to change). Content is going to cover the basics, data structures, graph problems, sliding window, string problems, linked lists, dynamic programming (hopefully everything you need to ace the tech interview). 
The first week is going to cover data structures and relevant leetcode easy problems. Each week will slowly increase difficulty and we will "assign" problems to work on over the week on your own to perfect the topic covered in the previous week. It is done entirely in python and it is expected that you are familiar with programming in python already (I.e CS 61A/88/etc) although advanced topics like those found in CS 170 will be taught but from a practical/coding perspective and not so much a theoretical one. Only around 40-45 spots are available so sign up soon. Note that you will have to sign up for each workshop individually, although it is possible that we will give preference first to those who attended the prior workshop. It is open to anyone who would like to improve their Leetcode skills for technical interviews. 
You can sign up for the first workshop using the link below! Further communication will be sent out upon signing up. 
https://forms.gle/Dj7p7cxRLK5vCq4t9
Hope to see you there :)']
