["Hey Everyone,

Blockchain At Berkeley is hosting its first Ecosystem Meetup/Workshop of the semester with NEAR Protocol on this Thursday February 8th, from 5:30-7:30PM in the Haas School of Business - Cheit Hall C210. Come enjoy some pizza and learn how to build a decentralized application (DApp) in JavaScript using Jutsu.ai!

You'll be taught by Jutsu founder and CEO Zahidul Islam, and will leave the workshop having built and deployed a decentralized frontend component, right from your browser! All you'll need to bring is your laptop (and a good attitude)! See you there, RSVP here: https://lu.ma/gr7r60zn"]
column11: Haas School of Business - Cheit Hall C210

column5: ['Visit the Woz on Monday (2/5) from 5:30pm to 8:00pm to learn about the challenges that Intel is tackling today. In addition to sharing information about internships and full-time positions, Intel will be doing resume reviews to help your application stand out!']

['Hi friends!
Starting Monday (02/05), HKN, the EECS honors society, is offering free in-person, drop-in tutoring hours daily, Monday through Friday, from 1 PM to 5 PM. These tutoring sessions will take place at our offices in Soda 345 and Cory 290. Feel free to just walk in and ask for tutoring from a tutor on duty! You can find out more at hkn.mu/tutor. While you‚Äôre there, we recommend hovering over the tutors‚Äô names to see which classes they have completed and what their tutoring preferences are.
Please note that HKN will not assist with course projects in any way due to course policies.
We will also be hosting midterm and final review sessions throughout the semester. More information on individual review sessions will be posted approximately 1-2 weeks before the exam on the respective course Ed. Be on the lookout for these!
Lastly, if you‚Äôre ever interested in checking out the variety of fields that our EECS courses have to offer, check out our course guide at hkn.mu/courseguides. You can see which classes in the department fall under which fields and get an idea of the classes that you may be interested in taking. You can also click on a class bubble to get a detailed overview about what to expect from the class: mini-syllabi, breakdowns of the class‚Äôs workload, usefulness in industry, research, and more!
If you ever have any questions, we will be more than happy to answer! Please email current-tutoring@hkn.eecs.berkeley.edu with any questions that might arise.
Happy studying!
Eta Kappa Nu‚Äôs (HKN) very own Tutoring Committee']

['CSUA General Meeting #1 will be this coming Thursday 2/1 from 6-8 PM in the Wozniak Lounge! Join us to learn about what resources CSUA has to offer and how to become involved through officership, as well as meet new people and play fun games! **Pizza and drinks will be provided! **Looking forward to seeing you all there :D\nRSVP by reacting to the announcement on our discord: https://csua.org/discord']

column2: ['Join AWE, the Association of Women in EE&CS! #2903']
column5:
["Interested in joining a community of female-identifying and nonbinary undergraduate students interested in tech? Join AWE!
AWE, or the Association of Women in EE&CS, is a student-run organization at UC Berkeley that seeks to empower female-identifying and nonbinary undergraduate students in electrical engineering, computer science, and related disciplines.
We host a variety of academic, industry, and social events throughout each semester. Some of the events we host include Breaktimes (casual lunches for members to chat with company recruiters), along with technical and recruiting resources if you're looking to hone your skills. We also host fun socials to interact with other members of the community, as well as engaging social programs such as mentorship, which connects you with another member from AWE.
Ready to join? Our membership form is at https://tinyurl.com/AWE-membership-sp24!
Learn more at our website, follow us on Instagram (@awe.berkeley), and check out our Facebook page to keep in touch. 

Upcoming Events:
üß∫ Welcome Back Picnic - Monday, 1/29, 12 - 2 pm @ the Glade
üìö Black, Latinx, and Indigenous Study Hours - Thursday, 1/31, 11 am - 2 pm @ Soda 373
ü§ù Mentorship Mixer - Thursday, 2/1, 3 - 4 pm @ the Glade
üë©‍üíª Tech Series: Product Management - Wednesday, 2/7, 5 - 6 pm @ Cory 293"]

["Do you know how many computers were connected to the Internet on January 1, 1989? Or how many YouTube videos have more than 1 billion views? What about the bandwidth beneath the Atlantic Ocean?
If you want to solve problems like these, join Jane Street at the upcoming Estimathon¬Æ at UC Berkeley, hosted with HKN! The Estimathon is a team-based contest that combines trivia, game theory, and mathematical thinking.
In teams, you'll attempt 13 Fermi problems in 30 minutes, ranging from totally trivial to positively Putnamesque. Be prepared to come up with the best set of confidence intervals!
The event will be on Tuesday, February 6th, from 5:30 - 6:30pm PT. Location details will be shared upon participation confirmation! Food and swag will be provided! Sign up at the following link by Friday, February 2nd if you‚Äôre interested! This event has limited capacity; attendees will be confirmed by EOD on Monday, February 5th.
Signup link: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSd_tlLJqiNcyqkpER8QD2bF8b5RwSqzXfgbWlCd6vawPl3kmw/viewform"]

['Join NVIDIA on Monday (1/29) from 6:00 pm - 7:00 pm in an event hosted with HKN to hear from NVIDIA engineers, including a UC Berkeley alum, about the technical problems that NVIDIA is solving today. You will also get the chance to hear about career and recruiting opportunities at NVIDIA, and ways to make your application stand out!\nRegister for the event here using your Berkeley email:  https://events.nvidia.com/ucberkeleytechpanelwithnv24']

["Calling all AI Startup founders! We at AI Entrepreneurs at Berkeley have opened the applications for our next cohort of AI startups. 
Quick recap: in just two semesters, alumni have created more than $40M worth of value, and we've had awesome guests like Cory Levy and Harrison Chase. 
About the program: 
Mentorship from startup veterans as advisors
Access to capital - many of our founders have raised with awesome VCs like Pear VC, Y Combinator, Antler, Berkeley SkyDeck, Z Fellows, Unusual Ventures, and many more 
Weekly hacking sessions with weekly instructional sessions on topics like GTM, discovery, and technical topics 
Speaker sessions with awesome founders
Access to resources (partnerships with OpenAI, Microsoft Azure, Amazon Web Services (AWS), Mercury, etc.) 
Personalized introductions to design partners and customers 
Pitch to a ton of awesome investors at the end-of-semester demo day! 
If you're interested, and your team is affiliated with Berkeley, then apply here
Check out our website: www.aientrepreneurs.org 
Or send a message to contact@aientrepreneurs.org to chat with us directly!"]

['ANova apps are open! üíô
We seek to empower students by providing CS education and mentorship to under-resourced schools and marginalized communities \U0001faf6
If you‚Äôre interested in CS education and mentorship, you‚Äôve found the right place! We are recruiting for the Spring 2024 semester (no CS experience required!) ‚Äî apply here !!
Come to our LAST infosession TONIGHT at Dwinelle 145 from 8 - 9:30 PM !! üíô
APPS ARE DUE THIS SAT (1/27) AT 11:59 PM !
Check out our Linktree and Instagram to learn more about us ‚ú®']

["Are you interested in cybersecurity and want to find out more about what it's like? Are you considering a career in security and don't know where to start? Come to Berke1337!
Berke1337 (pronounced berk-leet) is the cybersecurity club at UC Berkeley. We connect Cal students with resources and opportunities to learn more about, and explore a career in, the cybersecurity space. This includes hosting technical talks, workshops, speakers, and cybersecurity competitions that will help give you real experience with common security topics. Anyone is welcome to join, and there is no application process!
Just fill out the registration form here to join and get info about our meetings this spring: https://forms.gle/WzDf88K4fWsANefC8
You can also join our discord to stay involved: https://discord.gg/dd7a6VN5ut
See you there, and have a great spring semester!"]

["Entering UC Berkeley with no real world coding experience, I went through a rough (ROUGH) journey of trying to find my true passion within computer science. In my efforts, I ended up taking the Web Development at Berkeley DeCal on a whim and it was truly one of the best decisions I could've made! The class not only taught me all about full stack, but about the confidence and creativity every programmer should have! 

Introduction to Full Stack Development is for those of you who are looking to get a start in your web development journey in a fun, safe, and inviting environment. Our course is open to all experience levels! Check out our course website to learn more! https://fullstackdecal.com

Our Spring 2024 recruitment season is in full swing, and our applications are now open for both our club and DeCal! https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfktrNEIJovVzKOTV2gJEpg30kK0SVKoXXur0boEhNwlJ-jpg/viewform 

Interested? Come out to our various recruitment events to get to know us and what we‚Äôre all about! You can find all of our recruitment events on the WDB Facebook page as well as linked below.

DeCal Infosession 1 \\ 01/23/24 8-9PM PST @ Dwinelle 234
DeCal Infosession 2 \\ 01/25/24 8-9PM PST @ Wheeler 104
Decal Application Due \\ Sat, Jan 27 @ 11:59

Stay tuned on our socials through our Linktree to hear even more updates, events, and exciting news for the semester. https://lnkd.in/gE-rd7R9"]

["Hi everyone!

I'm teaching a decal this semester covering the history and applications of esoteric programming languages like BF, LOLCODE, and Piet if anyone needs an easy 1-unit course!

https://decal.berkeley.edu/courses/7243"]

['How do self-driving cars decide who deserves moral priority in an accident? Why are most voice assistants female? How should social media platforms moderate content? What is the relationship between data collection and power? How do you form your beliefs and values about technology? 

We often push the bounds of technological advancement without considering the ethical implications and consequences of our actions. From the rise of performative activism to internet sovereignty and the various ethics of Zoom proctoring, this DeCal explores the above questions and more, with topics spanning social media, bioethics, education, AI, data science, and the environment. We will analyze how technology has evolved to become intertwined with our society as well as the morals that we harbor.

This is a 1-unit class that meets in person once per week on Wednesdays from 5 - 6:30 pm in Dwinelle 235. Each class will be 1 hour 20 minutes. Interested students should fill out the application form by 26th January, accessible at https://tinyurl.com/tsi-decal-sp24']

["You're invited to attend the 14th Global Leadership Organization Leadership Summit from March 16-17! If you are seeking to build and practice your leadership skills, the Global Leadership Organization's Leadership Training Summit is an excellent opportunity! You will learn and apply skills that will help you become a leader in the community and succeed in professional development. 
At the summit, you will receive training directly from qualified counselors from a variety of different industries, ranging from Apple to Bain & Company, in a small group setting. Students learn to develop a leadership mentality, work within a team, practice public speaking, and network with top professionals in the business and with other like-minded peers!
For more information, check out the Global Leadership Organization (GLO) website! 
Fill out our application form today! Early bird registration discount ends Feb. 16."]

['Calling all Black, Latinx, and Indigenous Computer Science students! Have you joined ColorStack yet? We provide resources and opportunities that will help you succeed in completing your degree and jumpstart your career in the tech industry. Make sure to fill out our membership form to receive more information on upcoming events!\nMembership Form: http://tinyurl.com/ColorStack-Berkeley']

['Codebase applications are open - work on industry projects & join a tight-knit supportive community <3 

We empower students to break into the software industry through real projects with companies! we have a mentored track for people with no prior experience where you work with a nonprofit and a client track where we partner with high growth tech companies like etsy, door dash, and postman with projects that range from ML to augmented reality!! come join a really supportive group of friends, mentors, and coders

Check out our information on our Linktree, email us at contact@codebase.berkeley.edu, stop by tabling until 1/25, or shoot us a message on our discord server! 

Apply by WEDNESDAY NIGHT HERE
Talk to us during our URM panel (MONDAY 1/21 7-8 PM BNorth 82D)
Learn more about our semester plans HERE']
['Interested in learning more about extracurricular opportunities in EE? Come to EE club fair 1/24 at 2pm in the Woz! There will be hands-on demos :)']

['Interested in leveraging technology to save lives and improve medicine on a global scale? At Medical Technology @ Berkeley (MT@B), we develop medical software, devices, educational tools, scientific writing, and clinical skills to cultivate an interdisciplinary intellectual community uniting future professionals in technology, biomedical and computational science, and medicine. 
Our past consulting partners, such as Stanford Medicine, UCSF Medical Center, and Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory have facilitated our software engineering products to be deployed internationally. We are your one-stop shop to get clinically impactful technology development experience, achieve technical actualization in disciplines across technology and medicine, and contribute to intellectual dialogues across our research and editorial publications community. 
Join one of the fastest growing communities at Berkeley dedicated to building technologies to save patient lives and improving the delivery of medicine internationally. We look for passionate and committed contributors from a multitude of disciplines in any year of education at Berkeley!
Check out our website at mtab.berkeley.edu or send us an email at ucbmtab@gmail.com
For email updates please fill out our interest form at tinyurl.com/mtabsp24 and check out our flier below with more details on our Spring 2024 recruitment cycle. ']

["If you're looking for a fun group of tech-loving individuals to hang out with, look no further than IEEE (https://ieee.berkeley.edu)!
We're an inclusive technical community org on campus, and we'd love to have you in our community :) Among other things we 
Host infosessions (Apple, TSMC, Intel, and more!)
Run 2 DeCals, HOPE and Micromouse
Lead Technical Projects
Host fun socials!
Join us at our infosessions from 5-6pm at the Wozniak Lounge (Soda 430-438) on Thursday, 1/25 and Thursdays, 2/1!
We take EVERYONE who applies! :D General members can sign up anytime!
General Member sign-up: https://berkie.ee/gm-app 
If you're interested in getting more involved, apply to be an officer on a committee or be a participant in a project! Applications are due 2/8, 11:59pm
Committee Officer Application: https://berkie.ee/committee-app 
Project Member Application: https://berkie.ee/project-app "]

["Hello everyone!
I hope the first week of the semester went well for you!
We are recruiting new club members for Spring 2024! Applications are open NOW and due Friday 1/26! http://tinyurl.com/xrab-sp24-app 
We have a ton of project and research teams you can read about on our website (https://xr.berkeley.edu/) and on our application, but if you are more interested in starting a new project, we will hold a project mixer for all members to pitch their ideas and team up with other members to form project groups mentored by senior members of XR@B. If you're looking to propose your own team OR project idea to XR@B, please fill out the team application form: https://forms.gle/hdVNTgbbh8hvYCL4A 
No experience in VR/AR is required to join our club, but if you would like an introduction to the field, we highly recommend you to take the XR DeCal! It's made for people with no prior experience, but you will have a working VR/AR app by the end of the semester :0 
XR DeCal: https://xr.berkeley.edu/decal/ 
DeCal application: http://tinyurl.com/xrab-sp24-decal 
(Both club and DeCal applications close at 11:59 PST on Friday, January 26th) 
If you or anyone you know would like to take the time to get to know us first, Extended Reality at Berkeley will be tabling on the glade throughout this week and next week, where you can learn about our projects, the XR DeCal, and meet some of our members! 
Additionally, drop by our infosessions this week! 
We'll be in Dwinelle 234 from 8-9:30 PM on Monday 1/22, and Wheeler 220 from 8-9:30 PM on Monday 1/25 
Looking forward to meeting you!
All the best,
Harris Thai
XR@B President"]

column2: ['Join the International Software Product Management Association at Berkeley #2841']
column5: ['Are you interested in Product Management or Technology? Join the International Software Product Management Association at Berkeley. We are the first and only university chapter of ISPMA, an established association of experts, researchers, and industrial professionals fostering software product management excellence across industries. It is our first semester recruiting new members, and we would love to meet students eager to learn about PM! Come out to our infosessions on Tuesday 1/23 and Thursday 1/25 at 8:00PM in Dwinelle 130 to learn more! https://linktr.ee/ispma.berkeley']

column2: ['Interested in teaching senior citizens technology or learning wise career/life advice from an elder community member? #2840']
column5: ['Elder Welfare Mentorship is a new student organization nonprofit empowering seniors with tech skills and offering students valuable learning from elder community members. We match Berkeley students 1-1 with senior citizens in our participating partnership sites (UC Berkeley Retirement Center and StageBridge Oakland + more!) and pairs can meet on a weekly basis either online or in-person (up to the pair to decide). Anyone can be a mentor, no matter their technology literacy level!!\nFill out our interest form to receive the link to our 2/6 and 2/7 infosessions. For more information, check out our website, follow us on Instagram, (@elderwelfarementorship), and visit us on Sproul tabling Jan 29-Feb 2 + Feb 5 9AM-3PM :)']
column11: UC Berkeley Retirement Center and StageBridge Oakland

column5:
["The Esperanto DeCal is open and has seats left!
Time: Mondays 1400‚Äì14:59 (2‚Äì2:59pm), first class 22 January!
Application: None (but automatic enrollment is currently disabled by the department, so email me at s.a.sato@berkeley.edu to get added to the bCourse).
Context: This class aims to take students from 0 to intermediate in Esperanto, the international language, in one semester. (It's not as hard as it might sound!)
Side effects might include (1) boosting your language-learning skill by getting familiar with language-learning techniques, grammatical ideas, and Esperanto words shared by other languages and (2) connecting with an international community which cares about bringing peace through mutual understanding.
More info: decal.berkeley.edu, classes.berkeley.edu, and feel free to reply with questions!
If you can't make the course but want to hear about Esperanto events, including a recurring conversation hour, a≈≠ se vi jam parolas Esperanton (!), sign up for announcements here!
(Technically not EECS-related, but I know a lot of STEM people are interested in languages and conlangs.)"]

column2: ['Join the Berkeley AI Safety Initiative for Students (BASIS)! #2833']
column5:
['We think powerful AI systems will have very large, and potential catastrophic consequences. BASIS is a student organization and research community focused on safely navigating the transition to powerful AI systems.
We have four programs:
Our Fellows Program:
The BASIS Fellows Program is a technical Al safety network that will offer exclusive social events and opportunities to members.
Apply by Wed, 2/7!
Our Intro to AI Safety Decal: 
We provide a technical career/research overview for students interested in technical AI safety research, covering topics like neural network interpretability, learning from human feedback, and goal misgeneralization in reinforcement learning agents. 
Apply by Mon, 1/27!
Our Supervised Program for Alignment Research (SPAR):
An opportunity to do guided alignment research under an AI safety researcher, including researchers from Stanford and FAR AI.
Applications will open by Wed, 1/27. Apply by Wed, 2/7!
Our AI Governance DeCal:
An 8-week program to discuss governance solutions to risks from advanced AI models. We cover the capabilities and threats from current and future frontier AI systems, and discuss methods to mitigate potential misalignment and misuse. Anyone interested in law or AI is welcome to apply! 
Apply by Mon, 1/27!
Please fill out our interest form!
Helpful resources:
Email
Discord server
Website']

['Do you enjoy learning about computer science, engineering, design, or business? If so, come and check out Berkeley‚Äôs premier mobile development student organization: Mobile Developers of Berkeley! Our training program is designed to teach new members how to develop full-stack mobile applications, no prior experience required. Returning members can either choose to work on projects for real clients, develop further passion projects, or teach the training program!
Come to our infosessions and meet some of our members:
ABCDs of Tech: Thursday, January 18th 8-10 PM (Dwinelle 155)
Tech Diversity Night: Friday, January 19th 8-10 PM (Chou 150)
MDB Infosession 1 (free pizza): Tuesday, January 23rd, 8-9:30 PM (Dwinelle 105)
MDB Infosession 2 (free cookies): Wednesday, January 24th, 8-9:30 PM (Dwinelle 105)
Sign up for a coffee chat with one of our members at mdb.dev/recruitment
Learn more about our process at mdb.dev/recruitment or our instagram @mdbdev
Our application is live at mdb.dev/apply. Apps are due Thursday, January 25th at 11:59 PM PST!
If you have any questions, email us at contact@mdb.dev']

['‚õì Blockchain for Developers Decal ‚õì 

Interested in learning smart contract development? Looking for a technical 3 unit P/NP course? Join us for the Blockchain for Developers DeCal! This DeCal is designed to provide students a comprehensive overview of relevant topics in blockchain development, as well as hands-on experience in developing and deploying their own smart contracts & sovereign Cosmos blockchains. By the end of the course, you will have experience in Solidity on the EVM, Rust on CosmWasm, and the ability to develop your own blockchain solutions! üöÄ 
 Enrollment is as easy as adding the course on CalCentral, lecture starts on 1/31! Course listing here: https://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2024-spring-compsci-198-077-grp-077
Excited to see you in class!']

column2: ['Join the Fundamentals of Blockchain Technology Decal! #2806']
column5:
['‚õì Blockchain Fundamentals Decal ‚õì 

Interested in learning what blockchain is and how it works? Looking for a fascinating 2 unit P/NP course? Join us for the Fundamentals of Blockchain Technology DeCal! This course offers an in-depth exploration of blockchain technology, covering foundational aspects of cryptography and distributed systems, advanced topics such as zero-knowledge proofs and game theory, and practical applications in Ethereum and smart contracts. By the end of the course, you will have a solid understanding of blockchains and cryptocurrencies and the ability to form educated perspectives on these topics! üöÄ 
Enrollment is as easy as adding the course on CalCentral, lecture starts on 1/31! Course listing here: https://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2024-spring-compsci-198-078-grp-078
Excited to see you in class!']

column2: ['Join the Going Down the EECS Stack Decal! #2804']
column5: ['Are you unsure what areas of EECS you want to focus on? Are you curious about what EECS is in the first place? \nHKN is excited to be hosting its DeCal, Going Down the EECS Stack, which explores various fields within EECS and provides guidance as to how you can dive deeper into these fields as a Berkeley student. This DeCal is open to all experience levels and all majors, but we will prioritize enrollment for those who have little to no experience in EECS. This class will feature guest speakers, field trips, interactive labs, and more.\nLearn more on our website decal.best or apply at hkn.mu/decalapp. The deadline to apply is Friday, January 26th at 11:59 PM. However, please apply as soon as possible; applications will be processed on a first-come-first-serve basis. The first class will be on Wednesday, February 7th.']

column2: ['The Best Minimum Wage Job of All Time #2795']
column5:
['Get paid $15/hour to learn (or play) the greatest game of all time. 
Come to our weekly bridge club meetings on Sundays. Free lunch is provided. No bridge experience is required as we teach from the ground up. If you attend at least 7 sessions this semester, you can receive $15 for every hour that you attend. Our first session is this Sunday, Jan 21, from 1 to 4 pm, at Hearst Field Annex B5.
If this is of interest to you, please fill out this form. Please also share this with your friends that may be interested. If you have any questions, I can answer them in this thread or you can send an email to ucbbridgeclub@gmail.com.
What is bridge:
Bridge is an incredibly fun card game that is played by millions worldwide in clubs, tournaments, and online. Prominent players include Bill Gates and Warren Buffett. It is also one of the last mind sports where computers still cannot outperform humans. 
About me:
I am Jonathan, a 3rd year studying Computer Science. I learned bridge when I was in first grade and loved the game ever since. I most recently represented the US at the World Youth Team Championships hosted in the Netherlands in 2023, winning a silver medal in the under-21 division. I am passionate about spreading my love for the game to my peers and have taught bridge for the last 8 years. ']

['Are you excited about Generative AI and have been or are interested in building Generative AI applications? Generative AI at Berkeley is a student organization (started last semester and now has over 30 members) focused on groundbreaking applications of Generative AI. We partner with startups in the space to work on projects relating to things like developing LLM agents, LoRA fine-tuning, building Stable Diffusion pipelines, etc. We have worked with companies like Capital One and startups from YCombinator and also have a dedicated new member program that teaches you all about Generative AI technologies through weekly workshops and an advanced curriculum for those without prior experience. If this sounds interesting you can find our application forms on our LinkTree (https://linktr.ee/berkeleygenai). ']

['Hi everyone! Are you interested in software engineering and cloud computing? Cloud at Cal offers a wide range of opportunities to explore the world of cloud technology.

As part of Cloud at Cal, you‚Äôll have the opportunity to gain industry experience and develop products for companies such as Amazon, Grabango, Accenture, and more, and learn from software engineering experts. Through our research team, you‚Äôll be able to tackle impactful machine learning and cloud projects with leading research groups in MIT, Waymo, and MSK Cancer Center, on interdisciplinary initiatives spanning medical imaging, autonomous vehicles and more. You‚Äôll also be able to dive into hands-on projects using AWS resources, help teach our decal, compete in competitions, and even pursue your own ideas, either independently or within a group, to publish research papers.

We are constantly looking for passionate students to join us! Applications are now live and can be found here! Our recruitment timeline is posted on our instagram (@cloudatcal) as well as our website (cloudatcal.org) and applications will be due on 1/28. If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to us at cloudatcal@gmail.com!']

['Cal Hacks SP24 director applications are officially open! 
Join the Cal Hacks Director team this spring and help us in welcoming the ELEVENTH edition of the world‚Äôs largest collegiate hackathon! All UC Berkeley students are welcome regardless of major or technical/hackathon experience‚Äîwe can‚Äôt wait to meet you all and welcome the future organizers of the WORLD‚ÄôS LARGEST COLLEGIATE HACKATHON!
Have any questions? Feel free to email team@calhacks.io, come up to our table from 1/16-1/25, or shoot us a message on our discord server! Apply by 1/31 @11:59pm HERE.
ALSO... come to our infosession (1/25 7-9 PM @ Moffitt 102)

RSVP for our Meet & Eat with Directors (1/29 8-10 PM @ SOCS 166) HERE
Learn more on our Notion HERE and join our Cal Hacks Discord server HERE.']

["Visit the course site at ocf.io/decal for more info! We will also hold infosessions next week at 7-8PM on Tuesday, January 23rd and Thursday, January 25th. You can attend in-person at the OCF Lab in 171 MLK, or online on ocf.io/meet.
We will be covering the basics of administering a Linux-based server environment in the manner of the EECS Instructional Servers (hivexx.cs.berkeley.edu) and the Open Computing Facility (tsunami.ocf.berkeley.edu, etc.). By the end of this course, you'll be comfortable using GNU/Linux, understand in a broad sense how the system‚Äôs various parts work together, e.g. init, filesystems, services, daemons, etc., understand basic networking, have a good sense of how to maintaining system security, and have a practical taste of what sysadmins do in industry.
We know potential students will have differing backgrounds in terms of CS and sysadmin experience. The OCF will provide support for students of all levels by being available for drop-in help during staff hours and of course during lab time. Everyone is welcome!

To enroll, you must complete Lab 0 by Saturday, January 27th 11:59PM, which serves as your application. We will try to enroll as many people as we can! "]

['We are Blockchain @ Berkeley, a student org at the forefront of the blockchain industry. Recruitment is right around the corner, and we want you to join us!
Blockchain at Berkeley drives innovation in the blockchain industry by building an ecosystem that empowers students to make an impact through practical education, consulting for enterprise companies, and conducting cutting edge research.

Some of our work includes our EdX courses taken by over 300k students, various development consulting projects at fortune 50 companies, and major DeFi governance voting decisions.

Check out our website for the recruitment timeline, our past work, and to learn more about our club.
Interested? Join us at our first info session:
üìÖ Date: Thursday, 1/18  
‚è∞ Time: 8:00 PM 
üìç Location: VLSB 2040
 We look forward to seeing you at our events! ']

['Data Science Discovery Program
Are you passionate about working with data to solve real-life problems? Do you want to gain relevant research experience and skills while forming a network with industry and academic partners?
Apply now to be a part of this semester‚Äôs Data Science Discovery program! As the largest undergraduate data science research program in the United States, the Data Science Discovery Program connects undergraduates with hands-on, team-based opportunities to contribute to more than 85 cutting-edge data research projects with on and off-campus partners.
Our partner cohort includes: Honda, IBM, Rivian, BART, Proofpoint, Lawrence Berkeley National Lab, MIT, Pfizer, American Heart Association, UC Berkeley Discovery Hub, and many more! A full list of partners and application links to their projects can be found on the application page. If you want to work on research projects that will have an impact on the world around you, be sure to apply by the deadlines below!
Check out descriptions and expectations for previous projects here.
Click Here to Apply
Prerequisites: Data 8 or equivalent coursework/experience. Additional coursework or experience in data science, stats, programming and/or computer science encouraged. Each project will specify what skills they‚Äôd like to have.
Priority Application Deadline: Wednesday January 10th, 11:59 PM PT
Final Application Deadline: Monday January 15th, 11:59 PM PT
*Deadlines are subject to change. Some projects may close their applications early, while others may extend their deadlines. We strongly recommend that you apply as early as possible.
Next Steps: Project Partners will reach out to students to schedule interviews on a rolling basis and make offers by January 19th.
Academic Credit: If you accept an offer with a Discovery project you will be invited to enroll in a section of Data 198. More details on receiving credit will come after the application deadline. Students can receive between 2-3 units of academic credit.
Questions: ds-discovery@berkeley.edu? ']

column2: ['Apply to be a mentor for Computer Science Mentors (CSM) for Spring 2024! #2572']
column5:
['Hi! Are you interested in joining the teaching community at Berkeley? Do you want to help support students looking for support in a small group setting, and also find friends and community? 
Computer Science Mentors (CSM) is a student-run organization that provides guidance and resources in a smaller classroom environment through group tutoring sessions for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 70, CS 88, EECS 16A, and EECS 16B. Each section has 4-7 students and meets once or twice a week for 1 or 1.5 hours. The goal of CSM is to build a personal learning community and social network so that both students and mentors can comfortably seek and receive support.

For Spring 2024, we‚Äôre recruiting for the following roles:
Junior Mentors (JMs) for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 70, CS 88, EECS 16A and EECS 16B
Associate Mentors (AMs) for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, EECS 16A, EECS 16B, CS 88, and CS 70
Content Mentors (CMs) for CS61B, CS 61C, EECS 16A and EECS 16B

This application is available at https://tinyurl.com/sp24-csm-app. Submissions are due Wednesday, January 17th at 11:59pm PT. No late applications will be accepted! In CSM, we are committed to diversity and inclusion and value applicants of all backgrounds. We consider applications holistically and value passion for mentoring and willingness to learn over your grades and struggles during your time as a student - we do not consider grades in our application process. Overall, we encourage all who are interested to apply and to give the application your best effort! Want to hear from real mentors what CSM is like? See our info session recording and slides. 
slides: https://tinyurl.com/csm-infosession-sp24
recording: https://tinyurl.com/csm-infosession-sp24-recording
Visit https://csmentors.berkeley.edu for more information or reach out to us at mentors@berkeley.edu!
Well done on finishing finals, and happy holidays!']

['Interested in joining Berkeley‚Äôs EE/CS teaching community?

Computer Science Mentors (CSM) is a student-run organization that provides guidance and resources in a smaller classroom environment through group tutoring sessions for CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 70, CS 88, EECS 16A, and EECS 16B. Each section has 4-7 students and meets once or twice a week for 1 or 1.5 hours. The goal of CSM is to build a personal learning community and social network so that both students and mentors can comfortably seek and receive support.
Join us on Friday to learn more about our mentor roles and experiences, how you can give back to the CS community, and ways to get involved in teaching CS!

['Happy early Thanksgiving! Lavender Alliance at Berkeley here presents you with our last event this semester‚Äî‚ÄúWomen* Who Code‚Äù career panel on 11/30 at 6:30pm! ü§©ü§©ü§©ü§©‚ú®‚ú®‚ú®‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

As computer languages and data analysis methods are fastly advancing along with AI, coding skills are important and applicable to many different fields of work. However, STEM has been a male-dominated sphere due to biased culture and gender norms. 

To better support women students and young professionals in coding, data, tech, and related fields, we are organizing the ‚ÄúWomen* Who Code‚Äù panel. We have invited three amazing panelists who have diverse experiences working in these fields to share their advice for students getting ready to enter the work force. After the panel, students will get to network with these inspiring mentors to get more career support in the future. 

To sign up: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSexM_Xbjle-2UDfvfI-VzS51dIgMWivB9jP-GQfacs4psi8GA/viewform
Time: 11/30 starting at 6:30pm! 
Location: QARC Center (TBD)
We will provide some pizzas! 
‚ú®‚ú®‚ú®‚ú®‚ú®‚ú®‚ú®‚ú®‚ú®
The panel is open to all women students in coding, data, tech. To better address the needs of international students, one of our panelists will share info about H1B sponsorship!!! Please help spread the word! 

Fill out RSVP form now and indicate whether you want to join our Women* Who Code Slack channel to join a women-based career network. We will share resources for career development, make announcements for future events like this. It‚Äôs a platform for women* supporting women*!!! 

#women#womenempowerment#womensupportingwomen#womenempoweringwomen#womeninspiringwomen#womenpower #strongwomen#womenrock #womenintech#womenwhocode#womenincoding #womencoders#womenanddata#womendatascience']

['Hello friends!
Starting Monday (9/11), HKN, the EECS honors society, is offering free in-person, drop-in tutoring hours. These will occur Monday through Friday every week, from 11am to 5 PM, at our offices in Soda 345 and Cory 290. Feel free to just walk in and ask for tutoring from a tutor on duty! You can find out more at hkn.mu/tutor. While you‚Äôre there, we recommend hovering over the tutors‚Äô names to see which classes they have completed and what their tutoring preferences are. Please note that HKN will not assist with course projects in any way due to course policies.
We will also be hosting midterm and final review sessions throughout the semester. More information on individual review sessions will be posted approximately 1-2 weeks before the exam on the respective course Ed. Be on the lookout for these!
Lastly, if you‚Äôre ever interested in checking out the variety of fields that our EECS courses have to offer, check out our course guide at hkn.mu/courseguides. You can see which classes in the department fall under which fields and get an idea of the classes that you may be interested in taking. You can also click on a class bubble to get a detailed overview about what to expect from the class: mini-syllabi, breakdowns of the class‚Äôs workload, usefulness in industry, research, and more! These will soon be updated to include missing courses and reflect the structure of more recent offerings of courses.
If you ever have any questions, we will be more than happy to answer! Please email current-tutoring@hkn.eecs.berkeley.edu with any questions that might arise.
Happy studying!
Eta Kappa Nu‚Äôs (HKN) very own Tutoring Committee']

['Hi everyone! 
Interested in conducting computational biology research? Check out ULAB: Computational Biology! We‚Äôre a research-oriented club that provides students the tools to perform quality scientific research and network to join labs on campus. 
Students learn about ongoing research that meshes computer science and biology with weekly lectures on omics, environmental community modeling, protein simulations, bioinformatics, etc.! 
Moreover, as a mentee, you will be paired with experienced mentors to work on your own year-long research projects. You‚Äôll have the opportunity to publish your research and present a poster at the ULAB symposium. You can expect to engage with scientific literature, get professional development, listen to guest speakers, etc.! 
We‚Äôre also looking for enthusiastic and experienced mentors. Join our leadership team to start designing lectures, modules, workshops, and more! Improve your leadership skills and give back to the community by mentoring like-minded students through year-long research projects. 
We will be hosting an infosession on Sunday, September 10th from 12 pm - 1pm on zoom. The deadline for applications is Saturday, September 16th. The first class will be Tuesday, September 12th from 7-8 PM PDT in-person in Social Sciences 56.
Check out our link tree! 
Mentee Application 
Mentor Application ']

Our goal is to connect technology and data science with advancements in biological science and medical science to generate innovation and collaboration among students. We welcome any students who are interested in hearing from professionals in this field and learning about analyzing data and applying machine learning techniques to medical data.\nPlease fill out the registration form in order to receive updates for the club. column2: ['[Berkeley Math Tournament] Join Our Problem Writing or Logistics Team This Fall! #2015']
column5:
["TLDR: Join BMT (We write & run math tournaments for HS/MS students)! No math/contest experience required https://bmt.berkeley.edu/join

Berkeley Math Tournament is recruiting Berkeley students for both our logistics and problem writing teams! BMT is a registered 501c3 dedicated to mathematics education and building interest in STEM by running some of the largest student-run math tournaments in the USA. 
We prioritize creating holistic events that make math more accessible and engaging to middle and high school students compared to what is usually presented in the classroom. Our problem writing team is responsible for putting together the contest rounds of BMT. 
If you are interested in coming up with fun, challenging problems then you should check out our problem writing meetings! No formal experience in competitions, problem-writing, or even math is required to make a meaningful impact in BMT. 
Our logistics team handles all other aspects of running the tournament. If you are interested in: planning large events and fun activities; fostering community; managing tech; working to attain the diversity, equity, and inclusion goals of our organization; marketing to new audiences; collaborating with our international partners; designing graphics, merchandise, etc.; or bringing in sponsorships to help expand our potential impact -- you would be a great fit for our logistics team! 
To anyone interested, fill out our interest form https://bmt.berkeley.edu/join where you'll find a link to join our discord server! While now is an ideal time to join, members will be able to join on a rolling basis at any point throughout the year -- happy Fall semester!! 
Email: questions@bmt.berkeley.edu
Web: https://bmt.berkeley.edu
Instagram: @berkeley_mt"]

['Hi everyone!  
For those of you who are looking for extra tutoring in your lowerdiv EE/CS courses, Computer Science Mentors (CSM) is an organization that runs small group tutoring sections to supplement lecture, lab, discussion, and tutorials. Wed 9/6 for 61B, 70, 16A @ 12 PM
Thurs 9/7 for 61A, 61C, 88, 16B @ 12 PM
Sign up at https://scheduler.csmentors.org/! Sections start the week of Monday 9/11. 
Computer Science Mentors (CSM) is a student organization with the goal of creating a supportive community among the lower-division CS courses (CS 61A, CS 61B, CS 61C, CS 70, CS 88 (now DATA C88C), EECS 16A, and EECS 16B). We offer small (4 to 7 students), 1 or 1.5 hour long sections each led by a mentor that you regularly attend to review the past week‚Äôs material. Detailed information on logistics and expectations for students can be found here. We ask that all students read this document in full, carefully before enrolling in a CSM section. 
Looking forward to seeing you in section!']

column2: ["Apply to Women in Computing and Data Science's (WiCDS) Data Science, Machine Learning and Project Committees! #1994"]
column5:
['Hello!

WiCDS (Women in Computing and Data Science) is recruiting for our Fall 2023 team and we would love it if you applied!
Our recruitment timeline this semester is as follows:
Zoom info session: Tuesday, Sep 5th, 6-7 PM
Committee Application deadline: Sunday, Sep 10th by 11:59 pm
Final decisions released: by Friday, September 15th, 11.59pm
Committee meetings will begin the week of September 18th
Our committees consist of the Machine Learning, Data Science and Project Committees.

Machine Learning Committee: Explore the field of machine learning with the Women in Computing and Data Science‚Äôs Machine Learning Committee! Our committee offers a mix of introductory and intermediate ML courses, accompanied by hands-on mini projects where you‚Äôll put your Python skills to the test with real-world datasets. While having a background in Data 8 or an introductory CS is a plus, we‚Äôre open to all levels of experience. Join our supportive community, providing female and non-binary students with a platform to enhance technical prowess while thriving in an inclusive environment.

Data Science Committee: Hi! We‚Äôre the Data Science Committee! Our goal is to create an inclusive community for women interested in anything Data Science related. We provide an interactive course to teach students the foundations of data topics such as data cleaning, SQL, linear regression and testing hypothesis, which will allow you to work on personal projects to be presented at the end of the semester. We look forward to meeting you!

The Project Committee will complete a technical project for a startup using a combination of Data Science and Machine Learning concepts. Members will collaborate and work as a team to clean and visualise the provided datasets using various tools, improve their analytical and technical skills, and present their findings in a final deliverable at the end of the semester.

We would also like to mention that our General Membership application will be open for the entire semester, and gives you access to networking sessions (Hudson River Trading, Visa, Citadel etc.) and club socials (coaster painting, boba socials, big-littles etc.)

You can access all committee application forms and the General Membership form here.

Looking forward to seeing your applications!
Malavikha Sudarshan
WiCDS Officer Team
LinkedIn | Instagram | Facebook']

column2: ['Open Computing Facility is looking for new volunteer staff! #1992']
column5: ['If you‚Äôre interested in Linux, Kubernetes, free and open-source software, getting hands-on experience managing industrial-grade servers, or helping fulfill the computing needs of the wider UC Berkeley community, consider joining us at the Open Computing Facility! We‚Äôre a group of volunteer staff who both maintain a physical computer lab (located at 171 MLK) and provide services such as web hosting, software mirrors, an HPC cluster, and one-on-one staff hours for all UC Berkeley students and faculty. \nWe hold general meetings in the fall and spring on Wednesdays at 8-9 PM in the lab. Anyone can attend at any point in the semester to participate in staff trainings and work on OCF projects. No application or prior experience is required to join; we welcome all majors and backgrounds, and there is lots of both technical and administrative work to be done. Even if you‚Äôre not interested in joining the staff team, feel free to stop by to use our desktop computers, scanners, and printers (all students get 20 free pages per day), or to just hang out and study!']

['Hello!
Interested in leveraging technology to save lives and improve medicine on a global scale? Founded in 2017, Medical Technology @ Berkeley (MT@B) is a student organization dedicated to cultivating an interdisciplinary intellectual community to unite future professionals in technology, biomedical and computational science, and medicine. Our past consulting partners, such as Stanford Medicine, UCSF Medical Center, and Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory have facilitated our software engineering products to be deployed internationally. As a community, we are your one-stop shop to get clinically impactful project experience, achieve technical actualization in disciplines across technology and medicine, and contribute to intellectual dialogues across our research and editorial publications community. We welcome partnership inquiries from companies and other student organizations. For more information about MT@B check out our website at https://mtab.berkeley.edu/ or send us an email at ucbmtab@gmail.com.
Infosessions:
Monday 9/4 in Blum Hall (Health Tech Co-Lab) from 6-8pm
Thursday 9/7 in Blum Hall (Health Tech Co-Lab) from 6-8pm
Please check out our card below and fill out our interest form (https://tinyurl.com/mtab-interest) for email updates!']

column2: ['Girls Who Code @ Berkeley is recruiting for Fall 2023! #1986']
column5: ['Girls Who Code @ Berkeley is recruiting for Fall 2023! Girls Who Code College Loops are university-level networks for college-aged women interested in tech to support one another and help each other persist and succeed in the field. \nOur alumni work at Apple, Accenture, J.P. Morgan, Two Sigma, Microsoft, and more. As a Girls Who Code @ Berkeley member, you‚Äôll have access to nearly 100 corporate companies, regional events, and the Girls Who Code network!\nWe host technical workshops, club collabs, and socials throughout the semester!! If you are interested in joining us as an active member, use this link to join our Slack: https://join.slack.com/t/girlswhocodeberkeley/shared_invite/zt-1nzq44ch3-QVd6K7cyKDRkclEHyjioDg']

column2: ['Join the Berkeley AI Safety Initiative for Students! #1975']
column5:
['Join the Berkeley AI Safety Initiative for Students (BASIS)!
‚ÄúMitigating the risk of extinction from AI should be a global priority alongside other societal-scale risks such as pandemics and nuclear war.‚Äù
You may have seen the above statement from the Center for AI Safety, signed by top AI scientists and influential figures such as Geoffrey Hinton, Yoshua Bengio, Dawn Song, Sam Altman, and Demis Hassabis. The statement mirrors growing public sentiment: a recent poll found that 61 percent of Americans believe AI threatens humanity‚Äôs future.
The Berkeley AI Safety Initiative for Students is a student organization focused on mitigating catastrophic risks from advanced AI systems. We‚Äôre supporting students through four programs this semester:
Our Introduction to AI Safety Decal, a technical overview of AI safety and the alignment problem, sponsored by Professor Stuart Russell. We‚Äôll cover topics like neural network interpretability, learning from human feedback, goal misgeneralization in reinforcement learning agents, and eliciting latent knowledge from large language models. Our curriculum was first developed by an AI safety researcher at OpenAI. See here for more details (e.g. curriculum, application, FAQ).
The Supervised Program for Alignment Research (SPAR), an opportunity to do guided research under a AI safety researcher.
Our AI Governance reading group, an 8-week program to read about and discuss governance solutions with free food!
Our Paper Reading Group, where students with technical experience discuss recent ML safety papers each week over snacks! This is open to all members; sign up on our interest form to stay posted!
We‚Äôll be having two info sessions on August 31st and September 1st (location TBA) ‚Äî sign up on our interest form to stay tuned!. If you have any questions, please feel free to contact us at aisafetyberkeley@gmail.com, join our Discord server, or reach out/book a meeting with any of our board members. Thanks so much, and we look forward to seeing y‚Äôall around!
INTEREST FORM: https://airtable.com/shrwLNx78Ymus0ojp
Check out our website to keep track of our recruitment timeline! https://berkeleyaisafety.com/']

['Heard about ‚Äúquant‚Äù and want to learn more? Enjoy puzzles and games?
Traders at Berkeley is the premier quantitative finance organization at UC Berkeley. We are dedicated to cultivating professional and academic interest in quant development, trading, and research.
We‚Äôre excited to announce that applications for our DeCal and the club are open!
IEOR 198: Introduction to Quantitative Finance DeCal
Infosession and First Lecture Facebook Event
We invite all undergraduate and graduate students with any quantitative background to apply! Applications will close next Friday, September 1st 2023.
This is a 2-unit course that teaches fundamentals of quant finance, including topics from market microstructure, market making (options and ETFs), statistical modeling in finance, how to enter the industry, and high frequency trading.
Students will build trading intuition via games, learn how to design predictive models, and build trading bots in Python. The DeCal covers a broad set of topics and aims to reduce the barrier of entry into the field. Guest lectures may be given from traders at companies like Citadel and Headlands to provide perspectives into the industry. Grading is based on attendance, weekly quizzes, and a final project involving real world data.We recommend that students have Python programming experience and a basic probability/statistics knowledge. Locations and times will be finalized but will likely be Thursday evenings (6pm-8pm or 8pm-10pm) on campus.
Club Recruitment
Infosession 2 Facebook Event
We‚Äôre seeking new club members with an aptitude for quantitative careers and an interest in the industry. All grade levels and backgrounds are welcome to apply. As a member, you‚Äôll help us engage sponsors, plan events, and develop trading games. You can find more about our process on our website. Applications for club membership are open and will close at 11:59 pm PST, September 1st 2023.
Questions?
Please email us if you have any questions. We look forward to seeing your application!
Links
Website
Instagram
DeCal application
Club application
Coffee chats']

column2: ['Interested in mentoring, science, or education? Join BEAM! #1955']

column2: ['Interested in the brain? Apply to Neurotech@Berkeley! #1946']
column5: ["Hi everyone, hope your semester is off to a great start! If you're interested in neuroscience,  brain-computer interfaces, machine learning, computer-aided design, writing colloquial science papers, or finding modern neurotech solutions to modern problems, check out Neurotech @ Berkeley (NT@B)!\nWe have an infosession on Tuesday (8/29) from 8PM-10PM in Blum 120 and Thursday (8/31) from 8PM-10PM in Blum 120. It will be a great chance to meet current members and leads. You can learn more about our projects spanning across a variety of domains (software, devices, education, publications, operations, and consulting).\nIf you're interested in getting hands-on experience in this cutting-edge field, we encourage you to apply! Applications are due Friday, 9/1, at 11:59 PM."]

column2: ['Why solve problems when you can create them instead???? #1936']
column5:
["Hello!
The California Informatics Competition (https://calico.cs.berkeley.edu/) is a Berkeley student organization that creates original algorithmic problems and hosts fun programming contests to encourage students to grow their problem-solving skills and learn about algorithms in new and exciting ways. 
Our main event is a semiannual team programming contest for high schoolers with many unique topics and challenges. Last contest, we had over 650 contestants compete from 25 different countries and 22 US states!
Because of this, we need YOU to help join our cause!
From problem writing to event logistics to contest infrastructure, we have plenty of places where we can use your help! Joining CALICO is a great way to learn algorithms, meet friends, and have fun! There is NO APPLICATION PROCESS--anyone is welcome to join us, regardless of major, background, or prior experience! We‚Äôre more than happy to get you caught up; if you're interested in anything mentioned above, we highly encourage you to check us out!
Come to our intro meeting is Friday, 9/1 from 6-7 pm at Cory 212 and üçïüçïüçï FREE PIZZA üçïüçïüçï will be served! In the meantime, please join our Discord server: https://discord.gg/T94F42KP66. We'll post announcements and more info about the club there (such as relevant updates and meeting slides too if you can‚Äôt make it!).
See you Friday!"]

["Are you interested in cybersecurity and want to find out more about what it's like? Are you considering a career in security and don't know where to start? Come to Berke1337!
Berke1337 is the cybersecurity club at UC Berkeley. We connect Cal students with resources and opportunities to learn more about, and explore a career in, the cybersecurity space. This includes hosting technical talks, workshops, speakers, and cybersecurity competitions that will help give you real experience with common security topics. Anyone is welcome to join, and there is no application process!
Just fill out the registration form here to join and get info about our meetings this fall: https://forms.gle/LjLc4PAGiuQJ6Hvs5
You can also join our discord to stay involved: https://discord.gg/K4AF7qNkC7
See you there, and have a great fall semester!"]

["If you're looking for a fun group of tech-loving individuals to hang out with, look no further than IEEE (https://ieee.berkeley.edu)!
We love getting to know each other with weekly socials and frequent events (food lovers, we've got free food), technical projects, and more, and we'd love to have you join in as part of our community! We've worked with industry sponsors like Google, Apple, NVIDIA, Intel, Cisco, Micron, Texas Instruments, and more, and we love giving back to our members with exclusive connections and career development opportunities. We also host two DeCals, Micromouse and Hands on PCB Engineering (HOPE), for people to learn about technical fields and offer teaching opportunities for students! You don‚Äôt have to be in EECS/CS to join, just a person interested in technology!
Join us at our infosessions from 8-10pm at the Wozniak Lounge (Soda 430-438) on Friday, 9/1 and Tuesday, 9/5!
We take EVERYONE who applies!
General Member application: https://tinyurl.com/ieeefa23general 
Committee application: https://tinyurl.com/ieeefa23committee "]

column5:
['Hey everyone,
We are Generative AI at Berkeley, the first and largest Generative AI student organization on campus. Our applications have just opened up, you can find them here.
We welcome all majors and all technical skill levels and we embrace the multi-disciplinary nature of Generative AI. If you are curious, excited, or obsessed with Generative AI, we would love to have you here. Here is a blurb about what we do:
Generative AI at Berkeley is a new student organization focused on exploring the groundbreaking field of Generative AI, as well as its transformative potential applications. Members collaborate on diverse projects that combine technical and creative work: applying cutting-edge technologies such as Stable Diffusion and LLMs to real-world problems or exploring new forms of artistic expression through multi-modal AI. Generative AI at Berkeley also is a space for anyone simply seeking to learn more about Generative AI and find others who share that interest. Whether you‚Äôre a coder, artist, musician, or anyone else, this club offers an inclusive and social space for anyone curious about the limitless possibilities of Generative AI.']

column2: ['Linux SysAdmin DeCal enrollment info this week! #1886']
column5:
["Hey Linux fans,
The Open Computing Facility is offering the Linux System Administration DeCal (CS 198-008) this Fall 2023! Check out the course site here: https://decal.ocf.io
If you're interested in productively using Linux from the perspective of a sysadmin and learning what kinds of skills Site Reliability Engineers or Production Engineers make use of, you will likely find this DeCal of interest. We cater to students with differing levels of experience using Linux. Whether you've never heard of Linux before or you're a bash wizard, come join us!
To get enrolled in the DeCal, (1) attend an infosession next week and (2) complete Lab 0 (~10 minutes) by next Saturday 9/2. There will be two infosessions, on Tuesday 8/29 and Thursday 8/31, both from 7-9pm at the OCF Lab (171 MLK Student Union) and over Zoom (ocf.io/decalzoom)."]
column11: OCF Lab (171 MLK Student Union) and Zoom

column5:
['Hi all!

We are Blockchain @ Berkeley, a Cal student organization at the forefront of the blockchain industry. Recruitment is right around the corner, and we want you to join our B@B family!

Blockchain at Berkeley drives innovation in the blockchain industry by building an ecosystem that empowers students to make an impact through practical education, consulting for enterprise companies, and conducting open source research.

Some of our work includes our EdX course taken by over 250k students, multiple development consulting projects at fortune 50 companies, and major DeFi governance voting decisions.

Check out our recently updated website for info regarding our Fall 2023 recruitment timeline, our past work, and to learn more about our club. We look forward to seeing you at our events!']

["Hi all, 
Poker decal course staff positions are currently open for FA23! Sign up for the opportunity to teach the largest decal on campus with over 240+ students, educating students on the fundamentals of Texas hold 'em poker and more importantly, the game theory that is applicable both within the game and in real life. If you're interested email me at shreyg17@berkeley.edu for more information. However the deadline to renew the decal is approaching quite fast, so please reach out asap. Thank you (: Oh and if you weren't familiar with the class, here's part of the blurb from the course page:
The purpose of this course is to teach students poker fundamentals, both to help them improve at the game and learn wider applications of the game theory found in poker. While we believe students of all skill levels will benefit from the course, it is primarily targeted at beginners and those with an advanced understanding of the game may already be familiar with most material. The course will focus on 6-max No Limit Texas Hold‚Äôem, the most popular variant of Poker played today. We will begin by covering the rules of the game, basic strategic principles, before diving into the mathematics and heuristics used by strong players. While not the focus of the course, we will additionally briefly touch on the psychological aspects of poker, including some common tells and reads found in live play.
Disclaimer: At no point during this course will you wager real money. We understand that betting is a sensitive topic for some and you might have issues with the ethical implications, please let us know. We will be focusing on the probability and statistics behind betting."]

["CSUA is excited to announce our upcoming summer mentorship program, designed to pair you up with a compatible mentor/mentee for the summer! To kick off this program, we‚Äôll be hosting a Meet & Greet event on Monday, June 5th at 6pm on Zoom (https://csua.org/zoom). \nWhile more details will be given during the event, mentors are typically experienced upperclassmen (pre-soph and above) that can provide valuable insights/advice into navigating Berkeley, getting involved in recruiting/research/clubs, or simply be a friendly presence to connect with! The Meet & Greet aims to introduce you to new faces through speed-friending and fun online game activities, where you may even find your possible mentor/mentee! At the end of the event, you'll have the chance to fill out a form expressing your interest in becoming a mentor or mentee; if there's someone in particular you'd like to be paired with, you can mention them in the form. \nPlease note that mentorship applications are accepted on a first-come first-served basis, so if you're interested, don't miss out! The form for mentees can be found here: http://bit.ly/csuamentee23, and the form for mentors is available here: http://bit.ly/csuamentor23. Remember, the deadline for form submission is Monday 06/05 at 11:59pm!  For more updates and to RSVP, check out our Instagram page: https://www.instagram.com/csua.berkeley/"]

column2: ['Proven.Tools Infosession 4/13 5:00-6:30 at 290 Heast Memorial Mining Building #1216']
column5:
["Don't Worry, It's Proven!
At Proven, our mission is to revolutionize security, scalability, and trust in the financial ecosystem. We do this by developing products based on recent breakthroughs in cryptography and market design. We're working at the forefront of cryptography to enable an entirely new trust-enabled computing paradigm. We see a future where everyone can fairly transact in financial markets, and our cryptography-based solutions provide a level playing field for everyone.
We‚Äôre mathematicians, engineers, traders, and writers, and have decades of collective experience trading and building mission-critical systems at places like Jane Street, Two Sigma, PIMCO, and Blockstream. We hold patents in chip design, we‚Äôve produced research in cryptography and published articles and books on asset management and market anomalies. We value a highly-collaborative work environment where the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.
Join us for a talk from founder Agustin Lebron who was a chip designer before becoming a quantitative trader and researcher at Jane Street. At Jane Street, he led the development of many highly profitable quant strategies and systems. After leaving Jane Street he wrote a well-received book, The Laws Of Trading.
Free food will be provided :)"]

For those who make it to the final day, we‚Äôll have an exclusive venue in Berkeley complete with professional tables/sets, more opportunities to network with SIG traders/engineers, catered lunch, even bigger prizes from the $2000+ prize pool, and an exclusive dinner with SIG traders for the final table!
Join Poker@Berkeley and fill out the form to sign up below by April 12th at 11:59pm PST.
P@B membership: https://tinyurl.com/pab-membership
Tournament sign-up: https://tinyurl.com/pab-spring']

column5:
['Cal Hacks is excited to announce the (re)launch of Hack Month in honor of Earth Month in April!
What is Hack Month?
Teams of up to four undergraduate or graduate students can work together on a month-long project based on the following prompt‚Äîbuild a game about sustainability or a game that brings awareness to sustainability. The 1st place team will receive a $100 Amazon gift card, and the 2nd and 3rd place teams will receive a $50 Amazon gift card. Winners will also be featured on our Instagram!
How to Get Involved?
Check out our Hack Month website to learn more!
Submit your project here by April 30th @ 11:59 PM PST!
Join the Hack Month Discord server to form a team with other participants!
Follow our socials to stay updated on the latest news about Hack Month, Cal Hacks 10.0 (coming soon this fall üëÄ), and more!
Instagram
Twitter
TikTok
Cal Hacks Website
If you have any questions, don‚Äôt hesitate to email us at team@calhacks.io. We can‚Äôt wait to see the projects you all come up with‚Äîget coding! üêª']

column2: ['Join our Weekend Hackathon at Stanford! (The Berkeley AI Safety Student Initiative) #948']
column5:

We‚Äôll be making a WEEKEND TRIP to Stanford on Saturday, February 11, with the option to stay overnight, first come first serve.

column2: ['a16z Tech Talk w / Applied Intuition, Believer and Kaedim - Wednesday 9/18 #4485']
column5:
['RSVP HERE
Join a16z and our portfolio companies at the UC Berkeley tech talk on Wednesday, September 18th at 5:30pm. You will have an opportunity to interact live with company representatives and learn more about their latest product launches and future career opportunities. Featured companies include:
Applied Intuition
Believer
Kaedim
You won‚Äôt want to miss this line-up of companies!
RSVP HERE
Kesav Viswanadha | Software Engineer - Applied Intuition
Topic ‚Äì ‚ÄúAutonomy in Action: From Cal to Applied Intuition‚Äù Kesav Viswanadha will share about his experience at Applied Intuition working on some of the most interesting problems in safety and autonomy. He will talk about how his research at Cal made him excited about this autonomy, and how working at Applied Intuition‚Äôs startup experience is unique in many different ways.
Bio ‚Äì Kesav Viswanadha is a Software Engineer focused on validating autonomous systems at Applied Intuition. Prior to joining, Kesav graduated from UC Berkeley with a Bachelor‚Äôs (2017-2020) and Master‚Äôs degrees (2020-2021) in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science before joining Google as a Software Engineer on their SMB Ads Quality team. His master‚Äôs thesis was about actively searching for failure cases of autonomous vehicle systems in an efficient and scalable way, a topic he still thinks about in his work at Applied!
Zac Litton | VP of Engineering - Believer
Topic ‚Äì ‚ÄúEmpowering Creativity: Pushing the Boundaries of Digital Art through Game Technology‚Äù Games are the world‚Äôs biggest entertainment form and an increasingly important form of digital art. The tools we use in games are about ways to empower the world‚Äôs most creative people to work faster and unleash new ideas to delight people everywhere. From AI and procedural generative to intricate animation tools, game technology is about pushing digital expression forward and I will talk about past and current innovations we‚Äôre taking in this area.
Bio ‚ÄìA technology leader in engineering for over two decades, Zac is the current VP of Engineering for the recently started Believer Company. He was formerly the CTO Telltale Games after serving for seven years as VP of Engineering. He has led teams that created world-class tools for developing award-winning games distributed on every platform, from The Walking Dead to Batman: The Enemy Within.

John Bridge | Software Engineer - Kaedim
Topic ‚Äì ‚ÄúBuilding AI for the intersection of art and technology: How Kaedim is developing AI solutions to enable faster, more efficient creative processes in the gaming industry and beyond‚Äù. The presentation will start with a quick overview of John‚Äôs career, showing how his experiences led him to Kaedim and why he chose to join the team. From there, he‚Äôll discuss how Kaedim is being used to innovate traditional processes in game development, product design, and more.
Bio ‚Äì John is a Software Engineer at Kaedim. He grew up in Syracuse, NY and had always enjoyed working with computers. After learning how to code, he knew that he wanted to be a software engineer and after high school, he attended University of Rochester to study Computer Science. He joined Kaedim to be a part of a driven team that truly loves what they do, and every day he gets to write code that has a positive impact on 3D modelers around the world.
RSVP HERE']

column2: ['Now Open: Apple Ph.D Fellowship in Integrated Systems, 2025/26 #4436']
column5:
['EECS is now accepting applications for the Apple Ph.D Fellowship in Integrated Systems, to be awarded in the 2025/26 Academic Year.

Apply Here:
https://berkeley.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_9mZhz31MWKLj7xQ

This unique and highly selective program provides both a summer internship at Apple and financial support covering one year of the PhD program. Academic expectations of an Apple PhD Fellow in Integrated Systems include successful participation in the PhD program and continued research related to IC engineering / computer architecture. 

The Fellowship is made possible by funding from the Apple New Silicon Initiative (NSI), which aims to prepare students for careers in hardware technology, computer architecture, and silicon chip design. The program‚Äôs objective is to address the growing demand in the US for a workforce in IC design and computer architecture areas.
https://eecs.berkeley.edu/academics/new-silicon-initiative-nsi/

Timing
-The application deadline is: Oct. 13, 2024 at 11:59 PM PST
-To be eligible, you should ideally be between your first and fourth year of PhD.
-An Apple internship, offered as a part of the Fellowship, is generally the summer before the start of funding, but timing can be adjusted.
-Finalist interviews: from November 2024 to January 2025
-Decisions back: March 2025

Eligibility
-The Fellowships are for students who are enrolled full-time at Berkeley
-Students who currently hold another industry-sponsored full-fellowship will not be considered
-Current Apple employees and household members are not eligible']

column5:
["See below for opportunities to apply your skills in non-profit sectors. FLYER for QR code. Emails for contacts below:
Students will join a specific project aimed at a particular country. They will work on the project during the school year and may have the option to implement it on-site during the break, depending on the project. Project topics are developed in collaboration with non-profit organizations in developing countries and can range from business and psychology to robotics and computer science. These topics are starting points; we expect them to evolve as project members engage with the non-profits and learn more about their specific needs.

Robotics: Low cost robotic arm for independence of people in quadruplex paralysis (this could even be the 106A project). More about this project on this notion page
Knowledge Visualization: Developing new ways for educating people with special needs through visuals, more about the project on this notion page: 
Automazing clinician/therapist work:  Each clinician at the rehabilitation center spends roughly 1 hour in note taking a day. Automating this process we will be able to bring 168 more hours of care a week which will impact 363 people at the rehabilitation center. More about this project on this notion page
Growth Marketing Team for Tukuypaj's Chocolate center, more about the project in this: notion page
Psychology for childs at the clinical rehabilitation center and their families: The focus is to develop a mental health program for the users and their families. For this project please submit your resume with a paragraph showing your interest to gloria@tukuypaj.org and crivelli@berkeley.edu."]

column2: ['Registration Open: Hardware Workshop with DigiKey September 19th! #4479']
column5:
["Are you looking to experience some hands on examples of the hardware DigiKey supplies and the exciting start-up LabsLand develops? Well, look no further my friends. This will be the chance to get some insight into how these companies train and teach electronics remotely, with a special appearance from LabsLand's CEO. Sign ups have just opened up, below are descriptions of the two different sessions for the workshops, please keep in mind that the second session is geared more towards students that have taken upper division courses in EE and have an understanding of Hardware Programming Languages such as VHDL, SystemVerilog, or Verilog! Both session will take place September 19th!
Session 1:
Leveraging AI in hands-on lab sessions: learning microcontrollers with the support of Generative AI while interacting with real remote setups via LabsLand and DigiKey
In this workshop, participants will work with different microcontrollers (Arduino UNO, an Arduino-controlled Robot, and an STM32 board connected to multiple peripherals) to learn essential and advanced concepts of microcontroller programming. Throughout the process, an AI Assistant will support questions they may have and ask and help with the code activities. Participants will run their code on real equipment located in different countries and will be able to interact with the hardware in real time.
Will take place from 12:00PM - 2:00PM
Session 2:
Using multiple platforms and AI support for hands-on lab sessions on various FPGA platforms through remote laboratories via LabsLand and DigiKey
This workshop shows how to leverage remote access to various real boards of different manufacturers for learning FPGA-related technologies (e.g., Hardware Programming Languages such as VHDL, SystemVerilog, or Verilog). Participants will be able to test and adapt their code to different types of FPGAs using different technologies and adapting them to real and virtual peripherals, assisted by an AI assistant. They will then be able to send their designs to real FPGAs located in other locations and access them and interact with them remotely.
Will take place from 2:30PM - 4:30PM
Registration: http://berkie.ee/Digikey-fa24

Hosted by IEEE."]

column2: ['EECS Colloquium - "Mixed-Autonomy Traffic at Scale" with Alexandre Bayen - Wednesday, September 11, 2024 #4442']
column5:
['Mixed-Autonomy Traffic at Scale
Wednesday, Sept. 11, 2024
4:00 - 5:00 pm PDT
306 Soda Hall (HP Auditorium)
3:30 - 4:00 pm Light Refreshment Service in the lobby
Alexandre Bayen
Director, CITRIS and the Banatao Institute
Associate Provost, Berkeley Space Center
Liao-Cho Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences, UC Berkeley
YouTube Webinar 
Join us Wednesday, Sept.11 for our next EECS Colloquium with Alexandre Bayen.

Abstract
This lecture will present the story of the MegaVanderTest, a test involving 100 self-driving vehicles, which ran the week of Nov. 18, 2022, on I24 in Nashville, TN. The MegaVanderTest is the test that achieved the largest concentration of self-driving vehicles collaboratively controlling traffic on a single stretch of freeway in the history of self-driving vehicles. The talk will first cover the architecture built and deployed by the CIRCLES team. It will present some of the algorithms populating the planning layer of the system, mostly based on optimal control and imitation learning of Kernel-based expert controllers. It will also present some of the algorithms populating the local control regulation layer, based on deep-reinforcement learning and MPC. Finally it will present the way the algorithms had to run in the field, due to the fact that most modern ACC architectures do not always open access to all sensed quantities collected by onboard instrumentation.

Biography
Alexandre Bayen is director of CITRIS and the Banatao Institute, associate provost for the Berkeley Space Center, and Liao-Cho Innovation Endowed Chair and professor of electrical engineering and computer sciences and of civil and environmental engineering at UC Berkeley. He received an Engineering Degree in applied mathematics from the Ecole Polytechnique, France, in 1998, and an M.S. and Ph.D. in aeronautics and astronautics from Stanford University in 1999 and 2004, respectively. He was a Visiting Researcher at NASA Ames Research Center from 2000 to 2003. Between January 2004 and December 2004, he worked as the Research Director of the Autonomous Navigation Laboratory at the Laboratoire de Recherches Balistiques et Aerodynamiques, (Ministere de la Defense, Vernon, France), where he holds the rank of Major.']
