column2: ['Intern in Washington D.C. next summer! Apply to Cal in the Capital today! #4429']
column5:
['Cal in the Capital (CITC) is a student-led internship program housed in the Public Service Center that helps Berkeley students secure public service internships in Washington, DC. At CITC, we strive to promote the spirit of public service among the Berkeley community and empower students to prioritize social justice. CITC interns come from all majors and have worked in a variety of positions including research, business development, data analysis, policy, and legislation. column2: ['Remote study of Python programmers - last call for participants! ($30 gift card opportunity!) #4414']
column5:
["(Posting this message again for visibility, since we're wrapping up the study soon and recruiting our last participants. Sorry if you've already seen this!)
Hi! I'm a master's student in the Computer Science department at UC Berkeley. My colleagues and I are researching how programmers work with unfamiliar programming languages and libraries, and we could use your help!
This study will involve performing programming tasks in Python using an unfamiliar library. The study is fully remote, and all sessions will take place on Zoom. Participants must have access to a laptop or desktop computer. Please budget up to 1.5 hours for the study, although the actual session may be shorter. Participants will be compensated with a $30 Amazon gift card.
If you are interested, please take this screening survey to determine your eligibility: https://tinyurl.com/unfabstudy. Participants with all levels of programming experience are eligible, as long as you have some Python familiarity.
Thank you!"]

column2: ['Help us improve future Data Work Tools! ($50 amazon giftcard) #4334']

I‚Äôve built a Python library, and now I‚Äôm looking for participants for an evaluative study! I‚Äôm looking for folks who are familiar with Python, with bonus points if you have prior web or UI dev experience! If you decide to participate, sessions involve incrementally adding capabilities to an interface. column2: ['[Human Subjects Study] Teach Computers How to Play Soccer and Get Paid! #4330']
column5:
['Hi, this is Edward Kim, a postdoc in the EECS department at UC Berkeley. 
What: We are recruiting participants for our experiment, who will be compensated $30 for 1 hour participation. 
Why: The purpose of this study is to evaluate our system which can learn to play soccer from a user‚Äôs tutorial. 
How: Participants will be asked to give a tutorial on how to solve various tactical soccer scenarios in a FiFA11-like soccer game on a laptop using a XBox controller. We will ask participants to provide verbal explanations during demonstrations, as if they are giving a tutorial to a beginner player. Our system will learn from the demonstrations and explanations to model the participants‚Äô behavior. Then, our system will demonstrate back what it learned for you to assess its accuracy. 
Where: At Cory Hall
When: September 2nd - 10th, 2024
If you would like to participate, please fill out this google form. 
Gratefully,
Edward Kim']

We have a ton of project and research teams you can read about on our website (https://xr.berkeley.edu/) and on our application, but if you are more interested in starting a new project, we will hold a project mixer for all members to pitch their ideas and team up with other members to form project groups mentored by senior members of XR@B. If you're looking to propose your own team OR project idea to XR@B, please fill out the team application form: https://forms.gle/hdVNTgbbh8hvYCL4A
No experience in VR/AR is required to join our club, but if you would like an introduction to the field, we highly recommend you to take the 2-unit XR DeCal! It's made for people with no prior experience, but you will have a working VR/AR app by the end of the semester :0
XR DeCal: https://xr.berkeley.edu/decal/
DeCal application: http://tinyurl.com/xr-decal-fa24 due 11:59PM PST on Saturday, September 7th
If you would like to take the time to get to know us first, Extended Reality at Berkeley will be tabling on Memorial glade at Calapalooza tomorrow and on Sproul on Friday, where you can learn about our projects, research, the XR DeCal, and meet some of our members!
To get even more information and more time to ask questions, drop by one of our infosessions next week!
We'll be in SOCS 185 from 8-9:30 PM on Wednesday 9/4 and Thursday 9/5
Looking forward to meeting you!"]

column2: ['EECS Colloquium: From Theory PhD to Startup Land - 9/4 @ 2pm #4261']
column5:
['https://events.berkeley.edu/eecs/event/259685-eecs-colloquium-from-theory-phd-to-startup-land
On this super flattering occasion I get to tell the story of my career since graduating in 1998 with a theory PhD: working at Mike Luby‚Äôs startup Digital Fountain; co-founding the startup that became Google Maps; the spectacular failure of Google Wave; seed investing in Australian Canva; and now mostly angel investing around the world from sunny Greece. Oh and Go Bears!
Lars Rasmussen is an angel investor and startup advisor based in Athens, Greece. Lars holds a Ph.D. in theoretical computer science from UC Berkeley in California. In 2004, Lars and his brother Jens sold their mapping startup Where 2 Tech to Google. Lars became the lead engineer on the team that created Google Maps from Where 2‚Äôs technology. Lars was next a director of engineering at Facebook in Menlo Park and London. His favorite investments include Canva, Astranis, Chiaro, Neara, and Protio. In his copious spare time, he enjoys boating the Greek Islands, kitesurfing, and coffee.
Dedicated to hosting presentations at the intersection of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, the EECS Colloquium offers a mix of short talks by faculty describing their latest research results as well as internationally distinguished speakers. It provides an opportunity for an exchange of ideas between our department‚Äôs community and the outside world.

Light refreshments served at 1:30 pm
Speaker: Lars Rasmussen']

column2: ['Berkeley NASA Summer Scholars Poster Session on Tuesday, August 27th at 11am-2pm in HMMB Lobby #4226']
column5: ['The Aerospace Engineering program is hosting a poster session event on Tuesday, August 27th, 11:00am-2:00pm, in the lobby of the Hearst Memorial Mining Building (HMMB), featuring the work of 14 aerospace engineering majors who participated in an internship this summer 2024, as part of the Berkeley NASA Summer Scholars Program. Please stop by the lobby of HMMB anytime between 11am and 2pm to check out their work and learn about the various projects they conducted while interning at NASA Ames. Your support of this event is greatly appreciated. For questions, please contact Karren Tanisaki at (510) 643-8017.\nhttps://aero.berkeley.edu/']

column2: ['Enroll in CE153 - Data-Driven Class for Students Interested in Aviation #4217']
column5:
["Interested in the intersection between Aviation and Data Science? Want to meet and collaborate with top experts in the field, from NASA, Airports like SFO, OAK, leading Aviation startups like Sabrewing, go on cool field trips to SFO/LAX, get involved in UC Berkeley's NEXTOR Research lab?
Take CE153: Airport Design this semester!
Lecture: TU, TH 10:00 am - 10:59 am
Class #: 28421
Units: 3

If you are interested in data-driven studies about airport and airspace systems, this is the right course for you.
- Do you know where recreational drones enter our commercial airspace the most frequently? 
- Or how Bird-strikes can damage aircraft? Is pointing green lasers into an aircraft fun or is it dangerous?

This is a design course focused on airport systems. The course includes an introduction to aviation systems and to airport planning. Lectures cover the operating characteristics of airplanes as they relate to airport operations and design; the planning and design of the airfield; passenger and cargo terminal systems; airport land use and layout planning; air traffic control; environmental impact analysis; and airport economics and finance.

The course includes a design project where students work in teams on current airport and airspace planning and design issues. Projects typically involve the planning and design of an airport expansion program for a major air carrier airport, or data-driven analyses of current issues in aviation. The class is organized in working teams each focusing on one component of the project. The course includes lectures, laboratory exercises, homework assignments, a design project report, a midterm take-home exam, and a final take-home examination. Students present results of the design project in front of a jury of visiting airport planning professionals. A field trip to one of the local area airports or LAX is always offered.
Only a few open seats left, enroll now! Prerequisites are waived
http://faculty.ce.berkeley.edu/rakas/ce153.html
CE153 Airport Design class Fall 2024 "]

column2: ['Remote study of Python programmers, still recruiting participants! ($30 gift card opportunity!) #4181']
column5:
["Hi! I'm a master's student in EECS. My colleagues and I are researching how programmers work with unfamiliar programming languages and libraries, and we could use your help!
This study will involve performing programming tasks in Python using an unfamiliar library. The study is fully remote, and all sessions will take place on Zoom. Participants must have access to a laptop or desktop computer. Please budget up to 1.5 hours for the study, although the actual session may be shorter. Participants will be compensated with a $30 Amazon gift card.
If you are interested, please take this screening survey to determine your eligibility.
Thank you! (And sorry if you've already seen this message, or if you've already participated!)"]

['Students, the CDSS Discovery program is now open for your application. Check out the research projects of interest to you and apply by September 2! \nThe CDSS Discovery program incubates and accelerates high-impact research in academic, government, non-profit, and industry projects while providing UC Berkeley students real-world research experiences and mentorship opportunities. \nPlease direct any questions to ds-discovery@berkeley.edu.']

column2: ['Help us improve future Data Work Tools! ($50 amazon giftcard) #4159']
column5:
['Hello everyone!
I‚Äôve been working on a system for building human-in-the-loop data processing interfaces. The goal is to easily generate custom GUIs that folks can use to perform repetitive data transformation tasks.
I‚Äôve built a Python library, and now I‚Äôm looking for participants for an evaluative study! I‚Äôm looking for folks who are familiar with Python, with bonus points if you have prior web or UI dev experience! If you decide to participate, sessions involve incrementally adding capabilities to an interface. Plus in addition to the joy of providing input to make it easier to build data work tools in the future, you get a $50 Amazon giftcard :)
If you‚Äôre interested, please fill out this quick screening survey. If you know anyone else who might be interested in participating, please feel free to share the link! If eligible, sessions will be 2.5 hours long and done on campus. Sessions will likely run into the school year.
Thank you!!!']

['Hey! We‚Äôre Katherine & Chris. A PhD student and an undergraduate student at the Hybrid Ecologies Lab on campus, studying how people design electronics using unconventional/sustainable power sources.

This study will involve programming ESP32 microcontrollers and using electrical tools to examine your work. The workshop will be held in person (in Sutardja Dai), Monday Aug 12. We expect the study to run for 2-3 hours and you will be compensated $20/hr via an Amazon gift card.

Requirements: Laptop with Arduino IDE installed.

If you are interested, please fill out this this survey.']

["The Black Engineering and Science Student Association (Berkeley's NSBE Chapter) is bringing back its annual career fair! RSVP HERE"]

column2: ['Research Study on AI Learning Tool, Looking for Participants! #4076']
column5:
["Participants Needed for Research Study on AI learning tool!
The Vive Center at UC Berkeley is looking for participants for an innovative research study on an AI learning tool. This project aims to help students with their course learning through various features and academic planning. We want to get your input on what helps you! 
Study Details:
Duration: 10-20 minutes
What You'll Do:
Share the specific challenges you often face when learning a new topic
Describe your personal experience in course and degree planning
Provide insight into features that could make it easier to learn
The session will be recorded
Eligibility:
Must be a Berkeley student
All majors and backgrounds are welcome and encouraged!
Able to view a computer monitor
No previous experience with AI or teaching necessary
Interested? Please sign-up for a time slot using the QR code in the flyer below (at https://calendly.com/ines-b-berkeley/30min). For any questions or more information, please feel free to reach out to ines.b@berkeley.edu or leave your email in a comment below and we will reach out to you!
Your input on what we are developing will help future Berkeley students!"]

['Sharing on the behalf of a campus program
___
W.T. Chan Fellowship Overview
Partnered with the Lingnan Foundation since 2004, UC Berkeley Public Service Center (PSC) annually hosts six Lingnan W. T. Chan Fellows. This 5¬Ω-month program brings undergraduate and graduate students from mainland China and Hong Kong for a significant intercultural service-learning experience. The program involves complete immersion in U.S. society -- fellows live with homestay families and work with nonprofit organizations. Furthermore, Fellows attend weekly seminars, leadership training, cultural events, educational excursions, and other campus-community events. Through these activities, fellows gain a first-hand understanding of social issues in the Bay Area and the larger United States and participate in advocating for disadvantaged communities through public service. 
W.T. Chan Fellowship Campus Buddies Program
The Chan Fellowship Campus Buddy program seeks to achieve the following:
Serve as an ambassador connecting Chan Fellows to UC Berkeley student experience 
Engage in cross-cultural exchange and learning 
Spread and inspire ideas to promote social justice worldwide
Open to undergraduate and graduate students
Responsibilities as a Buddy: 
Attend these events
Welcome Event - mid-September
Final Reception - December, TBD
Community building + food provided! 
Monthly meetups coordinated between with you and your Chan Fellow
Messages/emails in between monthly hangouts are highly encouraged
What You Gain as a Buddy:
Connect and build friendships with Fellows from Hong Kong, mainland China, and Kazakhstan
Get first-hand insights about social justice issues in an international context
If interested, please complete this brief application by Thursday, August 29, 2024 at 11:59pm. 
Link to application: https://forms.gle/Pj8QKKMB6kdiRpT2A
You will be notified the first week of September if you are selected as a Campus Buddy. 
If selected, please be prepared to attend the Welcome Event mid-September. 
Questions? Email Rosa Enriquez, at RosaLeeEnriquez@berkeley.edu.']
